text:
ABS-CBN (Alto Broadcasting System-Chronicle Broadcasting Network) aka Channel 2, Kapamilya. The main headquarters of ABS-CBN are located on Sergeant Esguerra Ave corner Mother Ignacia Ave in South Triangle, Quezon City. It has 13 studios. Studio 1, now named Dolphy Theater, is the oldest. Beside the headquarters is its 720-foot transmitter.

In 1955, the prominent Lopez family of Iloilo, headed by Eugenio Lopez Sr aka Eñing, obtained a legislative franchise to operate a radio and a television station under the Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN). On 24 Sept 1956, CBN began its radio broadcasts on CBN-DZXL Radio. Its studio and transmitter were located at the CBN Building on Aduana St in Intramuros, Manila. On 24 Feb 1957, Lopez Sr bought Alto Broadcasting System (ABS), formerly Bolinao Electronics Corporation, from Antonio Quirino and James Lindenberg, which operated the radio station DZAQ and Channel 3, the country’s first TV station. This purchase made Lopez the biggest investor in the broadcast industry in the Philippines. For four years, ABS radio and television stations were operated separately from CBN stations, their common ownership notwithstanding. In 1958, ABS Channel 3 transferred its facilities from Santa Cruz in Manila and San Juan, Rizal, to its new studio and transmitter site on Roxas Blvd in Pasay City. In the same year, on 19 Apr, CBN began its television broadcasts on CBN-DZXL-TV Channel 9 using its facilities in Intramuros. CBN 9’s first programs included the daily noontime show Student Canteen and the singing talent search program Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage). Other programs included Chelsea Dancetime, Pacosta Hit Parade, Darigold Jamboree, Tia Dely (Aunt Dely), United American Tiki-Tiki, and Operetang Sampay Bakod (Rag Tag Operetta). In 1961, ABS and CBN stations began using the name ABS-CBN. At the same time, on 14 Jun 1961, ABS-CBN opened its television station Channel 3 in Cebu City, which aired four hours a day.

Lopez Sr and son Lopez Jr, aka Geny or Kapitan, were mainly responsible for the rise of ABS-CBN as the country’s biggest network. The network got the rights to cover and air the 1962 and 1966 ASEAN Games. In 1963, ABS-CBN tested the first color television transmission in the Philippines using technology imported from the USA. In 1966, the network started telecasting color programs and introduced the sarimanok (mythical bird with a fish in its beak) logo. On 12 Feb 1967, the network launched its iconic logo, which features an aerial transmitter and three concentric rings symbolizing broadcast waves, in the primary colors of red, green, and blue, and the letters ABS on top of the graphic and the letters CBN below it.

On 18 Dec 1968, ABS-CBN moved its radio and studio facilities to its new headquarters called Broadcast Plaza, located along Bohol Ave (now Sergeant Esguerra Ave) in Diliman, Quezon City. It had the most advanced broadcasting center in Asia during the period.

In 1969, the government assigned Channels 3 and 9 as Channels 2 and 4, respectively. With its two other provincial stations in Bacolod and Dagupan, ABS-CBN was operating with two national and three regional TV stations: Channel 3 Cebu, Channel 4 Bacolod, and Channel 10 Baguio. It also owned 20 radio stations in areas like Bacolod, Baguio, Cagayan de Oro, Davao, Iligan, Iloilo, Laoag, Legaspi, Lucena, Naga, and Zamboanga; six of these radio stations were in Manila. By 1972, ABS-CBN was considered the most powerful radio-television network in the Philippines.

The pre-martial law ABS-CBN produced a series of hits. It converted DZAQ into a 24-hour radio news station, called Radyo Patrol (Radio Patrol), 1969. Popular television shows included Tawag ng Tanghalan, 1958; Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life), 1964; The Nida-Nestor Show, 1965; Your Evening with Pilita, 1965; Tang-Tarang-Tang, 1966; Panagimpan (Dream), 1968; Stop, Look, and Listen, 1968; D’Sensations, 1970; and 12 O’Clock High, 1972. Other hit programs between 1965 and 1972 included Super Laff-In, Two for the Road, My Family Three, and Oh My Love. It was home to most of the country’s big stars of the period like Pilita Corrales, Marlene Dauden, Nida Blanca, Nestor de Villa, Sylvia La Torre, Oscar Obligacion, Doro de los Ojos, Pugo, Chichay, Bentot, Dolphy, Panchito, Elvira Manahan, and Joey Lardizabal. It was also building up the career of young talents like Jeanne Young, Vilma Santos, Ariel Ureta, Tina Revilla, Nora Aunor, Tirso Cruz III, and Edgar Mortiz. It had the best directors like Lupita Concio, Mitos Villareal, Maria Montelibano, Fritz Ynfante, Al Quinn, Ading Fernando, Raul Silos, Heidi Sison, and Fr James Reuter, SJ. For news and public affairs, it had Rod Reyes, Orly Mercado, Boo Chanco, Hal Bowie, Tony Seva, Marita Manuel, Sylvia Mayuga, Jorge Arago, Bong Lapira, Ric Tierro, Henry Halasan, Duds Rivera, Bobby Guanzon, Bert Salonga, Jun Bautista, Henry Garcia, Max Soliven, and Soc Rodrigo. It had program strategists, producers, and executives like Jake Almeda Lopez, Jun Jison, Ben Aniceto, George Gaddi, Jimmy Navarro, Gumsy Alba, Marcial Sanson, Frankie Evangelista, Benny Rivera, Romy Jalosjos, Freddie Infante, and Freddie Garcia.

When Marcos declared martial law in 1972, ABS-CBN was shut down and its stations and facilities were taken over by the government and Roberto S. Benedicto, a close ally of Marcos. Eñing went into exile in the United States. His eldest son Geny was among those incarcerated for allegations of subversion. Eñing died in 1975 in San Francisco, California, with Geny still in prison. In 1977, Geny and fellow detainee Sergio Osmeña III escaped from their detention cell by crawling beneath barbed wires, beyond the fenced-in perimeter of Fort Bonifacio, and off via a chartered aircraft to the USA where they sought political asylum. He returned to the Philippines on 28 Feb 1986, two days after the fall of the dictator.

The Lopezes regained possession of Channel 2 after the EDSA Revolt in 1986. The government of Pres Corazon C. Aquino, however, retained Channel 4. The call sign “Channel 2” was first introduced into the network’s logo in 1986. The network only had one television and one radio station: ABS-CBN Channel 2 and DZMM 630 kHz. On 22 Jul 1986, DZMM was launched with the slogan “Ang Himpilan ng Mamamayan” (The Station of the People). Radio anchors included Dely Magpayo, Jun Ricafrente, Rene Jose, Gel Santos-Relos, Mel Tiangco, Angelique Lazo, Ernie Baron, and Kuya Cesar.

ABS-CBN Channel 2 was relaunched on 1 Mar 1987 with a live musical special called Star Network: Ang Pagbabalik ng mga Bituin(Star Network: The Return of the Stars). The network’s tag line “In the service of the Filipino” was introduced in 1988. It resumed its provincial operations, beginning with DYCB-TV Channel 3 in Cebu, also in 1988.

On 1 Jan 2000, the network unveiled a new logo that had the three tri-colored iconic rings in a bigger and transparent 3-D box and aired the voice-over of the tag line “Kapamilya namin, kapamilya ninyo, kapamilya ng bawat Pilipino” (Our family, your family, the family of every Filipino). In 2003, the network officially launched its present brand name, “Kapamilya” (Family Member).

ABS-CBN’s programs dominated the ratings game during the post-EDSA period. Highly popular programs were Martin & Pops, 1987; Palibhasa Lalake (Because They Are Guys), 1987-89; Luv Ko si Kris (I Love Kris), 1990; The Sharon Cuneta Show, 1988-97; Sa Linggo nAPO Sila (The APO Are Now on Sunday), 1990-95; Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 1991 to present; Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Wait for the Next Chapter), 1991-97; Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad), 1992-2003; Ang TV (The TV) and Oki Doki Dok (Okay, Doc), 1993-2003; Mara Clara, 1992-97; Esperanza, 1997-99; Mula sa Puso (From the Heart), 1997-99; Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000-2002; Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009; and Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14. Top-rating news and public affairs programs were TV Patrol, 1987 to present; The World Tonight, 1986-99; Magandang Gabi, Bayan! (Good Evening, Nation!), 1988-2005; Mel & Jay, 1988-96; and Balitang K (K News), 1996-2001. Some of the popular stars of the network during the period were Dolphy, Sharon Cuneta, Aga Muhlach, Kris Aquino, Judy Ann Santos, Claudine Barretto, Piolo Pascual, Rico Yan, Jolina Magdangal, Marvin Agustin, Jericho Rosales, Kim Chiu, Coco Martin, Angel Locsin, John Lloyd Cruz, and Boy Abunda. Among its stable of news directors were Rod Reyes, Angelo Castro, and Maria Ressa. For newscasters, it had Noli de Castro, who became vice president of the country from 2004 to 2010; Loren Legarda, who became senator; Angelo Castro; Frankie Evangelista; Korina Sanchez; Karen Davila; and Ted Failon. ABS-CBN Foundation produced many excellent educational-instructional programs—namely, Sineskwela (School on Air), 1994-2001; Bayani (Hero), 1995-2000; Hiraya Manawari (Reaching One’s Dreams), 1995-2003; Mathtinik (Math Wiz), 1997-2003; and Epol/Apple, 1999-2003.

ABS-CBN expanded into other ventures. On 6 Jun 1990, the company went into cable distribution with SKY Cable, which provided Cinema One on 12 Jun 1994 and Sarimanok News Network (SNN) on 10 Jul 1996. SNN, now ABS-CBN News Channel (ANC), was then launched as the Philippines’ first 24/7 news channel. On 24 Sep 1994, ABS-CBN launched The Filipino Channel (TFC), the country’s first international channel. TFC brought locally produced shows to Filipino expatriates. ABS-CBN Global was later made as a separate subsidiary as TFC developed. In Oct 1996, ABS-CBN acquired another free television channel, which was named Studio 23. In 1993, Star Cinema was established as the filmmaking arm of the company. Star Records was established to offer recorded music since Feb 1995. With the advent of the Internet, ABS-CBN Interactive (ABSi) was launched in Feb 1999 as the new media subsidiary of ABS-CBN.

When Lopez Jr died on 29 Jun 1999, Lopez III, aka Gabby, became the network’s president and chief executive officer (CEO). He spearheaded the establishment of more channels under ABS-CBN Broadcasting Corporation. These included cable channels Lifestyle Network, 11 Jul 1999; Knowledge Channel, 6 Nov 1999; MYX, 1 Jan 2001; Hero TV, 1 Oct 2005; DZMM Teleradyo, 12 Apr 2007; and Balls TV, 1 Jan 2008. MYX and DZMM Teleradyo were as groundbreaking as ANC. MYX is the first Filipino 24/7 music channel while DZMM Teleradyo is the first television channel that provided a televised radio broadcast in the country round-the-clock.

ABS-CBN dropped the word “Broadcasting” from its corporate name on 27 May 2010. Lopez III intensified his pursuit to diversify ABS-CBN as the Philippines’ largest media conglomerate after SKY, Star Cinema, Star Records and ABSi. ABS-CBN diversified into publication with ABS-CBN Publishing in 2000, sports programming and licensing under ABS-CBN Sports, and telecommunications with Bayan Telecommunications and ABS-CBN Mobile in 2013 under ABS-CBN Convergence. SKY is also an Internet service provider.

Federico “Freddie” M. Garcia was the president of ABS-CBN Corporation from 1997 to 2003. He was succeeded by Luis F. Alejandro, 2004-06, and later, Eugenio Lopez III, 2006-07. Charo Santos-Concio succeeded Lopez III in 2008. Lopez III stepped down as CEO in 2013 but remained as the network’s chairman. He announced the strengthened diversification of ABS-CBN. The company invested in the development of a family entertainment center at Bonifacio Global City in Taguig through ABS-CBN Corporation subsidiary Play Innovations. Carlo Lopez Katigbak replaced Santos-Concio as president and chief executive officer of ABS-CBN in Dec 2015.

As of 2013, ABS-CBN TV broadcasts in 43 provinces, apart from the National Capital Region (NCR). Twenty-five of these are relay stations and 18 are originating. Nineteen provincial stations use ultra-high frequency broadcasting. Fifty-three provinces have access to Studio 23, with 49 of these as relay stations. Nineteen provinces, apart from NCR, can access ANC. TFC is broadcast in the Philippines, the Asia-Pacific, Australia, Canada, Europe, Japan, the Middle East, USA, and New Zealand. The network currently has 21 radio stations.

ABS-CBN and its management people, creative staff, broadcasters, and stars have received several awards. The station received the Gawad CCP para sa Radyo at Telebisyon para sa Natatanging Kontribusyon in 1990. From the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP), it won the Golden Dove Award for Best TV Station in Metro Manila for Channel 2 in 1995, 1996, 1998, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2004, and every year from 2006 to 2015; Best Provincial Television Station for DYCB TV-3 Cebu in 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, and 2006, for DXAB Davao in 2002, and for TV 2 Cagayan de Oro in 2012; Best AM Radio Station in Metro Manila for DZMM in 1995-98, 2001, 2004-5, 2007-9, 2011-12, and 2015; Best Provincial AM Radio Station for DYAB Cebu in 1998; and Best FM Radio Station in Metro Manila for DWRR 101.1 in 1994, 2002, and 2004. Recipients of the KBP Lifetime Achievement Awards were Eugenio Lopez Jr in 1999, Federico M. Garcia in 2000, Francisco Evangelista in 2004, Charo Santos-Concio in 2013, and Eugenio Lopez III in 2014. Recipients of the KBP Ka Doroy Broadcaster of the Year were Loren Legarda in 1997, Tina Monzon Palma in 2003, Angelo Castro in 2006, Korina Sanchez in 2008, Ces Drilon in 2010, Noli de Castro in 2011, and Ted Failon in 2013. It won the Star Awards for Television of the Philippine Movie Press Club (PMPC) for Best Station with Balanced Programming in 1992, 2003, 2004, 2007, and every year from 2009 to 2015. Among the important awards that its programs, broadcasters, artists, and technical people received were the Citizens Awards for Television, the Gawad CCP para sa Radyo at Telebisyon, the KBP Golden Dove Awards, the PMPC Star Awards for Television, the Catholic Mass Media Awards, the Anak TV Seal Awards of the Southeast Asian Foundation for Children and Television, the Golden TV Screen Awards of the Entertainment Press Society, the World Medals of the New York Festivals, and the Asian Television Awards. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III and Laya Boquiren , with notes from Gian Carlo C. Librojo and Elizabeth L. Enriquez

text:
Boy Abunda (Eugenio Romerica Abunda Jr) is a TV host and talent manager. He was born in Borongan, Samar on 29 Oct 1955. He is one of the two children of Eugenio Arago Abunda Sr, a politician, and Licerna Romerica Abunda, a retired public school teacher. He has been in a 30-year relationship with partner Elmer “Bong” Boydon Quintana. He finished his elementary education at Borongan Pilot Elementary School, now Eugenio Daza Elementary School, in 1971 and high school at Seminario de Jesus Nazareno High School in 1975. He started studying business management at Ateneo de Manila in 1976, but the untimely death of his father in 1977, plus his distaste for math and the government-required Reserved Officers’ Training Corps or ROTC, forced Abunda to leave school in 1978.

The National Commission for Culture and the Arts invited him to serve as its ambassador for the Philippine International Arts Festival in 2011.

 

In 1982, he became an assistant to Conchita “Tita Conching” Sunico, the executive director of the Manila Metropolitan Theater where he learned the rudiments of public relations. While Abunda was doing public relations consultancy, GMA executive Bobby Barreiro met him in 1993 and suggested that he host a television show. The Bottomline with Boy Abunda won Best Talk Show at the Asian TV Awards in 2011. Abunda received the Hall of Fame Award from the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards for TV in 2011 for having won Best TV Showbiz-Oriented Show Host for Startalkfrom 1995 to 1999, The Buzz from 1999 to 2008 and 2010, and SNN: Showbiz News Ngayon in 2009; Best Magazine Talk Show Host for Kontrobersyal in 2004, Homeboy from 2005 to 2007, and Boy and Kris in 2008; and Best Public Affairs Program Host for Private Conversationsin 2004 and The Bottomline with Boy Abunda in 2010 and 2011. Abunda won Outstanding Male Program Host for The Bottomline with Boy Abunda at the Asia Radio TV Awards in 2014.

AGONCILLO, RYAN (Kristoffer Lou Ryan Gonzalez Agoncillo) b. Manila 10 Apr 1979. Television host, actor, model, photographer. He is one of the two sons of Luis “Chito” Agoncillo and Rowena “Nina” de los Reyes Gonzalez. He is married to film and movie actor Judy Ann Santos, with whom he has three children. The sister of Ryan’s father is Carina Agoncillo, whose showbiz name is Carina Afable, the former wife of musician-composer Raul Silos. His father’s family belongs to the clan of Felipe E. Agoncillo, a diplomat in the First Philippine Republic established by Emilio Aguinaldo and one of the defense lawyers for the journalists of El Renacimiento charged with libel by Dean C. Worcester for the editorial “Aves de Rapiña” (Birds of Prey), 1908. Felipe was the husband of Marcela Mariño de Agoncillo, the principal seamstress of the first official Philippine flag, whose daughter Maria became the second wife of Emilio Aguinaldo. Ryan’s mother traces her roots to Joaquin Gonzalez from Baliuag, Bulacan, who served as the first rector of the Universidad Cientifico-Literaria de Filipinas and representative of Pampanga to the 1898 Malolos Congress. Four of Joaquin’s sons were Bienvenido Maria Sioco Gonzalez, the sixth and eighth president of the University of the Philippines in 1939-43 and 1945-51, respectively; Augusto, father of former education secretary and former De La Salle University (DLSU) president Andrew Gonzalez; Virgilio, grandfather of popular dermatologist Dr Victoria “Vicki” Gonzalez Belo; and Francisco Javier, grandfather of Ryan’s mother and of writer Barbara “Tweetums” Gonzalez, whose daughter, TV host Panjee Tapales, married and later separated from Eugenio “Gabby” Lopez III of the ABS-CBN conglomerate. Ryan finished his elementary and high school education at San Beda College in Alabang. He graduated with a bachelor of arts degree in organizational communication from DLSU in 2000.

He started his television career at age 15 when he appeared in the television commercials of Penshoppe, Greenwich Pizza, Sprite, Islacom, and later in Emperador Brandy, Swish Mouthwash, and Fitrum. Agoncillo started hosting at GMA in the daily television program Mornings at GMA, 1998-99, and the music video show Campus Video, 1999-2001. He hosted variety shows and reality TV programs in other networks, which include Breakfast, 1999-2001, and the youth-oriented debate forum Y-Speak, 2003-10, on ANC Studio 23; Review Night, 2001, on Cinema One; Talk TV, 2001-2, Magandang Umaga, Pilipinas (Good Morning, Philippines), 2001-4, Star in a Million, 2003-6, and Pinoy Fear Factor, 2008-9, on ABS-CBN; and Philippine Idol, 2006, and Talentadong Pinoy (Talented Filipino), 2008-13, on TV5. He joined the daily noontime show Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!) on GMA, replacing the late rapper Francis Magalona in 2009. In 2015, he became the host aka Kuya Driver of the Philippine edition of Cash Cab, the popular UK game show aired on AXN Asia.

Agoncillo also acted in television dramas, situational comedy shows, and fantasy programs, such as Krystala, 2004-5, Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2005, Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), 2006, Pieta, 2008-9, May Bukas Pa (Tomorrow Is Another Day), 2009-10, and George and Cecil, 2009-10, on ABS-CBN; Lady Dada, 2010, on TV5; and a cameo role in My Husband’s Lover, 2013, and a main character in Ismol Family (Small Family), 2014, on GMA.

Agoncillo appeared in the movies Kutob (Premonition), 2005, Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo (Partner, Participant, Partaker), 2006, its sequel Sakal, Sakali, Saklolo (Strangle, Perchance, Help), 2007, My Househusband, 2011, and Ano ang Kulay ng Nakalimutang Pangarap? (What Is the Color of the Forgotten Dream?), 2013, all directed by Jose Javier Reyes. His other movies include Umaaraw, Umuulan (Sun Shining, Rain Pouring), 2006, and My Kuya’s Wedding (My Older Brother’s Wedding), 2007. He produced music albums in 2006, exhibited his photographic works in 2007, and published the photography coffee-table book Ploning: The Making, a collection of images taken during the making of his wife’s movie Ploning, in 2007.

For hosting Y-Speak, he received the KBP Golden Dove Award for Best Public Affairs Program Host in 2005, 2007, and 2010, the Catholic Mass Media Award for Best Talk Show Host in 2006, and the Anak TV Seal in 2009 and 2010. For hosting Talentadong Pinoy, he won the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Award for Best Talent Show Host in 2009 and the Entertainment Press Society Golden Screen Award for Outstanding Reality Competition Program Host in 2011. He received the Hall of Fame Award for Best Male Emcee at the 2010 Aliw Awards for having won in the category in 2007, 2008, and 2009.

Written byFernando A. Austria Jr and Eulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Noel Ferrer

Gina Alajar (Regina Liguid Alatiit) is a film and television actor and director. She was born in Manila 28 Jun 1959. She is the eldest child of Bernardino Alatiit of Roxas City and Angelica Liguid of Cavite. She was married to actor Michael de Mesa, with whom she has three children—two of whom, Ryan Eigenmann and Geoff Eigenmann, are actors. Their marriage was annulled in 2006. She attended grade school at P. Burgos Elementary School. After high school, she took a one-year course in tourism and travel at Centro Escolar University. She was a member of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines (CAP), which was headed by her mentor and friend, the late Lino Brocka.

Alajar was only eight years old when she auditioned for Lea Productions’s Kaibigan Ko’ng Sto. Niño (The Holy Infant Is My Friend), 1967. She stood out among the almost 300 aspirants and played the title role opposite Roderick Paulate. Later, she appeared in several films produced by Sampaguita Pictures. One of her early movies is Donata, 1968, where she plays the role of the girl who grows up to be Gina Pareño. She is the young Irene Marcos in Pinagbuklod ng Langit (Joined by Heaven), 1969, and is one of the children in Lino Brocka’s Wanted: Perfect Mother, 1970. By the time she appeared in the remake of Cofradia, 1973, in the role popularized by Gloria Romero in 1953, Alajar was already a Sampaguita contract star.

Her other films include Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels without Heaven), 1970; Robina, 1971; Mga Basag na Kristal (Crystal Fragments), 1977; Modelong Tanso (Fake Model), 1979; Diborsiyada (Divorcee) and City after Dark, 1980; Kontrobersyal (Controversial) and Playgirl, 1981; Moral, 1982; Dalmacio Armas, 1983; Orapronobis (Fight for Us), 1989; “Ate” (Elder Sister) episode of Shake, Rattle & Roll 3, 1991; Jose Rizal, 1998; Bahay ni Lola (Grandma’s House), 2001; Singsing ni Lola (Grandma’s Ring) and Mano Po (I Kiss Your Hand), 2002; Mano Po 5: Gua Ai Di (I Love You), 2006; and The Reunion, 2012.

As a director, she worked with GMA Network in such television series as Temptation of Wife, 2012; Unforgettable and Anna Karenina, 2013; and Yagit (Pushcart of Dreams), 2014.

On stage, she performed in Dulaang UP’s Misteryo ng Pumpon ng Rosas (Mystery of the Rose Bouquet), 1992, a translation of Manuel Puig’s play of the same title, and Larawan (A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino), 1993, where she played Paula opposite Malou de Guzman who played Candida. 

Alajar won awards for child actor for Kaibigan Ko’ng Sto. Niño from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 1968 and for Wanted: Perfect Mother from the Citizens’ Council for Mass Media in 1971. Later, she received Best Supporting Actress awards for Brutal, 1980, from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF); for Kaya Kong Abutin ang Langit (I Can Reach the Sky), 1984, from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP); for Andrea, Paano Ba ang Maging Isang Ina? (Andrea, How Does One Become a Mother?), 1990, from the MMFF and the FAP; for Biktima, 1990, from the FAMAS, the Gawad Urian, and the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA); and for Mulanay: Sa Pusod ng Paraiso (Mulanay: Deep in Paradise), 1996, from the Gawad Urian. She won Best Actress awards in the Gawad Urian for Brutal in 1981, for Salome in 1982, and for Bayan Ko : Kapit sa Patalim (My Country: Gripping the Knife’s Edge) in 1986. At the 1991 CMMA, she also won Best Actress for Andrea, Paano Ba ang Maging Isang Ina?   Written by Galileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

ALIW BROADCASTING CORPORATION (ABC) Founded in 1991 by former ambassador Antonio L. Cabangon Chua, ABC owns and operates 10 radio stations in the Philippines. It is an affiliate of the ALC Group of Companies involved in pre-need plans, property development, banking, hotel, retail mall, and publishing. Its flagship station is Manila-based DWIZ 882 on AM, with the moniker Todong Lakas! (Full Blast!), with a Dagupan-based FM counterpart, DWIZ 89.3. ABC’s primary FM station, DWQZ 97.9, branded as 97dot9 Home Radio, is a fully automated music station.

Introduced in 2000, the format, credited for making it a leading music station in Metro Manila, is replicated in Home Radio’s eight provincial FM stations: DWAZ 89.5 Dagupan City, DWQJ 95.1 Naga City, DWQA 92.3 Legazpi City, DYQN 89.5 Iloilo City, DYQC 106.7 Cebu City, DXQR 93.5 Cagayan de Oro City, DXQM 98.7 Davao City, and DXQS 98.3 General Santos. All of ABC’s stations are heard worldwide through online streaming. ABC believes that radio is an effective medium for connecting the Philippine archipelago through the delivery of news, commentary, entertainment, and educational programs. Written byLorna Israel

Aliw Broadcasting Corporation 2009; Home Radio 2009, 2013; KBP 2007b; Lecruz 2013.

ALTO BROADCASTING SYSTEM- CHRONICLE BROADCASTING NETWORK (See ABS-CBN.)ANICETO, BEN (Benjamin Flores Aniceto) b. 1934. d. California, USA 16 Mar 2016. Announcer, producer, media executive. Aniceto was the son of Vicente Aniceto, a physician, and Adela Flores, a pharmacist. He was married to Mila de la Cruz, with whom he had nine children. He attended Lakan Dula Elementary School and Torres High School. He finished a two-year course in fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas and took two years of speech and drama at Ateneo de Manila University. In 1971, while working at ABS-CBN, he attended a management program for senior executives at the Asian Institute of Management. After a five-decade career in Philippine radio and television, he retired and lived in the United States.

Aniceto was in college in the 1950s when he began his career as radio drama actor and commercial announcer for programs sponsored by leading multinational companies such as Procter & Gamble, Unilever, and Colgate Palmolive. This was followed by other assignments, including staff announcer at DZPI, chief announcer at DZRH, production manager at DZMB, operations director for Radio Philippines Network, program director for radio and television in ABS-CBN Network, station manager for Channels 2 and 13, and general manager for ABS-CBN Broadcasting Corporation. He was also account executive and radio-TV director of RRA Advertising & PR Agency, executive vice president and general manager of Blackgold Records Corporation, and editor and bureau chief of Philippine News in Los Angeles, California.

When Marcos declared martial law in 1972 and ABS-CBN closed, Aniceto continued broadcasting at DZQL, then managed the Soriano-owned IBC Channel 13. When Roberto Benedicto, a powerful ally of Marcos, took over IBC in 1976, Aniceto moved to Vicor Music Corporation where he managed its affiliate, Blackgold Records. Later, he left for the United States and joined the anti-Marcos group in Los Angeles, California, while producing and hosting the TV shows Grand Chevrolet Hour on Channel 56 and Atin Ito (This Is Ours) on Channel 18. He edited Philippine News, the Filipino-American newspaper in Southern California, and bought airtime on KMAX to disseminate news and opinions that countered Marcos’s propaganda through the radio program Hello, Philippines. He also bought airtime on Channel 52 and aired several Philippine TV shows such as Martin after Dark, Maricel Drama Special, and Chicks to Chicks.

In 1986, Aniceto returned to the Philippines and again became general manager of ABS-CBN when it reopened a few months after Marcos’s ouster. He built up the network’s news and public affairs division by hiring Loren Legarda, Angelo Castro Jr, Korina Sanchez, Cheche Lazaro, Mel Tiangco, Angelique Lazo, Tony Velasquez, and Bill Velasco. He moved Noli de Castro to DZMM’s primetime hour and then to TV Patrol. A year later, in 1987, he left ABS-CBN and went into blocktiming. He also served as broadcast media strategist for presidential candidate Raul Roco and Sen Jovito Salonga.

Aniceto wrote and edited a 678-page book, Stay Tuned: The Golden Years of Philippine Radio; A Historical Perspective of Philippine Radio—Its Beginnings, Its Golden Years and Its Suppression in September 1972, published in 2007.The book covers landmark developments in radio broadcasting and personality profiles of announcers, managers, entertainment personalities, radio staff and crew members, with focus on the postwar years until the martial law period. article.value: ALTO BROADCASTING SYSTEM- CHRONICLE BROADCASTING NETWORK (See ABS-CBN.)ANICETO, BEN (Benjamin Flores Aniceto) b. 1934. d. California, USA 16 Mar 2016. Announcer, producer, media executive. Aniceto was the son of Vicente Aniceto, a physician, and Adela Flores, a pharmacist. He was married to Mila de la Cruz, with whom he had nine children. He attended Lakan Dula Elementary School and Torres High School. He finished a two-year course in fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas and took two years of speech and drama at Ateneo de Manila University. In 1971, while working at ABS-CBN, he attended a management program for senior executives at the Asian Institute of Management. After a five-decade career in Philippine radio and television, he retired and lived in the United States.

Aniceto was in college in the 1950s when he began his career as radio drama actor and commercial announcer for programs sponsored by leading multinational companies such as Procter & Gamble, Unilever, and Colgate Palmolive. This was followed by other assignments, including staff announcer at DZPI, chief announcer at DZRH, production manager at DZMB, operations director for Radio Philippines Network, program director for radio and television in ABS-CBN Network, station manager for Channels 2 and 13, and general manager for ABS-CBN Broadcasting Corporation. He was also account executive and radio-TV director of RRA Advertising & PR Agency, executive vice president and general manager of Blackgold Records Corporation, and editor and bureau chief of Philippine News in Los Angeles, California.

When Marcos declared martial law in 1972 and ABS-CBN closed, Aniceto continued broadcasting at DZQL, then managed the Soriano-owned IBC Channel 13. When Roberto Benedicto, a powerful ally of Marcos, took over IBC in 1976, Aniceto moved to Vicor Music Corporation where he managed its affiliate, Blackgold Records. Later, he left for the United States and joined the anti-Marcos group in Los Angeles, California, while producing and hosting the TV shows Grand Chevrolet Hour on Channel 56 and Atin Ito (This Is Ours) on Channel 18. He edited Philippine News, the Filipino-American newspaper in Southern California, and bought airtime on KMAX to disseminate news and opinions that countered Marcos’s propaganda through the radio program Hello, Philippines. He also bought airtime on Channel 52 and aired several Philippine TV shows such as Martin after Dark, Maricel Drama Special, and Chicks to Chicks.

In 1986, Aniceto returned to the Philippines and again became general manager of ABS-CBN when it reopened a few months after Marcos’s ouster. He built up the network’s news and public affairs division by hiring Loren Legarda, Angelo Castro Jr, Korina Sanchez, Cheche Lazaro, Mel Tiangco, Angelique Lazo, Tony Velasquez, and Bill Velasco. He moved Noli de Castro to DZMM’s primetime hour and then to TV Patrol. A year later, in 1987, he left ABS-CBN and went into blocktiming. He also served as broadcast media strategist for presidential candidate Raul Roco and Sen Jovito Salonga.

Apeng Daldal (Serafin Maniego Gabriel) was a stage, film and television actor, comedian, singer, dancer, and scriptwriter. He was born in San Luis, Pampanga on 12 October 1928. He died on 9 February 1992. He was the son of Moises Gabriel and Mauricia Maniego. He was married to Elma Modesto with whom he had eight children. It is believed that his moniker was based on his set of big teeth (apen in his native Kapampangan) and his being a fast talker (daldal), although the nickname Apeng is also a diminutive of the first name Serafin.

Apeng Daldal began his career dancing in bodabil in his Tondo, Manila neighborhood, where he was a favorite dancing partner of cross-dressers. In the late 1940s to 1950s, his performances in comedy skits at the Manila Opera House with Mar Lopez and Bebing Santos, who formed the trio Top Three, were a crowd drawer.

In the 1960s, actor Johnny Wilson discovered him for television and put him in The Big Show with Cris de Vera, later becoming a mainstay in the sitcoms Tindahan sa Nayon (Village Store) and Trio los Bobos (The Three Idiots) in the 1970s and Cafeteria Aroma and Super Laff-In in the 1980s. At the same time, Apeng Daldal began to make movies, mostly in supporting roles. In 1964, he appeared with Susan Roces in Libis ng Baryo (Barrio Edge). His major movie roles were in Magic Bilao (Magic Winnowing Basket) and Walis ni Tenteng (Tenteng’s Broom), both in 1965. His first starring role was in Maskulado (Muscular), also in 1965.

Apeng wrote scripts for several TV shows in the 1970s, including Ayos Lang, Pare Ko (It’s Okay, My Friend) and The Nida-Lita Show on Channel 9, and Barok-an Subdivision on Channel 13. He was also on radio in the afternoon and evening timeslots. He wrote several songs, the most well-known of which were Hoy, Mama ng Kaminero (Hey, Mr Street Sweeper) and Pandanggo ng Aswang (Fandango of the Viscera Sucker), both released in 1968.

Though lacking in recognition from award-giving bodies, Apeng Daldal won praise from critics for his dramatic role in an episode of the TV drama series Eliza, 1970-72, ABS-CBN (Channel 9), deviating from his comic stereotype.

Most of the movies Apeng Daldal appeared in were from Sampaguita Pictures, including Alias Golden Boy, 1963; Babaing Kidlat (Lightning Woman), Mga Daliring Ginto (Golden Fingers), Show Business, Bandong Pugante (Bando the Escapee), and Simbangis ng Tigre (Ferocious as a Tiger), 1964; Tatlong Mabilis (The Three Fast Ones), Magic Bilao (Magic Winnowing Basket), Maskulado (Muscular), Tatlong Mabilis sa Hong Kong (The Three Fast Ones in Hong Kong), and Walis ni Tenteng (Tenteng’s Broom), 1965; Mistico Meets Mamaw and Pitong James Bonds (Seven James Bonds), 1966; The Son of Dyango Meets Dorango Kid, Langit Pa Rin Kita (You’re Still My Heaven), and The Pogi Dozen (The Handsome Dozen), 1967; Yolindina, Concentration Camp No. 5, and Ang Inyong Lingkod, Matutina (At Your Service, Matutina), 1975; Habang Pinipigil, Lalong Nanggigigil (The More You Try to Control, the More the Desire Gets Stronger), and Wow, Sikat! Pare, Bigat! (Wow, Famous! Dude, Heavy!), 1977; Dobol Dribol (Double Dribble), for which he created the story and wrote the screenplay, 1979; and Kamakalawa (Day before Yesterday), 1981.   Written by Rolando F. Santos

Lupita Aquino-Kashiwahara (Guadalupe Lampa Aquino-Kashiwahara), also known as Lupita Aquino-Concio, is a television and film director. She was born in Concepcion, Tarlac on 28 May 1934. She is one of the children of Aurora Lampa and Benigno Quiambao Aquino Sr, a former congressman, 1919-25, senator, 1928, secretary of agriculture under Commonwealth president Manuel L. Quezon, 1937, and Speaker of the National Assembly of the Second Philippine Republic, 1943-45. Her siblings are Maria Aurora Aquino-Lichauco, former senator Benigno Simeon Jr aka Ninoy, Maria Gerarda, Paul, former senator Agapito aka Butz, and former senator Maria Teresa Aquino-Oreta aka Tessie. Her brother Butz was a film and television actor. She is the aunt of TV host Kris Aquino and former president Benigno “Noynoy” Aquino III. She married her first husband Cesar Rafael Concio Jr in 1961, with whom she has six children, one of whom is Mia Concio, a screenwriter and former chair of the government station National Broadcasting Network Channel 4, formerly People’s Television. Concio Jr was a recipient of the Ten Outstanding Young Men in the field of technology in 1966. After their separation and divorce, she married Emmy Award-winning Japanese journalist Ken Kashiwahara, who was then working as ABC’s San Francisco bureau chief, in the early 1980s. She took up liberal arts, major in social studies and minor in journalism, at Maryknoll College (now Miriam College). She obtained a master of arts in communication, major in television, from the American University in Washington, DC, in the late 1950s.

When she returned to the Philippines, she directed TV programs on ABS-CBN, beginning in the early 1960s, such as the children’s program Magnolia Sunday Party; the instructional show Education on TV; the live 30-minute drama program Family Theater by Fr James Reuter, SJ, which usually featured adaptations of American plays; and Northern Motors’ Filipinesques, a music program that featured a 24-piece orchestra playing Filipino compositions. From 1963 to 1967, she worked with the Educational TV Project of Ateneo de Manila University under the leadership of Fr Leo Larkin. When she returned to television, she directed the pre-martial law drama anthologies on ABC 5: Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), 1967-72, and Malikmata (Illusion), 1972, the first TV horror-suspense-psychological drama in the Philippines.

Her decision to go to filmmaking moved one critic to say that “TV’s loss was moviedom’s gain” (Nograles 1976, 7). She directed only a few films, but they are all memorable productions. Her first film directorial work was Premiere Productions’s Alkitrang Dugo (Blood Tar), 1975, for Nora Aunor’s NV Productions. The movie was inspired by the English novel Lord of the Flies by William Golding. This was followed by Premiere Productions’s Magandang Gabi sa Inyong Lahat (Good Evening Everyone), 1976, starring Aunor and Tirso Cruz III, and Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth), also in 1976, starring Aunor, a film critical of the Philippine-American relations, specifically the maintenance of US bases in the country. She also made Filmmaster’s Ibalik Mo ang Araw sa Mundong Makasalanan (Bring Back the Sun to a Sinful World), 1978, which is based on a true occurrence: the theft of the image of the Santo Niño to which religious folk attributed several calamities that befell them in Tondo. For Viva Films, she directed Hati Tayo sa Magdamag (Let’s Split the Night between Us), 1988, starring Edu Manzano, Jaclyn Jose, and Tetchie Agbayani, and co-directed Dear Diary, 1989, starring Lea Salonga; and for Premiere, she made Babae (Woman), 1997, starring Aunor and Judy Ann Santos.

While doing films, she continued directing the long-running TV music program Superstar, 1971-89, and Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora), 1970s-1980s, both on RPN 9. On top of these two shows, there was a time in the 1970s that she directed several shows a week—namely, Sulyap sa Kalinangan (A Look at Culture) with Joy Virata on Fridays; From the Mouths of Babes and Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora, both on Saturdays; and Musika ng Lahi (Music of the Race) and Premyo sa Palaro (Prize in Games), both on Sundays. She also directed the interview program Celebrity Hour, with Leila Benitez as host.

After the fall of the Marcos administration, she continued directing TV programs, such as the drama series Bisperas ng Kasaysayan (Eve of History), 1994, RPN 9; the single-airing drama Evelio, 1986, PTV 4, starring Gina Alajar and Joel Torre; other dramas like Higpitan Mo ang Yakap Mo (Embrace Tight) and Umaandap na Ningas (Flickering Light); and the documentaries Kataksilan sa Bayan (Betrayal to the Nation) and Sabwatan sa Kataksilan (Conspiracy to Treachery), both in 2006, of RTV Malacañang, which tackled the failed coup attempts against the Arroyo administration on 24 Feb 2006. She worked as a project consultant for the musical film Emir, 2010, directed by Chito Roño.

In 2004, Aquino-Kashiwahara worked for the presidential election campaign of PresGloria Macapagal Arroyo and came to be known as the president’s “personal director.” She personally oversaw the technical and production aspects of the president’s activities, media appearances, photo opportunities, speeches, and press releases. Aquino-Kashiwahara works as a consultant with Digna Santiago in the Philippine Film Export Services Office of the Film Development Council of the Philippines.

She received the Patnubay ng Kalinangan Award from the city government of Manila, 1970, in connection with the Araw ng Maynila celebrations for “her contribution to the development of Filipino drama on TV and helping to focus public interest in Philippine culture” (Nograles 1976, 6). She and the programs and the artists she had directed won the Citizens’ Award for Television several times: Outstanding TV Director for Balintataw, 1967; Best Educational TV Program for Education on TV, 1966; Best News Interview Program for J. V. Cruz Interviews, 1966 and 1967; Best Special Events for Election ’67, 1967; Best Anthology Series for Balintataw, 1967, 1968, 1969, 1970, and 1971; and the Hall of Fame award for Balintataw, 1972. From 1975 to 1978, her shows Superstar and Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora won for her, Nora Aunor, and the show the awards for Best Director, Best Actress, Best Musical Program, and Best Drama Program, respectively, from the Philippine Academy of Television Arts and Sciences or PATAS. She won Best Director for the film Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo at the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards in 1977, which also won Best Picture, Best Story and Best Screenplay for Marina Feleo-Gonzales, and Best Editing for Edgardo Vinarao. The film also won Best Story and Best Editing in the 1976 Metro Manila Film Festival. Bisperas ng Kasaysayan won the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon in 1994. She also received the Gawad para sa Natatanging Kontribusyon at the 1994 Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon.    Written by Lena S. Pareja and Eulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Mae Urtal Caralde

Dely Atay-Atayan (Adelaida Marquez Fernando-Cruz) was a radio, television, and stage actor, and a singer. She was born in Tayabas, Tondo, Manila on 17 Mar 1914. She died in Parañaque on 30 Aug 2004. She studied at Rizal Elementary School, Torres High School, and Philippine Normal School up to the second year. Her father Amado Fernando was a painter and composer, mother Carmen Marquez, a singer, and brother Fernando aka Ading Fernando was an actor, scriptwriter, and director. When first spouse Alejandro Villegas, aka Andoy Balunbalunan, died, she married Catalino Cruz, aka Jockey Tenoy. Her only child with Villegas, Alfonso, is a dancer, while Alfonso’s three daughters, Ann, Armi, and Aida, are actors. Her great-grandson, Manuel Villegas Quizon II, also the grandson of Dolphy, is an actor and singer.

Atay-atayan was 15 when she first joined amateur singing contests in Binondo, where her family lived. She then landed a stint as a kundiman singer at the Palace Theater, touring the country as a member of a bodabil troupe from 1930 to 1934. It was also during this period when she began to sing on KZIB with her brother Ading. She also performed at the Clover Theater with comedians Dolphy, Aruray, the duo Pugo and Togo, Casmot, Balot, Panchito, and Chiquito. When she married Villegas in 1934, they became partners in Radio Variety Revue Company performing on stage and on the air. Radio programming manager G. S. Fernandez gave her the moniker Dely Atay-atayan while Matty Torres gave her husband the nickname Andoy Balunbalunan. Their nicknames (atay is Tagalog for liver while balunbalunan is chicken gizzard) led to their theme song “Awit ng Manok” (Song of the Chicken). Producing the most popular blocktime programs, the couple was the biggest earner among prewar radio blocktimers, making over one thousand pesos a month, a fabulous sum when top-level government employees earned 30 to 35 pesos a month. Some of their songs, interspersed with comic routines, were critical of the colonial condition at the time, such as “Alila” (Slave). Moreover, the husband-and-wife team sang radio commercials, the most popular being Kiko Baterya (Kiko Battery) and Alviz Tailoring.

She was tagged as “queen of laughs,” “sweetheart of the airlanes,” and Gracie Allen of the Philippines (referencing the American comedienne, half of the George Burns and Gracie Allen Show). She was outstanding in such radio shows as Tang-tarang-tang (Daddy-O), Gabi ng Shell (Night of Shell Company), and Ay, Neneng (Oh, Neneng). She formed a quartet called the Ancient Fox with Pugak, Lopito, and Doro de los Ojos. Even during the war, she continued performing comedy at the Life Theater and at the Manila Grand Opera House under the direction of Lou Salvador Sr.

Her first movie was Lakambini (Muse), 1940, opposite Balunbalunan. She made some five dozen films, including the popular movies of Premiere Productions, like Bulaklak at Paru-Paro (Flower and Butterfly) and Kumander Sundang (Commander Dagger), 1948; Padre Burgos (Father Burgos), 1949; Kenkoy (Comic), 1950; Mr. and Mrs., 1956; Pitong Gatang (Seven Gantas), 1959; Nobody’s Child, 1970; Mahiwagang Kris (The Fantastic Kris), 1975; and Buhay Misis (Life of a Housewife), 1983. Her other films include I Won, I Won: Ang Swerte Nga Naman (I Won, I Won: How Lucky of Me), 1985; Si Baleleng at ang Gintong Sirena (Baleleng and the Golden Mermaid), 1988; Everlasting Love, 1989; and Chickboys, 1994.

From the 1970s to the 1980s, she concentrated on TV, appearing as the moralizing mother-in-law in the long-running comedy series John en Marsha (John and Marsha), 1973-1990, with Dolphy and Nida Blanca. Written and directed by her brother Ading, John en Marsha, one of the longest running television sitcoms, was the program for which she is best remembered. She reprised her TV role in several movie spinoffs of the series from 1974 to 1991. Atay-Atayan also appeared in another popular television show, Iskul Bukol (Truants), from 1977 to 1990, starring the comedy trio of Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, and Joey de Leon. Like John en Marsha, this series also spawned movie adaptations and remakes.

Atay-Atayan received the Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining (PATAS) Award as Outstanding Actor, 1977, and Best Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series, 1978. She also received the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) at the age of 81 during ceremonies held at the Philippine International Convention Center in 1993. In 2001, the Film Academy of the Philippines honored Atay-atayan with another Lifetime Achievement Award.   Written by Malou L. Maniquis and Lena S. Pareja, updated by E. Carreon and Yna Marei Aguilar

BANAHAW BROADCASTING CORPORATION CHANNEL 2 (BBC 2) BBC Channel 2 started broadcasting in Nov 1973 and ceased operations at the height of the EDSA Revolt on 25 Feb 1986 that ousted Pres Ferdinand Marcos from office. Its headquarters were located in Broadcast City at Old Balara, Capitol Hills, Diliman, Quezon City. The name Banahaw came from Mount Banahaw, a dormant volcano in Quezon province in Southern Luzon believed by many as a holy mountain and is associated with mystics and faith healers. Its transmitter was located on Panay Ave in Diliman, near the headquarters of ABS-CBN.

The first flagship station of BBC 2 was DWWX-TV, formerly DZAQ-TV owned by ABS-CBN. When Marcos declared martial law in 1972, he ordered the shutdown of ABS-CBN. One of the broadcast stations acquired by Marcos crony Roberto S. Benedicto was ABS-CBN, including DZAQ-TV. The station’s name was changed to BBC when it started operating in 1973.

BBC’s AM radio station was DWWA. Its FM station was DWWK 101.9, which aired pop vocal and instrumental jazz, then labeled as jazz fusion. By Dec 1973, BBC was also operating radio stations in the Visayas. It was broadcasting on two originally owned stations by ABS-CBN: DYCB-TV 3 in Cebu, which was changed to DYCW-TV, and DYXL-TV 4 in Bacolod, renamed DYBW-TV. The Cebu and Bacolod stations, however, switched affiliations to the government-owned GTV 4, later called the Maharlika Broadcasting System, in 1978 and reverted to their former call letters.

BBC 2, together with two more Benedicto-acquired broadcast stations, the Radio Mindanao Network–Interisland Broadcasting Corporation (RMN-IBC) Channel 13 and the Kanlaon Broadcasting System–Radio Philippines Network (KBS-RPN) Channel 9, moved to new headquarters in Broadcast City in 1976. The station became popular for its trademark jingle “Big Beautiful Country,” composed by Jose Mari Chan. BBC 2 was rebranded as City 2 Television in 1980, but its name reverted to BBC 2 in 1984. Its last broadcast was during the 1986 EDSA Revolt, just before rebel soldiers who bolted from Marcos disabled its transmitters. BBC 2, together with RPN 9 and IBC 13, were sequestered by the administration of Pres Corazon Aquino. BBC 2 never returned on air. DWWX-TV and the Cebu and Bacolod stations were returned to ABS-CBN on 16 Jul 1986. Also in 1986, DWWA was renamed DWAN when it was handed over to IBC, and DWWK-FM 101.9 in Manila was awarded to ABS-CBN.

BBC 2 was the original home of Inday Badiday’s much-maligned showbiz talk show Nothing but the Truth, 1976, followed by Would You Believe?, 1978, before she moved to GMA 7. The station pioneered the daily serialized drama on television during the martial law period through Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), 1977-85, which was based on a famous radio soap. Its weekly drama anthologies beginning in 1973 focused on love stories of women characters with mainstay women actors, such as Boots Anson-Roa’s Eliza, Amalia Fuentes’s Nagmamahal, Amalia (Lovingly Yours, Amalia), Tina Revilla’s Christina, Vilma Santos’s Dulambuhay ni Rosa Vilma (Life Story of Rosa Vilma), and Pinky de Leon’s Ito Ako, Pinky (This Is Me, Pinky). Other drama anthologies featuring various women actors were Babae (Woman), Maria Morena, Panata (Oath), and Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home). In these programs, women were conventionally stereotyped as martyrs. The station also produced the drama anthology, Ulila (Orphan), 1978-79, hosted by Rosa Rosal, based on true stories of orphaned children. BBC 2 was one of the first television stations to produce a daily early morning talk show, Coffee with Lee, 1976, 8:00-9:00 am, hosted by Lee Andres and Noel Trinidad. Another pioneer was the culinary show Cooking It Up with Nora, with host Nora Daza. Old Filipino movies were broadcast on BBC in Sinehan Dos (Movie Theater on Two) and Sunday Super Sine (Sunday Super Movie).

A top-rating program was the live coverage of the basketball games of the Manila Industrial and Commercial Athletic Association or MICAA, which aired on Channel 4 before martial law, then on RBS Channel 7 for a few months in 1973, then moved to BBC 2 later that year until 1974. A ratings winner was the live coverage of the games of the Philippine Basketball Association (PBA), which began airing on BBC 2 on 9 Apr 1975 and broadcast three times a week. The PBA coverage was produced by Jun Jison, Romy Jalosjos, and Ramy Diez and anchored by Dick Ildefonso and Emy Arcilla. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III

Sources: Abelardo 1975a, 1975b; Bautista 1980; Capino 2003; Del Mundo 2003; Enriquez 2003; Lo 2003; Nofuente 1979, 1986; Rodrigo 2006; Sagisag 1976; Sioson-San Juan 1999; Star for All Seasons 2012; Weekend 1978, 1979, 1980; Wikipedia 2015a.

BASILIO, RINO (Ceferino Mercado Basilio) b. Apalit, Pampanga 23 Dec 1929. Announcer, broadcast executive. His parents are Timoteo Basilio and Sinforosa Mercado. He was married to the late Gloria Basilio, with whom he has three children, including Howard, a journalist. Basilio attended Apalit Elementary School and Arellano North High School, and earned a bachelor of science in psychology from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1953. He attended a master’s program in psychology at Far Eastern University until 1954.

He started a career in radio when he volunteered as a student announcer on DZST, the campus radio station of UST. After college, he worked as staff announcer in Republic Broadcasting System’s DZBB and DZXX in the 1950s, reading the news, playing music, and covering live the Manila Stock Exchange daily market report. He later became chief announcer and special events head of the twin radio stations, followed by a string of assignments in various executive positions in the Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN), through its merger with Alto Broadcasting System (ABS), from chief of announcers to assistant vice president with postings throughout the country, from 1957 to 1972.

When then president Ferdinand Marcos declared martial law in 1972, which caused the closure of ABS-CBN, Basilio moved to Nation Broadcasting Corporation as director, vice president, and program and operations manager, 1974-80; vice president for radio, Vicor Music Corporation, 1985; and general manager, Radio Philippines Network, 1985-89. He then returned to ABS-CBN as vice president for DZMM, DWRR, and all provincial stations, 1989-92. He then served as president and general manager of Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation Channel 13, 1992-97; and vice president for provincial operations of ABC Channel 5, 1997-2009.

Basilio trained in broadcast management locally and internationally. He represented the Philippines in international broadcast conferences such as the International Telecommunications Union conference in Malta, 1997.

As one of the founding members of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) in 1973, Basilio served as member of the KBP board of directors for 34 years. He was among the original framers of the KBP Code of Ethics for Radio and Television, the forerunner of the Broadcast Code of the Philippines. He received the KBP Golden Dove Lifetime Achievement Award in 2008. Written by Edgardo Ray G. Pedroche

He later became chief announcer and special events head of the twin radio stations, followed by a string of assignments in various executive positions in the Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN), through its merger with Alto Broadcasting System (ABS), from chief of announcers to assistant vice president with postings throughout the country, from 1957 to 1972.

When then president Ferdinand Marcos declared martial law in 1972, which caused the closure of ABS-CBN, Basilio moved to Nation Broadcasting Corporation as director, vice president, and program and operations manager, 1974-80; vice president for radio, Vicor Music Corporation, 1985; and general manager, Radio Philippines Network, 1985-89. He then returned to ABS-CBN as vice president for DZMM, DWRR, and all provincial stations, 1989-92. He then served as president and general manager of Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation Channel 13, 1992-97; and vice president for provincial operations of ABC Channel 5, 1997-2009.

Basilio trained in broadcast management locally and internationally. He represented the Philippines in international broadcast conferences such as the International Telecommunications Union conference in Malta, 1997.

As one of the founding members of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) in 1973, Basilio served as member of the KBP board of directors for 34 years. He was among the original framers of the KBP Code of Ethics for Radio and Television, the forerunner of the Broadcast Code of the Philippines. He received the KBP Golden Dove Lifetime Achievement Award in 2008. Written by Edgardo Ray G. Pedroche

BENEDICTO, KITCHIE (Kitchie Campos Benedicto-Paulino) Her parents were Roberto Salas Benedicto, founder of Kanlaon Broadcasting System (KBS) Channel 9 and a close ally of former president Ferdinand Marcos, and Julieta Campos. She is married to Robert Paulino. She went to high school at Maryknoll College, now Miriam College, and then attended a finishing school at Lausanne, Switzerland. She completed a bachelor of arts in broadcast communication at the University of the Philippines, belonging to the second batch of graduates of the program, in 1969. While at UP, she co-founded with Maria Montelibano the UP Broadcasting Association in 1968.

She began as executive assistant to the general manager, then program manager, and later general manager of RPN 9 at age 25 during the martial law period in the 1970s. She handled five departments of the broadcast station: news, public affairs, entertainment, production services, and branch operations. She produced top-rating programs on RPN 9, such as the weekly music variety show Superstar, 1971-89, the comedy series John en Marsha (John and Marsha), 1973-90, and the fantasy-adventure anthology Darna, 1977. She was also the producer of the children’s program Kuskos Balungos (Just Making Noise), 1980-82, BBC 2, which followed the format of the Imee Marcos-produced Kaluskos Musmos (Kiddie Noise), 1979-89, RPN 9.

She lived in the USA after the ouster of Marcos in 1986. She returned to the Philippines sometime in the early 2000s and put up EB Entertainment, a talent managing company. She went back to producing video programs and directing live shows, such as beauty pageants and festivals in the provinces. She line-produced for ABS-CBN the sitcom John en Shirley (John and Shirley), 2006-7, the sequel to John en Marsha, and directed the music game show Fam Jam, 2005-6, QTV 11, and the weekend afternoon game show Toink! Sino ang Tama? (Toink! Who Is Correct?), 2012, TV5. She is also the chair and chief executive officer of New Riviera Hotel Development Corporation. She owned a 34 percent minority share in RPN 9 when the network entered into a joint venture with Solar Entertainment Corporation in Jan 2011, which later became CNN Philippines.

She received the Ading Fernando Lifetime Achievement Award at the Star Awards of the Philippine Movie Press Club in 2013. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III

BENITEZ-BROWN, LYCA (Lydia Liboro Benitez-Brown) b. Manila 14 Jan 1952. TV producer, director, writer. She is the fourth among nine children of Tomas Conrado Benitez and Conchita Liboro. Her aunt Leila Benitez was one of the original hosts of the noontime TV show Student Canteen.Another aunt, Helena Z. Benitez, is the founder of the Bayanihan Dance Company. Her grandparents are Conrado Benitez, the first dean of the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Business Administration, and Francisca Tirona Benitez, one of the founders of the Philippine Women’s University (PWU). She is also related to Mariel Benitez and Marco Benitez, ABS-CBN sports commentators; Cillet Liboro of ABS-CBN News Channel; and Tamara Benitez, director of photography for some of the films by Lav Diaz. She graduated with a bachelor’s degree in broadcast communication, 1987, at UP. She is the director of the Media Center of PWU in Manila.

She was instrumental in the realization of the first Asian co-production of the children’s educational TV program Sesame Street, co-produced with the Children’s Television Workshop (CTW) of New York. She took over the directorship of the Philippine Sesame Street Project, which was with the Ministry of Human Settlements headed by First Lady Imelda Marcos, from her cousin’s wife Betty Bantug-Benitez when the latter died in 1983. Upon the expiration of the CTW co-production contract for Sesame in 1984, she established the Philippine Children’s Television Foundation Inc and produced the all-Filipino TV production Batibot (Small but Strong). She was the program’s executive director and producer from 1984 to 1992. The program ran from 1984 to 2000 on RPN 9, PTV 4, GMA, and ABS-CBN, and was revived in 2010 on ABC 5/ TV5. The TV program spawned Radyo Batibot (Batibot Radio), broadcast in the late 1980s on DZAM, later called DZAR. It also launched Batibot Books in collaboration with Anvil Publishing, children’s audio cassettes with Ivory Records, live shows for children, and the TV show Pin-Pin, a Chinese-Filipino children’s program produced in cooperation with Kaisa Para sa Kaunlaran.

During the early years of martial law, Benitez-Brown worked as writer for the programs of ABS-CBN, BBC 2, RPN 9, and the Philippine Production Center, an independent TV company set up by former ABS-CBN employees. She developed and wrote the game show Spin-a-Win, starring Jeanne Young, in the 1970s. She wrote scripts for the TV programs of Nora Aunor, Pilita Corrales, Celeste Legaspi, and Kuh Ledesma, and TV specials such as the First Metro Manila Pop Music Festival, Binibining Pilipinas, and the awards ceremonies of the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences. She worked with Global Village in New York from 1976 to 1980 to set up the public television workshop for independent video and film producers all over the United States. She also helped set up Other Visions, Other Voices, a festival of independent video and film productions.

With close friend June Keithley, Benitez-Brown worked for Radyo Bandido (Bandit Radio), an anti-Marcos dictatorship underground radio program instrumental in broadcasting events during the EDSA Revolt. She served as head of the broadcast arts division of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts during the term of Pres Corazon Aquino.

She was consultant for the International Telecommunications Union of TV Zanzibar, Tanzania, 1992-93, and became program director of Tanzania’s first private TV and radio station, ITV / Radio One, 1994-96. She wrote and directed video documentaries, such as Children of the Mines and Children of the Plantations, both commissioned by the International Labor Organization’s Programme on the Elimination of Child Labor, 1994; Gertrude Mongella: Woman of Africa, 1995, about the secretary general of the 4th World Conference of Women, which was screened at the United Nations Conference on Women in Beijing, China; Against the Tide: Teresia, 1996; and Dance of My Life, 2010, about the life of Bessie Badilla, the first Philippine Carnival Queen in Brazil, which was premiered at the New York Hell’s Kitchen Film Festival, 2011, and also shown at the 8th Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, 2012.

Her script for the TV show Truly Pilita was awarded best script for a musical in the KBP Golden Dove Awards in 1976. Batibot’s awards during her term include the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon in 1987, 1988, 1989, 1991, and 1992; the KBP Golden Dove Awards for Best Children’s TV Program in 1986, 1991, and 1992; the PMPC Star Awards for TV in 1987, 1989, and 1992; a citation for the program’s major contribution to the propagation of the national language from the Kalinangan ng Wikang Pambansa in 1987; a Hall of Fame Award from the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 1988 for having won the award for Best Children’s Show from 1984 to 1987; Star Awards for Best Children’s TV Show from the Philippine Movie Press Club in 1987, 1989, and 1992; the Tanglaw ng Lahi Award in 1992; the International Advisors’ Award from the Prix Jeunesse International in Munich in 1990; the Best Production Award for contributing to the knowledge of the peoples of the world in the First Latin American Festival and Market of Films, TV and Video in Colombia in 1992; and the gold medal for its animation segment “Nguyamyam” (Devour) at the New York TV and Film Festival in 1992.

Benitez-Brown received the Ten Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service Award in 1989, the Outstanding Alumna Award for communication arts from the UP Alumni Association in 2012, and the Mariang Maya Award for Excellence in Media and Communications from the UP Sigma Delta Phi in 2013. Written by Mae U. Caralde, with notes from Romulo P. Baquiran Jr and Eulalio R. Guieb III

BENTOT (Arturo Vergara Medina) aka Ben Cosca. b. San Simon, Pampanga 13 Jul 1928. d. Manila 19 Jun 1986. Radio, television, and movie actor-comedian. Bentot was the son of Claro Medina and Leoncia Vergara. He was married to Rosario Garcia, with whom he had four children. One of his sons, Luisito G. Medina, was a child star with the screen name Bentot Jr. Bentot attended La Loma Elementary School.

 

Bentot was first noticed as a comedian when he teamed up in the 1950s with Mariano Contreras aka Pugo. The comedic duo became popular through the radio program Sebya, Mahal Kita (Sebya I Love You) with Sylvia La Torre, Rosa Aguirre, and Eddie San Jose. He also appeared in the show’s film adaptation in 1957 and sequels such as My Little Kuwan (My Little Something), 1958; Nukso nang Nukso (Always Teasing), 1960; and Oh Sendang, 1961. He is remembered for his role in the television shows Tang-Tarang-Tang, 1960s, and its spin-off Si Tatang Kasi (Blame It on Father), 1970s. In all his shows, Bentot played the role of an overgrown child. In Tang-Tarang-Tang and Si Tatang Kasi, he was Bitoy, son of Mang Nano (Pugo), who naively disclosed his father’s schemes. Among his other films were Maria Kapra, 1947, and Mr. Kuripot (Mr Frugal), 1958.

In 1963, Bentot was nominated at the Citizen’s Award for Televison for his role in Tang-Tarang-Tang. Written by Claudine Keith V. Regino

BOMBO RADYO PHILIPPINES This is one of the largest radio networks in the country, with 21 AM stations branded as Bombo Radyo and 16 FM stations called Star FM. It is a partnership among the Newsounds Broadcasting Network Inc (NBN), licensee of the Mindanao-based stations; Consolidated Broadcasting System Inc (CBS), Visayas licensee; and People’s Broadcasting Service Inc (PBS), Luzon licensee. Its flagship station is DYFM in Iloilo, where its headquarters are also located. Except for one FM station, DWSM, all its stations are outside Manila, including DXIF in Cagayan de Oro, DZBR in Butuan, DZVR in Laoag, DZGR in Tuguegarao, DZVV in Vigan, DZNC in Cauayan, DZSO in La Union, DZWX in Baguio, DZWN in Dagupan, DZNG in Naga, DZLG in Legazpi, DYWB in Bacolod, DYMF in Cebu, DYTX in Tacloban, DYIN in Kalibo, DYOW in Roxas, DXMF in Davao, DXES in General Santos, and DXMC in Koronadal.

 

“Bombo” is an Ilonggo term for a big bass drum of a marching band. The name symbolizes the network’s predominantly news and public affairs programming. The Bombo Network News is simulcast over 31 of its stations at 7:00 am, 12:00 nn, and 6:00 pm. The stations also stream live online through bomboradyo.com. Apart from news programs, the stations have commentaries and discussions on law and justice; programs on health, sports, and religion; talk shows on lifestyle and public service; and music and entertainment shows.

 

In 2010, Bombo Radyo in Laoag, Cauayan, Baguio, Bacolod, Roxas, General Santos, and Iloilo, as well as Star FM in Bacolod, Zamboanga, and Dipolog, won the KBP Golden Dove People’s Choice award. Its other awards include the 35th Catholic Mass Media Awards for Best News Program for Bombo Radyo Iloilo’s Bombo News & Views AM Edition, which featured “The Papacy Special” hosted by Divine Cuello and Ted Francia; Best Business News or Feature for Bombo Hanay Bigtime segment “Unlad Pinoy ng Bombo Radyo” (Filipino Development of Bombo Radyo), hosted by Bombo Radyo Bacolod’s station manager Roger Gencianeo; and Best Counseling Program for Bombo Radyo Bacolod’s Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday), hosted by Jaz de Jesus-Madrigal. Written by Karryl Faye D. Katigbak

CANLAS, ELOISA (Eloisa Cruz-Canlas) aka Lola Sela Bungangera (Talkative Grandma Sela). b. 12 Feb 1946. d. 15 Jul 2012. Veteran radio personality. Eloisa Canlas was fondly called “Eloi” by her family, friends, colleagues, and fans. She was barely three years old when she began to sing on stage during fiestas in her hometown of Lubao, Pampanga.

 

Canlas was dubbed “Queen of Radio Drama” for her versatility in voice acting. She would make convincing performances of a prince, a flirty teenager, a wicked witch, and even a dog or a rooster. Moreover, she could voice two or more characters in the same drama. She played both the protagonist and antagonist in Zimatar. Aside from radio drama, she dubbed characters in animated television shows for children, hosted children’s TV shows on Channel 5 and UNTV, and voiced advertisements.

 

As a high school student in Manila, she would hang around the studios of DZRH to see her favorite performers and broadcasters. She could not get past the guard until Ramona Pablo (Lola Basyang from Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang or Stories of Grandma Basyang) let her in. In her third year of political science in the University of the East in 1968, she was given the opportunity to be personal assistant to Tina Loy (a well-known soap opera director). She then quit school to pursue her dream.

 

She worked as a production assistant for two years without any salary or talent fee. Later on, she served as assistant director to Johnny de Leon, director of Operetang Putol-Putol (Operetta in Pieces). After that, she voiced one of the characters in the drama Dose Cruzes (Twelve Crosses).

 

Canlas was given her first break for radio drama by director Art de Guzman and drama producer and host Robustiano Abellera. In those early days, she would observe the techniques of radio artists Luz Fernandez and the late Err Ramos so that she could hone her own voice acting skills. She was a talent for Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror), Mr. Romantiko (Mr Romantic), and Hukumang Pantahanan (Family Court), among others.

 

Canlas is said to have always been the first one to arrive at the radio station even before it opened and would be the last one to leave at the end of the day. She worked in DZRH and Manila Broadcasting Corporation for more than four decades. She said that her moniker “Lola Sela Bungangera” came from DZRH owner Federico Elizalde when in the 1990s she performed the role of a grandmother in a popular morning news and commentary program, Balitang Bayan Numero Uno (National News Number One), hosted by Joe Taruc. Here she gave commentary on politicians and public figures.

 

She also voiced the program Lola Sela Bungangera (Loudmouth Grandmother Sela) with the Senior Citizen and Livelihood Project of DZRH, and hosted the “Pondohan” (Fund) segment of UNTV’s early morning show Good Morning Kuya (Good Morning, Elder Brother). Additionally, she was executive producer of Drama sa Nuebe Nubenta (Drama on 990) of DZIQ Radyo Inquirer 990, featuring six different romances that included tearjerkers, adventures, and values-oriented stories. Aside from being a voice actor, she was also a radio scriptwriter, director, producer, and host. Moreover, she was a patient and meticulous teacher to younger and newer voice talents.

 

With the conviction that radio will endure as a medium despite the popularity of television and the Internet, she established the Tanghalang Parisukat Training Center in the Communication Foundation for Asia Compound on Old Santa Mesa, Manila, in 2004. This caters to young people as young as five years old who are interested in radio and other performing and visual arts. The training center holds free classes in radio announcing; acting on radio, television, film, and stage; voice dubbing; singing; musical composition and musical instruments; production; direction and scriptwriting for radio and theater; and painting. Canlas handled some of the training. Many students are from poor families. Several graduates from her training center have gone on to work in radio and television.

 

In 2011, Canlas received the University of the Philippines Gawad Plaridel for her exceptional skill and contribution to the broadcast industry. At that time, she was drama director and supervisor on DZRH and executive producer of dramas on DZIQ. Written by Karryl Faye D. Katigbak

 

Sources: Canlas 2014; Enriquez and Canlas 2012; Flordeliz 2012; Inquirer.net 2012b; Jose 2011; Lapeña 2012; Melican 2012.

article.value: CANLAS, ELOISA (Eloisa Cruz-Canlas) aka Lola Sela Bungangera (Talkative Grandma Sela). b. 12 Feb 1946. d. 15 Jul 2012. Veteran radio personality. Eloisa Canlas was fondly called “Eloi” by her family, friends, colleagues, and fans. She was barely three years old when she began to sing on stage during fiestas in her hometown of Lubao, Pampanga.

Canlas was dubbed “Queen of Radio Drama” for her versatility in voice acting. She would make convincing performances of a prince, a flirty teenager, a wicked witch, and even a dog or a rooster. Moreover, she could voice two or more characters in the same drama. She played both the protagonist and antagonist in Zimatar. Aside from radio drama, she dubbed characters in animated television shows for children, hosted children’s TV shows on Channel 5 and UNTV, and voiced advertisements.

As a high school student in Manila, she would hang around the studios of DZRH to see her favorite performers and broadcasters. She could not get past the guard until Ramona Pablo (Lola Basyang from Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang or Stories of Grandma Basyang) let her in. In her third year of political science in the University of the East in 1968, she was given the opportunity to be personal assistant to Tina Loy (a well-known soap opera director). She then quit school to pursue her dream.

She worked as a production assistant for two years without any salary or talent fee. Later on, she served as assistant director to Johnny de Leon, director of Operetang Putol-Putol (Operetta in Pieces). After that, she voiced one of the characters in the drama Dose Cruzes (Twelve Crosses).

Canlas was given her first break for radio drama by director Art de Guzman and drama producer and host Robustiano Abellera. In those early days, she would observe the techniques of radio artists Luz Fernandez and the late Err Ramos so that she could hone her own voice acting skills. She was a talent for Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror), Mr. Romantiko (Mr Romantic), and Hukumang Pantahanan (Family Court), among others.

Canlas is said to have always been the first one to arrive at the radio station even before it opened and would be the last one to leave at the end of the day. She worked in DZRH and Manila Broadcasting Corporation for more than four decades. She said that her moniker “Lola Sela Bungangera” came from DZRH owner Federico Elizalde when in the 1990s she performed the role of a grandmother in a popular morning news and commentary program, Balitang Bayan Numero Uno (National News Number One), hosted by Joe Taruc. Here she gave commentary on politicians and public figures.

She also voiced the program Lola Sela Bungangera (Loudmouth Grandmother Sela) with the Senior Citizen and Livelihood Project of DZRH, and hosted the “Pondohan” (Fund) segment of UNTV’s early morning show Good Morning Kuya (Good Morning, Elder Brother). Additionally, she was executive producer of Drama sa Nuebe Nubenta (Drama on 990) of DZIQ Radyo Inquirer 990, featuring six different romances that included tearjerkers, adventures, and values-oriented stories. Aside from being a voice actor, she was also a radio scriptwriter, director, producer, and host. Moreover, she was a patient and meticulous teacher to younger and newer voice talents.

With the conviction that radio will endure as a medium despite the popularity of television and the Internet, she established the Tanghalang Parisukat Training Center in the Communication Foundation for Asia Compound on Old Santa Mesa, Manila, in 2004. This caters to young people as young as five years old who are interested in radio and other performing and visual arts. The training center holds free classes in radio announcing; acting on radio, television, film, and stage; voice dubbing; singing; musical composition and musical instruments; production; direction and scriptwriting for radio and theater; and painting. Canlas handled some of the training. Many students are from poor families. Several graduates from her training center have gone on to work in radio and television.

In 2011, Canlas received the University of the Philippines Gawad Plaridel for her exceptional skill and contribution to the broadcast industry. At that time, she was drama director and supervisor on DZRH and executive producer of dramas on DZIQ. Written by Karryl Faye D. Katigbak
Sources: Canlas 2014; Enriquez and Canlas 2012; Flordeliz 2012; Inquirer.net 2012b; Jose 2011; Lapeña 2012; Melican 2012.
