CANOY, HENRY (Henry Rabe Canoy) b. Cagayan de Oro City, Misamis Oriental 1 Nov 1923. d. Cheyenne, Wyoming, USA 16 May 2008. Businessman, civic leader, broadcaster, public servant, philantrophist, and founder of RMN. Canoy was born to public school teachers Laureana Rabe and Mariano Canoy. His brother Reuben Canoy is a journalist, broadcaster, lawyer, and a former mayor of Cagayan de Oro City. He was married to Maria Clara Suniel-Canoy with whom he had three sons. He attended college at the University of Santo Tomas where he graduated summa cum laude in 1947.

Canoy’s interest in radio began after World War II. He, Robin Cui, and Vicente Rivera put together a ramshackle radio laboratory from two home-built tube radio receivers in Cagayan de Oro to listen to the Listerine Amateur Hour, Esco Salon Show, and The Kolynos Hour. They then built a 30-watt radio transmitter from surplus parts from Manila armed only with a copy of the Radio Amateurs Handbook and an improvised horizontal wire antenna tied to a coconut tree. In 1948, he experimented with an amplifier, a turntable, a microphone, and a loud speaker to build a radio station in Cagayan de Oro. The following year, in 1949, he broke the airwaves as a pirate radio station with the words, “This is Cagayan de Oro calling …” The station had no call letters and operated illegally without a license.

In 1950, he and his brother Reuben R. Canoy applied for a congressional franchise to establish a more powerful radio station with a 500-watt transmitter. In 1951, a new transmitter arrived. With only a telescopic steel pole as antenna borrowed from the Bureau of Telecom, the Canoy team attached one end of a copper wire to the pole and the other end to a coconut tree a block away. The following year, on 23 Jun 1952, they were granted a permit to maintain and operate the radio broadcasting station. Eleven days later, on 4 Jul 1952, test broadcasts of station DXCC began with a power of 500 watts on 1560 kHz from Cagayan de Oro. On 28 Aug 1952, the first radio station in Cagayan de Oro was born—DXCC officially started broadcasting, greeting listeners every hour with the station ID, “This is radio station DXCC, Cagayan de Oro calling …”

After a visit to the United States in 1954 under an observation grant, Henry Canoy transformed his homespun operations into the first public service station—a radical concept in the country at the time. He set up the Jambalaya Fund Drive, DXCC’s first public service program that provided community service through radio. DXCC thus served as a public assistance center, post office, long distance telephone system, dog pound, medical dispensary, and civil engineering headquarters.

DXCC’s success enabled it to expand to Iligan, then to Butuan and Davao. He named the growing operation Radio Mindanao Network (RMN), which grew to a family of AM and FM radio stations when he partnered with business tycoon Andres Soriano of San Miguel Corporation and Philippine Airlines. RMN is one of the largest radio networks in the Philippines today, with over 50 broadcast stations from Jolo, Sulu in Mindanao to Aparri, Cagayan, in Luzon. Until his death, Canoy continued to work as the chairman of the board of the network, but began to turn over in the late 1990s the day-to-day operations of RMN to his sons: Eric, Butch, and Charley.

In 1997, he established WRMN Radio Pinoy in New York, reaching the eastern United States and Canada. In the same year, he received from the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas the KBP Lifetime Achievement Award. Upon his death in 2008, the 14th Congress of the Republic of the Philippines named Canoy one of the pillars of Philippine radio, citing his contribution to rural progress and development through local radio. Written by Yna Marei Aguilar

Sources:

Canoy 1997; Climaco 2008; GMA News Online 2008a; Mabuhay Radio 2008; Montalvan 2008; Mosquera and Dayco 2008; Radio Mindanao Network 2015; Senate of the Philippines 2015.

CANOY, REUBEN (Reuben Rabe Canoy) b. Cagayan de Oro City, Misamis Oriental 6 Jun 1929. Journalist, editor, newscaster, producer, disc jockey, poet, scriptwriter, short story writer, film producer, publisher, lawyer, and politician. Canoy is the son of public school teachers Mariano Canoy and Laureana Rabe. His brother Henry Canoy was the founder of Radio Mindanao Network, the largest radio network in the Philippines. He is married to Solona Calo Torralba, a business executive and educator, with whom he has four children. He attended Cagayan Central School and Misamis Oriental High School. He studied law for one year at the University of the Philippines (UP) and later transferred to Silliman University (SU) where he obtained his bachelor of laws degree in 1953. He passed the Philippine bar examination in the same year, and then was appointed community development officer by Pres Ramon Magsaysay.

Canoy’s interest in media was first developed as a student journalist in the UP student paper Philippine Collegian, the SU student paper Sillimanian, and the SU literary journal Sands and Coral, where he served as literary editor in 1947 and managing editor in 1948-49. While in his teens in Manila before he moved to Dumaguete to study at SU, he tagged along with Francisco “Koko” Trinidad, who was program director of KZFM, the radio station organized by the United States Office of War Information as General MacArthur retook Manila from the Japanese in early 1945, ending World War II. He helped produce the programs Radio Documentary and Radio Newsreel. He learned to deliver the news, spin records, do remote broadcasts, and conduct interviews. (KZFM was turned over in 1946 to the Philippine government, making it the first of a network of government-owned radio stations.) In the meantime, while he was at SU, his older brother Henry experimented with surplus transmitting equipment he bought from the US Armed Forces. In 1950, the brothers applied for a congressional franchise in Manila. On 23 Jun 1952, they were granted a permit to maintain and operate the radio broadcasting station. With a modest investment, the Canoy brothers used their resources and talents to build what is now the Radio Mindanao Network (RMN).

Canoy went into marketing and advertising, serving as media director of the Philippine Advertising Counsellors, and learned about the different facets of media, which he used to help his brother expand RMN. They first concentrated their radio stations in Mindanao. In Manila, they established DZHP in partnership with Andres Soriano of the giant San Miguel Corporation. With varied interests, he also dabbled in writing for Hollywood productions, working with several actors including Jack Nicholson. While filming in the countryside, he was exposed to the deterioration of government services in many provincial municipalities, one of them his own hometown, Cagayan de Oro. He then ran for public office, was elected mayor of Cagayan de Oro City in 1971, and was subsequently appointed by Pres Ferdinand Marcos to three national positions in the martial law government in 1972 as undersecretary of public information, presidential action officer for Northern Mindanao, and chairman of the Southern Philippines Development Authority. He held all three positions while serving as city mayor until he resigned his positions in 1976 in protest against the Marcos dictatorship. In 1978, he won a seat in the Interim Batasang Pambansa (National Assembly) as the lone opposition member from Mindanao.

Aside from being a Fulbright-Smith-Mundt scholar, Canoy received several other grants in 1966 from the Federal Republic of Germany and the United States to observe public administration, with emphasis on urban planning and management, as well as mass communication in these two countries. In the same year, he was also invited to observe radio and television operations and programming at the British Broadcasting Corporation in England and Radio-Television Francaise in France. Written by Yna Marei Aguilar

Sources:

Aniceto 2007; ASEAN Who’s Who 1992; Canoy 1980, 2001; Philippine Poetry Annual n.d.; Radio Mindanao Network 2015; Valeros and Valeros-Gruenberg 1987.

CANTADA, JOE (Jose Maria Javier Cantada) aka Smokin’ Joe Cantada. b. Manila 15 Mar 1942. d. 22 Mar 1992. Sportscaster, TV host, singer. He was the son of Ambrosio Cantada and Angelina Javier. He was married to Ma. Bella Macam, with whom he had a son. He earned a bachelor of arts degree from Ateneo de Manila University in 1962.

 

Cantada began his broadcasting career in 1962 on DZHP (now DZXL) where he hosted the musical program The Joe Cantada Show. In the 30 years he was in broadcasting, he hosted other programs both on radio and television, including news programs, the evening entertainment talk show Late Late Show on IBC Channel 13 in the late 1960s, and the public service talk show Damayan in the late 1970s, which he co-hosted with Rosa Rosal. He penned newspaper columns, including a weekly entertainment review column for the Graphic in the 1960s, and recorded a musical album. He is best remembered, however, as a sportscaster. As a former boxer and track-and-field athlete, Cantada found his transition from news to sports effortless, even as he continued to host other programs.

 

He first became famous for his action-packed and colorful radio accounts of the summer cycling Tour of Luzon beginning in the 1960s. Listeners followed the race closely, eager to find out the latest results and hear the struggles of cyclists to overcome the treacherous roads and distances. He gave audiences blow-by-blow accounts of the silver-medal finish of Filipino boxer Anthony Villanueva who lost to Russian Stanislav Stepahskin in the 1964 Tokyo Olympics, the Flash Elorde–Yoshiaki Numata boxing bout in Tokyo in 1966, and the Asian Games from the 1960s to the 1980s. In the 1970s, he anchored the TV boxing shows Fistorama and In This Corner.

 

Cantada’s career gained international stature when he was the ring announcer for the Muhammad Ali–Joe Frazier fight dubbed Thrilla in Manila at the Araneta Coliseum. His stirring and buoyant introductions of the legendary boxers set the stage appropriately for the final showdown of the two heavyweight champions.

 

In 1982, Cantada became senior anchorman of the Vintage Sports coverage of the Philippine Basketball Association (PBA) games. Along with fellow senior announcer Pinggoy Pengson, he worked with analysts Andy Jao, Joaqui Trillo, Quinito Henson, and others to put together a more incisive TV presentation of the popular basketball league. The emphasis was on game insights and analysis, and Cantada was perceived by budding sportscasters and sports analysts as a generous anchorman, allowing them to shine in the coverage.

 

For nine years, until he fell ill in 1991, the PBA’s opening and annual awards ceremonies were Cantada’s staple performances, marked by his baritone voice, witty remarks, lively interaction with players and league personalities, his command of language and colorful descriptions of the games while deftly weaving references to literature and popular culture into his sports accounts. Written by Severino R. Sarmenta Jr

The Catholic Mass Media Awards was established in 1978 under the auspices of the Archdiocese of Manila, through Archbishop Jaime Lachica Cardinal Sin. The awards are given in observance of International Social Communications Day to stress the importance of the mass media in the people’s lives and to instill in communicators a sense of responsibility.

Outstanding men and women and their works in mass media are chosen by a body of more than 50 jurors appointed by the archbishop of Manila. The jurors include academicians, civic and religious leaders, and the clergy. The awards are for 40 categories. The awards body stipulates that to be considered, works must be local productions produced and exhibited in the Archdiocese of Manila at any time during the year in consideration and must promote basic human values for total human development. These values include love for God, respect for the environment, positive Filipino values, and love for life. Over the years, CMMA has recognized works that reflect sensitivity to human rights and the integrity of creation; contribute to the country’s economic growth; promote equity and accountability in the use of public resources and performance of public duties; portray nationalism and values of pagkakaisa (unity), pagsasarili (independence), pakikipagkapwa-tao (human relations), pagkabayani (heroism), and pagiging makabuhay (pro-life); and provide access to and participation by people, especially the poor. Awardees need not be Christian or Catholic.

Winners are awarded a trophy called The Rock, a one-kilogram stone held on a wooden base with the staff of Saint Peter, a bronze banner, and an inscription: “A tribute to the men and women who are serving God through media – Cardinal Sin.” The trophy is composed of several symbolic figures: the rock, which underscores the role of the Catholic Church as the foundation of Filipino values in media; the mirror, which represents the Church’s desire to reflect Catholic standards that bring about transformative changes in society; the curved figure with an upward movement, which represents a transformed Philippine society through the responsible use of mass media; and the two figures, which symbolize the harmonious mother-and-child relationship. Cesario “Jhundy” P. de Lina Jr designed in 2000 the current CMMA trophy.

The CMMA has seven categories for media, one category for student works, and four special awards. Media categories include print, television, radio, film, advertising, music, and the Internet. Initially, the CMMA recognized communicators only in print, television, radio, and film in Manila. It added advertising in 1979 and music in 1980. In 1984, it began including entries from all over the country for assessment. In 2001, it added the category for the Internet, in response to the increased usage and distribution of content in new media platforms. On 7 Feb 2001, it instituted the Student CMMA, which recognizes the role of the youth in raising social consciousness through the media. In 2004, it began recognizing institutions and individuals with the Serviam Awards, primarily as a tribute to its founder, Cardinal Sin. The Pope John Paul Awards are given to a group or a person that creatively utilizes the mass media in evangelical service. The Hall of Fame Award is conferred on a mass media work that has won the CMMA for the same category for five times, though not necessarily in consecutive years.

A significant year in the history of the CMMA was 1981, when Pope John Paul II personally handed out the trophies at the Radio Veritas auditorium. In 1986, after the EDSA Revolt, communicators who served the resistance against the Marcos dictatorship, including foreign media persons, were all given recognition. The body of jurors also began to include members of the academe, civil society, and public service. CMMA took a hiatus from 1998 to 1999. Following its return in 2000, it expanded from being just an award-giving body and organized in 2001 the first CMMA Media Fair. In 2013, social networks were featured as “new spaces for evangelization.”

The first awardee for print in 1978 was Herky del Aguila’s “Service and Struggle in the Mountainsides,” which was awarded Best Feature Article. In 1979, new awards for print were conferred. Best Comic Story was “Santiago” by Jose Lad Santos, Silangan Komiks; Best Book in English was Myths and Symbols of the Philippines by Father Francisco Demetrio, SJ; best opinion piece in English was “Reflections” by Father Miguel Bernad, SJ, Philippine Daily Inquirer; best feature article in English was “Bicutan Behind Bars” by Chelo R. Banal, Panorama Magazine; and best feature article in Filipino was Noel Cabrera’s “MYRC Series,” Philippine Daily Express.

The first awardees for radio in 1978 were In Unum Deum (In One God), DZRH, best program; Err Ramos as best director for the drama program Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday); and Ric T. Santos, best writer for the drama episode “Buhay Pa si Plato” (Plato Lives On), DWRV.

The first awardees for television in 1978 were Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), BBC 2, best program in value formation; Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love my Fellowman), GMA 7, best public service program; and Concert at the Park, PTV 4, best program for cultural development. New categories were introduced in 1979. The award for best TV program for human development and value formation went to the drama anthologies Fort Santiago, RPN 9, Pananagutan (Responsibility), GMA 7, and Gulong ng Palad, and Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), both of BBC 2. Best children’s program went to Mario O’Hara’s Marcelino, Pan y Vino: Alamat o Milagro (Marcelino, Bread and Wine: Legend or Miracle?), BBC 2. In 1980, new categories were added. Outstanding instructional series program was Tele-Aralan ng Kakayahan (Knowledge Educational TV), PTV 4; outstanding documentary program was Bagong Sibol ang Gubat (The Forest is Budding), produced by the Bureau of Forest Development; outstanding TV magazine program was given to Metromagazine; and the award for Metro Manila Commission Outstanding TV Program was given to Uncle Bob & Friends, GMA 7. In 1981, new awards were given: the outstanding variety program award which went to Champoy, RPN 9, and the outstanding drama award which was given to Panagimpan (Dream) for its episode “The Neglected Mother,” PTV 4.

The first awardees for film in 1978 were in three categories: Hubad na Bayani (A Hero Stripped), best film; Robert Ylagan, best screenplay for the same movie; and Ishmael Bernal, best director for Dalawang Pugad, Isang Ibon (Two Nests, One Bird). In 1979, the awards were expanded to five categories, and the winners were: Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Mother, Sister, Daughter), best film; Lino Brocka, best director for the same movie; Mel Chionglo, best screenplay; Charito Solis, best lead performer, and Joonee Gamboa, best supporting performer.

The first awardees in advertising in 1979 were San Miguel Corporation and Magnolia Ice Cream’s Sundays with Lolo and Lola (Sundays with Grandfather and Grandmother), J. article.value: The Catholic Mass Media Awards was established in 1978 under the auspices of the Archdiocese of Manila, through Archbishop Jaime Lachica Cardinal Sin. The awards are given in observance of International Social Communications Day to stress the importance of the mass media in the people’s lives and to instill in communicators a sense of responsibility.

Outstanding men and women and their works in mass media are chosen by a body of more than 50 jurors appointed by the archbishop of Manila. The jurors include academicians, civic and religious leaders, and the clergy. The awards are for 40 categories. The awards body stipulates that to be considered, works must be local productions produced and exhibited in the Archdiocese of Manila at any time during the year in consideration and must promote basic human values for total human development. These values include love for God, respect for the environment, positive Filipino values, and love for life. Over the years, CMMA has recognized works that reflect sensitivity to human rights and the integrity of creation; contribute to the country’s economic growth; promote equity and accountability in the use of public resources and performance of public duties; portray nationalism and values of pagkakaisa (unity), pagsasarili (independence), pakikipagkapwa-tao (human relations), pagkabayani (heroism), and pagiging makabuhay (pro-life); and provide access to and participation by people, especially the poor. Awardees need not be Christian or Catholic.

Winners are awarded a trophy called The Rock, a one-kilogram stone held on a wooden base with the staff of Saint Peter, a bronze banner, and an inscription: “A tribute to the men and women who are serving God through media – Cardinal Sin.” The trophy is composed of several symbolic figures: the rock, which underscores the role of the Catholic Church as the foundation of Filipino values in media; the mirror, which represents the Church’s desire to reflect Catholic standards that bring about transformative changes in society; the curved figure with an upward movement, which represents a transformed Philippine society through the responsible use of mass media; and the two figures, which symbolize the harmonious mother-and-child relationship. Cesario “Jhundy” P. de Lina Jr designed in 2000 the current CMMA trophy.

The CMMA has seven categories for media, one category for student works, and four special awards. Media categories include print, television, radio, film, advertising, music, and the Internet. Initially, the CMMA recognized communicators only in print, television, radio, and film in Manila. It added advertising in 1979 and music in 1980. In 1984, it began including entries from all over the country for assessment. In 2001, it added the category for the Internet, in response to the increased usage and distribution of content in new media platforms. On 7 Feb 2001, it instituted the Student CMMA, which recognizes the role of the youth in raising social consciousness through the media. In 2004, it began recognizing institutions and individuals with the Serviam Awards, primarily as a tribute to its founder, Cardinal Sin. The Pope John Paul Awards are given to a group or a person that creatively utilizes the mass media in evangelical service. The Hall of Fame Award is conferred on a mass media work that has won the CMMA for the same category for five times, though not necessarily in consecutive years.

A significant year in the history of the CMMA was 1981, when Pope John Paul II personally handed out the trophies at the Radio Veritas auditorium. In 1986, after the EDSA Revolt, communicators who served the resistance against the Marcos dictatorship, including foreign media persons, were all given recognition. The body of jurors also began to include members of the academe, civil society, and public service. CMMA took a hiatus from 1998 to 1999. Following its return in 2000, it expanded from being just an award-giving body and organized in 2001 the first CMMA Media Fair. In 2013, social networks were featured as “new spaces for evangelization.”

The first awardee for print in 1978 was Herky del Aguila’s “Service and Struggle in the Mountainsides,” which was awarded Best Feature Article. In 1979, new awards for print were conferred. Best Comic Story was “Santiago” by Jose Lad Santos, Silangan Komiks; Best Book in English was Myths and Symbols of the Philippines by Father Francisco Demetrio, SJ; best opinion piece in English was “Reflections” by Father Miguel Bernad, SJ, Philippine Daily Inquirer; best feature article in English was “Bicutan Behind Bars” by Chelo R. Banal, Panorama Magazine; and best feature article in Filipino was Noel Cabrera’s “MYRC Series,” Philippine Daily Express.

The first awardees for radio in 1978 were In Unum Deum (In One God), DZRH, best program; Err Ramos as best director for the drama program Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday); and Ric T. Santos, best writer for the drama episode “Buhay Pa si Plato” (Plato Lives On), DWRV.

The first awardees for television in 1978 were Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), BBC 2, best program in value formation; Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love my Fellowman), GMA 7, best public service program; and Concert at the Park, PTV 4, best program for cultural development. CHAVEZ, ESTER (Ester Albeza Benjamin Chavez)b. Santa Cruz, Manila 1 May 1928. Radio, television, and film actor. She is the daughter of Teofilo Benjamin and Isabel Albeza. She is married to radio announcer William Nepomuceno Chavez, with whom she has three children. Her nephew Leonel Benjamin is a radio drama actor. She attended Francisco Balagtas Elementary School and Arellano High School, both in Santa Cruz, Manila.

Chavez began her career in 1949 in the first radio soap opera in the Philippines, Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), in the lead role of Aling Chayong. Written by Liwayway Arceo, the soap aired for 10 years on DZRH, DZPI, and DZMB. Chavez then was cast as Reyna Regina in another soap, Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), written by Clodualdo del Mundo, which aired on DZRH in 1949-53. The two soaps were the first of her long string of acting assignments in radio, television, and film over a period of 55 years. She performed various roles in the longest-running radio drama in the country, Ang Kasaysayan sa mga Liham kay Tiya Dely (The Stories behind the Letters to Aunt Dely), which aired from 1953 until 2009 with brief interruptions.

On television, Chavez appeared in the dramas My Son, My Son, 1977, on RPN 9; Anna Liza, 1980, on GMA 7; Coney Reyes on Camera, 1984, on RPN 9; and Marinela, 1999, on ABS-CBN 2. Her film credits include Mother Dear, 1982; Palipat-lipat, Papalit-palit (Changing Partners), 1982; Strangers in Paradise, 1983; Lovingly Yours, Helen, 1984; Kung Mahawi Man ang Ulap (Should the Skies Clear), 1984; Bakit Manipis ang Ulap (Why Are the Clouds Thin), 1986; Boy Negro (Negro Boy), 1988; Paano Kung Wala Ka Na (What If You Are Gone), 1987; Savage Justice (1988); Orapronobis (Pray for Us), 1989; Bala at Rosaryo (Bullet and Rosary), 1990; Nagsimula sa Puso (It Began from the Heart), 1990; Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), 1991; Kadenang Bulaklak (Chain of Flowers), 1994; Senswal (Sensual), 2000; and Ebolusyon ng Isang Pamilyang Pilipino (Evolution of a Filipino Family), 2004. Written by Lindo Lindo

text:
Chichay (Amparo Robles Custodio-Moya) was a stage, radio, film, and television actor, singer, and dancer. She was born in Tondo, Manila on 21 Jan 1918. She died in Manila on 31 May 1993. The 10th of 13 children born to Maria Robles and Jose Pacifico Custodio, a ship steward, she was educated at Tondo Elementary School and Torres High School. Orphaned early, she appeared in school stage shows and became a member of the Samahang Antonieta as a singer and tap dancer. She and sister Iluminada came to be known as the Custodio Singers. She married Hercules Saenz Moya of Iloilo, with whom she had six children.

Fellow vaudeville actor Atang de la Rama gave her the moniker “Chichay,” from the Japanese word “chiisai,” meaning “tiny.” Along with her short but stocky built, she was later known for her toothless appearance, whiny voice, and aged look, which gave her the chance to portray the role of a feisty but laughable grandmother in many broadcast sitcoms and films, becoming famous with the hoarsely delivered line “O, weno?” (So what?).

Chichay appeared in her first film, Premiere Productions’s Itanong mo sa Bulaklak (Ask the Flower), 1948, directed by Paquito Bolero and which starred Dely Atay-Atayan. She became famous through her comedic tandem with Tolindoy, beginning in Sampaguita Pictures’s Buhay Pilipino (Filipino Life), 1952, and Gorio at Tekla (Gorio and Tekla), 1953. The latter was directed by Olive La Torre, the father of actor-singer Sylvia La Torre, written by Mars Ravelo for the comics Tagalog Klasiks, and starred Fred Montilla, Norma Vales, and Ramon Revilla Sr, who would become a senator.

Chichay was one of the first talents of Manila Broadcasting Company’s DZRH beginning in 1949; one of ABS-CBN’s legion of radio and TV personalities on DZAQ and Channel 3 in the 1960s until the declaration of martial law in 1972; a mainstay of the TV variety program The Main Show, later retitled Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour), 1964, with Oscar Obligacion, Sylvia La Torre, and Ading Fernando; the main character in the radio show Miss Loudspeaker, 1965, with Al Mendez, Sylvia La Torre, Apeng Daldal, and Ike Lozada; part of the TV musical The Nida-Nestor Show, 1965, directed by Mitos Villareal, choreographed by Julie Borromeo, and written by Ading Fernando; anchor of the daily news program Radyo Patrol (Patrol Radio) in the late 1960s, with Rod Navarro and reporters Cris Daluz, Hector Villanueva, Edgar Malay, Jun Eusebio, and Orly Mercado; and a philanthropist in the pre-martial law sitcom Ginang Milyonarya (Madam Millionaire), 1972, with Rudy Manlapaz, later retitled Mrs. Milyonarya (Mrs Millionaire) when it went on air again in late 1973 on IBC 13, then on RPN 9. She was the first choice for the role of Doña Delilah for what would become RPN 9’s top-rating sitcom John en Marsha, starring Dolphy and Nida Blanca, but she opted to stay in Mrs. Milyonarya, with the role of Doña Delilah going to Dely Atay-Atayan.

During the martial law period, she appeared in the comedy programs of RPN 9: My Son, My Son with Jay Ilagan and Tange; Ang Biyenan Kong Mangkukulam (My Witch Mother-In-law), a local version of the US television program Bewitched and which featured Pancho Magalona; Ang Lola Kong Baduy (My Out-of-Style Grandmother), 1976, with Charo Santos; and Kaluskos Musmos (Kiddie Noise), 1979-89, RPN 9, a children’s program produced by Imee Marcos, directed by Johnny Manahan, with a cast of children headed by Maricel Soriano and Herbert Bautista, and adult mainstays Bert Marcelo, Gary Lising, and Estrella Kuenzler. She also appeared in the family comedy programs Two Plus Two, 1982, BBC 2, about the daily concerns of a young middle-class couple, with Vic Sotto, Dina Bonnevie, their daughter Danica who was then a toddler, Maricel Soriano, William Martinez, Gary Lising, and Herbert Bautista; and Bistek, 1990, Islands TV 13, with Bautista.

She appeared in 149 films. She played doting grandmother to an overgrown man-child portrayed by Fred Montilla in Sampaguita Pictures’s comedy films Bondying, 1954, and Tatay Na si Bondying (Bondying Is Now a Father), 1955, both directed by Armando Garces and story by Ravelo, and by Jimmy Santos in Viva Films’s Bondying: The Little Big Boy, 1989, directed by Mike Relon Makiling and written by Jose Javier Reyes. Her other movies include Sampaguita Pictures’s Barbaro (Barbarian), 1952, written by Francisco V. Coching and starring Pancho Magalona, and Madame X, 1952, written by Fausto J. Galauran; Dalisay Films’ comedy Pitong Atsay (Seven Housemaids), directed by Tony Santos Sr, and starring Patsy, Aruray, Menggay, Elizabeth Ramsey, Dely Atay-Atayan, and Metring David, and its sequel Ang Pinakamalaking Takas ng Pitong Atsay (The Great Escape of the Seven Housemaids), 1962; RVQ Productions’s comedy-musical Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life), 1967, directed by Luciano Carlos, written by Ading Fernando, and starring Dolphy and Susan Roces; NV Productions’s musical Annie Batungbakal, 1979, directed by Maryo J. de los Reyes, written by Jake Tordesillas, and starring Nora Aunor, and its sequel Associated Entertainment Corporation’s Bongga Ka 'Day! (You're Fabulous, Pal!), 1980; Viva Films’s love story Forgive and Forget, 1982, directed by Eddie Garcia, written by Orlando Nadres, and starring Sharon Cuneta and William Martinez; and Regal Films’s fantasy movie Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), 1985, in which she portrayed the folk storyteller Lola Basyang. Her last movie was Regal Films’s Cheeta-eh: Ganda Lalake? (Cheeta-eh: Handsome Guy?), 1991, which starred the comedian Rene Requiestas.

She was nominated Best Supporting Actress by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Bilangguang Puso (The Heart Is a Prison), 1972. She was the Citizen’s Awards for Television Best Female Supporting Performer for her performance in The Nida-Nestor Show from 1966 to 1969; Manila Film Festival Outstanding Actress, 1967 and 1968; one of the Top Ten TV-Radio Personalities, 1969; Tandang Sora Awardee, 1980; one of the Walang Kupas Awardees chosen by the Doña Josefa Edralin-Marcos Foundation, early 1980s; Gintong Ina Awardee for Arts and Culture, 1989; Philippine Movie Press Club (PMPC) Star Lifetime Achievement Awardee, 1989; Film Academy of the Philippines Lifetime Achievement Awardee, 1989; and PMPC Ulirang Artista Awardee, 1993. She received the Gawad Natatanging Kontribusyon sa Telebisyon Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines at the 7th Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon in 1994.  Written by Glecy Atienza, Malu Maniquis, and Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Eulalio R. Guieb III and Rolando R. Santos

CITY LITE 88.3 FM A radio station owned and operated by Raven Broadcasting Company, City Lite 88.3 FM was on the air from 1987 to 1997. Its management was composed of former marketing executive Francis Lumen, businessman Alexander Limjuco, Guam-based real estate developer Gerry Geronimo, lawyer Steve Salonga, engineer Francisco “Kit” Ravina, and broadcast programming expert Joselito “Mike” Pedero. The station carried the tag line “Manila’s intelligent alternative.”

The station gained a cult following, as it came at a time when radio listeners were craving for a sound which was different from those of pop and mellow format stations that dominated the FM airwaves of the period. Although adult contemporary in format, it was unlike the rest of its easy listening format counterparts, as it featured a playlist that consisted primarily of vocal and instrumental jazz, combined with rhythm and blues, which appealed to a more high-end market. It was more music-oriented and had disc jockeys whose ad-libs were quite minimal but highly informative and whose delivery style was laid-back.

City Lite 88.3 FM had its fair share of innovations, having introduced to its listeners New Age music, which is a hybrid music genre combining jazz with classical undertones, as well as genre-specific musical programs. It was also known for its “stress-free” programming, transcending boundaries in terms of musical genre featured in its general playlist. Its musical mix was described as eclectic and had, for years, enjoyed a huge following among the A, B, and upper C economic class markets, with ages ranging from 18 to 45 years. Its classy sound also managed to attract and eventually capture a portion of the expatriate community as part of its target audience. It was also considered one of FM’s more successful radio stations in terms of breakthroughs in marketing, such as organizing music events as a strategy to reach wider audiences. It was also known for its innovative and “out-of-the-box” music, news and information segments, which constantly enjoyed the support of advertisers. These included the “San Miguel Super Dry Beer Dry Fusion,” a three-song sweep of tunes lifted from the station’s playlist; “Double Play,” which featured two songs in a row by the same artist played back-to-back; “The International Time Check,” sponsored by Sharp Philippines Corporation; and the “Expat Bulletin,” which catered to expatriates staying or working in the Philippines. It also aired syndicated jazz programs imported from the United States, like the Dave Koz Radio Show.

Its original stable of on-air personalities included Pinky M. Aseron, who eventually became the station manager, Mike Taylor aka Adam Kite, Ramon Cruz aka Joey Pizza, Alfonso Alvarez aka Pancho, Jay Zorilla aka J Latin, and newscasters Rosella Perdigon-Shishido and Celine Ulgado aka Wicket. Other personalities who joined later on were Reuben Chua aka Benjamin, Mary Ann Tupas aka Bi-Anne, who eventually became its program director, Paul Ratulin aka Paul Riser, Raymund Trinidad aka Mike Grain, Paul Espiritu aka Paolo, and newscasters Karen Wu, Carissa Tiongson-Palanca, Marie Anjanette Fernandez, and Armie Jarin-Bennett, who eventually became the station’s news director and the president of CNN Philippines.

In 1997, a new management took over ownership and operations of the station in 1997. City Lite 88.3 changed format in 2003 and had since become Jam 88.3, targeting a much younger audience. Written by Marinela M. Aseron

CLTV-36 (Central Luzon Television–36) 6:30 am to 10:30 pm, Mondays to Sundays. A terrestrial regional television station established in 2007 by Levi P. Laus, CLTV-36 holds the call sign DWRW-TV. Owned and operated by the Laus Group of Companies, its transmitter, offices, and studios are located in the city of San Fernando, Pampanga. The Philippine Congress granted its franchise through Republic Act 8219 on 12 Sep 1997. The National Telecommunications Company approved its license to operate on 10 Jan 2007. Launched on 19 Mar 2007, it first aired on 10 May 2007. Operating on a power of 10,000 watts, the station reaches the provinces of Pampanga, Bulacan, Nueva Ecija, Tarlac, Bataan, Zambales, and Aurora, and portions of Metro Manila, Rizal, Cavite, and Laguna.

The station’s programs are mainly news and public affairs. Its flagship program, CLTV-36 Balitaan (CLTV-36 News), is considered one of the region’s main sources of news and information. Other programs include the daily magazine Aldong Maningning (Beautiful Morning); the women’s program WAGI (Winner, aka Women Are Great Inspirations); the public affairs programs Hamon: Central Luzon (Challenge: Central Luzon), So to Speak, Opinyong Legal (Legal Opinion), Dayalogo (Dialogue), and Spot Report; the business show Negotalk (Business Talk); the on-air clinic program OK si Dok (The Doctor Is OK); and the lifestyle, travel and culture programs Travel Blog, Queng Cucina (In the Kitchen), Trip Treat Gimik (Trip Treat Gimmicks), and Spotlight. The station is the official broadcaster of the annual Giant Lantern Festival held every December in San Fernando, Pampanga. On 10 May 2009, the station spearheaded the project Takbo para kay Lola (Run for Grandma), a charity run to raise funds for comfort women or victims of Japanese military sexual abuses during World War II.

The station’s tag line is “Tapat na naglilingkod sa Central Luzon” (Sincerely serving Central Luzon). Its slogans are “Karehiyon: atin ’to!” (People of our region: this is ours!) and “Mas masaya, mas makulay” (Happier, more colorful).

CLTV-36 won the KBP Golden Dove Awards for Best Provincial Television Station in 2001 and 2014, and Best Provincial Public Affairs Program for So to Speak and Best Provincial Public Affairs Show Host for its anchor Sonia Soto in 2001. Written by Jason Paolo R. Telles

article_title: College of Mass Communication, University of the Philippines Diliman
text:
COLLEGE OF MASS COMMUNICATION,UNIVERSITY OF THE PHILIPPINESDILIMAN The University of the Philippines College of Mass Communication (UP CMC) is the first and largest institution in media and communication education in the Philippines. Created by Republic Act 4379 in 1965 as the Institute of Mass Communication, it was elevated into a college in 1988 given its growth in academic offerings, faculty expertise, and student population. It is situated at several buildings in the UP Diliman campus, with Plaridel Hall as the main building. Plaridel Hall is named in honor of Filipino journalist and reformist Marcelo H. del Pilar, who edited the newspaper La Solidaridad in 1889-95.

 

UP CMC has produced a significant number of media practitioners and media and communication educators in the country through its degree programs. It offers four major areas in the bachelor of arts programs: journalism, broadcast communication, film, and communication research. Its graduate programs include master of arts in media studies, with two majors, broadcast and film; a master of arts in journalism; and a master of arts in communication. At the doctoral level are the doctor of philosophy in media studies and doctor of philosophy in communication, the only doctoral programs in the Philippines in the field of media and communication. The Commission on Higher Education declared its Departments of Broadcast Communication, Communication Research, and Journalism as Centers of Excellence (COE), a recognition of the quality of their instruction, research and publication, and extension and linkages.

 

Department of Broadcast Communication. The undergraduate program leading to a bachelor of arts in broadcast communication provides students with the requisite training to become critical, creative, and competent broadcast practitioners, who are able to adapt to the fast-changing broadcast landscape in terms of new technologies, new modes of production, distribution, and exhibition of broadcast products. The department also offers the program leading to a master of arts in media studies in broadcast communication, which focuses on how the media affect the socioeconomic, cultural, or political life of the people and how these forces in turn shape the media. It is also in the forefront of the program leading to a doctorate in media studies, the only doctoral program in media studies in the country, which aims to produce knowledge about the vast array of evolving global and local technologies, economies, and powers that affect the way people communicate.

 

The department operates radio station DZUP, the official radio station of the University. It airs on 1602 kHz on the AM band, with live webstreaming on www.dzup.org and its web counterpart, DZUP Online. These platforms serve not only as laboratories of broadcast majors but also as alternatives to commercial radio.

 

Among its regular activities is the annual Sining del Pilar (SdP). Named after Marcelo H. del Pilar, it is a weeklong series of lectures, paper presentations, production screenings, and forums where students showcase their works and engage in critical discussions of their future as broadcasters. Launched in 2011, SdP has two sections: the Cecilia Lazaro Kritika Series (Cecilia Lazaro Criticism Series) and Sineng Lito Tiongson (Lito Tiongson Videos). Named after broadcast journalist, Gawad Plaridel awardee, and former member of the faculty of the Department of Broadcast Communication Cheche Lazaro, the Kritika Series is a dialogue of a community of scholars rigorously engaged in the examination of broadcast and related media in various contexts. Broadcast students present their critical papers and noted scholars react to the presentations. Scholars who have served as critics in the SdP are Aristotle Atienza, Fernando Austria Jr, Aleli Bawagan, Reuben Cañete, Patrick Campos, Flaudette May Datuin, Elizabeth Enriquez, Patrick Flores, Edel Garcellano, Tessa Maria Guazon, Ramon Guillermo, Jason Jacobo, Skilty Labastilla, Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez, Rolando Tolentino, JPaul Manzanilla, Teilhard Paradela, Sarah Raymundo, Jaime Oscar Salazar, and Joseph Salazar.

 

On the other hand, Sineng Lito Tiongson, named in honor of the late filmmaker, video documentarian, and activist Lito Tiongson, is a festival of student productions that include sound design experiments, music videos, animation, video poetry, short narratives, experimental videos, documentaries, dramas, video rants, online talk programs, reality TV productions, broadcast journalism productions, ethnographic videos, and similar explorations on audio and video concepts that critique as well as entertain. Tiongson was also a former member of the faculty of the department.

 

Department of Communication Research. The undergraduate program leading to a bachelor of arts in communication research offers courses designed to develop scholarship and skills in conducting communication research within the context of processes and effects. The department grounds its courses with practical experience through fieldwork and internships to ensure that its graduates are equipped to contribute to the practice of social research in the academe, in the communication and media industries, and in governmental and nongovernmental sectors. The department offers the master of arts in communication and the doctor of philosophy in communication programs, which are founded on the principle of communication as an applied science that combines theory and practice. The doctorate in communication program is the only doctoral program in communication in the country. Among the department’s regular programs is the National Communication Research Conference for Communication Research majors.

 

UP Film Institute (UPFI). The UPFI is the only internationally accredited academic institution in the country offering film courses for both undergraduate and master’s degrees. The undergraduate program leading to a bachelor of arts in film aims to contribute to the development of a genuinely Filipino national cinema by producing graduates with a well-rounded liberal arts education as well as creative and technical skills. Its masters program leading to a master of arts in media studies in film focuses on the study of film in the context of globalization and new media technologies, and as a complex social, cultural, and economic phenomenon. The UPFI conducts regular workshops, seminars, exhibits, and other film-related events and activities under the university’s mandate to promote film literacy and appreciation in the country and as a supplement to the institute’s academic and research thrusts. It also holds the annual Likha Adarna (Adarna Creations) festival of films created by its students.

 

The UPFI operates the Cine Adarna, an 800-seat university cinema that screens films free from censorship and programmed for purposes of varied studies and broadened appreciation of cinematic arts. Among its programs are festivals of full-feature films, shorts, documentaries, and indie films celebrating various causes and movements such as the annual women’s film festival in March, films about indigenous peoples, human rights, and the LGBTQ. The theater is also a regular venue for various international film programs designed by different embassies and other cultural institutions.

 

Department of Journalism. The undergraduate program leading to a bachelor of arts in journalism, the oldest in the college, gives students a strong grounding in the arts and sciences and equips them with the skills currently required by the profession.Students are trained to be socially responsible and critical professionals who are aware of the power and responsibilities of the press, committed to defend press freedom, and living up to the highest professional and ethical standards. The department also offers the program leading to a master of arts in journalism. It organizes the annual Philippine Journalism Research Conference, participated in by journalism students from all over the country. It serves as adviser to the UP CMC student newsletter Tinig ng Plaridel, which first came out in 1978. The department leads the college in holding the annual Graciano Lopez Jaena Community Journalism Workshop, which provides continuing education courses for community journalists.

 

Office of Research and Publication (ORP). Apart from its degree programs, CMC has regular research and publication programs. Through the ORP, the college helps fund faculty and student researches, conducts colloquiums and brownbag meetings to present research output, and co-publishes reference books and textbooks. Since 2004, it has been publishing biannually the Plaridel: A Journal of Communication, Media and Society, which contains scholarly research on media and communication as well as reviews of books, films, websites, and television and radio programs. It publishes the lectures of the recipients of the annual Gawad Plaridel, filmographies, and relevant and timely documents. The Plaridel journal is an international publication whose articles pass a referee process. At first focused on media and communication in the Philippines, it now publishes articles on different areas of media and communication studies in Asia. There is a strong emphasis on original research on media effects, industry, political economy, subcultural practices, and journalism studies using interdisciplinary perspectives.

 

Office of Extension and External Relations (OEER). The OEER sponsors activities that link the college with institutions that support its mission to empower the people through information and media literacy. It conducts seminars, workshops, and short training courses for adults as well as children. One of its annual events leads to a coveted recognition bestowed by the CMC on media practitioners for their outstanding contribution to print, film, radio, television, or new media, the UP Gawad Plaridel. Founded in 2004, it is the only award given by UP to media practitioners. The award, named after the propagandist and reformist Marcelo H. del Pilar, selects awardees who have produced a body of work marked by excellence and social relevance and recognized nationally or internationally. Each awardee delivers a lecture on a media issue, subsequently published in the Plaridel journal, and receives a trophy sculpted by National Artist Napoleon V. Abueva.

 

Among the recipients of the Gawad Plaridel are journalist-publisher Eugenia Duran-Apostol, 2004; film actor Rosa Vilma Santos, 2005; radio broadcaster Fidela “Tiya Dely” Magpayo, 2006; broadcast journalist Cecilia “Cheche” L. Lazaro, 2007; community journalist Pachico A. Seares, 2008; independent filmmaker Kidlat Tahimik, 2009; radio dramatist Eloisa “Lola Sela” Cruz Canlas, 2011; Florence “Rosa Rosal” Danon-Gayda for public service in television, 2012; journalist and fictionist Jose Maria “Pete” Lacaba, 2013; multimedia artist Nora C. Villamayor aka Nora Aunor, 2014; and scriptwriter and novelist Ricardo “Ricky” Lee, 2015. Written by Gian Carlo C. Librojo, Jonalou S. J. Labor, Yna Marei Aguilar, and Elizabeth L. Enriquez

 

Sources: Department of Broadcast Communication, UP CMC, 2014; Lee 2015; UP CMC 2011; UP CMC 2014a, 2014b, 2014c, 2014d, 2014e, 2014f.

COMMUNICATION FOUNDATION FOR ASIA (CFA) Established in 1975 as a nonstock, nonprofit organization, the Communication Foundation for Asia seeks the integral development of people through innovative learning processes using media technology and other forms of communication. The vision of the organization began in 1960 when its founder, Dutch missionary Fr Cornelio Lagerwey, MSC, and his mission partner and journalist Genaro Ong, published the Philippine Catholic Digest. They pursued a dream of building a center for social communications which was best realized through the incorporation of its mother institution, the Ang Tao Foundation, later known as the Social Communications Center–Development and Research Foundation, in 1965. CFA played a big role in Philippine society as it became a major multimedia production and training center in Asia and one of the first institutions that provided socially relevant radio and television programs, films, and publications at a time when the Marcos dictatorship controlled the content of media.

It first radio drama, Silahis (Ray of Light), 1973-74, is a weekly series of 30-minute dramas on land reform, civic education, social services, economic reform, and moral values. Among its notable radio dramas are the top-rating Panginorin (Horizon), 1974-75, based on real-life stories aired on DZRH; Isang Dipa … Langit (Heaven within Reach), 1979-94, directed by Rosanna Villegas and written by Julie Fe Navarro, about true-to-life stories showing the power of ordinary people to craft their destinies and aired for 15 years on DZRH; Buhay Lansangan (Street Life), a docudrama on the experiences of people on the streets trying to earn a decent living; Pasya ng Bayan (Public Judgment), 1986, a 48-part series that draws its stories on the principles of the preamble of the draft Constitution; Pananagutan sa Bayan (Public Responsibility), 1987, a daily-ending series of 54 episodes on the accountability of public officials and aired over 50 AM radio stations all over the country; Kapirasong Langit sa Lupa (A Slice of Heaven on Earth), 1979, a drama in 72 parts about the comprehensive agrarian reform program, aired on 50 radio stations; Bata, Karapatan Mo … (Child, Your Rights … Fight for Them), 1994, about the rights of the Filipino child; and Unos sa Paraiso (Tempest in Paradise), 2001, a weekly 30-minute series in 67 episodes about real-life stories sent in by listeners. CFA produced cassette magazine programs, such as Ugnayang Pilipino (Filipino Connections), 1983, a series sent to overseas Filipinos to keep them connected to the Philippines, and Landas ng Buhay (Path of Life), 1985, a series containing a half-hour drama on a Bible story.

Its first television production is Batang Pinoy (Filipino Child), 1980-81, an educational children’s show aired on MBS-4 that employed puppets in presenting stories with social and cultural values.Its other video productions include Bata, Saan Ka Patungo? (Child, Where Are You Going?), 1981, a documentary on underprivileged children; Lorenzo Ruiz, 1981, about the life of later-to-be-canonized Lorenzo aired nationwide via satellite on RPN 9; Kutitap (Sparkle), 1981-82, a children’s catechetical show focusing on Bible parables aired on RPN 9; Pambata at Iba Pa (For Kids and Others), 1983, a children’s program aired on IBC 13; Balikbayan (Homecoming), 1983, a six-hour miniseries aired on ABS-CBN about the dilemma of a returning US-based Filipino doctor who sees the need of rural folks for medical care; 11 Days in August, 1983, the only documentary made at that time that chronicles the 11 days of Ninoy Aquino from his assassination to his funeral; People Power: The Philippine Experience, 1986, a documentary that recorded the tumultuous events in the history of the country from the 1983 Aquino assassination to the aftermath of the 1986 EDSA Revolt; Beyond EDSA, 1987, an eight-episode television series commemorating the first anniversary of the EDSA Revolt and aired over Channels 4 and 13; TV Gospel Komiks, 1989, a one-hour weekly semi-animated series about real-life stories that carried messages from the Gospel; The Phenomenon, 1995, a video documentary about the visit of Pope John Paul II to the Philippines and aired on ABC 5; and Vote 4 U, 2007, a three-part reality TV game show for young audiences about their rights as responsible voters.

CFA’s first film, Batingaw (The Bells of San Jose), 1974, directed by Pablo Santiago, written by Ding M. de Jesus and Tommy C. David, and funded by Ford Foundation, centered on the dilemma of large rural families suffering from economic insecurity and uncontrolled population. Among the films it produced are People Media, 1982, a 15-minute critical examination of media, written and directed by Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, and Sugat sa Ugat (The Wounded Root), 1984, a feature film directed and co-written with Jorge Arago by Ishmael Bernal, about the issues that tear apart a traditional agricultural town threatened by the various forces of modernization, such as mining.

Among its print publications are Gospel Komiks, Jesus, KidSmarts, Pambata (For Kids), and Barkada (Group of Friends), which have become supplementary educational materials for elementary and high school students. In the 1960s, it produced the hard-hitting magazines Action Now and Ang Tao (The Man), but it lost its publishing license during the imposition of martial law in 1972. Books it produced include Komiks Magazine Scriptwriting, 1980, by Ramon Marcelino; Writing for Film, 1981, and Philippine Mass Media, 1986, by Clodualdo del Mundo Jr; Radio Drama Scriptwriting, 1983, by Noel T. de Leon; and Short Film, 1985, by Nick Deocampo. CFA also published From the Village to the Medium, 1976, edited by Demetrio Magalang; Communication Challenges of Our Time: An Asian Perspective, 1985, edited by Teresita Z. Hermano; Monograph on Development Communication, 1990, edited by Fely Soledad; and Film and Faith, 2008, and Film, Faith and the Church, 2009, by Peter Malone, MSC.

CFA produced music albums containing original compositions, which include Sigaw ng Kalayaan (Shout of Freedom), about fighting for justice, freedom, and peace during the 1986 EDSA Revolt, and Habang Buhay (As Long as There Is Life), about love and marriage.

CFA won awards from the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA), the highest of which was the Serviam Award conferred on the institution in 2012. The Serviam Award, launched in 2004, is a recognition of institutions and individuals who serve God through the media. It received two Hall of Fame Awards in 2010, for Gospel Komiks as Best Children’s Magazine, which it earlier won in 2003, 2007, and 2009, and the institution’s website, www.cfamedia.org, as Best Website for having won the award in 2007, 2008, and 2009. Best Radio Dramas were Pananagutan sa Bayan in 1988, Kapirasong Langit sa Lupa in 1990, Unos sa Paraiso in 2002, and Isang Dipa … Langit, several times from 1979 to 1994. Special awards were given to the cassette magazine series Ugnayang Pilipino in 1983 and Landas ng Buhay in 1986. For television, Kutitap won Outstanding Children’s Show in 1981, and Bata, Saan Ka Patungo? won a special award as part of CMMA’s celebration of the International Year of the Child.

In film, Batingaw won a Best Supporting Actor award for its actor Van de Leon at the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards in 1975, and Best Art Direction and an award for an outstanding expression of a theme of social significance at the 20th Asian Film Festival in Taipei in 1974. It was selected for screening in the Third Tehran International Film Festival in 1974. Sugat sa Ugat was chosen as an entry in the 1984 Berlin Film Festival and distributed internationally by a German film company. People Media won third place in the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines Short Film Festival in 1982. People Power: The Philippine Experience were shown also in Australia, Bangkok, Beijing, and in several countries in Europe. Written by Judy Rosario A. Diño and Eulalio R. Guieb III

CRUZ, NATHANIEL (Nathaniel Agustin Cruz) aka Mang Tani. b. Manila 22 Feb 1960. Meteorologist, weather broadcaster.He is the second among five children of Ernesto de la Merced Cruz and Cecilia Sanchez Agustin of Baliuag, Bulacan. He is married to Gloria Concejo with whom he has three children. He finished his elementary education at Sabang Elementary School, 1972, and his secondary education at Mariano Ponce High School, 1976, both in Baliuag. He graduated with a bachelor of science degree in agricultural engineering from La Salle–Araneta University, 1981. He enrolled in a meteorologist training course at the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical, and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA), 1981-82 and earned a master of science degree in meteorology from the University of the Philippines (UP), 1999, under a scholarship from PAGASA. He is pursuing a doctorate in meteorology, also at UP. He is a member of the Philippine Weathermen Employees Association, the Philippine Society of Agricultural Engineers, the Delta Phi Omicron Fraternity, the National Research Council of the Philippines, and the Philippine Meteorological Society.

He worked at PAGASA from 1982 to 2010, serving as the agency’s official spokesperson responsible for bringing weather updates to the public. In 1989, while on leave from PAGASA, he was employed as a forecaster for the Arab-American Oil Company in Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia. Beginning in 2006, while with PAGASA, he provided occasional on-cam weather live feeds to GMA’s news programs. In 2008, while again on leave from PAGASA, he was a climatologist for the Bangkok-based Asian Disaster Preparedness Center. In 2010, he left PAGASA and moved to Darwin, Australia, to become an aviation forecaster for the Bureau of Meteorology. After his wife recovered from a stroke in Australia, he returned to the Philippines in 2012 and accepted the invitation of GMA Network to become its resident meteorologist for its weather arm, GMA Weather. He provides the weather news for “I M Ready,” the news segment for the programs 24 Oras (24 Hours), Saksi (Witness), Unang Hirit (First Blow), GMA Weekend Report, State of the Nation with Jessica Soho, News to Go, Balitanghali (Afternoon News), and GMA’s and GMA News TV’s regular weather updates. On television, Mang Tani interprets complex weather data and simplifies technical terms, climate change issues, and disaster advocacy concerns in Filipino without the gimmickry that characterizes most broadcasters who only read scripts about the weather. He hosted Hamon ng Kalikasan (Challenge of Nature), 2012, the first broadcast meteorology program in the Philippines, with science and weather consultant Karen Cardenas.

At PAGASA, Mang Tani was awarded four times as the agency’s model employee. The Baliuag municipal government awarded him the Dangal ng Lahi Award in 2006 and the Bulacan provincial government awarded him the Dangal ng Lipi Award in 2009. He received the Most Reliable Weatherperson Award from Media Newser Philippines in 2013 and was tagged the Most Understood and Appreciated TV Weather Presenter/Forecaster in the Philippines by the Philippine Public Safety and Order Support Group in 2014. Written byJonalou S. J. Labor, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

Sources: Glorioso 2012; Mang Tani 2014; Panela 2012; Raquel 2013.

CRUZ, RODELL b. San Fernando, Pampanga 18 Apr 1959. d. Quezon City 19 May 2018. Production designer and art director. He finished his studies at the University of Santo Tomas Faculty of Engineering. He was married to Catalina Villaluna with whom he had a son, Miguel. His earliest work as production designer for film was for Peque Gallaga’s Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982; followed by Misteryo sa Tuwa (Joyful Mystery), 1983; the TV movie Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1992; Magic Temple, 1996; Sa Huling Paghihintay (The Final Wait), 2001; Dos Ekis (Two X’s), 2001; Ang Agimat: Anting-Anting ni Lolo (The Talisman: Grandfather’s Amulet), 2002; Mano Po 2: My Home (I Kiss Your Hand 2: My Home), 2002; Mano Po III: My Love (I Kiss Your Hand 3: My Love), 2004; Resiklo (Recycle), 2007; and Mana (Inheritance), 2014.

Cruz has also worked for American films shot in multiple locations like the United States, Hong Kong, and the Philippines. He worked on the production design of films such as Hong Kong 97, 1994; Spitfire, 1995; Heatseeker, 1995; Soldier Boyz, 1995; and the Philippine-American war film Amigo, 2011, directed by Academy-Award nominee John Sayles. He was also the art director for Behind Enemy Lines, 1985; Platoon, 1987; Braddock: Missing in Action III, 1988; Born on the Fourth of July, 1989; A Dangerous Life, 1989; and Delta Force 2: The Colombian Connection, 1989.

As production designer for TV, he is known for his work on several TV series on GMA Network such as Encantadia, 2005; Etheria, 2006; Atlantika, 2006; Captain Barbell, 2007; Lupin, 2007; Marimar, 2008; Kamandag (Venom), 2008; Zaido, 2008; Dyesebel, 2008; Survivor Philippines, 2008-10; Zorro, 2009; Amaya, 2011; and Indio, 2013. He has also worked on the production design of TV commercials for corporate institutions such as Cosmos Bottling Philippines, Unilever Philippines, Pilipinas Shell, Smart Communications, PLDT Company, and San Miguel Corporation, among others.

His awards include three Gawad Urian for Best Production Design for Oro, Plata, Mata, Misteryo sa Tuwa, and Amigo; three Film Academy Awards for Best Production Design for Oro, Plata, Mata, Mano Po 2: My Home, and Resiklo; four Metro Manila Film Festival Best Production Design awards for Magic Temple, Mano Po 2: My Home, Mano Po III: My Love, and Resiklo; a Star Award for Production Designer of the Year for Mano Po 2: My Home; a FAMAS Award for Production Design for Resiklo; and Best Production Design award for Mana at the 2015 Madrid International Film Festival. Written byJhoanne Kristine Vinuya
