CUSTODIO, FRANCISCA (Francisca Binghoy Custodio) aka Babes Custodio. b. Tacloban, Leyte 6 Jun 1946. Radio host, newscaster, station manager. Custodio attended Divine Word University where she earned a bachelor of science degree in commerce, major in business management, in 1969. At 19, she began her long and ongoing radio career when, while in college, she joined in 1965 the accounting and traffic departments of DYVL, the Tacloban station of the Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC), upon the invitation of its first station manager, Eduardo Montilla. After a few years, then station manager Charlie Filamor tried her on the air by making her read commercials, spin records, and give time checks. When a program emcee lost her voice, Custodio filled in for her. This break led to her first regular programs where she emceed the amateur singing contest Search for Superwheel Singing Star, the singing contest for the elderly Diri Pa Kami Laos (We Are Not Yet Has-Beens), and the counterpart for children Wee Wee Jamboree.

She then became part of the public service program Operation Bulig (Operation Help), which led her to news and commentary programs. In 1984, she became part of management when she was appointed operations manager. While serving as the station’s newscaster, Custodio was appointed station manager of DYVL’s sister station on the FM band, DYMS. In 1994, MBC appointed her DYVL station manager. She then expanded the station’s public service programs by creating Kasayuran ha Balaud (Knowledge of the Law) and Salamat Po, Doktor (Thank You, Doctor). She also encouraged local composers and singers through the program Boses han Musika (Voice of Music).

Custodio is widely credited for reviving the literary genre siday, a type of poetry homegrown in Eastern Visayas, which is written and recited in Waray, the language of the region. Beginning in 1979, she read sayings in Waray called puplonganon before she delivered the news. Her goal was to keep the language alive. A year later, she began inviting listeners to send her their puplonganon, which she read on the air. Contributions poured in, many in siday form, which led to the production of the program DYVL Siday (DYVL Poetry). In 2005, she co-edited with the poet Merlie Alunan the compilation Mga Siday Han DYVL (Poems from DYVL), published by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, the provincial government of Leyte, and the University of the Philippines Tacloban.

DYVL suffered a setback when the historic Typhoon Yolanda killed thousands of people and devastated property in Leyte in 2013. The station lost its studios and two of its staff in the disaster. Custodio put the station back on the air two days later in a makeshift studio to provide information and broadcast public service.

For her use of radio to promote Waray language and culture through the siday, the University of the Philippines College of Mass Communication awarded her the 2016 Gawad Plaridel. Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez

DAVID, KARA (Kara Patria Constantino David)b. Manila 12 Sep 1973. Broadcast journalist. She is the daughter of sociologist Randolph “Randy” David and former member of the progressive singing group Inang Laya and chair of the Civil Service Commission Karina Constantino-David. She completed her elementary and high school education at the University of the Philippines Diliman, and obtained a bachelor of arts in broadcast communication, cum laude, from the same university in 1994. She first worked as a writer-researcher for the office of Senate president Edgardo Angara in 1994-95.

 

Her broadcast journalism career began and grew with GMA Network, first as a production assistant and researcher in Bantay Boto (Guarding the Vote), a news program on the 1995 national elections. She then became writer-researcher for the medical-public service program Emergency, 1995-98; reporter for the news and public affairs program Brigada Siete (Brigade at Seven), 1997-2001; host of “Huling Hirit,” a two-minute segment of the daily early evening news program Saksi (Witness), which featured stories of adventure and inspiration, 1998-2000; one of the reporters of the investigative program Case Unclosed, 2008; one of the writers and hosts of the feature documentaries 100% Pinoy (100 Percent Filipino), 2006-7, and OFW Diaries (Diaries of Overseas Filipino Workers), 2009-10; and voice-over narrator for the Filipino edition of the environmental program Human Planet, 2014. She began hosting the weekly inspirational program Powerhouse in 2013, and began anchoring the daily morning news program News to Go in 2012 of the network’s sister station GMA News TV Channel 11. She either wrote or hosted special documentaries, like Fate in Gold, 1995; Boses ng Kalayaan (Voice of Freedom) and Bayan sa Sangandaan (Nation at the Crossroads), both in 1998; and Sa Kuko ng Terorismo (In the Claws of Terrorism), 2002,

 

She became part of the weekly investigative documentary program i-Witness in 2002, in which she became known for her often heartbreaking but always sensitive and insightful analyses of various social issues. She continues doing nearly hourlong documentaries for the program. Among her outstanding documentaries are “Gamu-gamo sa Dilim” (Moth in the Dark), 2001, about several communities’ lack of access to power and electricity in spite of the presence of a hydroelectric dam in some of these areas; “Selda Inosente” (aka “Angels in Prison”), 2002, which examines the plight of young children born and living with their mothers in prison; “Bitay” (Sentenced to Die), 2004, about a communist rebel on death row; “Pagbabalik sa Selda” (Return to the Prison Cell), 2005, about prison life; “Buto’t Balat” (Malnourished), 2004, about extreme cases of malnutrition among children and the youth; “Mga Batang Hiram” (Borrowed Children), 2006, about the discrimination and slavery of young Aeta children given away by their parents at a young age; “Uuwi Na si Udong” (Udong Is Coming Home), 2006, about a 10-year-old boy who works in a sugar plantation in Luzon to pay off the debts of his family living in the Visayas; “Sa Mata ni Ekang” (Through Ekang’s Eyes), 2006, about a three-year-old girl who mouths expletives, has a thief for a father, a drug dealer for a mother, a pimp for a grandmother, and lives in an environment of other notorious characters; “Alaga” (Pet), 2006, which documents schistosomiasis that plagues a village in Agusan del Sur; “Gapos” (Bound), 2007, about 10 mentally ill individuals strapped down or imprisoned in their little cells at home; “Bundok na Kristal” (Crystal Mountain), 2007, about children sorting broken glasses for a living; “Tasaday,” 2008, about the controversial Tasaday in Lake Sebu in South Cotabato; “Ambulansyang de Paa” (Ambulance on Foot), 2007, about the lack of access of the Mangyan tribe to basic health services; “Paraisong Uhaw” (Thirsty Paradise), 2010, about waterless communities in the province of Masbate; “Gintong Putik” (Golden Mud), 2011, David’s reunion with a boy she met a decade ago, who turns to compressor diving to mine gold in depths of mud; and “Alkansya” (Piggy Bank), 2012, about a 12-year-old boy who dives at night for sea cucumbers to save up coins to fulfill his dream to continue his studies.

 

David uses mass media to promote social awareness and support for the underprivileged. She founded Project Malasakit in 2002, a foundation that supports the education of child laborers and abuse victims. The foundation has helped more than 800 families and 15 scholars in its community outreach programs.

 

David won local media awards, like the Rotary Club of Manila Journalism Award as Investigative Journalist of the Year in 2004 for “Bitay,” because of which a prisoner in death row was spared, and Broadcast Journalist of the Year in 2006; the PMPC Star Award as Best Documentary Program Host in 2007, 2008, 2009, and 2011; the Golden Screen Award as Best Documentary Program Host in 2011; the Titus Brandsma Leadership in Journalism Award in 2011; the Comguild Awards as Best Female Field Reporter in 2012 and 2013; and numerous honors from various university student award groups. David also garnered national awards, being recognized as one of the Ten Outstanding Young Men of the Philippines in 2007 and one of the Ten Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service in 2010.

Among international awards she received are the UNICEF Asia-Pacific Child Rights Award for her documentary “Selda Inosente” in 2003; a certificate for creative excellence from the US International Film and Video Festival for “Pagbabalik sa Selda” in 2005, “Gapos” in 2007, and “Tasaday” in 2009; Best Social Awareness Program from the Asian Television Awards for “Buto’t Balat” in 2005; a Silverscreen Award from the US International Film and Video Festival for “Buto’t Balat” in 2006 and “Sa Mata ni Ekang” in 2007; a George Foster Peabody Award for “Ambulansyang de Paa” in 2010, making her the second Filipino to have won the prestigious award; and a bronze medal from the New York Festivals for “Paraisong Uhaw” in 2011. Written by Christine A. Palattao and Eulalio R. Guieb III

Sources: David 2014; Wikipedia 2014n.

text:
DAVID, RANDY (Randolf Siongco David) b. Betis, Pampanga 8 Jan 1946. Sociologist, TV host, newspaper columnist, and professor emeritus of sociology at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. He is the eldest of 13 children of Pedro David and Bienvenida Siongco. He is married to Karina Constantino, a former chairperson of the Civil Service Commission, the daughter of historian Renato Constantino, and grandniece of opera singer and National Artist for music Jovita Fuentes. They have four children: broadcast journalist Kara, geological sciences professor Carlos Primo, painter and art teacher Nadya Melina, and corporate executive Jovita Erika.

He first studied literature at UP, but shifted to sociology which he completed in 1965, and joined the faculty of the UP Department of Sociology in 1967. Together with wife Karina, he went to England to pursue further studies in sociology at the University of Manchester in 1968. They both returned to the Philippines when they found themselves expecting their first baby, whom they felt had to be born in their own country. During martial law, David shunned opportunities to leave the country to resume his postgraduate studies. Instead, he continued to teach at UP.

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt, David, together with other members of the UP faculty, worked with the newly sequestered IBC Channel 13 and came up with a public affairs talk show that allowed people from different walks of life to express their opinions regarding various issues. Initially known as Truth Forum, later on, Public Forum, 1986-90, the program became popular for its content and its use of the Filipino language—a first for local talk shows. Directed by award-winning filmmaker Marilou Diaz-Abaya, the show got its title from the actual “Truth Forum”—a series of talks held in various barangays of the country that intended to expose the truth about the Marcos regime. This project was spearheaded by Sen Jose Diokno, with David and other fellow teachers from UP as regular speakers.

As the show’s host and writer, David gained popularity for his calm demeanor and insightful remarks. It was evident that this new career path suited him as much as teaching did, and he soon joined the newly revived ABC Channel 5 as newscaster and as host of a new talk show, Public Forum with Randy David, 1991-96, later changed to Public Life with Randy David, 1997-99, when the program moved to GMA. He co-hosted with Katrina Legarda the weekly talk public affairs program Off the Record, 2000-3, and has served as news analyst on the daily news program Bandila (Flag), since 2014, both on ABS-CBN.

David was one of the founders of the UP Third World Studies Center, and for 14 years served concurrently as its director and as editor of the center’s peer-reviewed journal Kasarinlan. He represented the UP faculty as a member of the Board of Regents, the University’s highest governing body, in 1999. He coordinated the Southeast Asian Perspectives Program of the Tokyo-based United Nations University, 1983-88, during which he led the joint research of a network of young scholars from the countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations on the region’s development experience. He was visiting professor at the Ryukoku University in Japan, 1990, and the National Autonomous University of Mexico, 1996, where he lectured on Philippine development and democracy, and on Filipino migrant workers.

David is active in civil society groups and other organizations. He was at one time the chair of the socialist group Bukluran sa Ikauunlad ng Sosyalistang Isip at Gawa. He served on the Board of Trustees of the Philippine Educational Theater Association and the Institute of Politics and Governance and on the Board of Advisers of the Philippine Rural Reconstruction Movement. He was at one time the chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation, which administers the prestigious Ramon Magsaysay Awards. He was also a member of the Social and Humanities Committee of the UNESCO National Commission of the Philippines and the Appeals Committee of the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board in 1999.

The Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon chose Public Forum every year as one of the country’s 10 most outstanding TV programs during the 12 years it was on the air. David won numerous awards, including the 1989-90 Journalist of the Year Award from the Rotary Club of Manila and the KBP Golden Dove Award for Best Male Public Affairs Host in 1994.

His weekly column Public Lives in the Philippine Daily Inquirer, continues to be as relevant as when it first came out in 1995. The Society of Publishers in Asia Awards cited the column for editorial excellence in 2002 and 2003. The Rotary Club of Manila awarded him the Opinion Writer of the Year in 2004 and 2011.

David is the author of four books, and his essays appeared in various local and international journals and publications. Two of his books, Reflections on Sociology and Philippine Society (UP Press, 2001) and Nation, Self, and Citizenship: An Invitation to Philippine Sociology (UP Department of Sociology, 2002), won the National Book Award in 2002 and 2003, respectively. article.value: DAVID, RANDY (Randolf Siongco David) b. Betis, Pampanga 8 Jan 1946. Sociologist, TV host, newspaper columnist, and professor emeritus of sociology at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. He is the eldest of 13 children of Pedro David and Bienvenida Siongco. He is married to Karina Constantino, a former chairperson of the Civil Service Commission, the daughter of historian Renato Constantino, and grandniece of opera singer and National Artist for music Jovita Fuentes. They have four children: broadcast journalist Kara, geological sciences professor Carlos Primo, painter and art teacher Nadya Melina, and corporate executive Jovita Erika.

He first studied literature at UP, but shifted to sociology which he completed in 1965, and joined the faculty of the UP Department of Sociology in 1967. Together with wife Karina, he went to England to pursue further studies in sociology at the University of Manchester in 1968. They both returned to the Philippines when they found themselves expecting their first baby, whom they felt had to be born in their own country. During martial law, David shunned opportunities to leave the country to resume his postgraduate studies. Instead, he continued to teach at UP.

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt, David, together with other members of the UP faculty, worked with the newly sequestered IBC Channel 13 and came up with a public affairs talk show that allowed people from different walks of life to express their opinions regarding various issues. Initially known as Truth Forum, later on, Public Forum, 1986-90, the program became popular for its content and its use of the Filipino language—a first for local talk shows. Directed by award-winning filmmaker Marilou Diaz-Abaya, the show got its title from the actual “Truth Forum”—a series of talks held in various barangays of the country that intended to expose the truth about the Marcos regime. This project was spearheaded by Sen Jose Diokno, with David and other fellow teachers from UP as regular speakers.

As the show’s host and writer, David gained popularity for his calm demeanor and insightful remarks. It was evident that this new career path suited him as much as teaching did, and he soon joined the newly revived ABC Channel 5 as newscaster and as host of a new talk show, Public Forum with Randy David, 1991-96, later changed to Public Life with Randy David, 1997-99, when the program moved to GMA. He co-hosted with Katrina Legarda the weekly talk public affairs program Off the Record, 2000-3, and has served as news analyst on the daily news program Bandila (Flag), since 2014, both on ABS-CBN.

DAVIS, IRA (Ira Efren Gonzalez Davis) b. Rosales, Pangasinan 1 Feb 1916. d. California, USA 9 Jan 2000. Radio and television producer, announcer, and executive. He was the son of Victorina Gonzalez of Pangasinan and Ira Lee Davis of Missouri, USA. He was married to Wilhelmine Baumann, who briefly hosted postwar radio in French. They had eight children, including radio announcer and advertising executive Roger Davis. His daughter-in-law Betsy Enriquez was a radio-television journalist while grandson Russ Davis is a radio announcer. He attended Bordner High School in Manila in the early 1930s.

One of the pioneers in Philippine radio, Davis began his broadcasting career in the early 1930s at KZIB by emceeing musical-variety shows while playing the ukulele. He was among the first Filipinos, along with Koko Trinidad, Vero Perfecto, and Norman Reyes, to be given announcing and newscasting jobs on the air in the mid-1930s, which until then were dominated by Americans in Manila. He also operated a radio repair shop in Manila before World War II. When war broke out, he and a few hundred Filipino-American mestizos were incarcerated in early 1942 at the Santo Tomas Internment Camp, along with 3,000 Americans and other Allied nationals.

After seven months, the Japanese freed the mestizos on the assumption that they were American only on paper but Filipino in spirit. However, when word got around that they were to be picked up again, Davis took his young family to Guimba, Nueva Ecija. While waiting out the war, he stole back into Manila a few times to procure radio parts for the guerrillas operating in Nueva Ecija.

After the war, Davis joined Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC) where he produced and hosted several programs on KZRH and its sister station KZPI, including the hit variety-game show Purico Jamboree, which he co-produced and co-hosted with Conde Ubaldo. In 1956, with Davis as producer, the show was replaced by Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), an amateur singing contest that first aired in 1950 on DZBB. Another memorable show that Davis produced and hosted was Radio Schoolhouse, a quiz show for grade school students. He likewise produced all the MBC programs sponsored by the Philippine Manufacturing Company (today Procter and Gamble).

Davis studied the radio audience in the 1950s when there were no sophisticated rating surveys yet, by poring over thousands of letters weekly sent by fans to MBC stations. His notes were then routed to management, which led to the production of successful and long-running shows on MBC stations. Davis thus rose to become general manager of MBC, until it expanded into television Channel 11 in 1962. Just before President Marcos declared martial law in 1972, Davis retired from broadcasting. Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez

Sources: Enriquez 2008a; Isorena-Arcega 2009.

DE GUZMAN, GLORIA (Gloria Lardizabal de Guzman Maylas) aka Ollie de Guzman and Oly Maylas. b. Manila 29 Nov 1940. Radio, television, and movie actor. She is the daughter of Jose Fenix de Guzman and Elisa Basa Lardizabal. Her sister Elizabeth is married to character movie actor and radio announcer Cristobal Masilungan aka Cris de Vera. She was married to the late Lucio Aguilar Maylas, radio drama actor, director, and music scorer, with whom she has five children, including music spinner Lucito and video editor Jeng. A grandson, Louie Ryan Maylas Paraboles, is a voice artist. She attended the University of Santo Tomas High School until she was 16.

She was seven when she appeared in the movie Babaeng Kalbo (Bald Woman). At age 10, she began performing in radio soaps and variety shows on DZRH in 1950, beginning with Tanghalan ng Gloco (The Gloco Stage), Dalaginding ng Nayon (Barrio Lass), Tanghalan ng Buhay (Life Stage), Camay Theater of the Air, and Eskuwelahang Munti (Little Schoolhouse). In all she played child roles, which became her specialization as a voice actor in dramas and commercials, even as an adult.

By the time she reached her teens, she had voiced several roles in a single program. She trained under broadcaster Hernando R. Ocampo, who also became a renowned painter, and radio drama director Fred Gonzales. In the 1960s, she performed in radio dramas produced by the government’s National Media Production Center while it was under the helm of Ocampo, such as Sangguniang Pangnayon (Barrio Council) and Ms. Verdote: Barrio Teacher.

She also voiced commercials beginning in the 1950s, such as those of food products Dari Creme, Star Margarine, and Carnation canned milk, for radio and television in Tagalog and other Filipino languages such as Tausug and Visayan. She dubbed children’s voices on telenovelas as well as dialogues in Filipino on foreign programs such as the title characters in the anime programs Sailormoon, A Little Princess: Sara, Utawarerumono, and Cedi. Written byEdgardo Ray G. Pedroche, with notes from Cynthia Cruz-Paz

Sources: Aniceto 2007; De Guzman 2004

DE LEON, JOEY (Jose Maria Ramos de Leon) b. Manila 14 Oct 1946. Television host, movie actor, comedian, composer, writer, visual artist. He is the son of Jose Seoane de Leon and Emma Manahan Ramos. He has two children with actor and former wife Daria Ramirez: Joseph Joachim “Keempee” de Leon and Jacinda Myrtle “Cheenee” de Leon, who are also actors. He is married to Eileen Macapagal with whom he has three children. He grew up in Sampaloc, Manila, studied at Juan Sumulong High School, and proceeded to study business administration at the University of the East and, later, architecture at National University, both of which he did not finish.

He started working at age 15. He worked as hauler of tissue paper, mall salesman, Commission on Elections fieldman, technician at the National Institute of Science and Technology, and promotions boy of a broadcasting company. De Leon believes that his quirky humor and popular appeal were formed by his early life as a poor member of a rich clan and his experiences in the odd jobs he took on.

His career as a broadcast artist began in the 1960s when he served as a disc jockey for half a decade in a dozen FM radio stations, mostly owned by pre-martial law ABS-CBN. A break came with a hosting job in the gag show Ok Lang (It’s Okay) on IBC 13, 1973, where he first worked with the Sotto brothers (Tito, Vic, and Val), Ricky Manalo, and the Apo Hiking Society. Tito and Vic became his co-hosts in a new GMA musical show, Discorama, 1975, and the trio did comedy newscast segments that featured hilarious interpretations of Top 40 hit songs using farcical lyrics written by Joey. The three later became hosts of GMA’s Student Canteen, 1976. Their comedic group became popular in the IBC 13 sitcom Iskul Bukol (School Bumps), 1977, where they spoofed a bunch of lazy, ambition-less students making fun of people around them. The trio formed in 1979 the noontime variety show Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!), now the longest-running TV program in the country. His humor spoofs advertisements, situations, and characters, especially movie king Fernando Poe Jr. The language of his spoofs usually conveys double meanings and sexual insinuations.

De Leon appeared in 54 television shows as either a host or a cast member. He hosted Apple Pie, Patis, Atbp. (Apple Pie, Fish Sauce, Etc.) for RPN 9, 1986; The Sharon Cuneta Show for IBC 13, 1986-88, then for ABS-CBN; and Let’s Go Crazy for ABS-CBN, 1987, with Maricel Soriano. He acted in leading roles in the RPN 9 comedy sitcom Joey and Son, 1980, with Ian Veneracion and the IBC 13 gag show T.O.D.A.S., 1978-88, in which he played Helen Bola and Indoy Badidoy, imitations of broadcaster Helen Vela and entertainment talk show host Inday Badiday, respectively. Among his notable TV programs are the prank show Wow Mali (Oh No, It’s a Mistake) on ABC/TV5, 1996, and revived as Wow Mali Pa Rin (Oh No, It’s a Mistake Again) after a few years of break; Nuts Entertainment on GMA, 2003-8; Mel & Joey on GMA, 2004-11; and Takeshi’s Castle on Q Network / GMA, 2006-9. He served as judge in the reality talent search programs of GMA: Starstruck, 2003-6, and Protégé, 2011-12.

He also appeared in more than three dozen movies, some of which with favorite sidekick Rene Requiestas. His iconic comedic characters include Starzan in two films in 1989 and one in 1990, and Barbie in 1989, 1991, and 1995. He wrote columns: De Leon’s Den, for the Manila Bulletin, and Me, Starzan for the Philippine Star.

His hit compositions include “Ipagpatawad Mo” (Forgive Me), “Awitin Mo, Isasayaw Ko” (Sing and I Will Dance), “Boyfriend Kong Baduy” (My Geeky Boyfriend), “Iskul Bukol,” “Itaktak Mo” (Shake It Off), and “Walang Daya” (No Rigging).

He also paints. He mounted his back-to-back exhibit Fish and Chips, with Igan D’Bayan at the Crucible Gallery in 2009. He used casino chips from his personal collections as a metaphor for chance and accidental beauty to punctuate his acrylic paintings of clowns and fishes.

He was suspended several times by the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board for uttering foul words in Eat Bulaga! He has been constantly criticized for his toilet humor, sexual innuendos, and jokes on serious events and personal affairs. He tussled with fellow host Willie Revillame over the latter’s alleged cases of game rigging and unscrupulous practices in Eat Bulaga!’s competitor Wowowee, Willing Willie, and Will Time, Big Time.

As a TV personality, he won Best Male TV Host for Eat Bulaga! at the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards in 2010 and 2001, and a Supremo Award from the young writers of the Philippine Star in 2008. As a movie actor, he was named Box-Office King of the Year by the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Scholarship Foundation in 1989. As a composer, his “Longganisang Maong, Dagang Denims” (Sausage Denims, Mouse Denims) received a special award in the Third Metropolitan Manila Popular Music Festival in 1978. Written byJPaul S. Manzanilla, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

David 1995; Domingo 2007; Lo 1989; Montreal 1987; Ravencrow’s Owlery 2009; Screenwriters Guild of the Philippines 1985b;

DE LOS ANGELES, FENY b. Quezon City 5 Jul 1958. TV producer, educator, children’s literature writer. She is the second of eight children of Walfrido de los Angeles and Irene Montano. Playwright and novelist Servando de los Angeles is her grandfather. She obtained her bachelor’s degree in Family Life and Child Development from the University of the Philippines (UP), 1979, where she taught upon graduation and served as chairperson of the Department of Family Life and Child Development, UP Diliman from 1980 to 1983. She has a master’s degree in Educational Leadership from Bank Street College of Education in New York, 1989. She has also taken graduate courses in psychology and in communications at the University of the Philippines.

De los Angeles was co-founder of two nongovernmental organizations committed to children: Community of Learners Foundation (COLF) and the Philippine Children’s Television Foundation (PCTVF) which produced the award-winning children’s show Batibot (Small but Strong) and other educational television programs and multimedia products.

She trained as a curriculum director for the Philippine Sesame Street Project of the Children’s Television Workshop (CTW) in 1983. Upon the establishment of PCTVF in 1984, she became the research and curriculum director of Batibot, and later its executive producer. The program ran from 1984 to 2000 on RPN 9, PTV 4, ABS-CBN, and GMA, and was revived in 2010 on TV5. The TV program spawned Radyo Batibot (Batibot Radio), broadcast in the late 1980s on DZAM, later called DZAR. It also launched Batibot Books in collaboration with Anvil Publishing, children’s audio cassettes with Ivory Records, live shows for children, and the TV show Pin-Pin, 1987-92, a Chinese-Filipino children’s program produced in cooperation with Kaisa Para sa Kaunlaran. She was also the executive producer of the following PCTVF-produced shows aired on GMA Network: 1896 Kalayaan, a children’s magazine show on culture and history, 1995-96, and PG (Parents’ Guide), 1996-99, a magazine show on parenting.

As an educator and family life and child development specialist, de los Angeles has devoted her work to children and families through schools, media, community-based educational programs and capacity-building programs for the past 39 years. She is the Executive Director of COLF, a pioneer in progressive and inclusive education in the Philippines, which has been implementing working models of developmentally appropriate, culturally relevant, and gender-fair educational programs for Filipino children. COLF has been a long-time partner of UNICEF, the Department of Education, and the Department of Social Welfare and Development to improve the quality of education and early childhood care and development programs in the Philippines. COLF continues the work of PCTVF in developing digital media such as the Batibot app for today’s Filipino children.

De los Angeles has worked as an international consultant in various countries such as Vietnam, Indonesia, Thailand, Nepal, Colombia, and South Africa, and has been active in various international partnerships in education and child development, children’s media, and children’s rights. From 1993 to 2001, she was actively involved in the Consultative Group for Early Childhood Care and Development and served as a member of the International Secretariat representing Southeast Asia from 1990 up to 2001. She was also a founding member of the International Council of WATCH or the World Alliance of Television for Children and served as a member of the Board of the World Summit for Children’s Media Foundation.

De los Angeles has also written storybooks for children which were published by Cacho Hermanos, UNICEF, and PCTVF: Ang Kuya ni Karina (Karina’s Older Brother) and Ang Prinsesang Ayaw Matulog (The Princess Who Does Not Want to Sleep), 1996; and Isang Mundong Makabata (A Child-friendly World) and Sa Bagong Planeta (In the New Planet), 1997.

During her term as research and curriculum director and executive producer of Batibot, the show won numerous best children’s program citations from the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon, Star Awards for Television, Catholic Mass Media Awards, and the Prix Jeunesse, the latter regarded as the Oscars of children’s programming around the world. Written byElmer L. Gatchalian

De los Angeles was co-founder of two nongovernmental organizations committed to children: Community of Learners Foundation (COLF) and the Philippine Children’s Television Foundation (PCTVF) which produced the award-winning children’s show Batibot (Small but Strong) and other educational television programs and multimedia products.

She trained as a curriculum director for the Philippine Sesame Street Project of the Children’s Television Workshop (CTW) in 1983. Upon the establishment of PCTVF in 1984, she became the research and curriculum director of Batibot, and later its executive producer. The program ran from 1984 to 2000 on RPN 9, PTV 4, ABS-CBN, and GMA, and was revived in 2010 on TV5. The TV program spawned Radyo Batibot (Batibot Radio), broadcast in the late 1980s on DZAM, later called DZAR. It also launched Batibot Books in collaboration with Anvil Publishing, children’s audio cassettes with Ivory Records, live shows for children, and the TV show Pin-Pin, 1987-92, a Chinese-Filipino children’s program produced in cooperation with Kaisa Para sa Kaunlaran. She was also the executive producer of the following PCTVF-produced shows aired on GMA Network: 1896 Kalayaan, a children’s magazine show on culture and history, 1995-96, and PG (Parents’ Guide), 1996-99, a magazine show on parenting.

As an educator and family life and child development specialist, de los Angeles has devoted her work to children and families through schools, media, community-based educational programs and capacity-building programs for the past 39 years. She is the Executive Director of COLF, a pioneer in progressive and inclusive education in the Philippines, which has been implementing working models of developmentally appropriate, culturally relevant, and gender-fair educational programs for Filipino children. COLF has been a long-time partner of UNICEF, the Department of Education, and the Department of Social Welfare and Development to improve the quality of education and early childhood care and development programs in the Philippines. COLF continues the work of PCTVF in developing digital media such as the Batibot app for today’s Filipino children.

De los Angeles has worked as an international consultant in various countries such as Vietnam, Indonesia, Thailand, Nepal, Colombia, and South Africa, and has been active in various international partnerships in education and child development, children’s media, and children’s rights. From 1993 to 2001, she was actively involved in the Consultative Group for Early Childhood Care and Development and served as a member of the International Secretariat representing Southeast Asia from 1990 up to 2001. She was also a founding member of the International Council of WATCH or the World Alliance of Television for Children and served as a member of the Board of the World Summit for Children’s Media Foundation.

De los Angeles has also written storybooks for children which were published by Cacho Hermanos, UNICEF, and PCTVF: Ang Kuya ni Karina (Karina’s Older Brother) and Ang Prinsesang Ayaw Matulog (The Princess Who Does Not Want to Sleep), 1996; and Isang Mundong Makabata (A Child-friendly World) and Sa Bagong Planeta (In the New Planet), 1997.

During her term as research and curriculum director and executive producer of Batibot, the show won numerous best children’s program citations from the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon, Star Awards for Television, Catholic Mass Media Awards, and the Prix Jeunesse, the latter regarded as the Oscars of children’s programming around the world. Written byElmer L. Gatchalian

DUAVIT, GILBERTO JR (Gilberto “Jimmy” Roy Duavit Jr) aka Jimmy Duavit. b. 6 Dec 1932. Broadcast executive, film and television producer. He is the son of Gilberto “Bibit” Duavit Sr and Vilma Roy Duavit. His father is a former GMA executive and chair of the board and former first district representative of Rizal Province. His mother is a daughter of former senator Jose Roy of Moncada, Tarlac. He is married and has four children. He has an older sister—Judith Duavit-Vasquez, a member of the board of GMA Network Inc—and two younger brothers: Joel Roy, first district representative of Rizal Province since 2010, and Michael John, former first district representative of Rizal, 2007-10, and a member of the board of GMA Network. He graduated with a bachelor of arts in philosophy from the University of the Philippines.

Duavit Jr has been a board director of GMA Network since 1999 and since age 51 has been the president and chief operating officer of the company. He is the chair of GMA’s executive committee, chair of the board of GMA Network Films and GMA Worldwide, and vice-chair of the board of GMA Marketing and Productions. He also serves as president and chief executive officer of GMA Holdings, RGMA Marketing and Productions, Film Experts, Scenarios, and Dual Management and Investments. He is the president and director of Group Management and Development, MediaMerge Corporation, and Citynet Network Marketing and Productions; and director of RGMA Network, GMA New Media, Alta Productions Group, Optima Digital, and Mont-Aire Realty and Development Corp. He also serves as the president and a trustee of GMA Kapuso Foundation.

For television, he produced the remake of the short film Kamada (State of Being), 1997, directed by Raymond Red, written by Ian Victoriano, and starring Francis Magalona as a musician who writes songs in a boarding house and gets entangled in forbidden love, deceit, and crime. He developed the concept with writer Jun Lana and produced the daily horror drama series Liwanag ng Hatinggabi (Light of Midnight), 1999-2000, directed by Joel Lamangan, about a cruel governor, played by Lorna Tolentino, whose daughter (Angelika Dela Cruz) falls in love with a childhood friend (Victor Neri), who goes against the governor’s tyranny. Duavit Jr’s biggest TV project was the daily drama series Ang Iibigin Ay Ikaw (My One and Only Love), 2002-3, directed by Joyce Bernal and Lore Reyes, about three characters, played by Christopher de Leon, Alice Dixon, and Richard Gomez, whose lives and loves are intertwined because of the choices they make due to the ambitions they have set for themselves.

Under GMA Films, Duavit Jr produced Jose Rizal, 1998, a biopic of the Philippine national hero; Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 1999, about child labor in illegal fishing systems, both directed by Marilou Diaz-Abaya and both starring Cesar Montano; and Death Row, 2000, directed by Joel Lamangan, starring Cogie Domingo, about the plight of juveniles inside death row.

In 2000, Duavit helped revolutionize the news department of GMA, whose programs won international recognition at the George Foster Peabody Awards, the New York Festivals for Television, and the Asian Television Awards.

Kamada won Best TV Special at the KBP Golden Dove Awards, 1997, and Best Dramatic Feature at the Southeast Asian Television Awards in Singapore, 1997.

Jose Rizal won Best Picture, Best Director for Diaz-Abaya, Best Actor for Cesar Montano, Best Supporting Actor for Jaime Fabregas, Best Supporting Actress for Gloria Diaz, Best Screenplay and Best Story for Ricky Lee, Jun Lana, and Peter Ong Lim, Best Cinematography for Rody Lacap, Best Editing for Jess Navarro and Manet Dayrit, Best Sound Engineering for Albert Michael Idioma, Best Production Design for Leo Abaya, Best Special Effects for Optimal Digital, Best Makeup for Dennis Tan, Best Musical Score and Movie Theme Song for Nonong Buencamino, and the Gatpuno Antonio J. Villegas Cultural Award at the 24th Metro Manila Film Festival, 1998. It also won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Supporting Actor, Best Screenplay, Best Production Design, Best Editing, and Best Musical Score at the PMPC Star Awards for Movies, 1998. It won Best Director, Best Supporting Actor, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Sound, and Best Music at the Gawad Urian, 1999.

Muro-ami won Best Picture, Best Director for Diaz-Abaya, Best Supporting Actor for Pen Medina, Best Screenplay and Best Story for Lee and Lana, Best Cinematography for Lacap, Best Editing for Navarro and Dayrit, Best Sound Engineering for Idioma, Best Production Design for Abaya, Best Special Effects for Marc Ambat, Best Musical Score for Buencamino, and the Gatpuno Antonio J. Villegas Cultural Award at the 25th Metro Manila Film Festival, 1999.

Death Row won Second Best Picture and awards for Best Actor for Eddie Garcia, Best Editing for Navarro and Kelly Cruz, Best Sound Engineering for Idioma and Rudy Gonzales, and Best Production Design for Joey Luna at the 26th Metro Manila Film Festival, 2000; Best Actor, Best Supporting Actor for Pen Medina, Best Production Design, and Best Editing at the Film Academy of the Philippines Awards, 2001; and Best Actor, Best Editing, and Best Sound at the 24th Gawad Urian, 2000. It received the Prix du Meilleur Film Engage au Service d’une Cause (Prize for the Best Committed Film Championing a Cause) at the 23rd International Festival of Independent Films in Brussels, Belgium, 2001. Written by Dean Airo Salvador E. Dancel and Eulalio R. Guieb III

DWIZ DWIZ 882 kHz on AM is the flagship station of Aliw Broadcasting Company (ABC). It is one of only five radio stations permitted by the National Telecommunications Commission to operate on a powerful 50-kilowatt transmitter, allowing its signal to reach the entire island of Luzon and Mimaropa (Occidental and Oriental Mindoro, Marinduque, Romblon, and Palawan). With Tagalog as its primary language, the station’s tag line is “Todong lakas!” (Full blast!).

DWIZ began its life as DZPI on 20 Mar 1949. Owned by the Philippine Broadcasting Corporation (PBC), DZPI was on the air until 23 Sept 1972, the day following the announcement of the declaration of martial law by former president Ferdinand E. Marcos.The following day, former ambassador Antonio L. Cabangon-Chua acquired PBC and changed DZPI’s call letters to DWIZ. In 1992, he renamed PBC as ABC. In Jul 2013, a second DWIZ began broadcasting from Dagupan City, relaying news reports and current affairs programs aired by DWIZ Manila. Filipinos all over the world listen to DWIZ through online streaming via host radyokabayan.com.

Primarily a news and talk station, DWIZ counts veteran journalists and newspaper columnists among its broadcast staff, including Philippine Star columnist Jarius Bondoc, 2013 Metrobank Foundation Journalist of the Year awardee and host of Sapol ni Jarius Bondoc (Jarius Bondoc Hits the Point), and former Department of Labor and Employment undersecretary Susan “Toots” Ople, 2013 Trafficking in Persons Hero Award recipient and host of Global Pinoy, a program about overseas Filipino workers. Other anchors include Teddy “Boy” Locsin, Boying Remulla, Obet Pagdanganan, Ely Aligora, Alvin Capino, Jonathan dela Cruz, Rolly Gonzalo, Cristy Dailo, and Ramon Tulfo.

DWIZ was named Best AM Station of the Year at the Golden Dove Awards of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) in 1996, 2000, and 2010.

In 2004, its program Kasangga Mo ang Langit (The Sky Is Your Partner), hosted by station manager Rey Langit, received the Hall of Fame Award for Best Public Service Program from the Catholic Mass Media Awards. In 2010, its investigative documentary program Siyasat (Investigate) won the Rotary Club of Manila Journalism Award for Radio Program of the Year. Written by Lorna Israel

Sources: DWIZ 2011; Guirao 2013; Philstar.com 2010; Rotary Club of Manila 2011

DWJM DWJM 88.3 kHz on FM is popularly known as Jam 88.3, with the tag line “New music alternative.” Owned and operated by Raven Broadcasting Corporation (RBC), it operates from Pasig City and is heard in Metro Manila, Batangas, Bulacan, Lucena, Pampanga, and Olongapo.

DWJM was formerly DWCT, a jazz station with the moniker Citylite 88.3, from 1988 to 2003. RBC changed its call letters and broadened its music format in 2003 to include popular music and the trend-setting acoustic music, which is produced naturally and without the use of electronics, and also called unplugged music. In 2005, Jam 88.3 began to play more original Pilipino music (OPM) than other stations, helping revive OPM popularity. The station is also credited for discovering new talent and music through the daily program Fresh Filter, where DJ Russ Davis features local independent musicians. On Saturdays, the station plays WRXP or Week End Rock Xperience, while Sundays are dedicated to the programs Republ!k and Different Sunday.

Jam 88.3 won the Best Web Site Media and Entertainment prize at the Philippine Web Awards in 2004 and 2005. At the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) Golden Dove Awards, it won Outstanding Station Promotion Material and Outstanding Station-Produced Radio Commercial in 2004, Best Magazine Program Host for DJ Patti and Best Radio Documentary Program for Audiofiles in 2007, and Best FM Radio Station in 2008. Written byLorna Israel

DWRK DWRK 96.3 kHz on FM is branded as Easy Rock, with the tag line “Just the rite rock,” which refers to the contemporary and soft rock music of the 1970s and 1980s. DWRK is heard in Metro Manila, Baguio, Boracay, Iloilo, Bacolod, Cebu, Zamboanga, Cagayan de Oro, Davao, and General Santos. It is owned by Cebu Broadcasting Company (CBC), an affiliate of Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC).

DWRK’s moniker was WRock when it first went on the air in 1988 under the ownership of ACWS–United Broadcasting Network Exodus Broadcasting Company. In 2008, MBC acquired the station to cater to listeners who enjoy light rock music. However, because the law limits to one the ownership of a radio station on either the AM or FM band in a municipality or city, DWRK’s ownership was assigned to CBC even as it broadcasts from the MBC headquarters in Pasay, Metro Manila. The following year, DWRK rebranded itself as Easy Rock but kept its less-talk-less-noise-more-music format favored by its target audience of busy young professionals who prefer contemporary and mellow music.

In 2012, it began a series of mall concerts dubbed Easy Rock Mall Tour series featuring the performances of established and rising recording artists such as Sabrina, Jay R, Nyoy Volante, Freestyle, True Faith, Bloomfields, and Jose Mari Chan.

As WRrock, the station was awarded by the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas the Golden Dove Award for Best FM Station in 2000.Written by Lorna Israel

Sources: Easy Rock 2010; Manila Times 2008; Radyo Natin 2014.

DXUP DXUP 105.5 MHz on FM is one of the community radios set up under the GENPeace Program operated by the Upi Community Media Education Center (CMEC) and heard in Nuro Upi, South Upi, and other parts of Maguindanao, some parts of North Cotabato, Lanao del Norte, and Baganian Point of Zamboanga Sibugay. The U in its call sign stands for Upi while P stands for Peace. The GENPeace Program, a network of organizations and individuals working toward a just and sustainable peace in the Philippines, initiated the establishment of DXUP while the local government of Upi provided the site, building, and the station’s 300-watt transmitter.

The establishment of DXUP in 2004 fulfilled a community’s dream for a tool to communicate peace and development as well as the perspectives and concerns of the most marginalized and underrepresented members of the community composed of Muslims, Teduray, and Christians. Prior to the establishment of DXUP, the local government of Upi paid for a 30-minute program that aired on Sundays over DXMS in Cotabato City. It was then the only means to inform community members of government programs and services apart from its VHF transceiver handheld radio.

DXUP is now also seen on DXUP Teleradyo via a local cable channel. Its programs include Suara, meaning peace; Kedat-adatan, from the Teduray word adat, which may mean a way of life, customs, or codes of conduct and responsibilities for interpersonal respect; Bantay Buhay (Life Guard), which discusses livelihood and agriculture, sociocultural development, gender advocacy, children’s rights and education; the newscasts DXUP Balita (DXUP News) and Bantay Bayan (Nation Watch); Talakayang Pambarangay (Barangay Talk), which reports on local government initiatives at the barangay level; and the musical programs Musikahan (Music Time), Salu-Salo Together (Getting Together) and Udto na Di! (It’s Noontime!).

Community volunteers run the station while volunteers trained under the GENPeace Project anchor the programs.

DXUP, one of the few surviving GENPeace community radios in Mindanao, received the 2007 Titus Brandsma Special Citation for Community Communication for its contribution to peace and interfaith dialogue, proving the importance of multi-stakeholder partnership and ownership for a community radio to survive and the strength of radio as a medium for peace communication and cross-cultural understanding. Written by Fraulein A. Oclarit and Ariel Marco T. Oclarit

Sources: Anso 2013a, 2013b; Debolgado 2013; Piang 2013; Rivera 2010.

DZAS DZAS 720 kHz on AM is a commercial-free religious radio station owned and operated by Far East Broadcasting Company (FEBC), heard in Manila, Central Luzon, and Calabarzon (Cavite, Laguna, Batangas, Rizal, and Quezon), with the tag line “Agapay ng sambayanan” (Together with the people). Its studio is in Pasig City while its transmitter is in Bocaue, Bulacan.

DZAS is the first of nine radio stations of FEBC in the Philippines. Until 1948, the eve of the 1949 Chinese Communist Revolution when China banned religious missions, FEBC broadcast from Shanghai. On 4 Jun 1948, KZAS, with AS then standing for the Airway for Salvation, began its Philippine broadcast. On 1 Jan 1949, its initial call letter changed from K to D along with all radio stations in the Philippines to comply with new call letter assignments issued by the International Telecommunications Union following World War II. That same year, DZAS began its international broadcast to China. Today, FEBC is part of an international network of religious stations broadcasting in 150 languages.

Pioneering religious programming in the Philippines, DZAS sends all-terrain vehicles called Glory Vans to deliver narrow-tuned radios nicknamed “portable missionaries” to remote barangays. Its longest-running program, Hardin ng Panalangin (Garden of Prayer), produced and hosted by Proceso H. Marcelo since 1958, grants listener prayer requests on the air.

DZRB DZRB 738 kHz on AM, or Radyo ng Bayan (The Nation’s Radio), is the flagship station of the Bureau of Broadcast Services (BBS), also known as the Philippine Broadcasting Service (PBS), a nationwide network of 31 AM and 6 FM stations owned and operated by the Philippine government. It is based in Metro Manila but heard throughout the country.

DZRB began as KZFM, which began broadcast from Manila in 1945 right after World War II, under the US Office of War Information. Upon granting independence to the Philippines in 1946, the US government transferred KZFM to the new Philippine republic. The transfer also marked the establishment of the PBS, which then opened other radio stations throughout the country. KZFM became DZFM in 1949 following a shift in broadcast station call letters mandated by the International Telecommunications Union. PBS was renamed Bureau of Broadcast (BB) upon the declaration of martial law in 1972 by Pres Ferdinand E. Marcos while DZFM was renamed DZRB. Following the 1986 popular uprising that overthrew Marcos, commonly called EDSA Revolt, the BB was renamed the Bureau of Broadcast Services-Philippine Broadcasting Service in 1987 attached to the Office of the President through the Presidential Communications Operations Office.

Public affairs dominate DZRB’s programming, with emphasis on government activities including those of the president, Congress, and local government units. Among its news programs are Radyo ng Bayan Network Balita (Radyo ng Bayan Network News), Radyo Peryodiko (Radio Newspaper), and Patrol ng Bayan (Nation Patrol). Programs that aim to aid development are also aired, such as Maunlad na Agrikultura (Progressive Agriculture), Census Serbilis (Fast Census Services), and Ang Tipo Kong Negosyo (My Type of Business).

The Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas’ 2009 Golden Dove Awards and the 2007 Catholic Mass Media Awards recognized DZRB’s Sulyap Kultura (A Glimpse at Culture), which featured facts and figures about Philippine arts and culture, as Best Culture and Arts Program. Written byLorna Israel

text:
DZRJ/Radyo Bandido This station broadcasts at 810 kHz on the AM band from its studios in Makati City. It is operated by Rajah Broadcasting Network Inc. Founded in 1963 by Ramon Jacinto, thus the RJ in its call letters, it first aired at 780 kHz branded as Boss Radio. In the 1970s, it rebranded itself as The Rock of Manila, with the daily show Pinoy Rock ’n’ Rhythm, later shortened to Pinoy Rock, as its flagship program.

The station is credited for the popularization of the musical genre Pinoy Rock by recording and airing independent, unsigned, and unknown music artists and by hosting concerts at the J&T Building in Santa Mesa, Manila, where its studios were formerly located. Among the new artists in the 1970s who received public exposure through DZRJ were Florante, Heber Bartolome and the Banyuhay Band, Juan de la Cruz Band, Sampaguita, Mike Hanopol, Anakbayan, Maria Cafra, and the then relatively unknown Apolinario Mabini Hiking Society.

 

DZRJ played a critical part in the Feb 1986 EDSA Revolt against the Marcos dictatorship. When then defense minister Juan Ponce Enrile and Armed Forces of the Philippines vice chief of staff Fidel Ramos holed themselves up in Camp Crame along EDSA and announced in a press conference their withdrawal of support from Marcos, signaling the beginning of the revolt, Catholic prelate Jaime Cardinal Sin went live on Catholic station DZRV to rally the public to go to EDSA to support the rebels. DZRV’s transmitter was subsequently bombed, so its broadcast moved to DZRJ in Santa Mesa; DZRJ then was off the air, shut down by the military years earlier.

It identified itself as Radyo Bandido (Bandit Radio) and began broadcast with “Mambo Magsaysay,” the campaign anthem of former president Ramon Magsaysay that decried corruption and called for democracy. With Jesuit priest James Reuter’s supervision, June Keithley and several others, including Lyca Benitez-Brown, executive producer of the children’s television show Batibot (Small but Strong), film director Peque Gallaga and his wife Madie and their son, and actor Jaime Fabregas, went on a four-day marathon broadcast of updates on the developments on EDSA.

Keithley called on people to keep coming to the site and serve as human barricade against the approaching military tanks, appealed for food and water for the people keeping vigil on EDSA, and transmitted military orders from rebel officers to rebel soldiers in the field. She did not announce the location of the Radyo Bandido studio while hundreds of nuns surrounded the J&T Building to protect the broadcast. The others who assisted Keithley in the broadcast were musical director Nonong Buencamino, Teofilo Hilario, Geny Luber, Lore Reyes, Don Escudero, Mario Taguiwalo, Gerry Cerena, Kokoy and Melissa Jimenez, Maryanne Borromeo and her family, and the brothers Paolo and Gabby Mercado (Benitez-Brown 2006, 33-34; Fenix 1989, 19-20).

 

Following Marcos’s ouster, DZRJ kept the name Radyo Bandido and switched to a public service format, even as it continued to air music. In 2001, it covered the so-called EDSA II, which removed Pres Joseph Estrada from office. In 2004, it began airing news from the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) and the Voice of America (VOA). Reportage on the Philippine Basketball Association games was moved to DZRJ from DZSR in 2009, while that on the games of the University Athletic Association of the Philippines started in 2010. In 2010, it again rebranded itself as the Voice of the Philippines. It continues to carry news from BBC and VOA as well as from the daily Philippine Star, and public service and entertainment programs.

 

Its program Ngayon Na, Bayan! (Now Is the Time, People!) received the 2002 Golden Dove Award for Best Public Affairs Program for Radio in Metro Manila from the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas. Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez, Thea Claudette Castañeda, and Frances Louise M. Ronquillo

 

Sources: Arao 2010; Benitez-Brown 2006; CMFR 2011; DZRJ 810 AM 2014; Fenix 1989; GMA News Online 2012b; Wikipedia 2014h.

text:
DZRM DZRM 1278 kHz on AM is one of the radio stations owned and operated by the government agency Bureau of Broadcast Services / Philippine Broadcasting Service (BBS/PBS). Nicknamed Radyo Magasin (Radio Magazine), it broadcasts from Quezon City and is heard in Metro Manila and the provinces of Rizal, Bulacan, Pampanga, Nueva Ecija, Laguna, Bataan, Tarlac, and Mindoro.

DZRM began broadcasting in 1958 as the sister station of DZFM (later DZRB) when the latter acquired a new transmitter, allowing a new station to be born on DZFM’s old transmitter. At the time, PBS was not yet BBS/PBS. Tagged Radyo Manila (Manila Radio) in 1973 under station manager Al Cuenca, its programs tackled issues such as health, education, culture and the arts, war veterans’ welfare, community development, youth, and agriculture. In the 1980s, DZRM showcased itself as the arts and culture radio of the government to pursue one of the mandates of PBS, which was to help enhance the country’s cultural heritage. In 2000, DZRM reformatted its programming, combining the design of print with radio in the delivery of news and entertainment.

DZRM received recognition for its work, including the Most Outstanding Media Organization of the Year given by the Dangerous Drugs Board in 1984, Science and Technology Media Institutional Award given by the Department of Science and Technology in 1990 and 1992, and the Gawad para sa Natatanging Ambag sa Radyo given by the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1991. Written byLorna Israel

text:
DZRV/Radio Veritas Owned and operated by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Manila through the Global Broadcasting System, DZRV broadcasts at 846 kHz on the AM band. Its call letters stand for its brand name, Radio Veritas (Truth Radio). Broadcasting 24 hours daily from its studios in Veritas Tower on 162 West Ave corner EDSA, Quezon City, DZRV’s programming includes news, commentary, public affairs programs, and talk shows on health and other issues. Being a religious station, its slogans are “Makinig” (Listen), “Sumainyo ang katotohanan” (May the truth be with you), and “Kapanalig” (One in faith).

The history of Radio Veritas began in 1950 when the University of Santo Tomas established DZST (for Santo Tomas) as an instrument to spread the gospel. In 1961, DZST was transferred to the Philippine Radio Educational and Information Center Inc (PREIC), which was organized to manage Radio Veritas, and its call letters were changed to DZRV. PREIC, chaired by Rufino Cardinal Santos, was established as a Catholic Asian broadcasting system, with support from the Federal Republic of Germany and Australian bishops, among others. However, the station took several years to go on air due to delays in the arrival of new equipment from Germany. It finally went on test broadcast in 1968, and was inaugurated on 11 Apr 1969 with some Asian bishops in attendance, including Antonio Cardinal Samore who represented Pope Paul VI. The programming on this day included a broadcast transmission from Radio Vatican, relaying the message of Pope Paul VI. When the pope visited the Philippines the following year, he blessed DZRV’s studios, then located in Pope Pius XII Center along United Nations Ave. It broadcast both on the AM band and on shortwave for overseas broadcast. Its studios later moved to Fairview Park, Quezon City.

In 1973, following the death of Cardinal Santos, the station suffered financial difficulties, which forced it to reduce programming hours. The new archbishop of Manila, Jaime Cardinal Sin, then changed its management, acquired new equipment, recruited a new staff, and developed a new format. The station recovered and in 1975 it was back on air for 18 hours a day. It also changed its call letters to DWRV. It shed off its image as an elite station and assumed a mass-oriented personality, with programs appealing to the poor, rural listeners, and laborers. Without abandoning classical music, it began to air Filipino music. Trying to combine religion and education that appealed to the masses, the station enlisted famous cinema, radio, and television stars such as Tiya Dely Magpayo, Boots Anson-Roa, Bert “Tawa” Marcelo, Matutina, and Nova Villa. Veteran commercial radio broadcaster Orly Punzalan was hired as program consultant to restructure the station. Soap operas then became part of programming, conveying religious and social messages, such as Serviam (Latin for “I will serve,” the motto of Cardinal Sin), Nasaan (Where), Buhay Pa si Pilato (Pilate Is Still Alive), and Mariang Eba (Mary Eve).

Radio Veritas is best remembered by the public for its key role in major political events in the 1980s. The assassination of Sen Benigno Aquino Jr on 21 Aug 1983 signaled the station to take a critical stance toward the martial rule of Pres Ferdinand Marcos. Radio Veritas was the only broadcast station that covered the entire 12-hour funeral procession that brought Aquino’s body from the Santo Domingo Church in Quezon City to the Manila Memorial Park in Parañaque, with an estimated two million people in the procession and lining the streets. Radio stations, including Radio Veritas, then became bolder in their political commentary in the following months. However, it was only Radio Veritas that, at first, covered the tabulations made by the National Citizens’ Movement for Free Elections (Namfrel) when Marcos called for a snap presidential election on 7 Feb 1986. Namfrel’s count challenged that of the Commission on Elections. The latter proclaimed Marcos reelected. This meant Aquino’s widow, Corazon, was defeated, which the public doubted. Because of reports of alleged fraud, Cebu Archbishop Ricardo Cardinal Vidal issued a statement on behalf of the Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines condemning the elections.

Two weeks later, on Saturday, 22 Feb 1986, the historic EDSA Revolt began. Defense MinisterJuan Ponce Enrileand Armed Forces of the Philippines Vice Chief of Staff and Philippine Constabulary Chief Fidel V. Ramos announced in a press conference their withdrawal of support from Marcos. Enrile asked Radio Veritas to cover the announcement as he holed himself up in Camp Aguinaldo across Camp Crame on EDSA. The public then heard Cardinal Sin calling people on the air via Radio Veritas to go to EDSA to protect Enrile and Ramos. The effect was almost immediate; people began to go to EDSA that afternoon and by nightfall a siege was underway. Only Radio Veritas was covering the event live. Not one of the other television and radio stations broke regular programming to announce the unfolding revolt.

The following day, Sunday, 23 Feb 1986, the station’s transmitter was bombed, presumably by Marcos partisans. Jesuit priest James Reuter and June Keithley, who was in the anchor pool of Radio Veritas, went to DZRH in Makati to request for airtime. DZRH, which had just aired Marcos’s press conference where he declared that he was in control of the situation, declined. After considering DZFE in Bulacan, Reuter and Keithley went to DZRJ on Santa Mesa, Manila, just a few blocks from Malacañan. DZRJ, then off the air as it was shut down by the military years earlier, was the perfect choice. DZRV’s frequency of 810 kHz on the AM band was next to DZRV’s 846 kHz. Enrile’s staff, Col Ruben Ciron, a broadcaster, shifted the DZRJ frequency to 840 kHz, as close as possible to the DZRV frequency, so people would find it on the dial more easily. Keithley then called children’s television show Batibot (Small but Strong) executive producer Lyca Benitez-Brown for help. Benitez-Brown in turn called colleagues and friends to help her and Keithley with the broadcast. Among them were Benitez-Brown’s husband; film director Peque Gallaga, his wife Madie, and their son; actor Jaime Fabregas; musical director Nonong Buencamino; Teofilo Hilario; Geny Luber; Lore Reyes; Don Escudero; Mario Taguiwalo; Gerry Cerena; Kokoy and Melissa Jimenez; Maryanne Borromeo and her family; the brothers Paolo and Gabby Mercado; and several others.

Benitez-Brown named the station Radyo Bandido, a spin-off from Radyo Batibot (Batibot Radio), the radio version of the television show Batibot. She also called her mother, Conchita L. Benitez, to call the Assumption nuns through Cardinal Sin to guard the hastily organized volunteer staff of Radyo Bandido. Hundreds of Assumption nuns, who were the only ones not yet on EDSA, came and sat on the steps leading to the radio studio at the top floor of the eight-story J&T Building to protect the broadcast. With Keithley as anchor, the volunteers handled the telephones and two-way radios and verified and wrote stories that came in. Without disclosing the station’s location, Radyo Bandido broadcast updates on the developments on EDSA and called on people to keep coming to the site, appealed for food and water for the people keeping vigil on EDSA, and transmitted military orders from rebel officers to rebel soldiers in the field. The four-day demonstration swelled up to an estimated three million people, who blocked the movement of army tanks still loyal to Marcos.

Defections from Marcos to the rebels followed. On the third day of the revolt, Monday, 24 Feb 1986, rebels captured the government television station Channel 4. Soon, other stations fell to the rebels. By this time, the rest of the broadcast world had been emboldened by the events and had begun to cover EDSA. The rest of the nation was listening, with provincial stations hooked up to Radyo Bandido / Radio Veritas, and then to other stations as well. The following day, Tuesday, 25 Feb 1986, Marcos and his family left the country.

In Jan 2001, Cardinal Sin again called on the people via Radio Veritas to once again rebel against a president, this time Joseph Estrada, following accusations of massive corruption. Estrada left Malacañan and his vice president Gloria Macapagal Arroyo succeeded him. Radio Veritas changed its call letters to DZNN in 1991 and became a commercial station, but reverted to DZRV and its current format before the 2001 EDSA Revolt.

On 26 Mar 1986, the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) recognized Radio Veritas and its staff for their reporting of events on EDSA. Among those honored were overseas program manager Harry Gasser, domestic program manager Orly Punzalan, announcer priests Laureano Faraon and Efren Dato, and June Keithley. In the same year, Radio Veritas received the Ramon Magsaysay Award for Journalism, Literature and Creative Communication Arts.

In 2007, its drama program Huwag Mangamba (Have No Fear) won Best Drama Program at the 29th CMMA. DJ priest Nono Alfonso was declared Best Music Radio Jock at the 18th Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) Golden Dove Awards in 2009. At the 22nd KBP Golden Dove Awards in 2014, the station won the Best Radio Public Service Announcement award for its entry titled Karapatan Mo ang Bumoto (It Is Your Right to Vote). Written byElizabeth L. Enriquez, with notes from Yna Marei Aguilar

Jesuit priest James Reuter and June Keithley, who was in the anchor pool of Radio Veritas, went to DZRH in Makati to request for airtime. DZRH, which had just aired Marcos’s press conference where he declared that he was in control of the situation, declined. After considering DZFE in Bulacan, Reuter and Keithley went to DZRJ on Santa Mesa, Manila, just a few blocks from Malacañan. DZRJ, then off the air as it was shut down by the military years earlier, was the perfect choice. DZRV’s frequency of 810 kHz on the AM band was next to DZRV’s 846 kHz. Enrile’s staff, Col Ruben Ciron, a broadcaster, shifted the DZRJ frequency to 840 kHz, as close as possible to the DZRV frequency, so people would find it on the dial more easily. Keithley then called children’s television show Batibot (Small but Strong) executive producer Lyca Benitez-Brown for help. Benitez-Brown in turn called colleagues and friends to help her and Keithley with the broadcast. Among them were Benitez-Brown’s husband; film director Peque Gallaga, his wife Madie, and their son; actor Jaime Fabregas; musical director Nonong Buencamino; Teofilo Hilario; Geny Luber; Lore Reyes; Don Escudero; Mario Taguiwalo; Gerry Cerena; Kokoy and Melissa Jimenez; Maryanne Borromeo and her family; the brothers Paolo and Gabby Mercado; and several others.

Benitez-Brown named the station Radyo Bandido, a spin-off from Radyo Batibot (Batibot Radio), the radio version of the television show Batibot. She also called her mother, Conchita L. Benitez, to call the Assumption nuns through Cardinal Sin to guard the hastily organized volunteer staff of Radyo Bandido. Hundreds of Assumption nuns, who were the only ones not yet on EDSA, came and sat on the steps leading to the radio studio at the top floor of the eight-story J&T Building to protect the broadcast. With Keithley as anchor, the volunteers handled the telephones and two-way radios and verified and wrote stories that came in. Without disclosing the station’s location, Radyo Bandido broadcast updates on the developments on EDSA and called on people to keep coming to the site, appealed for food and water for the people keeping vigil on EDSA, and transmitted military orders from rebel officers to rebel soldiers in the field. The four-day demonstration swelled up to an estimated three million people, who blocked the movement of army tanks still loyal to Marcos.

Defections from Marcos to the rebels followed. On the third day of the revolt, Monday, 24 Feb 1986, rebels captured the government television station Channel 4. Soon, other stations fell to the rebels. By this time, the rest of the broadcast world had been emboldened by the events and had begun to cover EDSA. The rest of the nation was listening, with provincial stations hooked up to Radyo Bandido / Radio Veritas, and then to other stations as well. The following day, Tuesday, 25 Feb 1986, Marcos and his family left the country.

In Jan 2001, Cardinal Sin again called on the people via Radio Veritas to once again rebel against a president, this time Joseph Estrada, following accusations of massive corruption. Estrada left Malacañan and his vice president Gloria Macapagal Arroyo succeeded him. Radio Veritas changed its call letters to DZNN in 1991 and became a commercial station, but reverted to DZRV and its current format before the 2001 EDSA Revolt.

On 26 Mar 1986, the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) recognized Radio Veritas and its staff for their reporting of events on EDSA. Among those honored were overseas program manager Harry Gasser, domestic program manager Orly Punzalan, announcer priests Laureano Faraon and Efren Dato, and June Keithley. In the same year, Radio Veritas received the Ramon Magsaysay Award for Journalism, Literature and Creative Communication Arts.

In 2007, its drama program Huwag Mangamba (Have No Fear) won Best Drama Program at the 29th CMMA. DJ priest Nono Alfonso was declared Best Music Radio Jock at the 18th Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) Golden Dove Awards in 2009. At the 22nd KBP Golden Dove Awards in 2014, the station won the Best Radio Public Service Announcement award for its entry titled Karapatan Mo ang Bumoto (It Is Your Right to Vote). DZSR Owned and operated by the government network Philippine Broadcasting Service, DZSR is the only radio station of its kind in Southeast Asia. Nicknamed Sports Radio, it promotes the development of Filipino athletes by covering sporting events such as the Palarong Pambansa, the Southeast Asian Games, the Asian Games, and the Olympic Games. Its program Radyo PBA (PBA Radio) covers the games of the Philippine Basketball Association, which is simulcast on eight government provincial AM stations under the Radyo ng Bayan group and on five FM stations under the Radyo5 network. It is also the official station of the Philippine Basketball League.

DZSR broadcasts at 918 kHz on the AM band daily from 6:00 am to 10:00 pm from its studios at the Philippine Information Agency on Visayas Ave in Diliman, Quezon City. It also reaches listeners worldwide through online streaming services. Written byDivine Marie Joanne P. Endriga

text:
DZUP The official radio station of the University of the Philippines (UP), DZUP broadcasts on the AM band at 1602 kHz and operates from UP’s flagship campus in Diliman, Quezon City. With the tag line “Matinong usapan para sa maunlad na bayan, sa DZUP… kasali ka!” (Rational discourse for a progressive nation, at DZUP… you are involved!), it serves both as a community radio and a laboratory of the Department of Broadcast Communication in the College of Mass Communication (CMC).

Initially established as an engineering laboratory in 1957, DZUP first went on the air on 2 Dec 1958 from the College of Engineering (COE), with programming by the Department of Speech and Drama (DSD) of the then College of Liberal Arts, on the frequency 1580 kHz. The following year, 1959, DZUP’s management was turned over to the DSD but the technical component remained with the COE. In 1960, DZUP also aired on the shortwave band, its signal reaching Indonesia, Tokyo, Japan, India, USA, and England. In 1962, DZUP increased its transmitting power from 500 watts to 1,000 watts at a lower frequency of 1410 kHz. Its studio was transferred to Palma Hall, then the College of Arts and Sciences, while its transmitter remained at COE.

In the 1960s, DZUP’s programming was a mix of entertainment and public service, with music, poetry reading, book reviews, roundtable discussions, news analysis, and coverage of UP’s important events and speeches by national leaders. At the height of student activism around 1970, it was taken over by activist students and faculty, calling it the Voice of Dissent as the growing unrest against the Marcos regime built up. The station became a platform for commentary and group discussions on national issues, reading of manifestos, and critical news analysis. Nationalistic and patriotic songs played on air. On 1 Feb 1971, the dissenters barricaded the campus as the police tried to enter the university. The standoff, which lasted nine days, came to be known as the Diliman Commune. In spite of its weak signal and frequent signal interferences, audiences listened to DZUP. When martial law was declared, the military destroyed its studios and transmitter.

In 1974, with martial rule still in effect, the National Telecommunications Commission (NTC) gave permission to DZUP to go back on air, sharing a frequency on 1566 kHz with DZAF, the radio station of the Armed Forces of the Philippines. Its studio was transferred in 1984 to the UP Information Office in Quezon Hall. In 1987, it was moved to then Institute of Mass Communication (IMC, later CMC), upon the initiative of Dean Georgina Encanto, who intended DZUP as a laboratory of IMC students as well as to bring programs to the rest of the university and adjacent communities. In the same year, the NTC allocated to it the frequency 1602 kHz. However, the station suffered from technical and financial setbacks, causing limited airtime and programming, which consisted mainly of student-produced shows.

In 2007, a year before the centennial of the university, UP Diliman Chancellor Sergio Cao raised funds that bought DZUP a new, more powerful transmitter, a new tower, and new studio equipment. After test broadcasts in 2009, its new programming went on the air in 2010. From a limited five hours airtime, DZUP aired for eight hours, and later for 14 hours, from 6:00 am to 8:00 pm. Student interns continue to train at DZUP but its programming is now produced by a full staff of professional broadcasters, including faculty of CMC and other colleges of UP Diliman and UP Manila. Among its programs are Radyo Iskool (Radio School), whose curriculum-based lectures are integrated into the syllabus of certain courses, and the student intern program Boses ng Estudyante (Student Voice). In 2015, DZUP began to also broadcast online, streaming live at www.dzup.org.

DZUP’s first recognition came in 1969 when it received the Catholic Mass Media Award for Best Musical Programming. Some of its programs received awards, including That’s Entreptainment (a combination of “entrepreneur” and “entertainment”), Best Business News Feature, 2011 Catholic Mass Media Awards; Tunog at Titik (Sound and Letter), Special Citation for Best Entertainment, 2011 Catholic Mass Media Awards; Health Matters, 2014 Hildegarde Award for Outstanding Achievement in Broadcast Media; and Tropang Rad’yo (Radio Troupe), Best Special Program, 2015 Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas Golden Dove Awards. Written byRosa Maria T. Feliciano

Sources: David 1982; Feliciano, n.d.; Lazaro 1989; Mendoza 1993; Parto and Umali 2000; Uyanguren 2015
