Eagle Broadcasting Corporation (EBC) Eagle Broadcasting Corporation is a network of radio, television, cable TV, and web-based news services owned and operated by the Iglesia ni Cristo (INC) through its key members. Founded on 17 Jun 1967, it operates from its own building complex on 25 Central Ave, Diliman, Quezon City. On 26 Apr 1968, its first radio station, DZEC, went on the air at 1062 kHz on the AM band, from its first studio in Delta Building on the corner of Quezon Blvd and West Ave. With Tagalog as its language medium, it had a format of news, public affairs, and music. In 1971, it acquired a second AM station, DZBU. However, it was short-lived. When all media outfits closed by the government upon the declaration of martial law by Pres Ferdinand Marcos reopened, DZBU remained off the air while DZEC resumed broadcast. EBC then moved its studios to Maligaya Building on 882 EDSA, Quezon City. With signals originating from Manila, DZEC’s programs are relayed throughout the country through DWIN 1080 kHz in Dagupan, DZEL 1260 kHz in Lucena, DYFX 1332 kHz in Cebu, and DXED 1224 kHz in Davao, all branded as Radyo Agila (Eagle Radio).

In 1987, with a new Philippine Constitution following the ouster of Marcos in 1986, the government gave EBC a franchise to run a second station, DWDM at 95.5 MHz on the FM band. The station ceased broadcast in 2007 for an equipment upgrade, then returned in 2011 with the brand Pinas FM 95.5. Its format is devoted to original music from Filipino artists and talents. Like DZEC, it streams live online.

In the 1990s, the network laid the groundwork for television broadcasting. On 23 Apr 2000, EBC launched station Net 25 on the UHF television band, with a powerful 120-kilowatt transmitter and state-of-the-art television technology. Its programs include imported canned shows on technology and science as well as news and lifestyle and entertainment shows. Apart from Net 25 in Manila, the station airs nationwide through Channel 46 in Baguio, Channel 41 in Cebu, and Channel 39 in Davao. While webstreaming, it is also transmitted via cable throughout the country and via satellite around the world, with partner agencies in the USA, Europe, the Middle East, and Northeast Asia.

In 2013, EBC launched the web-based Eagle News Service, with correspondents in different parts of the world, such as Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany, France, Switzerland, Spain, Italy, Canada, United States, Japan, and Dubai, filing news stories in audio and video formats. Accessible at eaglenews.ph, the site also streams the signals of the network’s stations.

Though run commercially, EBC reflects the doctrine and beliefs of the Iglesia ni Cristo, its owners being members of the said church. Net 25’s programming includes the religious program Ang Tamang Daan (The Right Path) and other INC-produced evangelical programs. The INC’s political inclinations are also apparent on EBC. In Apr 2001, Net 25 was the only television station that covered live the pro-Estrada rallies of support for ousted president Joseph Estrada, whom the INC backed. This coverage was followed by the airing of news and public affairs programs Agila Reports (Eagle Reports) and Liwanagin Natin (Let Us Explain). It also then tried but later abandoned the teleradyo (television-radio) format with DZEC.

DZEC received the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) Golden Dove Award for Best Children’s Program for EC Ka Lang Bata (Take It Easy Kid) in 1996 and Best Comedy Program for Sic O’Clock Na (It’s Already Six O’Clock) in 1996. The 2011 KBP Golden Dove Award for Best Culture and Arts Program was given to Net 25’s Landmarks and to Janice de Belen as Best Magazine Program Host. The station also received the 2012 KBP Golden Dove Award for Best TV and Science and Technology Program for Convergence.Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez and Lucia Isabel G. Macaventa

Sources: Eagle Broadcasting 2014; Wikipedia 2015b, 2015c, 2015h.

FERNANDEZ, LUZ (Luzviminda Arafiles Fernandez Gaspar) b. Manila 13 Jul 1935. Radio talent and radio drama director, television and movie actor. She is the fourth of eight children of Antonio Fernandez and Gabriela Arafiles. She married Leoncio Gaspar with whom she has three children. She attended Victorino Mapa High School in Manila.

 

Fernandez won second place in a DZFM-sponsored drama contest while she was a high school sophomore. Then, at age 16 in 1951, she began bit parts in several radio dramas, including the role of a mother in the soap Imelda on DZBB. A year later producer Ben Pangan picked her as Rosa Mia’s replacement in the DZRH drama Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), followed by assignments in numerous programs such as Camay Theatre of the Air and Kahapon Lamang (Only Yesterday). She was often cast as the villainess in radio soaps, including Flordeluna and Sagrado (Sacred). Her other radio programs in DZRH are Ukay-Ukay ni Manang Kikay (Sister Kikay’s Thrift Shop), Sa Kanyang Panahon (In His Time), and May Pangako ang Bukas (The Promise of Tomorrow). Fernandez also directs the program Mr. Romantiko (Mr. Romantic), the second longest running drama of the station.

 

She crossed over to television in the late 1950s appearing in such programs as Dr. Eduardo Roman, MD and Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror). She played Lola Torya, the grandmother-narrator of the fantasy anthology Ora Engkantanda (Enchanted Hour) aired on IBC 13 in the 1970s. In 1987 she was cast as the evil queen Luka in IBC 13’s Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!). She appeared in numerous TV dramas on ABS-CBN, including the primetime drama series Forevermore as well as in various episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) and Komiks (Comics). On GMA, she was a grieving grandmother in I Heart You Pare (I Love You Dude) and Gawas in Amaya, 2011; Madam Concha in My Beloved, 2012; and Belenita Fuentebella in Innamorata, 2014. She also appeared in several episodes of the drama anthology Magpakailanman (Forever), 2014-15.

 

Fernandez also starred in several movies, including Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once There was a Moth), 1976; Ang Pagbabalik ni Leon Guerrero (The Return of Leon Guerrerro), 1980; Sinasamba Kita (I Worship You) and Mga Uod at Rosas (Of Worms and Roses), 1982; Feng Shui, 2004; and Ang Darling Kong Aswang (My Darling Ghost), 2009. On stage she played Lola Basyang in Ballet Manila ’s Tatlong Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Three Stories from Grandmother Basyang), 2008, and Tatlo Pang Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Three More Stories from Grandmother Basyang), 2013. Written by Lucia Isabel G. Macaventa, with additional notes from Elmer L. Gatchalian

FERNANDO, ADING (Fernando Marquez Fernando) b. Manila. d. 1983. Radio, television, film director, writer, actor, singer. His parents were Amado Fernando and Carmen Marquez. He was the younger brother of singer and actor Adelaida Fernando-Villegas aka Dely Atay-atayan.

Fernando started as a musician in the 1950s, an excellent whistler, singer, and bass fiddle player. He was the bassist of a band playing at a cocktail party on 23 Oct 1953, which marked the first day that Alto Broadcasting System (ABS) covered an event on television.

He wrote several hit radio weekly comedy variety shows in the 1960s, which included Tuloy ang Ligaya (On with the Fun), Kulang sa Pito (Lacks a Whistle), with co-writer Eddie Ilagan, and The Big Show on DZRH; Harana ni Ruben Tagalog (Serenade of Ruben Tagalog) on DZFM; and Praybeyt Ditektib (Private Detective). Regular comedy sketch performers in Kulang sa Pito were Dolphy, Panchito, Teloy Cosme, Rick Gutierrez, and Tina Loy. The Big Show was later adapted to television as a daily noontime show on MBC Channel 11, which became highly popular.

In 1963, ABS Channel 3 adapted to television Fernando’s radio programs and were given new titles. Kulang sa Pito became Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life), where Dolphy and Panchito first appeared on TV. The Big Show, which the network got from MBC 11 by pirating the show’s stars Sylvia La Torre and Oscar Obligacion, was renamed The Best Show, 1964, which soon became Oras ng Ligaya, 1965. The new The Big Show on ABS was the first directorial job of Fernando on TV. It had new mainstays like Chichay and Fernando himself, who was also the program’s writer.

Oras ng Ligaya’s main attraction was the comedy sketches, conceived by Fernando only minutes before airtime. He simply explained the comic situations to the cast, who had no scripts to rely on but their individual acting ability, talent on doing adlibs and improvisations, and the confidence an actor places on each of the group members, who had worked together on the stage as bodabil actors before they went into television. According to writer Raul Rodrigo, “all the lines were made up on the fly by a skilled veteran vaudeville troupe that knew each other’s moves down to the last microsecond of comic timing.”

FLOIRENDO, MARISSA (Marissa del Rosario Floirendo) b. Manila 24 Oct 1959. Videographer, director of photography, editor, production designer, lighting director. She is fourth among six children of Davao banana plantation magnate Antonio Ocampo Floirendo and Nenita del Rosario Floirendo. Her brother, former Davao del Norte representative Antonio “Tonyboy” Floirendo Jr, is married to 1973 Miss Universe Margarita Moran. She spent her preschool in Ateneo de Davao in the 1960s and finished her elementary studies at Assumption College in the early 1970s. She moved to England in 1972 and completed her general certificate of education, ordinary and advanced levels, in the Convent of the Sacred Heart around 1978. She studied fine arts and design at the Byam Shaw School of Art from 1978 to 1982 where she was trained in mixed-media arts, combining painting, sculpture, film, music, and poetry in art installations. She pursued studies in directing and photography at the Parsons School of Design in New York from 1982 to 1984 and completed a bachelor’s degree in film studies at New York University in 1987. She is considered the first female underwater cinematographer and videographer in the country and is a member of the Filipino Society of Cinematographers. She founded The Blue Team, an underwater dive film crew unit specializing in different types of underwater shooting, in 1996.

Her earliest works on television were on RPN 9, editing the family drama series Cebu, 1991, directed by Peque Gallaga, Lore Reyes, and Don Escudero, and producing some episodes of the weekly legal drama anthology Ipaglaban Mo (Fight for It), 1992. She did the underwater photography of the daily fantasy drama Majika (Magic), 2006, the fantasy series Atlantika, 2006-7, the Filipino adaptation of the Mexican telenovela Marimar, 2007-8, the TV adaptation of Mars Ravelo’s comic book story Dyesebel, 2008, all on GMA; and Dyesebel, 2014, on ABS-CBN. In broadcast documentaries, she did the photography and underwater videography of Mindanao Now, Cheche Lazaro Presents, The Probe Team, Game Plan, Sports Unlimited, Born to Be Wild, and a few sequences of Shark Week, 2014, on Discovery Channel. She was involved in video projects about the environment produced by the BBC Palins Pacific Documentary, 1996, and UNESCO, 1997.

She directed the weekly drama anthology Pira-pirasong Pangarap (Broken Dreams), 2002, Halik sa Dagat (Kiss at Sea), 2002, and Narito ang Puso Ko (Here Is my Heart), 2003, all on GMA. She served as the director of photography of the music videos for Jaya, 1998, Rachel Alejandro, 2000, and Ivy Violan, 2001.

Some films for which she did the underwater photography are Peque Gallaga’s Abandonada (Abandoned), 1989, and Shake, Rattle & Roll 3, 1991; Emmanuel H. Borlaza’s Dyesebel, 1996; Marilou Diaz-Abaya’s Sa Pusod ng Dagat (In the Navel of the Sea), 1997, and Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 1999; Jeffrey Jeturian’s Minsan Pa (One Moment More), 2004; Dante Nico Garcia’s Ploning, 2008; and Star Cinema’s You Light Up My Life, 2011. She was the film cinematographer of Peque Gallaga’s Darna, 1994; Rowell Santiago’s Forever, 1994; Rory B. Quintos’s Mangarap Ka (Dream On) and Basta’t Kasama Kita (As Long as I’m with You), both in 1995; Jose Javier Reyes’s Maruja, 1995; Carlos Siguion-Reyna’s Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin (They Call Me Joy), 1996; Lupita Aquino-Kashiwahara’s Babae (Woman), 1997; Mike Tuviera’s The Promise, 2007; Joyce Bernal’s 10,000 Hours, 2013; and Mike Tuviera’s The Janitor, 2014.

She shot parts of the underwater cinematography or was part of the cinematography department of foreign films, such as Luca Bercovici’s Dark Tide, 1993; Jonathan Kaplan’s Brokedown Palace, 1998; James D. R. Hickox’s Blood Surf (aka Krocodylus), 2000, and Hideki Yamasaki’s Chateau de Roses (Château of Roses), 2004.

Her earlier works in film were as an assistant editor in Lino Brocka’s Orapronobis (Fight for Us), 1989, and as a production assistant for the films of Gallaga, such as Hiwaga sa Balete Drive (Mystery on Balete Drive), 1987; Tiyanak (Goblin), 1989; Isang Araw Walang Diyos (One Day without God), 1989; Shake, Rattle & Roll 4, 1992; and Aswang (Viscera Sucker), 1992.

In advertising, some television commercials and promotional materials in which she served as director of photography are NU 107’s Hip TV, Cool TV, and Cutting Edge, all in 2000; the Beer na Beer ads, 2000; Kamiseta’s Florence, 2001; Globe Telecom’s Diyes (Ten), 2001, and Moments, 2002; Caltex’s What Drives You, 2001; Asia Dot’s Dash, 2002; Pioneer Epoxy’s Dog Chain and Rhythm & Hues, both in 2002; Petite Monde’s My Life, My Petite, 2002, Summer Pictorial, 2003, and Hong Kong, 2004; Shangri-La Hotel’s Swoosh, 2003; Pepsi Cola’s Waves of Echo, 2004; and Milo’s Surfer. She was the production designer of the video commercials of Lux.

Floirendo won the Gold Award for Best Production Design at the 11th Philippine Advertising Congress, 1992, for her Lux commercials. The film Muro-ami won for her and co-cinematographers Rody Lacap and Manolo Abaya Best Cinematography in the 1999 Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) and at the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards, 2000. She received the Kodak Vision Award for Technical Excellence in Cinematography in 2001 and 2002. Her work in 10,000 Hours won Best Cinematography in the 2013 MMFF.Written by Dean Airo Salvador E. Dancel, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

Sources: ABS-CBN.com 2014a; Floirendo 2014a, 2014b; Gotico 1996; Kodak 2014.

FLOR, LINA (Carolina Chanco Flores-Trinidad) b. Caloocan, Rizal 6 Oct 1914. d. 11 Feb 1976. Radio soap scriptwriter, voice talent, singer, film actor, columnist, bilingual fictionist, biographer, lyricist, cartoonist, teacher. Her parents were Fernando Flores, a poet and journalist in Spanish and Tagalog, and Silvina Chanco, a sister of the well-known novelist and translator Gerardo Chanco. Her brother Virgilio “Beer” Flores was a television scriptwriter while sister Loida is a radio voice actor and a writer of radio, television, and film scripts. She was married to Francisco “Koko” Trinidad, one of the pioneers of Philippine broadcasting. Among their four children are comedian Noel Trinidad and editorial cartoonist and comic strip artist Francisco “Corky” Flores Trinidad Jr. She attended Rizal Elementary School, Manila North School (now Arellano High School), and Malabon Normal School (now Saint James Academy) where she completed secondary education.

 

Barely out of high school in the early 1930s, Flor hosted a morning program on KZIB with her distant cousin Ding Yalong, who just won the title Bing Crosby of the Philippines. In 1934, she transferred to KZRM where she sang in the morning program Sunrise Club with Cecilio Lloyd, aka The Mystery Singer Cecil Lloyd, and in the evening program Klim Dancing Party with the Three Ramons—Ramon Escudero, Ramon Estella, and Ramon Alberto. In 1935, while carrying the nickname Little Lark, Flor won the title Miss Radio KZRM. At around the same time, she started writing her first magazine column, the first column on radio, Ye Music Lovers’ Nook, for Graphic, which featured letters from radio fans; radio talents such as Ramon Escudero, Ramon Navales, Luz Mat. Castro, Carmen Rosales, and Francisco “Koko” Trinidad; and news about the radio industry. Soon, she also became KZRM’s publicity manager. Then, she shortened her radio name from Carolina Flores to Lina Flor.

 

Her first in a series of landmark radio programs was the pre-World War II radio show Si Aling Juanang Mapag-impok (The Thrifty Madam Juana), which she wrote and hosted as the character Aling Juana from 1938 to 1940 on KZRM. The show included short dramas, advice to listeners who wrote letters seeking guidance, and discussions on domestic matters and proper behavior. With a fresh format that attracted listeners and, thus, advertisers, the program later became the model for postwar radio soaps and advice programs.

 

Flor briefly worked for the Japanese-controlled KZRH in the early part of World War II, writing skits in Tagalog. She wrote mostly in English before the war but shifted to Tagalog in compliance with the cultural policy of the Japanese that declared Tagalog, along with Nihongo, as the official language of the country, while English was restricted. This was a turning point for Flor as a writer. She joined Juan C. Laya, N. V. M. Gonzalez, Francisco Arcellana, Paz Latorena, and Maria Luna-Lopez, among other writers who had been using English, in Tagalog classes conducted by Lope K. Santos. Flor published several Tagalog short stories in Liwayway in 1943 and contributed several essays to the Pillar, a monthly bilingual magazine founded by the Japanese.

 

After the war, Flor wrote two of the most successful radio dramas on Philippine radio, Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate) and Dr. Ramon Selga. Along with the soap Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home) written by Liwayway Arceo, Gulong ng Palad began airing in 1949 on DZRH as one of the first soap operas on Philippine radio. Until its final production in 1956, the daily 15-minute drama fascinated listeners with the conflicts and trials experienced by its characters, who mirrored the lives of ordinary people. In 1950, Premiere Productions produced the film of the same title based on the radio program. It became the blockbuster of the year.

 

In the meantime, Dr. Ramon Selga aired in 1950 on DZMB until at least 1953. It is credited with antedating American radio and television dramas situated in hospitals or a medical setting. Flor’s lesser known soaps include Binhi ng Buhay (Seeds of Life), aired over the Japanese-controlled PIAM during World War II, and Sining ng Buhay (Art of Life) on postwar DZFM, the first radio station of the government network Philippine Broadcasting Service.

 

Flor appeared in stage plays, including Dear Brutus, Forbidden Fruit, and Suppressed Desire, in the mid-1930s and in the film Kundiman ng Puso (Love Song of the Heart) in 1937 but her father stopped short her acting career. A prolific artist, she turned not only to hosting radio programs and writing radio scripts and magazine columns but also to comic strip drawing, commercial jingle lyric writing, and literary composition in both English and Tagalog. Three of her short stories, “Big Sister,” “Family Album,” and “Grandmother Muses,” all published in 1934, were included in the annual honor roll of Jose Garcia Villa. Throughout the 1950s until the 1970s, she wrote columns and literary pieces for the Daily Mirror, the Manila Times, Herald Magazine, Sunday Times Magazine, This Week, Kislap-Graphic, Weekly Woman’s Magazine, Woman’s Home Companion, Liwayway, Sinag-tala, Daigdig, Ilang-ilang, and the Philippines Free Press. She also published numerous essays, novels, and biographies, including Mrs. Luz Banzon Magsaysay: Constant Light, 1958; Sparklers for the Day, 1972; and Dilettante, 1973. An anthology of her works in various genres is in Lina Flor: Collected Works, 2001, edited by Soledad Reyes.

 

When martial law was declared in 1972 and publications were shut down, Flores turned to writing for television. She penned scripts for the musical program Aawitan Kita (I Shall Sing for You) and for the situation comedy Problema Mo Na ’Yan (That’s Your Problem). She also found time to conduct writing classes at the Children’s Museum and Library Inc. Her last publication before she died was her first and only book of poetry, Dilettante, 1973.

 

In 1950, the National Federation of Women’s Clubs named Flor one of the 20 Outstanding Women in Various Fields of Endeavor (Reyes 2000). Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez, Soledad S. Reyes, and Dean Airo Salvador E. Dancel

 

Sources:

 

Abunda 2010; Aniceto 2007; ALIWW 2014; Enriquez 2008a; Mapa 2014; Mella 1974; Mercado 2009; Philippine News Agency 2011; Reyes 2000, 2004.

Three of her short stories, “Big Sister,” “Family Album,” and “Grandmother Muses,” all published in 1934, were included in the annual honor roll of Jose Garcia Villa. Throughout the 1950s until the 1970s, she wrote columns and literary pieces for the Daily Mirror, the Manila Times, Herald Magazine, Sunday Times Magazine, This Week, Kislap-Graphic, Weekly Woman’s Magazine, Woman’s Home Companion, Liwayway, Sinag-tala, Daigdig, Ilang-ilang, and the Philippines Free Press. She also published numerous essays, novels, and biographies, including Mrs. Luz Banzon Magsaysay: Constant Light, 1958; Sparklers for the Day, 1972; and Dilettante, 1973. An anthology of her works in various genres is in Lina Flor: Collected Works, 2001, edited by Soledad Reyes.

When martial law was declared in 1972 and publications were shut down, Flores turned to writing for television. She penned scripts for the musical program Aawitan Kita (I Shall Sing for You) and for the situation comedy Problema Mo Na ’Yan (That’s Your Problem). She also found time to conduct writing classes at the Children’s Museum and Library Inc. Her last publication before she died was her first and only book of poetry, Dilettante, 1973.

In 1950, the National Federation of Women’s Clubs named Flor one of the 20 Outstanding Women in Various Fields of Endeavor (Reyes 2000). Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez, Soledad S. Reyes, and Dean Airo Salvador E. Dancel

FLORES, MARISSA L. (Marissa La Torre Flores) b. Quezon City 25 Apr 1964. TV network senior vice president, broadcast producer and manager. Her parents are Jose R. Flores and Susan La Torre. She comes from a family of broadcast and film artists. Her maternal grandfather was movie director Olimpio “Olive” La Torre whose films in the 1950s were Roberta and Dalagang Ilocana (Ilocano Maiden). Her maternal grandmother, Leonora Reyes, was a kundiman (love song) and opera singer. Her mother was a radio and TV performer in shows such as Operetang Putol-Putol, Operetang Tagpi-tagpi (Disjointed and Patched Up Operetta). Her mother’s sister is singer and actor Sylvia La Torre. Her uncles Roger and George La Torre were performers in Las Vegas. Cousins who were in show business are former child actor Che-che Perez de Tagle and actor/TV performer Artie Perez de Tagle. Her niece Anna Maria Perez de Tagle is a US-based singer and actor.

 

Flores finished elementary and secondary education at St. Scholastica’s Academy, Marikina City. She completed her journalism degree in 1985 at the University of the Philippines, Diliman, Quezon City. In the next three years after college, she worked as production assistant, writer, and researcher for foreign press and news organizations in Manila. In 1987, she joined the News and Public Affairs department of GMA Channel 7 and rose from the position of production assistant to executive producer. Her appointment as program manager in 1990 began her ascent on the corporate ladder. In the mid-2000s, she became the senior vice president of GMA Network’s News and Public Affairs and executive vice president for GMA News Online. She is also a member of the board of trustees of GMA Kapuso Foundation.

 

Under her management, GMA Channels 7 and 11 created successful shows. News programs include 24 Oras (24 Hours), Saksi (Witness), State of the Nation with Jessica Soho, and News to Go. Some long-running public affairs shows are Kapuso Mo, Jessica Soho (One with You at Heart, Jessica Soho), Imbestigador (Investigator), Wish Ko Lang! (Just My Wish!), i-Witness, Reporter’s Notebook, Front Row, Reel Time, Investigative Documentaries, and Biyahe ni Drew (Drew’s Trip), and the animation program Alamat (Legend).

 

Her able leadership in news and public affairs programming resulted in the consistent recognition of GMA Network. It earned numerous local and international awards such as the Catholic Mass Media Awards, Star Awards for Television, Asian TV Awards, Peabody Award, and US International Film and Video Festival.

 

Flores was cited as the Television News Producer of the Year by the Rotary Club of Manila in 1996. She was appointed as a juror of the International Emmy Awards in 2004, 2005, and 2008. She received the Ten Outstanding Young Men award for broadcast management in 2004, and the CEO Excel Awardee for Communication Excellence and Organization from the International Association of Business Communicators in 2012. Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

GALVANTE, WILMA V. (Wilma Yraola Valle-Galvante) b. Manila 24 Feb 1952. Broadcast producer and executive. She is the daughter of Ernesto Valle and Norma Yraola. She is married to Eleuterio Galvante Jr with whom she has four daughters. She obtained her bachelor’s degree in public relations and advertising from Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila in 1973.

Galvante has over 40 years experience in the Philippine entertainment industry. Her career spans television executive and administrative work with the major broadcast networks that include production, programming, operations, and talent development. She started as a production assistant for Radio Philippines Network (RPN) 9, later on becoming an executive producer from 1977 to 1981, and production manager from 1981 to 1988. Among the TV shows she conceptualized and produced for RPN are: Joey and Son, ca 1980, the first solo comedy series of Joey de Leon without his partners Tito and Vic Sotto, and also starring Ian Veneracion, who played de Leon’s son; It’s a Deal,


ca 1980, a comedy series starring Alma Moreno and Michael de Mesa, with the latter playing a homosexual pretending to be straight and married (to Moreno’s character); and Ang Bagong Kampeon (The New Champion), 1985-88, a singing competition that became a huge hit among audiences and successfully launched the career of Regine Velasquez who was the program’s grand champion in 1984. Ang Bagong Kampeon transferred to GMA 7 in 1989 and was retitled Tanghalan ng Kampeon (Stage of the Champion), with Galvante still in charge.

In 1993, she was hired by GMA Network where she spent the next 19 years as executive-in-charge of production and later senior vice president of the network’s Entertainment TV Group from 2001 to 2012. In GMA, she spearheaded productions of top-rating and award-winning television shows like the gag show Bubble Gang, 1995-2012; the fantasy series Mulawin, 2004-05, and Encantadia, 2005-06; the showbiz-oriented magazine show Startalk, 1995-2012; the morning talk show Sis, 2001-10; the drama anthology Magpakailanman (Forever), 2002-08; and the comedy series Pepito Manaloto, 2010-12. Through Galvante’s initiative, GMA Network bought the rights to produce the television adaptation of popular komiks novels like Darna , 2005 and 2009; Captain Barbell and Bakekang, 2006-07; and Dyesebel, 2008. Under her leadership, the network ventured into producing adaptations of foreign TV dramas like Korea’s Stairway to Heaven, Endless Love, and I Am Kim Sam Soon (retitled Ako si Kim Sam Soon), Argentina’s Lalola, and Mexico’s Marimar. The latter catapulted Marian Rivera to stardom when she portrayed the titular character in 2007. Galvante also conceptualized SOP (Sobrang Okay Pare), [It’s Super Okay, Pal], 1997-2010, a musical variety show hosted by Regine Velasquez, Ogie Alcasid, Janno Gibbs, and Jaya, and Starstruck, 2004-10, a reality star search. Other successful shows produced by Galvante for GMA include Pinoy Pop Superstar, All Star K, S Files, Celebrity Duets, Pinoy Idol, Kap’s Amazing Stories, Babangon Ako’t Dudurugin Kita (Sweet Revenge), Asian Treasures, The Last Prince, Diva, I Heart You Pare, Codename: Asero, Zorro, Totoy Bato, Kaya Kong Abutin ang Langit (I Can Reach the Sky), Amaya, and Munting Heredera (Little Heiress).

Galvante started GMA Artist Center in 2000 to pave the way for talent discovery, development, and management for GMA Network and to build its roster of stars.She conceptualized programs like Click to hone the talents of then new discoveries like Richard Gutierrez, Angel Locsin, Chynna Ortaleza, and Iya Villania.Starstruck, a huge success when it launched in 2004, paved the way to stardom for Jennylyn Mercado, Mark Herras, Yasmien Kurdi, Cristine Reyes, Megan Young, Aljur Abrenica, Kris Bernal, Sarah Lahbati, and many others.

After her retirement from GMA Network, Galvante joined TV5, initially as a creative consultant in 2012 and later as head of the network’s entertainment division from 2013 to 2015. She was one of the jurors of TV5’s talent search Artista Academy, 2012. Some of the programs she produced for TV5 include the primetime series Madam Chairman, the musical variety show The Mega and the Songwriter, the comedy series Confessions of a Torpe (Confessions of a Shy Guy), the game show Let’s Ask Pilipinas (Let’s Ask Philippines), and the drama series Positive and For Love or Money. In 2012, she also established the Asian Academy of Television Arts (AATA), a school that specialized in teaching acting, dancing, singing, writing, and producing for television. She was AATA’s founding member, president, and chief operations officer until 2016.

Galvante received numerous industry awards for the networks she worked for, including top awards in all categories from local and international award-giving bodies, most notable of which is the Best Terrestrial Television Station award given to GMA Network in 2005 by the Asian Television Awards.

Currently, Galvante heads ContentCows Company, Inc, a content creation company that she established in 2015 together with other industry professionals. She is also the Chief Executive Officer of Filhub Events Management, a newly organized events company based in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian

GARCIA, FREDDIE (Federico M. Garcia) aka FMG. b. Naic, Cavite 13 Jul 1943. Broadcast programmer and executive. He is the seventh of nine children of a Philippine Navy dental surgeon and a schoolteacher. He entered the College of Business Administration of theUniversity of the Philippines in the late 1950s but quit school on his third year. He is married to Gloria Dominguez with whom he has four children. He served as vice president for radio, then executive vice president for television, and later general manager of GMA, 1974-86. He was president of ABS-CBN Corporation, 1997-2003, from being its chief operating officer after the EDSA Revolt in 1986.

His first brush with the television industry was when he sold spots for MBC Channel 11 in the early 1960s, while at the same time selling cars, which he had learned to do while he was in college. He then sold spots for CBN Channel 9 in the late 1960s, eventually becoming its sales manager. He positioned Channel 9 as an upscale network, compared to sister station ABS Channel 2, which catered to the mass audience, and brought in foreign shows, such as The Flying Nun, that tripled the sales of the station. When the peso floated in 1969, resulting in a sales downtrend, he was shifted to the radio division of ABS-CBN as the Manila assistant sales manager during which he jacked up radio ads by 300 percent and raised the revenues of the radio station. When martial law was declared in 1972, he found himself jobless, but moved to Republic Broadcasting System (RBS), now GMA, when it reopened its radio station DZBB in late 1972, with the consent of ABS-CBN executive Eugenio “Geny” Lopez Jr, under the condition he would return to ABS-CBN should it reopen.

At GMA, Garcia managed to triple the sales of DZBB, which made possible the acquisition of DZXX. When the Greater Manila Area–Radio Television Arts (GMA-RTV) Corporation, headed by Marcos presidential assistant Gilberto Duavit, acquired majority of RBS stocks in 1974, Garcia handled the station’s business affairs. With help from GMA executive Menardo Jimenez and newspaperman Rod Reyes, who was then GMA’s general manager, Garcia invested in highly rated imported canned programs that increased the revenues of the network and fostered huge changes in broadcast programming. Examples of these shows were Three’s Company, Soap, ChiPs, Starsky and Hutch, Knots Landing, Falcon Crest, and Charlie’s Angels. He established Network Marketing, a programming company, and produced for GMA the weekly dance program Penthouse Live, 1982-87, and the highly popular daily drama soap Anna Liza, 1980-86.

Lopez got Garcia back to ABS-CBN when it reopened after the EDSA Revolt in 1986. Garcia was entrusted with the programming of the network. It was during this period that Garcia reinvented the network. With actor and broadcast executive Charo Santos-Concio, TV director Johnny Manahan, and image maker Salvii Casino, Garcia changed the landscape of local programming. He coined TV IDs like “Maraming Salamat Po!” (Thank You Very Much), and “The Star Network.” He was the brains behind the highly popular daily news TV Patrol, 1987 to present, which introduced conversational Filipino in newscasts and what critics would call the tabloidization of news. He co-produced with Santos-Concio the weekly talk magazine Mel & Jay, 1988-96, and the drama-counseling program Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), which premiered in 1991. With Manahan as director, he produced ABS-CBN long-running hits like the sitcoms Palibhasa Lalake (Because They Are Guys), 1987-98, Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Wait for the Next Chapter), 1991-97, and Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad), 1992-2003; and the music variety shows Loveliness, 1987, and Tonight with Dick and Carmi, 1988-91. He co-produced with Regal the drama anthology Maricel Drama Special, 1987-90. He moved the 30-minute daily soap Mara Clara, 1992-97, to an early evening primetime slot in 1996 to challenge the top-rating Mexican telenovela Marimar, 1996, RPN 9. He pushed ABS-CBN to strengthen its regional programming, formed the ABS-CBN Talent Center that made many child and teen stars popular, and dubbed into Filipino many foreign cartoons. He also served as a judge in the talent and reality show Pilipinas Got Talent, 2010-13, ABS-CBN.

Garcia is credited for Filipinizing local news programming, popularizing Filipino-dubbed foreign programs, establishing the star studio system in broadcast, instigating the vicious TV programming competition, fostering the rise of the Filipino soap, making possible the decline of the Mexican telenovela, and promoting the boom of the provincial TV industry and the growth of UHF TV.

Garcia received the Agora Awards for Marketing Excellence from the Philippine Marketing Association, 1992, and the Lifetime Achievement Award for Television from the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas, 1999. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III

Elmer L. Gatchalian (Elmer Lopez Gatchalian) is a screenwriter, playwright, editor, and translator. He was born in Bulakan, Bulacan on 15 Jun 1972. He is the son of Jose Gatchalian Jr and Epifania Lopez. He graduated from the University of Santo Tomas in 1992 with a degree in journalism.

Gatchalian’s career in TV production began with the Philippine Children’s Television Foundation (PCTVF), the organization behind the pioneering children’s program, Batibot (Small But Strong), where he worked as writer and producer from 1994 to 1997, under the supervision of Rene O. Villanueva, his writing mentor. Other PCTVF productions he was involved in are: as head writer, 1896 Kalayaan (1896 Independence), 1996-97, a magazine program on Philippine history, culture, and geography; and as producer, PG (Parents’ Guide), 1996-97, a magazine program for parents. All of these programs were aired in GMA 7.

In 1999, he joined GMA News and Public Affairs, starting as a segment producer for the news magazine program, Brigada Siete (Brigade Seven). Later, he became an associate producer and writer for the awardwinning documentary program, I-Witness: The GMA Documentaries, with Luchi Cruz-Valdes as host. He also wrote for the I-Witness episodes hosted by Vicky Morales, Jay Taruc, Jiggy Manicad, Maki Pulido, and Sandra Aguinaldo. He was also the script editor of the I-Witness episodes of Howie Severino.

In GMA, Gatchalian shuttled between writing scripts for documentaries and entertainment shows in various genres with proficiency and ease. He was the head writer of 2000 Today, the 25-hour Global Millennium Day Broadcast produced by GMA in cooperation with the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC). He wrote Signos: Banta ng Nagbabagong Klima (Signs: Threat of Climate Change), 2008, GMA’s first ever documentary on global warming, hosted by Richard Gutierrez. He was the head writer of the magazine show Kay Susan Tayo! (We Are For Susan!), 2003-09, and the environmental documentary Planet Philippines, 2009, and was one of the pioneering writers of the infotainment show Ang Pinaka (The Most), 2005-08, on QTV. He also wrote scripts for entertainment programs like Kasangga (Ally), 2000-02, a docudrama series; Kakabakaba (Scared to Death), 2000-02, a horror anthology; and the drama anthologies Larawan, 2001, Love to Love, 2003-04, and Magpakailanman (Forever), 2003-05. He was also the head writer of the soap opera Habang Kapiling Ka (While We’re Together), 2002-03; the fantasy series Fantastikids, 2006, and Fantastic Man, 2006-07; the horror anthology ’Wag Kukurap (Don’t Blink), 2004-06; and Pinoy Records, 2007-09, a magazine show on Filipino feats and achievements hosted by boxing champion Manny Pacquiao.

In 2010, he became a creative consultant and head writer for TV5. He was responsible for the conceptualization, content and script development, and creative supervision of the network’s shows of varied genres and formats, including the soap operas Babaeng Hampaslupa (The Poor Heiress) and Sa Ngalan ng Ina (In the Name of the Mother); the drama series Posi+ive; the reality talk shows Face to Face and Face the People; the drama anthologies Five Star Specials and Untold Stories Mula sa Face to Face (Untold Stories from Face to Face); the travel documentary Pinoy Explorer; the talent search Artista Academy (Star Academy); and the showbiz-oriented magazine shows Paparazzi and Showbiz Police.

Gatchalian is also a playwright and screenwriter. He wrote the one-act play, Ambon ng Kristal (Crystal Rain), which was toured by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Metropolitan Teen Theater League from 1994 to 1998. It was also during those years when the PETA Children’s Theater Collective commissioned him to write the children’s play, Ang Tiririt ng Ibong Adarna (The Song of the Adarna Bird), a reimagining of the popular metrical romance Ibong Adarna as a musical on gender equality, which also had a three-year national tour. article.value: Elmer L. Gatchalian (Elmer Lopez Gatchalian) is a screenwriter, playwright, editor, and translator. He was born in Bulakan, Bulacan on 15 Jun 1972. GENPEACE GenPeace stands for Gender, Peace and Development Project, which works toward peace in Mindanao through a network of Mindanao-wide community radio stations and a literacy program for women. Its objectives are to promote gender-sensitive, community-based peace education in selected areas in Mindanao; to build capacities in communities to develop and manage peace activities in said areas; and to promote the use of community radio as a tool for enhancing community mobilization, collaborative actions, and the development of effective communication for peace promotion and community development.

The target audience of the radio stations are the most marginalized and underrepresented of Mindanao’s so-called tri-people society composed of the Bangsamoro (Muslims), the lumad (indigenous peoples), and Christian settlers. A network of 15 community radio stations in Mindanao supports the program of GenPeace, relying on community volunteers to serve as anchors and generating counterpart funding from local governments, which also provide the sites for the radio stations. Each community has a multisectoral Community Media and Education Council whose members are elected by a community assembly.

Through funding from UNESCO-Jakarta, the Canadian International Development Agency–Local Government Support Program (CIDA-LGSP) and the Government of the Philippines–United Nations Multi-Donor Program (GOP-UNMDP) Phase III, the GenPeace program provided the initial equipment of the stations, technical support, and capacity building and training of the broadcasters. The Notre Dame Foundation for Charitable Activities Inc–Women in Enterprise Development Program, a community extension arm of the College of Commerce of the Notre Dame University in Cotabato City, began implementing the GenPeace program in 1999.

The GENPeace Community radio stations supported by UNESCO-Jakarta are DXLR-FM, called Lumad Radio, in Ipil, Zamboanga; DXPR-FM Peace Radio in Jolo, Sulu; DXSR Salam Radio in Marawi City; DXUM-FM Uswag Mahayag in Mahayag, Davao del Sur; DXSB-FM Sultan sa Barongis in Sultan sa Barongis, Maguindanao; and a station in Claveria, Misamis Oriental.

Supported by the GOP-UNMDP Phase III are DXSM-FM Sheik Makdun, in Simunul, Tawi-Tawi; DXLB-FM Lake Buluan in Buluan, Maguindanao; DXUS-FM Udul Sebu in Lake Sebu, South Cotabato; DXTM-FM Tingog Malita in Malita, Davao del Sur; DXRS-FM Radio Siocon in Siocon, Zamboanga del Norte; DXTR-FM Tangkal Radio in Tangkal, Lanao del Norte; and a station in Maluso, Basilan.

Supported by the CIDA-LGSP ARMM are DXIB Iranun Barira in Barira, Maguindanao, and DXUP-FM in Upi, Maguindanao. Written by Fraulein A. Oclarit and Ariel Marco T. Oclarit

GERONIMO, GERRY (Adolfo Rueda Geronimo) aka Ka Gerry, Kabayan. b. Santa Cruz, Manila 5 Oct 1941. Radio and television broadcaster. His parents are Elias Geronimo and Concordia P. Rueda. He is married to Zenaida Salvador of Binmaley, Pangasinan, with whom he has two sons. Relatives in broadcast include Estrella Salvador Cleofe, a producer director at MBS 4, the National Media Production Center, and PTV 4, 1976-93; and newscaster Veronica Cleofe Alejar of UNTV Channel 37. He is also related to fictionist, broadcaster, and filmmaker Eli Rueda Guieb III. He finished grade school at Andres Bonifacio Elementary School in Santa Cruz, Manila, 1957, and his secondary education at Manuel L. Quezon High School, 1961. He has a bachelor’s degree in foreign service and political science from the Lyceum of the Philippines University, 1965. He took special studies in broadcasting from the British Broadcasting Corporation, 1966. Geronimo taught English, public speaking, political science, and Philippine history at the Lyceum of the Philippines in 1966 and at St Paul’s College of Manila from 1974 to 1976. He served as sectoral representative for peasants and the fisherfolk in the 10th Philippine Congress from 1996 to 1998.

He was first heard on radio in 1963 as an announcer on DZFM of the Philippine Broadcasting Service. He moved to Radio Veritas in 1968 and to DZEC of the Eagle Broadcasting Corporation in 1969, where he was program manager and news supervisor until 1971. During the martial law period, he anchored news and public affairs shows on the government television station Channel 4 as part of then president Ferdinand Marcos’s New Society initiatives. One of the programs he hosted was Pulong-Pulong sa Kaunlaran (Public Forum for Development), which was simulcast on all other channels, weekdays at six in the evening. In the program, Geronimo delivered his spiels in straight Filipino. From 1974 to 1981, he served as producer and host on GMA Network’s DZBB and on FBS Radio Network’s DWBL, then transferred to ABS-CBN Broadcasting Corporation’s DZMM in 1988.

He is most popular for Ating Alamin (Let Us Find Out), a school-on-the-air livelihood and entrepreneurship radio and television program, which he has been hosting, directing, and producing since 1974. For 40 years, it continued to tackle technological innovations in agriculture for Filipino entrepreneurs. Geronimo expanded the reach of his educational program by crossing over to other media platforms: publishing AA Gazette, offering livelihood seminars called Gabay sa Kabuhayan (Guide to Livelihood), and producing Salin Kaalaman: Libro sa Video (Knowledge Transfer: Books on Video).

He is publisher and editor of Eumorpho Bodybuilding Magazine, chairman and organizer of Ginoong Eumorpho Amateur Bodybuilding Competition, and former president of the Philippine Combat Aikido Federation. His latest advocacy is Sulong Kabuhayan, an advocacy campaign that promotes local self-reliant entrepreneurship.

For his program Ating Alamin, Geronimo received the NHK Award for Television in 1985, the Hall of Fame Award from the Catholic Mass Media Award in 1986, the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon in 1987, the Science Award from the Department of Science and Technology in 1987, and the Anak TV Seal Award in 2011. Written by Cecile Angela A. Ilagan

GMA NETWORK (Global Media Arts Network) aka GMA 7, Channel 7, Kapuso. The present headquarters of GMA are on EDSA corner Timog Ave in Diliman, Quezon City. Its 777-foot transmitter, called Tower of Power and erected on 7 Nov 1988, is located in Tandang Sora, Barangay Culiat, Quezon City. Its pre-martial law transmitter, with a triangular base, was right beside its building on EDSA, with each side of the transmitter bearing the number 7, but its numbers were destroyed by Typhoon Yoling in 1970.

Popularly known as Channel 7, GMA traces its roots to Robert “Bob” La Rue Stewart, an American war correspondent of the Mutual Broadcasting Company who arrived in the Philippines with the liberation forces of General Douglas MacArthur in 1944. When World War II ended, Stewart remained in the country and married a Filipina, Loreto Feliciano. On 14 Jun 1950, the couple’s corporation, Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc, ventured into broadcasting through DZBB Radio. It operated from the fourth floor of the Calvo Building on the Escolta in Manila. The couple expanded their operations in 1955 to include DZXX, an AM-band station with a music format. It was the first popular music radio station in the country. In 1957, DZBB and DZXX moved their operations from the Escolta to a new site on EDSA. Also in 1957, the network opened its radio stations DYSS in Cebu and DYOO in Iloilo.

On 29 Oct 1961, Stewart started the operations of its television station, DZBB TV Channel 7, using very minimal equipment: two old cameras, a surplus transmitter, and no lighting equipment. It was the third television station in the Philippines to be established after World War II. The network opened its second station, DYSS Channel 7 Cebu, in 1963. By 1972, it had established radio stations in Dagupan, Laoag, Legazpi, and Roxas.

The network changed its name several times: Republic Broadcasting Corporation (RBS) in 1963, Greater Manila Area (GMA)–Radio Television Arts on 28 May 1974 and operating under the slogan “Where You Belong,” GMA Rainbow Satellite Network or Rainbow Network on 30 Apr 1992, and GMA Network Incorporated in 1996, with GMA now standing for Global Media Arts, under the banner “Kapuso” (One at Heart) beginning on 27 Oct 2002.

Stewart enjoyed substantial investments from the American Broadcasting Company of the USA. He was mainly responsible for the programming of DZBB during its early years, doing most of the promotional announcements himself. The first programs aired on radio included the satire Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), the radio drama Camay Drama Theater, the variety show Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), and the newscast Newscoop. The news was a major component of the station’s programming. The news highlights for radio included live news coverage of social and political events, such as the congressional and senate sessions, the 1953 presidential elections, detailed accounts of the crash of Ramon Magsaysay’s plane in Mount Manunggal highlighted by live telephone interviews, which was rarely done during the period, and the 1951 eruption of Mount Hibok-Hibok. Entertainment and educational programs were aired live. Some of the radio programs migrated to television when Channel 7 was opened in 1961, with Stewart anchoring The News with Uncle Bob.

Channel 7’s pre-martial law programming consisted of canned shows from the USA and the United Kingdom, such as Mission Impossible, The Untouchables, 77 Sunset Strip, Combat, and Ben Casey. In the 1960s, it launched the first TV show for children, Uncle Bob’s Lucky 7 Club, the dance variety program Dancetime with Chito, the children game and singing competition show Eskuwelahang Munti (Little Schoolhouse), the counseling program Father Bob and His Telephone, and the horror show Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror).

GMA was closed down when martial law was imposed in 1972. When the 1973 Constitution took effect, which prohibited foreigners like Stewart from owning mass media in the Philippines, Marcos presidential aide Gilberto M. Duavit Sr, Stewart legal counsel Felipe L. Gozon, and lawyer-businessman Menardo R. Jimenez bought the controlling interest in RBS-DZBB. The station reopened two years after the declaration of martial law.

On radio, DZBB, which focused on news, public affairs, and entertainment during its early broadcast in 1955, shifted to music and personality-oriented programs during the martial law period. Noted radio personalities of DZBB were news commentators Rafael “Paeng” Yabut and counseling program hosts Helen Vela and Eddie Ilarde; the latter two would also have their own television programs later. A radio program that caught the curiosity of many was the daily program of Johnny Midnight from midnight to 2:00 am, which featured a water therapy session called “toning” and pyramid healing. In 1976, DZXX was relaunched as DWLS in the FM band, with LS standing for Loreto Stewart, the wife of owner Bob Stewart; it played oldies and pop music.

GMA earned the moniker “The Popeye Station” during this period because of its excessively rerun syndicated show, the cartoon program Popeye. GMA’s financial stability during the martial law period was maintained partly because of the station’s imported canned shows, such as Charlie’s Angels, Love Boat, Three’s Company, CHiPS, Starsky & Hutch, Dance Fever, The 700 Club, and the highly popular Japanese cartoon program Voltes V. The pre-martial law ABS-CBN talk program, Two for the Road reappeared on Channel 4, then moved to GMA. Among popular Channel 7 programs of the period were the noontime show Student Canteen, 1975-86; the drama soap Anna Liza, 1980-86; the drama-counseling programs Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday), 1976-86, and Lovingly Yours, Helen, 1980-96; the drama program Coney Reyes-Mumar Drama Studio, 1977-81; the magazine talk show Ms. Ellaneous, 1976-81; the showbiz-oriented talk program See-True, 1979-87; the sitcoms Baltic & Co., 1974-76, Prinsipe Abante (Prince Abante), 1979, and Cafeteria Aroma, 1982; the public service program Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love My Fellowman), which premiered in 1974 and continued on air after martial law; and the dance shows Discorama, mid-1970s, and Penthouse 7, 1982-87, which featured the segment of the irreverent “Doña Buding.”

Some of the station’s programs tested the boundaries of censorship, particularly after the assassination of Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr. Two for the Road featured and interviewed activists and opposition leaders in some of its episodes; it also featured a 15-minute tribute to Ninoy Aquino, including footage of his funeral. GMA was daring enough to devote a limited time of its primetime news to the funeral procession; testimonies claim the on-air coverage ran for only eight seconds. Tina Monzon Palma’s outfit of black or yellow, the symbols of the opposition, on News at Seven, or the expressions on her face revealed her distrust of the news stories she was reading. Channel 7’s news reporters or anchorpersons would roll their eyes as they talked about the accomplishments of the dictator. Ricardo “Dong” Puno Jr interviewed newly widowed Cory Aquino on his talk program Viewpoint in 1984, during which Aquino announced her decision to run for the presidency. Orly Mercado came out with a GMA exclusive on the Marcos hidden wealth.

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt, GMA reoriented its radio programming to news, relaunching DZBB-AM as Radyo Bisig Bayan (Radio with the People) in 1989, then recast it as Super Radyo (Super Radio). “The Giant” DWLS 97.1 FM followed an easy listening format, playing mellow standards, but eventually adopted mass-based programming in the 1990s to reach the masa (masses), rebranding its FM station as DWLS 97.1 “Barangay LS.”

GMA was one of the targets of two major coup attempts during the post-EDSA period. The 28-29 Aug 1987 coup, one of the most serious destabilizing attempts by the military, led by then lieutenant colonel Gregorio Honasan, to overthrow the Corazon Aquino government, attacked Malacañan Palace, seized portions of Camp Aguinaldo, and took GMA, together with ABS-CBN and the government-owned PTV 4, under siege; 40 GMA employees were held hostage by Col Oscar Canlas. GMA was again one of the targets of another bloody military coup attempt in Dec 1989.

GMA went to broadcasting on UHF or ultra-high frequency. It launched DWDB-TV Channel 27 on 27 Aug 1995. Popularly known as CityNet Television from 1995 to 1999, Entertainment Music Channel (EMC) from 1999 to 2001, and resumed as CityTV in 2005, it was GMA’s main outlet for imported programs, freeing up slots in GMA’s programming for more domestic productions.

On 14 Feb 2004, GMA Network launched its first international channel, GMA Pinoy TV, available in key cities in the USA, the Middle East, Australia, and some parts of Asia and Europe. The network went into media-related ventures, such as GMA Films in 1998. Beginning in the 2000s, it included subsidiaries such as GMA New Media, GMA Marketing and Productions, GMA Worldwide Philippines, RGMA Marketing and Productions, GMA Records, Citynet Network Marketing and Productions, Scenarios Inc, Alta Productions Group, MediaMerge Corporation, Digify Inc, and Script2010.

In 2005, GMA CityNet changed to QTV 11 or Quality Television and also launched its sister channel called Q, which was intended to be a lifestyle channelfor women. QTV 11 and Channel Q were later replaced with GMA News TV Channel 27 in 2011.

Post-martial law GMA came out with public affairs programs anchored by veteran print journalists and people from the academe, like Luis Beltran in Straight from the Shoulder, 1987-94, Teddy Benigno in Firing Line, 1992-99, and Oscar Orbos and Solita Monsod in Debate with Mare at Pare (Debate with Mare and Pare), 1998-2006. Some news anchors and broadcast journalists of the station were Tony Seva, Bong Lapira, Tony Zorilla, Jose Mari Velez, Tina Monzon Palma, Mike Lacanilao, Jimmy Gil, Jun Bautista, Raffy Marcelo, Jessica Soho, Howie Severino, Karen Davila, Jiggy Manicad, Maki Pulido, Tony Lozano, Mel Tiangco, Mike Enriquez, Vicky Morales, Susan Enriquez, Sandra Aguinaldo, Arnold Clavio, Joseph Morong, and Joel Reyes Zobel.

It continued to broadcast entertainment shows, like the dance variety program Vilma!, 1986-95; the showbiz talk shows Eye-to-Eye, 1988, and Star Talk, which premiered in 1995; the daily youth-oriented variety show That’s Entertainment, 1986-96; the children’s program 5 and Up, 1996-2002; the sketch gag show Bubble Gang, which began in 1995; and the clean comedy shows Pepito Manaloto, which premiered in 2010, and Vampire ang Daddy Ko (My Daddy Is a Vampire), which premiered in 2013.

GMA 7 became home to quality and critically acclaimed news and public affairs programs and investigative documentary magazines, such as The Probe Team, 1988-2003; Cheche Lazaro Presents, 1999-2003; Imbestigador (Investigator), which premiered in 2000; i-Witness, which premiered in 1999; and Reporter’s Notebook, beginning in 2004. GMA News TV Channel 27 came out with the docu-magazines Reel Time, Front Row, and Investigative Documentaries, which all premiered in 2011, and all were either reshown on or migrated to Channel 7. It came out with important drama serials like Bayan Ko (My Country aka The Politician), 2013; Titser (Teacher), 2013; and Katipunan, 2014.

From the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP), GMA won the Golden Dove Award for Best TV Station in Metro Manila for Channel 7 every year from 1991 to 1994, and 1997; Best AM Radio Station in Metro Manila for DZBB in 1992; and Best Provincial FM Radio Station for DYRU Campus Radio Kalibo in 2001. Recipient of the KBP Lifetime Achievement Award was Menardo Jimenez in 1997. Recipients of the KBP Ka Doroy Broadcaster of the Year Award were Jessica Soho in 1991, Jose Mari Velez in 1991, Ricardo Puno Jr in 1993, Cheche Lazaro in 1997, Mel Tiangco in 1998, Solita Monsod in 2000, and Luchi Cruz-Valdes in 2001. GMA withdrew its membership from the KBP in 2003 and therefore no longer qualified in any of its awards. It won the Star Awards for Television of the Philippine Movie Press Club (PMPC) for Best Station with Balanced Programming in 1988, 1991, 2000, 2001, 2005, 2006, 2008, and 2013.

Among the important awards that its programs, broadcasters, artists, and technical people received were the Sinag Awards of the Philippine Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, the Gawad Cultural Center of the Philippines para sa Radyo at Telebisyon, the KBP Golden Dove Awards, the PMPC Star Awards for Television, the Catholic Mass Media Awards, the Anak TV Seal Awards of the Southeast Asian Foundation for Children and Television, the Golden TV Screen Awards of the Entertainment Press Society, the World Medals of the New York Festivals, and the Asian Television Awards. GMA won Best Terrestrial Television Station of the Year at the Asian Television Awards in 2005. GMA is the only network from the Philippines to have received the George Foster Peabody Award, and has won it four times: the Institutional Award for Investigative Reporting for the network’s programs i-Witness for its episode “Kidneys for Sale” and Brigada Siete (News Brigade on Seven) for its episode “Kamao” (Fist), 1999; i-Witness for its episode “Ambulansyang de Paa” (Ambulance on Foot), 2009; Reel Time for its episode “Salat” (Hunger), 2012; and for the coverage of super typhoon Yolanda by its news programs, 2013. article.value: GMA NETWORK (Global Media Arts Network) aka GMA 7, Channel 7, Kapuso. The present headquarters of GMA are on EDSA corner Timog Ave in Diliman, Quezon City. Its 777-foot transmitter, called Tower of Power and erected on 7 Nov 1988, is located in Tandang Sora, Barangay Culiat, Quezon City. Its pre-martial law transmitter, with a triangular base, was right beside its building on EDSA, with each side of the transmitter bearing the number 7, but its numbers were destroyed by Typhoon Yoling in 1970.

Popularly known as Channel 7, GMA traces its roots to Robert “Bob” La Rue Stewart, an American war correspondent of the Mutual Broadcasting Company who arrived in the Philippines with the liberation forces of General Douglas MacArthur in 1944. When World War II ended, Stewart remained in the country and married a Filipina, Loreto Feliciano. On 14 Jun 1950, the couple’s corporation, Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc, ventured into broadcasting through DZBB Radio. It operated from the fourth floor of the Calvo Building on the Escolta in Manila. The couple expanded their operations in 1955 to include DZXX, an AM-band station with a music format. It was the first popular music radio station in the country. In 1957, DZBB and DZXX moved their operations from the Escolta to a new site on EDSA. Also in 1957, the network opened its radio stations DYSS in Cebu and DYOO in Iloilo.

On 29 Oct 1961, Stewart started the operations of its television station, DZBB TV Channel 7, using very minimal equipment: two old cameras, a surplus transmitter, and no lighting equipment. It was the third television station in the Philippines to be established after World War II. The network opened its second station, DYSS Channel 7 Cebu, in 1963. By 1972, it had established radio stations in Dagupan, Laoag, Legazpi, and Roxas.

The network changed its name several times: Republic Broadcasting Corporation (RBS) in 1963, Greater Manila Area (GMA)–Radio Television Arts on 28 May 1974 and operating under the slogan “Where You Belong,” GMA Rainbow Satellite Network or Rainbow Network on 30 Apr 1992, and GMA Network Incorporated in 1996, with GMA now standing for Global Media Arts, under the banner “Kapuso” (One at Heart) beginning on 27 Oct 2002.

Stewart enjoyed substantial investments from the American Broadcasting Company of the USA. He was mainly responsible for the programming of DZBB during its early years, doing most of the promotional announcements himself. The first programs aired on radio included the satire Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), the radio drama Camay Drama Theater, the variety show Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), and the newscast Newscoop. The news was a major component of the station’s programming. The news highlights for radio included live news coverage of social and political events, such as the congressional and senate sessions, the 1953 presidential elections, detailed accounts of the crash of Ramon Magsaysay’s plane in Mount Manunggal highlighted by live telephone interviews, which was rarely done during the period, and the 1951 eruption of Mount Hibok-Hibok. Entertainment and educational programs were aired live. Some of the radio programs migrated to television when Channel 7 was opened in 1961, with Stewart anchoring The News with Uncle Bob.

Channel 7’s pre-martial law programming consisted of canned shows from the USA and the United Kingdom, such as Mission Impossible, The Untouchables, 77 Sunset Strip, Combat, and Ben Casey. In the 1960s, it launched the first TV show for children, Uncle Bob’s Lucky 7 Club, the dance variety program Dancetime with Chito, the children game and singing competition show Eskuwelahang Munti (Little Schoolhouse), the counseling program Father Bob and His Telephone, and the horror show Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror).

GMA was closed down when martial law was imposed in 1972. When the 1973 Constitution took effect, which prohibited foreigners like Stewart from owning mass media in the Philippines, Marcos presidential aide Gilberto M. Duavit Sr, Stewart legal counsel Felipe L. Gozon, and lawyer-businessman Menardo R. Jimenez bought the controlling interest in RBS-DZBB. The station reopened two years after the declaration of martial law.

On radio, DZBB, which focused on news, public affairs, and entertainment during its early broadcast in 1955, shifted to music and personality-oriented programs during the martial law period. Noted radio personalities of DZBB were news commentators Rafael “Paeng” Yabut and counseling program hosts Helen Vela and Eddie Ilarde; the latter two would also have their own television programs later. A radio program that caught the curiosity of many was the daily program of Johnny Midnight from midnight to 2:00 am, which featured a water therapy session called “toning” and pyramid healing. In 1976, DZXX was relaunched as DWLS in the FM band, with LS standing for Loreto Stewart, the wife of owner Bob Stewart; it played oldies and pop music.

GMA earned the moniker “The Popeye Station” during this period because of its excessively rerun syndicated show, the cartoon program Popeye. GMA’s financial stability during the martial law period was maintained partly because of the station’s imported canned shows, such as Charlie’s Angels, Love Boat, Three’s Company, CHiPS, Starsky & Hutch, Dance Fever, The 700 Club, and the highly popular Japanese cartoon program Voltes V. The pre-martial law ABS-CBN talk program, Two for the Road reappeared on Channel 4, then moved to GMA. Among popular Channel 7 programs of the period were the noontime show Student Canteen, 1975-86; the drama soap Anna Liza, 1980-86; the drama-counseling programs Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday), 1976-86, and Lovingly Yours, Helen, 1980-96; the drama program Coney Reyes-Mumar Drama Studio, 1977-81; the magazine talk show Ms. Ellaneous, 1976-81; the showbiz-oriented talk program See-True, 1979-87; the sitcoms Baltic & Co., 1974-76, Prinsipe Abante (Prince Abante), 1979, and Cafeteria Aroma, 1982; the public service program Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love My Fellowman), which premiered in 1974 and continued on air after martial law; and the dance shows Discorama, mid-1970s, and Penthouse 7, 1982-87, which featured the segment of the irreverent “Doña Buding.”

Some of the station’s programs tested the boundaries of censorship, particularly after the assassination of Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr. Two for the Road featured and interviewed activists and opposition leaders in some of its episodes; it also featured a 15-minute tribute to Ninoy Aquino, including footage of his funeral. GMA was daring enough to devote a limited time of its primetime news to the funeral procession; testimonies claim the on-air coverage ran for only eight seconds. Tina Monzon Palma’s outfit of black or yellow, the symbols of the opposition, on News at Seven, or the expressions on her face revealed her distrust of the news stories she was reading. Channel 7’s news reporters or anchorpersons would roll their eyes as they talked about the accomplishments of the dictator. Ricardo “Dong” Puno Jr interviewed newly widowed Cory Aquino on his talk program Viewpoint in 1984, during which Aquino announced her decision to run for the presidency. Orly Mercado came out with a GMA exclusive on the Marcos hidden wealth.

GMA was one of the targets of two major coup attempts during the post-EDSA period. The 28-29 Aug 1987 coup, one of the most serious destabilizing attempts by the military, led by then lieutenant colonel Gregorio Honasan, to overthrow the Corazon Aquino government, attacked Malacañan Palace, seized portions of Camp Aguinaldo, and took GMA, together with ABS-CBN and the government-owned PTV 4, under siege; 40 GMA employees were held hostage by Col Oscar Canlas. GMA was again one of the targets of another bloody military coup attempt in Dec 1989.

GOZON, FELIPE L. (Felipe Enrique Lapus Gozon) aka Henry, FLG. b. Malabon, Rizal 8 Dec 1939. Broadcast executive, lawyer, businessman. His parents, Benjamin Gozon and Carolina Lapus, operated their family agriculture business. His siblings are Benjamin Jr; Carolina, wife of GMA executive Menardo Jimenez; and Florencia. He is married to Ma. Teresa Manotoc. They have three children: Anna Teresa “Annette” Gozon-Abrogar, who has been director of GMA Network since 2000; Felipe Enrique Jr, who works as a senior associate lawyer in Belo Gozon Elma Parel Asuncion & Lucila Law Offices; and Ma. Teresa Gozon-Viterbo, a licensed physician.

He completed a bachelor of laws from the University of the Philippines (UP), 1962, graduating among the top 10 of his class. His notable batch mates are Chief Justice Reynato Puno and Ramon Magsaysay Awardee Haydee Yorac. He placed 13th in the bar examinations, 1962. He obtained a master of laws degree from Yale University, 1965.

Gozon has been chair of the board and chief executive officer (CEO) of GMA Network since 2000; chair and CEO of GMA Marketing and Productions and GMA New Media; chair of FLG Management and Development Corporation, Alta Productions Group, Citynet Network Marketing and Productions, Philippine Entertainment Portal, and Mont-Aire Realty and Development Corporation; vice-chair of Malayan Savings and Mortgage Bank; director of Gozon Development Corporation, Justitia Realty and Management Corporation, Antipolo Agri-Business and Land Development Corporation, Capitalex Holdings, BGE Holdings, Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Chamber of Commerce of the Philippine Islands; and president of Lex Realty. He serves as chair of the board of trustees of GMA Kapuso Foundation, of Kapwa Ko Mahal Ko Foundation, and of the Potter and Clay Christian School Foundation Inc; a trustee of Bantayog ng mga Bayani Foundation; and an advisory board member of the Asian Television Awards. He is a senior partner at Belo Gozon Elma Parel Asuncion & Lucila Law Offices, with which he has been affiliated since 1972. He was with the Ponce Enrile Law Firm prior to the declaration of martial law in 1972.

Gozon is one of the triumvirate of Gilberto Duavit Sr and Menardo Jimenez that built the current stature of GMA Network as one of the leading broadcast companies in the Philippines. The three bought the controlling interest in the Republic Broadcasting System (RBS-DZBB), renamed Greater Manila Area–Radio Television Arts (GMA-RTV) and later shortened to GMA, from Robert “Uncle Bob” Stewart, who relinquished the ownership of the station when the 1973 Constitution took effect, which prohibited foreigners, like Stewart, from owning shares in any mass media company in the Philippines.

Before holding the highest position in GMA, Loreto “Loring” Stewart, wife of Uncle Bob, tasked Gozon to write the basic plan to Filipinize and diffuse the ownership of the company. This happened during his time with the then Belo Gozon Elma Law Office on 20 Jul 1973. The plan became the basis for Gozon, Duavit Sr, and Jimenez in acquiring GMA. He modified the network’s tag line from “Where you belong” to “Kapuso ng bawat Pilipino” (One at heart with every Filipino) and its rainbow icon to an image of the heart. He created the tag line for its news: “Walang kinikilingan, walang pinoprotektahan, walang kasinungalingan—serbisyong totoo lamang” (On the side of no one, protecting no one, spinning no lies—only true service), to reinforce the news department’s credibility, objectivity, and integrity.

Gozon received awards and gained recognitions from his successes in law, public service, media, and business. Among his awards are the prestigious Chief Justice Special Award given by the chief justice of the Philippines, 1991; Presidential Award of Merit given by the Philippine Bar Association, 1990 and 1993; CEO of the Year given by Uno Magazine, 2004; the Master Entrepreneur of the Year by SGV / Ernst and Young, 2005; People of the Year 2005 by People Asia Magazine, 2006; Outstanding Manilan Award in the field of social responsibility and broadcasting by the city government of Manila, 2011; Quezon City Gawad Parangal Most Outstanding Citizen for 2011 by the Quezon City government, 2011; Tycoon of the Decade Award by BizNews Asia, 2011; Lifetime Achievement Award from the UP Alumni Association, 2012; Personality of the Year for Broadcast Media by SKAL International Makati, 2013; Outstanding Member-Achiever given by the International Honor Society Phi Kappa Phi UP Chapter, 2013; Visionary Management CEO Award by BizNews Asia, 2013; Lifetime Achievement Award given by UP Preparatory High School Alumni, 2014; Entrepreneurship Excellence Award and Best Broadcast CEO Award by BizNews Asia, 2014; and the Rotary Golden Wheel Award for Corporate Media Management given by Rotary International District 3780 and Quezon City government, 2014. He is the first Filipino to receive the Global Leadership Award for Excellence in Media given by the Leaders International together with the American Leadership Development Association in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, 2015. He ranks 48th on the list of “The Philippines’ 50 Richest” released by Forbes magazine in Aug 2015. He has a net worth of 155 million US dollars at age 75.

Written byDean Airo Salvador E. Dancel, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

Sources: Banal-Formoso 2001; Belo Gozon Elma Parel Asuncion and Lucila Law Office 2015; Bloomberg 2015a; Forbes 2015; GMA Network 2015; Gozon 2014.

HERMOSA, LAURA (Laura Dizon Laforteza Hermosa) b. Dagupan, Pangasinan 9 May 1928. Radio, television, and film actor. She is the daughter of Elidio Laforteza and Juliana Dizon. She is married to Fernando Hermosa, with whom she has six children, including comedian Tessie Tomas. She studied at Arellano High School in Santa Cruz, Manila, where literary and radio drama writer Genoveva Edroza was her class adviser.

 

Hermosa was 22 when she began her radio drama acting career at DZBB in 1950. She then moved to DZBC to star in the radio drama Digmaan ng Damdamin (War of Emotions), working with director Artemio Marquez and fellow voice talents Ernesto Ramos, Luz Fernandez, Romy Reyes, and Esther Chavez. In the late 1950s, she acted in Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love), a radio drama on DZRH written by Edroza. Hermosa voiced various characters from male to female and from a child to a grandmother. She also voiced the witch Buruka of the popular drama Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang). Her colleagues called her the woman with a hundred voices.

 

In the early 1960s she and her family moved to her husband’s hometown in Catbalogan, Samar, where she worked as a grammar teacher. They returned to Manila after a few years and Hermosa resumed her radio career in DZXL where she was part of the cast of Eddie Ilarde’s Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday). Apart from drama, Hermosa voiced numerous commercials in Tagalog as well as Waray, Cebuano, Ilonggo, and Bicolano. As she often took her kids to work, daughter Tessie became a voice talent at age 9, and at age 14 she became a model for Palmolive soap ads along with her mother.

 

In the 1970s, Hermosa moved to DWWW where she worked with Kuya Cesar, Rod Navarro, Vic Morales, Tina Loy, and Inday Badiday. Here she started directing drama programs, including Teenage Diary. At the same time, she began appearing in the television programs Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life), Nida-Nestor Show, John en Marsha (John and Marsha), and Hapi House (Happy House). She also acted in films, like Relasyon (An Affair) and Broken Marriage. Written by Alyssa Jean E. Alano, with notes from Irma Mutuc

She is married to Fernando Hermosa, with whom she has six children, including comedian Tessie Tomas. She studied at Arellano High School in Santa Cruz, Manila, where literary and radio drama writer Genoveva Edroza was her class adviser.

Hermosa was 22 when she began her radio drama acting career at DZBB in 1950. She then moved to DZBC to star in the radio drama Digmaan ng Damdamin (War of Emotions), working with director Artemio Marquez and fellow voice talents Ernesto Ramos, Luz Fernandez, Romy Reyes, and Esther Chavez. In the late 1950s, she acted in Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love), a radio drama on DZRH written by Edroza. Hermosa voiced various characters from male to female and from a child to a grandmother. She also voiced the witch Buruka of the popular drama Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang). Her colleagues called her the woman with a hundred voices.

In the early 1960s she and her family moved to her husband’s hometown in Catbalogan, Samar, where she worked as a grammar teacher. They returned to Manila after a few years and Hermosa resumed her radio career in DZXL where she was part of the cast of Eddie Ilarde’s Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday). Apart from drama, Hermosa voiced numerous commercials in Tagalog as well as Waray, Cebuano, Ilonggo, and Bicolano. As she often took her kids to work, daughter Tessie became a voice talent at age 9, and at age 14 she became a model for Palmolive soap ads along with her mother.

In the 1970s, Hermosa moved to DWWW where she worked with Kuya Cesar, Rod Navarro, Vic Morales, Tina Loy, and Inday Badiday. Here she started directing drama programs, including Teenage Diary. At the same time, she began appearing in the television programs Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life), Nida-Nestor Show, John en Marsha (John and Marsha), and Hapi House (Happy House). She also acted in films, like Relasyon (An Affair) and Broken Marriage. Written by Alyssa Jean E. Alano, with notes from Irma Mutuc
Sources: Aniceto 2007; Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino, n.d.; San Diego 2007.
