HERRERO, SUBAS (Ricardo Wright Herrero) b. Manila 3 Apr 1943. d. 14 Mar 2013. Actor, singer. He was of Mexican and American descent. His parents were Salustiano Herrero and Gertrude Wright. In 1966, he married Maria Paz Mendez, with whom he had five children. His daughter Cutuy is a former vocalist of the pop-acoustic band Chapter 2. Herrero graduated from the Ateneo de Manila grade school, 1954, high school, 1958, and college, 1962, with a bachelor of arts degree in premed. He attended medical school at the University of the East Ramon Magsaysay Memorial College, 1964-67.

 

Herrero received his theater training under Fr James B. Reuter, SJ, in college. He appeared in dramas and musicals on stage and on television for Family Theater. He was among the first members of Repertory Philippines. He played important stage roles, including Tevye in Fiddler on the Roof, 1969; Merlin in Camelot, 1970; the lawyer in Tiny Alice, 1970; the father in The Subject Was Roses, 1970; Doolittle in My Fair Lady, 1971 and 1992; The Knack, 1971; Slow Dance in the Killing Ground, 1972; Dr Dysart in Equus, 1979-80; The Wazir in Kismet, 1984; Mr Peachum in Operang Tatlong Kusing (The Threepenny Opera), 1990; and the Mikado in The Mikado, 1992. He also appeared in many other plays, such as Mother Courage, 1975; Ang Awit ni Grusha (The Caucasian Chalk Circle), 1976; and Pusa sa Yerong Bubong (Cat on a Hot Tin Roof), 1981. He was one of the three local actors chosen to do selected dramatic readings with Helen Hayes, acknowledged “First Lady of American Theater,” playing Mr Antrobus opposite Hayes’s Mrs Antrobus in Wilder’s The Skin of Our Teeth in 1966.

 

Herrero’s television career started in GMA 7’s adaptation of the Roni Santiago comic strip Baltic & Co., 1974-76. He starred in the TV comedy show Sandy’s Cousin, BBC 2, 1978, written by Jose Javier Reyes, and which featured Sandy Andolong. He co-hosted with singing and comedy partner Noel Trinidad the weekly gag variety show Champoy, 1980-86, for which he is best remembered as the “fat” character resembling that of Oliver Hardy of the Hardy-Laurel comedy duo that became popular in Hollywood films and television in the late 1920s until the 1950s. Champoy first aired on GTV 4 before it moved to RPN 9 after a few weeks. Herrero and Trinidad were already doing campus concerts prior to Champoy. They recorded the vinyl long-playing album Ibang-Iba ang Champoy (Champoy Is Something Else), Wea Records, 1983. Herrero also co-hosted programs on ABS-CBN, such as the magazine program Intermission with Susan Medina, 1984-85, and the children’s variety show The Star Smile Factory, 1993-95. He also played Padre Damaso in the television movie, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1993, produced by the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

 

In 1986, he made a concert tour of several American cities with Trinidad and singer Celeste Legaspi. He appeared in an original musical, My Hong Kong, performed for the prime minister of Malaysia and at the ASEAN Tourism Forum in 1988. In the early 2000s, Herrero performed live-comedy shows with Champoy colleagues Trinidad, Tessie Tomas, and Mitch Valdez. His last project was an American movie made for television, Noriega: God’s Favorite, 2000, directed by Roger Spottiswoode.

 

In films, he portrayed various villain and comic roles from the 1970s until the early 2000s. His first film was Kill the Pushers, 1972, which starred Joseph Estrada. The movie directors with whom he worked include Ishmael Bernal, Eddie Romero, Fernando Poe Jr, Peque Gallaga, Lore Reyes, Danny Zialcita, Johnny Manahan, and Marilou Diaz-Abaya.

 

Herrero was among a few broadcast personalities who first appeared on government television station Channel 4 when it was seized by rebel forces in the 1986 EDSA Revolt. He was among the on-air talents who read news stories in the improvised public affairs show directed by Johnny Manahan on Channel 4, whose name was changed from Maharlika Broadcasting System during the martial law period to People’s Television Network after the EDSA Revolt. He was also one of the artists who recorded the first EDSA Revolt theme song, “Handog ng Pilipino sa Mundo” (Filipinos’ Gift to the World), composed by Jim Paredes. In spite of his health condition after a stroke in 2000, he showed up on stage calling for the ouster of then president Joseph Estrada, the actor with whom he made his first movie, during the second EDSA Revolt in 2001.

 

In 2010, Herrero migrated to the United States with his whole family, except for one of his children. He died in Rochester, New York, due to complications from diabetes and pneumonia.

 

Herrero received an Aliw Award for Best Stage Actor in 1974. Champoy won the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 1980 and 1981. He and Trinidad won first place in the 5th Metro Manila Popular Music Festival, 1982, with the song “Kahit La La La Pwede Na” (A La La La Would Do).  Written by Rosalinda Galang and Ma. Criselda C. Sto. Domingo, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

 

Sources: De Villa 1982; Galang 1994; Herrero 2015; IMDb, n.d.b; Lo 1984; Medina 2013; Onedown 2008; Pañares 2013; Rodrigo 2006; San Diego 2013; Sanchez 2013; Sulat 2013.

HOLMES, MARGIE (Margarita Miclat Go-Singco Holmes) b. Manila 5 Jun 1950. TV host, clinical psychologist, newspaper columnist, book author. She is the third child of Florencia Miclat and Agustin Go-Singco. She was formerly married to John Holmes in 1977 with whom she had one child, daughter Alexandra. She was also formerly married to Fred Phillips in 1988 and Luigi Marinaccio in 1993. She has been married to Jeremy Alan Frank Baer since 2002. She completed kindergarten, grade school, and high school at Maryknoll College, now Miriam College. Holmes obtained a bachelor of arts in psychology, magna cum laude, from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, 1973, a master’s degree in public health from the University of Hawaii, 1982, and a doctorate in clinical psychology from Ateneo de Manila University, 1990.

Holmes has been an adjunct psychology professor at UP since 1997, teaching pioneer courses in spirituality and psychotherapy, cognitive behavioral therapy, and neuroscience and psychotherapy. She previously taught psychology courses in American institutions in North Carolina such as the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, Pfeiffer University, and Queens College. She was also an associate professor at the Department of Counselor Education of the De La Salle University in Manila. Holmes served as the director of the National Press Club, 1991-92; the Women’s Crisis Center, 1994-96 and 2001-9; and the Remedios AIDS Foundation, 2000-8. She does consultancy for the Department of Health.

Holmes was active as a journalist first, with her columns on sex therapy and marriage counseling regularly appearing in the Manila Times and the Philippine Daily Inquirer, late 1980s-2010s. She then guested in primetime TV programs like the talk show Oh No, It’s Johnny!, 1987-99, ABS-CBN, where her humor and candor in tackling sex-related topics made her a favorite among Johnny Litton’s guests. One guesting in 1986 became controversial when the then newly appointed chair of the Movies and Television Review and Classification Board, Manuel Morato Jr, suspended the show for 10 days due to Holmes’s candid mention of genitalia.

Holmes became more familiar to TV viewers via the daily daytime show Teysi ng Tahanan (Tessie of the Home), 1991-97, ABS-CBN, through the show’s segment “Magtanong kay Dra. Holmes” (Ask Doctor Holmes), which aired Tuesdays and Thursdays. But she gained widest attention in media as host of her own late-night 30-minute TV weekly show No Nonsense with Dr. Margie Holmes, Jun 1991–Mar 1993, produced by Probe. It was the first TV show in the country to exclusively discuss various sexualities, psychological issues, sex, and relationships with wit and humor but also objectively and professionally. She became a regular resource person in the early morning TV programs Umagang kay Ganda (Beautiful Morning), ABS-CBN, and Unang Hirit (First Blow), GMA. She was a contributor to various international news channels such as the BBC, CNN, and Al Jazeera.

Since 1989, she has been writing regular columns for the newspapers The Manila Times, Abante, Abante Tonite, Business Mirror, and Opinyon. Some of her written works were published in international periodicals like Newsweek, Time, Asiaweek, and the Far Eastern Economic Review. She was an active peer reviewer of the International Journal of AIDS Research.

Holmes has written 20 books in English and Filipino, mainly published by Anvil. She pioneered in writing trade books dealing with homosexuality in the Philippines, such as Life, Love, Lust: Straightforward Answers to Provocative Questions, 1990, and A Different Love: Being Gay in the Philippines, 1994. Best-sellers include Buhay Babae (Life as a Woman) and Buhay Lalake (Life as a Man), both in 1995; Buhay May Asawa (Married Life) and Buhay Single (Life as a Single), both in 1997; Wild, Wicked, Wonderful and Bad, Bold, Brazen, both in 2000; Lalakeng Barako (Macho Men) and Babaeng Palaban (Feisty Women), both in 2001; and Down to 1: Depression Stories, 2010.

Holmes began the five-to-seven-minute online program #AskMargie, 2012, Saturdays at 4:00 pm on Rappler.com. Here she elaborates on topics culled from her interaction with people in social media such as e-mails, Twitter, and Facebook. All episodes are archived and retrievable online.

In 1973, the UP Alumni Association honored her as the university’s Most Outstanding Graduate. She was elected into membership to the International Honor Societies of Phi Kappa Phi and Pi Gamma Mu, also in 1973. She won the Bahaghari Awards by Outrage Magazine, the only magazine in the Philippines that focuses on issues by the LGBTQ (lesbians, gays, bisexuals, transgenders, and queer) community in 2014. Written by Olivia L. Cantor

Sources: de la Cruz 2014; Holmes 2013.

IBC 13 (Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation Inc) aka Channel 13. IBC Channel 13 has headquarters in Broadcast City at Capitol Hills in Diliman, Quezon City. Its transmitters are on Roosevelt Ave in San Francisco del Monte, Quezon City.

It was first known as Inter-island Broadcasting Corporation (IBC) DZTV Channel 13 when it was founded in 1960, then as Radio Mindanao Network (RMN)–IBC TV 13 in 1962 and as Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation when it was acquired by the Benedicto Group of Companies in 1975. It was given E13 as its new name in 1987, was renamed back to Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation in 1989, carried the name Islands TV 13 from 1990 to 1992, and finally back to Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation beginning in 1992.

IBC was first owned by American businessman Dick Baldwin. It made its first broadcast on 1 Mar 1960. In 1962, businessman Andres Soriano Sr, who had investments in A. Soriano Corporation, also known as Anscor, and the food and manufacturing giant San Miguel Corporation, bought IBC-TV 13 from Baldwin. Soriano also bought the controlling interest in RMN, which operated radio and television stations, from brothers Henry and Reuben Canoy of Cagayan de Oro. Soriano was at that time also the owner of the daily newspaper The Philippines Herald. Also in 1962, Soriano merged his radio and television acquisitions into one entity—RMN-IBC. The radio and television station operated at the old ABS transmitter site, acquired by Soriano from the Lopezes, in Little Baguio in San Juan, which was then part of Rizal Province.

When Soriano passed away in 1964, his son Andres Soriano Jr took over IBC. The proclamation of martial law in Sep 1972 led to the temporary closure of RMN-IBC, which became operational again before the end of 1972 since Marcos did not consider Soriano a threat to national security. Martial law also stopped the publication of Philippines Herald, which never resumed publication even after the ouster of Marcos in 1986. The Canoy brothers bought back RMN during the martial law period while Soriano sold IBC to Marcos ally Roberto Benedicto, who was by then operating two television stations—Banahaw Broadcasting System (BBC) Channel 2 and RPN Channel 9.

In 1975, IBC started operating DWKB-FM 89.1, a pop music-format station. By 1977, IBC operated 12 TV and 18 radio stations. In 1976, IBC 13 moved to its new site at Broadcast City in Old Balara, together with BBC 2 and KBS-RPN 9. When it was sequestered by the Aquino government in 1986, IBC 13 had 20 television stations nationwide. After the EDSA Revolt in 1986, BBC Channel 2 handed over to IBC 13 the radio station DWWA, renamed DWAN.

Pre-martial law programming on IBC 13 consisted mostly of foreign shows from Columbia Broadcasting System of the USA. One popular local show was Joe Cantada’s Fistorama, which featured local boxing matches. It co-produced educational programs like UP ETC, Pilipino, and Meta Physics. IBC 13 was number one in terms of ratings during the martial law period. Its programs catered to the lower-income groups. It was home to old Filipino movies via Cine Pinoy (Pinoy Cinema), Piling-Piling Pelikula (Well Selected Movies), IBCinema 1, and Roadshow Pilipino. Highly popular shows were former ABS-CBN shows that moved to IBC 13, like Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life) and Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour), which became Oras ng Saya (Happy Hour). Other popular programs included Joe Quirino’s variety-talk show Seeing Stars with JQ, 1975-86; the gag show T.O.D.A.S., 1977-89; Tito, Vic, and Joey’s Iskul Bukol (School Bumps), 1977-90; Pilita Corrales’s music program Something with Pilita, 1978; Inday Badiday’s most prominent talk show See-True, 1979-87; and Imee Marcos’s children’s program Kulit Bulilit (Curious Children), 1982-88. Other shows that started on IBC 13 before they moved to other networks were the sitcoms Chicks to Chicks, 1980-86, and Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), 1987-89; the travel magazine programs Travel Time, 1986-2013, and Lakbay TV (Travel TV), 2003; the legal drama program Ipaglaban Mo (Fight for It), 1989-92; and the public affairs talk show Tapatan kay Louie Beltran (Dialogue with Louie Beltran), 1987-88. Goin’ Bananas, which first aired in 1986 on BBC 2, was on IBC 13 from 1986 to 1987 before it moved to ABS-CBN. Other important shows were the sitcom Hapi House (Happy House), 1987-88; the religious music variety show Mag-Smile Club Na (Join the Smile Club), 1996; and the music programs Kuh by Special Arrangement, 1986-87, and Celeste: Musika at Iba Pa (Celeste: Music and More), 2000-1. It aired good art documentary programs, like Cooltura (a play of the words “cool culture”) and Balay, Kanlungan, Tirahan (House, Home, Abode), both in 2011. IBC 13 was the home of the live coverage of the opening ceremonies and the basketball games of the University Athletic Association of the Philippines (UAAP), 1975-88, before its coverage by succeeding networks became highly commercialized. Noted film directors had their socially relevant drama anthologies on IBC 13: several directors handled Dahong Ginto (Golden Leaf), 1973; Maryo J. de los Reyes had Anak, 1979; Lino Brocka had Lino Brocka Presents, 1986; Ishmael Bernal had Dear Teacher, 1990-91; and Mario O’Hara had Mama, 1991-93.

In spite of being saddled with the most complicated legal battles with Marcos loyalists resisting the Aquino government’s sequestration of the network, several labor issues, and internal management conflicts during the post-EDSA years, IBC 13 produced its best programs during this period. It came out with politically relevant sitcoms and gag shows, like Barrio Balimbing (Barrio of Turncoats), 1986, before it moved to ABS-CBN, 1987-88; Kwentong Barbero (Barber’s Story), 1987; Sic O’Clock News, 1987-89; and Mongolian Barbecue, 1989-93. It was also during this period when it came out with a game changer in public affairs talk programming with The Truth Forum, hosted by Randy David. It was on IBC 13 from 1986 to 1989 before it switched to ABC 5 and GMA 7 under different titles. Public Forum was the first talk show on television that used Filipino as a medium of intelligent political and social discourse, although its first episode, like all talk programs of the period, was in English. IBC 13 hardly had any public information show before 1986, except for its news programs, but it came out with a series of socially relevant documentaries, which included People Power: The Philippine Experience, 1986; Ceasefire, 1986; Keithley Report: The U.S. Bases, 1986; Ramut: The Roots of Revolution in the Cordillera, 1986; Tiempo Muerto: Crisis and Poverty in Negros (Down Time: Crisis and Poverty in Negros), 1986; Autonomy: No Shortcut to Peace, 1987; and Hamon sa Pamahalaan, Hamon sa Taumbayan (Challenge to the Government, Challenge for the People), 1987. All these were produced under the management of IBC 13 president Noel Tolentino and public affairs manager Teresita G. Maceda.

In 1992, IBC 13 became a 100 percent government-owned station by virtue of a compromise agreement between former owner Roberto Benedicto and the Presidential Commission on Good Government. From 1996 to 2002, the station’s income heavily relied on its airing of the games of the Philippine Basketball Association. The station’s programming and facilities continued to deteriorate beginning in the mid-1990s. It continues to air programs produced by blocktimers, amidst talks of selling and privatizing the network.

Some programs of IBC 13 won the Citizens Awards for Television, the Gawad Cultural Center of the Philippines para sa Radyo at Telebisyon, the Catholic Mass Media Awards, the Star Awards for Television of the Philippine Movie Press Club, and the Golden Dove Awards of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas. Examples of these programs were the pre-martial law Fistorama, Pilipino, and Let’s Talk Business, and the post-EDSA Sic O’Clock News, Mongolian Barbecue, Truth Forum, Mama, Dear Teacher, Ipaglaban Mo, Travel Time, Kuh by Special Arrangement, Celeste: Musika at Iba Pa (Celeste: Music and More), Hotline sa Trese (Hotline on 13), its station ID “Pinoy ang Dating” (Looks Filipino), and the DWWW radio program Cancionan on the Air. IBC 13’s award-winning broadcast personalities were Joe Cantada, Randy David, Jaime Fabregas, Susan Calo-Medina, Luz Fernandez, Ricky Reyes, and Marissa del Mar. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez

Sources:

It was first known as Inter-island Broadcasting Corporation (IBC) DZTV Channel 13 when it was founded in 1960, then as Radio Mindanao Network (RMN)–IBC TV 13 in 1962 and as Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation when it was acquired by the Benedicto Group of Companies in 1975. It was given E13 as its new name in 1987, was renamed back to Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation in 1989, carried the name Islands TV 13 from 1990 to 1992, and finally back to Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation beginning in 1992.

IBC was first owned by American businessman Dick Baldwin. It made its first broadcast on 1 Mar 1960. In 1962, businessman Andres Soriano Sr, who had investments in A. Soriano Corporation, also known as Anscor, and the food and manufacturing giant San Miguel Corporation, bought IBC-TV 13 from Baldwin. Soriano also bought the controlling interest in RMN, which operated radio and television stations, from brothers Henry and Reuben Canoy of Cagayan de Oro. Soriano was at that time also the owner of the daily newspaper The Philippines Herald. Also in 1962, Soriano merged his radio and television acquisitions into one entity—RMN-IBC. The radio and television station operated at the old ABS transmitter site, acquired by Soriano from the Lopezes, in Little Baguio in San Juan, which was then part of Rizal Province.

When Soriano passed away in 1964, his son Andres Soriano Jr took over IBC. The proclamation of martial law in Sep 1972 led to the temporary closure of RMN-IBC, which became operational again before the end of 1972 since Marcos did not consider Soriano a threat to national security. Martial law also stopped the publication of Philippines Herald, which never resumed publication even after the ouster of Marcos in 1986. The Canoy brothers bought back RMN during the martial law period while Soriano sold IBC to Marcos ally Roberto Benedicto, who was by then operating two television stations—Banahaw Broadcasting System (BBC) Channel 2 and RPN Channel 9.

In 1975, IBC started operating DWKB-FM 89.1, a pop music-format station. By 1977, IBC operated 12 TV and 18 radio stations. In 1976, IBC 13 moved to its new site at Broadcast City in Old Balara, together with BBC 2 and KBS-RPN 9. When it was sequestered by the Aquino government in 1986, IBC 13 had 20 television stations nationwide. After the EDSA Revolt in 1986, BBC Channel 2 handed over to IBC 13 the radio station DWWA, renamed DWAN.

Pre-martial law programming on IBC 13 consisted mostly of foreign shows from Columbia Broadcasting System of the USA. One popular local show was Joe Cantada’s Fistorama, which featured local boxing matches. It co-produced educational programs like UP ETC, Pilipino, and Meta Physics. IBC 13 was number one in terms of ratings during the martial law period. Its programs catered to the lower-income groups. It was home to old Filipino movies via Cine Pinoy (Pinoy Cinema), Piling-Piling Pelikula (Well Selected Movies), IBCinema 1, and Roadshow Pilipino. Highly popular shows were former ABS-CBN shows that moved to IBC 13, like Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life) and Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour), which became Oras ng Saya (Happy Hour). Other popular programs included Joe Quirino’s variety-talk show Seeing Stars with JQ, 1975-86; the gag show T.O.D.A.S., 1977-89; Tito, Vic, and Joey’s Iskul Bukol (School Bumps), 1977-90; Pilita Corrales’s music program Something with Pilita, 1978; Inday Badiday’s most prominent talk show See-True, 1979-87; and Imee Marcos’s children’s program Kulit Bulilit (Curious Children), 1982-88. Other shows that started on IBC 13 before they moved to other networks were the sitcoms Chicks to Chicks, 1980-86, and Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), 1987-89; the travel magazine programs Travel Time, 1986-2013, and Lakbay TV (Travel TV), 2003; the legal drama program Ipaglaban Mo (Fight for It), 1989-92; and the public affairs talk show Tapatan kay Louie Beltran (Dialogue with Louie Beltran), 1987-88. Goin’ Bananas, which first aired in 1986 on BBC 2, was on IBC 13 from 1986 to 1987 before it moved to ABS-CBN. Other important shows were the sitcom Hapi House (Happy House), 1987-88; the religious music variety show Mag-Smile Club Na (Join the Smile Club), 1996; and the music programs Kuh by Special Arrangement, 1986-87, and Celeste: Musika at Iba Pa (Celeste: Music and More), 2000-1. It aired good art documentary programs, like Cooltura (a play of the words “cool culture”) and Balay, Kanlungan, Tirahan (House, Home, Abode), both in 2011. IBC 13 was the home of the live coverage of the opening ceremonies and the basketball games of the University Athletic Association of the Philippines (UAAP), 1975-88, before its coverage by succeeding networks became highly commercialized. Noted film directors had their socially relevant drama anthologies on IBC 13: several directors handled Dahong Ginto (Golden Leaf), 1973; Maryo J. de los Reyes had Anak, 1979; Lino Brocka had Lino Brocka Presents, 1986; Ishmael Bernal had Dear Teacher, 1990-91; and Mario O’Hara had Mama, 1991-93.

In spite of being saddled with the most complicated legal battles with Marcos loyalists resisting the Aquino government’s sequestration of the network, several labor issues, and internal management conflicts during the post-EDSA years, IBC 13 produced its best programs during this period. It came out with politically relevant sitcoms and gag shows, like Barrio Balimbing (Barrio of Turncoats), 1986, before it moved to ABS-CBN, 1987-88; Kwentong Barbero (Barber’s Story), 1987; Sic O’Clock News, 1987-89; and Mongolian Barbecue, 1989-93. It was also during this period when it came out with a game changer in public affairs talk programming with The Truth Forum, hosted by Randy David. It was on IBC 13 from 1986 to 1989 before it switched to ABC 5 and GMA 7 under different titles. Public Forum was the first talk show on television that used Filipino as a medium of intelligent political and social discourse, although its first episode, like all talk programs of the period, was in English. IBC 13 hardly had any public information show before 1986, except for its news programs, but it came out with a series of socially relevant documentaries, which included People Power: The Philippine Experience, 1986; Ceasefire, 1986; Keithley Report: The U.S. Bases, 1986; Ramut: The Roots of Revolution in the Cordillera, 1986; Tiempo Muerto: Crisis and Poverty in Negros (Down Time: Crisis and Poverty in Negros), 1986; Autonomy: No Shortcut to Peace, 1987; and Hamon sa Pamahalaan, Hamon sa Taumbayan (Challenge to the Government, Challenge for the People), 1987. All these were produced under the management of IBC 13 president Noel Tolentino and public affairs manager Teresita G. Maceda.

In 1992, IBC 13 became a 100 percent government-owned station by virtue of a compromise agreement between former owner Roberto Benedicto and the Presidential Commission on Good Government. From 1996 to 2002, the station’s income heavily relied on its airing of the games of the Philippine Basketball Association. The station’s programming and facilities continued to deteriorate beginning in the mid-1990s. It continues to air programs produced by blocktimers, amidst talks of selling and privatizing the network.

Some programs of IBC 13 won the Citizens Awards for Television, the Gawad Cultural Center of the Philippines para sa Radyo at Telebisyon, the Catholic Mass Media Awards, the Star Awards for Television of the Philippine Movie Press Club, and the Golden Dove Awards of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas. Examples of these programs were the pre-martial law Fistorama, Pilipino, and Let’s Talk Business, and the post-EDSA Sic O’Clock News, Mongolian Barbecue, Truth Forum, Mama, Dear Teacher, Ipaglaban Mo, Travel Time, Kuh by Special Arrangement, Celeste: Musika at Iba Pa (Celeste: Music and More), Hotline sa Trese (Hotline on 13), its station ID “Pinoy ang Dating” (Looks Filipino), and the DWWW radio program Cancionan on the Air. IBC 13’s award-winning broadcast personalities were Joe Cantada, Randy David, Jaime Fabregas, Susan Calo-Medina, Luz Fernandez, Ricky Reyes, and Marissa del Mar. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez

Roy Iglesias (Roy Claveria Iglesias) is a screenwriter, playwright, book author, and editor. He was born in Manila on 3 Mar to Felizardo Iglesias and Felicidad Claveria from Occidental Mindoro. He is married to Zenaida Pascua of Tarlac. They have three sons. Since 2014, Iglesias has been the creative director for drama in GMA Network.

He earned a bachelor of arts degree in mass communication at the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila. He also pursued a master’s degree in communication at Ateneo de Manila University and a master of arts degree in education at St Joseph’s College.

Right after college, he joined the advertising and public relations industry as a copywriter and later as a media campaigns consultant. During the last years of the Marcos administration, he worked as a radio commentator over DZME for a program that was critical of the authoritarian government.

Iglesias started his writing career in theater, writing one-act plays for the Kalinangan ng Lahi Café Theater in Cubao, Quezon City. He was only a teenager when he cowrote the classic historical film Ganito Kami Noon… Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were… What Happens to You Now?), 1976, with film director Eddie Romero. He wrote the screenplays of the following films: Sa Kabila ng Lahat (Despite Everything), 1991; Dahas (Rage), 1995; Bakit May Kahapon Pa? (Why Is There a Yesterday?), 1996; Ang Babae sa Bintana (Woman By the Window), 1998; Prosti (Prostitute), 2002; Xerex, 2003; Feng Shui, 2004; Bulong (Whisper), 2011; The Healing, 2012; and Feng Shui 2, 2014.  

In television, he was scriptwriter for the weekly musical Zsa Zsa, which was chosen by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) through its Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon as one of the best programs in 1987. He wrote a number of award-winning episodes in PEP Talk, 1986-90; Inside Story, 1990-98; and Coast to Coast, ca 1990. He was part of the creative team in ABS-CBN that pioneered the multi-awarded Café Bravo in the 1990s.

He wrote the first episodes of the docudrama, GMA True Stories, 1995-97, and served as creative consultant for ABS-CBN’s crime anthology, The Calvento Files, 1995-98. He wrote teleplays for drama programs such as ABS-CBN’s Star Drama, 1993-2001, and Your Honor, 2001-02; and GMA 7’s Spotlight, 1990-98, and GMA Telesine, 1993-99. Under GMA Network, he was head writer of the political soap opera Kung Mawawala Ka (A World Without You), 2002-03, as well as writer/script supervisor for the fantasy series Darna, 2005, with Angel Locsin as the heroine.

Iglesias received the Best Video Documentary award at the Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video for the documentary Edjop, 1987, about the life of political activist Edgar Jopson. He wrote The Palace of the People, a documentary about the Malacañan written during Pres Fidel V. Ramos’s administration. He was awarded the ICD Sony International Best Documentary for the environmental documentary Returning the Forest to the People. He won the KBP Golden Dove Award for Best TV Scriptwriter in 1994 for RPN 9’s miniseries De Buena Familia (The Good Family).

Iglesias wrote the screenplay of Sigaw (The Echo), 2004, a horror film with a remake in Hollywood under the title The Echo. He won Best Screenplay at the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) for three consecutive years: Yamashita: The Tiger’s Treasure in 2001, Mano Po (I Kiss Your Hand) in 2002, and Filipinas in 2003. Mano Po 2: My Home was awarded Best Original Story in the MMFF in 2003. His script for Baler won Best Story in the MMFF and Best Original Screenplay in the 2008 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards. His Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story won Best Screenplay at the MMFF in 2011.  Written by Cynthia Cruz-Paz

ILAGAN, RUBEN (Ruben de Leon Ilagan) aka Ruben de Leon. b. Shanghai 20 Aug 1933. Radio-television producer, director, actor, commentator. He is the son of Conrado Ilagan, aka Conrado Conde, character actor and band leader, and Anna de Leon. On the Ilagan side are several generations of writers and performing artists who adopted different names, beginning with Hermogenes Ilagan, tenor, actor, and playwright, who earned the title “Father of Tagalog Sarsuwela,” himself a descendant of poet laureate Francisco Balagtas; Marceliano Ilagan, lead actor in the first Philippine movie produced in the Philippines in 1919, Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), based on a sarsuwela written by Hermogenes; movie director Gerardo “Gerry” de Leon, National Artist for film; pianist-composer Tito Arevalo; comedian Eddie Nagali (Ilagan in reverse); and actors Fely Vallejo, Laling Talti, Angel Esmeralda, Juliet Ilagan, Robert Arevalo, Liberty Ilagan, Jay Ilagan, and Janno Gibbs. He was married to Cristina Santiago Tolentino, aka Tina Loy, radio soap opera, TV, and film actor, singer, radio variety show producer and host, drama coach, and program director, with whom he had five children. He attended Moises Salvador Elementary School, Arellano University High School, and Centro Escolar University until 1951.

Upon leaving school he began acting in radio dramas in the early 1950s on Republic Broadcasting System’s DZBB, Manila Broadcasting Company’s DZRH, and ABS-CBN’s DZXL, voicing characters in the soaps Imelda, Patibong (Trap), Camay Theater of the Air, Ito ang Maynila (This Is Manila), Mga Patak ng Luha (Teardrops), Salamat sa Buhay (Thanks to Life), Ito ang Katotohanan (This Is the Truth), and Kasaysayan ng Pag-ibig (History of Love). Moving beyond acting, he directed Ito ang Katotohanan, Kasaysayan ng Pag-ibig, and The Liberty Milk Show. In the 1970s, Ilagan directed television programs, including the GMA Channel 7 sitcom Baltic & Co., which was based on the serialized comic strip created by cartoonist Roni Santiago for the Manila Bulletin.

Ilagan also served as commentator on DZBB and Channel 7, 1955-72, and Bureau of Broadcast’s DZFM and DZRM, 1978-86; newscaster on Channel 7, 1972-73, and National Media Production Center’s Channel 4, 1973-75; and television producer on Channel 7 and Inter-island Broadcasting Corporation’s Channel 13, l973-75. He was a member of the board of directors of Radio Philippines Network’s Channel 9, 2001-10.

Among the citations he received for his work was a 1976 Philippine Academy of Television Arts and Sciences nomination as Best Director for a TV Comedy Series for Baltic & Co. Written byEdgardo Ray G. Pedroche

Sources: Ilagan 2014; Philippine Cinema on World War II 2014; Wikipedia 2014e, 2014i, 2014k

ILARDE, EDDIE (Edgar Ubalde Ilarde) aka Kuya Eddie. b. Iriga, Camarines Sur, 25 Aug 1934. His parents were schoolteachers Agapita Ubalde and Emilio Ilarde. He is married to Sylvia Berenguer Arrastia, with whom he has seven children. Son Nilo Ilarde is a visual artist, while another son, Rico Maria Ilarde, is a filmmaker. He graduated with a bachelor of arts degree from Far Eastern University.

Ilarde was 21 when he began working in radio, first as trainee on DZBB, then as announcer on DZRH where he played records of Nat King Cole, Vic Damone, and Frank Sinatra on the program A Date with the Stars. In 1955, Ilarde moved to Chronicle Broadcasting Network’s (CBN) DZXL to host Si Dely at si Eddie with Tiya Dely Magpayo. His most popular program Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday) began airing in the same year. Playing popular love songs, Ilarde dispensed advice to listeners who wrote about their love stories. As the station’s live commercial announcer on the noontime show CBN Canteen, where students comprised most of the studio audience, he convinced CBN to hold the show in the studio’s canteen, renaming the show Student Canteen. When in 1957 CBN merged with Alto Broadcasting System (ABS), which operated the first television station in the Philippines, DZAQ TV Channel 3, Student Canteen crossed over to television with Ilarde, Leila Benitez, Bobby Ledesma, and Pepe Pimentel as hosts and Amado Pascual as pianist. Ilarde and Benitez transferred to Channel 11 to host Darigold Jamboree, 1964-72. In 1975, Ilarde and Ledesma relaunched Student Canteen on GMA Channel 7 where Ilarde also hosted Suwerte sa Siyete (Lucky at Seven) and produced as blocktimer the soap opera Yagit (Abandoned Children) and the drama anthology Kahapon Lamang, 1976-86.

Kahapon Lamang on television was the first of Ilarde’s TV programs that dramatized the lives of lovelorn letter-writers who asked for his advice. The other was Napakasakit, Kuya Eddie (It Hurts, Brother Eddie), 1986-88, on ABS-CBN Channel 2. From these shows he became known for the lines “Dear Kuya Eddie” and “Mabalos!” (“Thank you” in Bikol language). The songs “Kahapon Lamang,” popularized by Sharon Cuneta, and “Nakapakasakit, Kuya Eddie” by Roel Cortez were inspired by Ilarde’s advice programs.

Ilarde also hosted The Eddie Ilarde Show, 1959-62, on ABS-CBN Channel 3; and Alas Dose sa Trese (Twelve Noon on 13), 1999-2000, on IBC Channel 13. He acted in the movies Omeng Satanasia, 1977; Dear Eddie and Ako’y Iyong-Iyo (I’m Yours), both in 1963; and narrated the movie Kahapon Lamang, 1959. He began hosting Kahapon Lamang: The Second 50 Years on DZBB in 2009.

In 1963, Ilarde entered politics, serving as councilor of Pasay City. In 1965, he was elected congressman for the first district of Rizal, then senator in 1969. In 1972, his term was cut short when Pres Ferdinand Marcos declared martial law and abolished Congress. In 1978, he aligned himself with Marcos and won a seat in the Interim Batasang Pambansa as assemblyman for Metro Manila and served until 1984.

Having logged over 60 years on radio and television, Ilarde received several lifetime achievement awards, including one from the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas in 2009.Written by Maricel L. Baltazar and Rolando F. Santos

Sources:

Dolor 2013b; Farolan 2009; GMA Network 2013a; Pe 2011; San Diego 2009; Senate of the Philippines 2013a; Video 48 2008b; Wikipedia 2013c, 2013e.

INVENTOR, NANETTE (Agnes Maniago Inventor) b. Mexico, Pampanga 20 Apr 1953. Singer, TV, film, and theater actor. Her father, a trial court judge, was from Iloilo, although his Panlilio roots hail from Pampanga. Her mother belongs to the Maniago clan of Mexico, Pampanga. She is one of four children. She studied at the University of the Philippines (UP) Preparatory School and graduated in high school in 1969. She earned a degree in foreign service from UP in 1974. She teaches communication courses at the Wesleyan College of Manila.

She started singing at the age of seven as a church choir member and was an active member of the UP Cherubims and Seraphims in the late 1960s and the UP Concert Chorus from 1974 to 1981 before pursuing a solo career in music. She was only 19 when she completed her university degree and, while waiting to turn 21 in order to take the qualifying exams given by the Department of Foreign Affairs, she first worked as a personnel officer at the Department of Public Works, Transportation, and Communication, while doing backup vocals with the group Filipina for Celeste Legaspi, Pilita Corrales, Basil Valdez, Leah Navarro, Apo Hiking Society, Imelda Papin, and Yoyoy Villame.

She first appeared in the social satire film Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (Will Your Heart Beat Faster?), 1980, by Mike de Leon in which she played the leader of singing fake nuns. But it was her television appearance in the weekly music variety show Penthouse Live, 1982-87, GMA, that launched her career in show business. She became famous for her character Doña Buding, a persona intended for the program’s resident musical comic Cynthia Patag, who had a vehicular accident and thus needed replacement. Created by Jose Javier Reyes and directed by Fritz Ynfante, Doña Buding, or Doña Leonila Evaporada Viuda de Ford, debuted on 14 Nov 1983 and became a regular segment of the program. The character alluded to the Blue Ladies, who were socialite wives of powerful men who used their political connections to advance their businesses and with whom then First Lady Imelda Marcos surrounded herself.

Her other programs were the talk show Telechismis (TV Rumors), 1994, IBC 13; the sitcoms U. F. O. (Urbana, Felisa and Others), 1984, Family Zoo, 2006, both on GMA, and Madam Chairman, 2013, TV5; the musical primetime series Pangarap na Bituin (Dream Star), 2007, ABS-CBN; the superhero series Flash Bomba, 2009, ABS-CBN; the fantasy-adventure Panday Kids (Blacksmith Kids), 2010, and Dyesebel, 2008, both on GMA; the comedy reality show Ang Yaman ni Lola (The Wealth of Grandmother), 2010-11, GMA; and the teleserye (TV series) On the Wings of Love, 2015, ABS-CBN. She appeared several times in the drama anthology Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), which began in 1991 on ABS-CBN, the most remarkable of which was in the episode “Bracelet,” 2015.

Some of the films in which she appeared were the critically acclaimed Batch ’81, 1982; the horror-comedy Multo in the City, 1994; the romance movies Let the Love Begin, 2005, and One More Chance, 2007; and the indie films Alagwa, 2012, Beauty in a Bottle, 2014, and Balut Country, Filemon Mamon, and Ms. Bulalakaw, all in 2015.

Some of her dinner theater productions and stand-up comedy revues were Tit for Tat, 1984-85, the Rock da Vote series, 1992-95, directed by Floy Quintos, and 2,000 Lbs of Laughter and Love, 2000, all with tandem Mitch Valdez; What’s Laff Got to Do with It!, 2011; the 12th Korus Concert in Vallejo, Bay Area, California, with the UP Concert Chorus, 2012; and Pinoy Comedy Concert with Mikey Bustos, 2015. She continued parodying personalities with the characters of Nanette Nafoolish and Vagigi Reyes, 2013, a caricature of people in high places accused of allegedly facilitating the plunder by politicians of the country’s treasury. Memorable theater-musicals in which she played important roles were Menopause, 2004; Honk! The Ugly Duckling, 2003; Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1995; and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1995. She was part of the Japan and Malaysia tour of Noli and Fili in 1995. She acted in the play Separasyon (Separation), 2013.

Her remarkable solo concerts were Buding for Mayor, 1988; Isang Dosenang Sarap (A Dozen of Zest), 1995; Fat, Fifty and F-aa-bulous!, 2003; and Naughty Nanette Me, 2013. As a singer, she released her album Sumpong (Caprice) in 1996.

She won, with Mitch Valdez, the Best Stand-Up Comedy Act award for Tit for Tat at the Aliw Awards, 1984, and the Best Solo Performer award at the Aliw Awards in 2000. Her interpretation of Gary Granada’s “Salamat, Salamat Musika” (Thank You, Thank You, Music) won for the song the grand prize at the 7th Metro Manila Popular Music Festival in 1984. JIMENEZ, MENARDO R. (Menardo Rodriguez Jimenez) aka Nards Jimenez. b. Dasol, Pangasinan 6 Dec 1932. Broadcast executive, accountant, businessman. His parents were Marcelo Jimenez, a four-term mayor of Dasol, and Emiliana Rodriguez, first female mayor in the Philippines and former vice mayor of Dasol, from the 1920s to the 1930s. He is eighth among nine siblings. He is married to Carolina Gozon, sister of his colleague at GMA, Felipe L. Gozon. They have four children, all of whom are connected with GMA: Menardo “Butch” Jr of GMA Films; Joel Marcelo, a board director of the network since 2002; Laura Jimenez-Westfall, also a board director of GMA since 2000; and Carmen Jimenez-Ong, a former head of the GMA Kapuso Foundation. Jimenez, during his high school days in Pangasinan, did odd jobs, such as shoe shining, renting out komiks and the popular magazines Bannawag and Liwayway, and managing the only bicycle store in his hometown. After college, he worked as a bookkeeper in the Abaca Corporation of the Philippines and gradually rose from the ranks to become its assistant general manager, but quit the government job in 1963 to serve as a consultant for a mining firm and put up his own export-import firm.

While working briefly with the Bureau of Internal Revenue, stamping “For Official Use Only” on countless documents, he attended night classes to complete a bachelor of science in commerce at Far Eastern University, which he obtained in 1952. He became a certified public accountant in 1955.

Jimenez is trustee of the Asian Institute of Journalism and Communication, a founding member of the Asian Institute of Design and Technology, and a member of the International Advertising Association Incorporated and the Manila Overseas Press Club. He runs 12 firms and sits on the board of more than a dozen corporations, including Cable Entertainment Corporation, Mabuhay Philippine Satellite Corporation, San Miguel Corporation, Coffee Bean and Tea Leaf Holdings, United Coconut Planters Bank, Albay-Agro Industrial Development Corporation, Majalco Finance and Investment Corporation, First Metro Bank Investment Corporation, and Meedson Properties Corporation.

Jimenez is one among the triumvirate of Felipe L. Gozon and Gilberto Duavit Sr that made GMA a respected broadcast network in the Philippines. They acquired the then fledgling Republic Broadcasting System (RBS-DZBB) from owner Robert “Uncle Bob” Stewart whose right to own a media company was disallowed by the 1973 Constitution in the aftermath of the declaration of martial law in 1972, as he was a foreigner. They renamed the station Greater Manila Area–Radio Television Arts (GMA-RTV), and rechristened it in 1996 as GMA Network Incorporated, with GMA standing for Global Media Arts.

Jimenez helped turn around the operations of GMA Network. He declined the offer of Gozon and Duavit Sr to serve as the president of RBS when they bought it from Stewart in 1974, but eventually agreed to become its president seven months later. Saddled with a debt of six million pesos to foreign suppliers of entertainment programs when they took over GMA and last on the spot of seven television stations then, he enforced measures to cut the station’s operating expenses until it became financially stable in a span of two years. The station then was called “The Popeye Station” because of its excessively rerun syndicated program, the cartoon program Popeye, plus its other foreign programs, the war serial Combat and the detective series Mission Impossible. Jimenez initiated the change in the network’s programming, driving a rapid expansion of its content by importing canned shows, such as the weekly detective drama Charlie’s Angels and the daily soap Rich Man, Poor Man. The station became the source of imported programs, like The Bionic Woman, Kolchak: The Night Stalker, The Muppet Show, Mork & Mindy, James at 15, Little House on the Prairie, The Paul Lynde Show, Love Boat, Three’s Company, CHiPS, and Starsky & Hutch. This move by Jimenez partly contributed to GMA’s rise in the ratings.

The daily public service program Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love My Fellowman), which premiered in 1974 and continued its run until after the downfall of the Marcos government, was his brainchild. Anchored by Orly Mercado, Boots Anson-Roa, Cielito del Mundo, kidney specialist Dr Antonio Talusan, and later with Connie Angeles and Rosa Rosal, the show helped those who needed medical attention, featured medical cases, and solicited funds on-air for indigents with all sorts of illnesses and needs. Jimenez encouraged more shows of this type, such as Agrisiete (Agriculture on Seven), co-produced with the Technology and Livelihood Resource Center and which regularly featured experts from the University of the Philippines at Los Baños and the Department of Science and Technology, and hosted by popular celebrity German Moreno; the entrepreneurial show Negosiete, 1987-92; and the blocktimer AgriLink, 1993-99, produced by Cheche Lazaro’s Probe Productions and hosted by Luchi Cruz-Valdes.

Jimenez retired as GMA president in 2000 and passed on the torch of the leadership and management of the network to his brother-in-law, Felipe L. Gozon. He ranked 27th on the Forbes list of the “Philippines’ 40 Richest” in 2012, with a net worth of 185 million US dollars. He was named 46th richest on the Forbes list of the “Philippines’ 50 Richest” in 2015, with a net worth of 165 million US dollars.

He received the Gawad para sa Natatanging Kontribusyon from the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon in 1990. The Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas conferred on him the Lifetime Achievement Award at the 7th Golden Dove Awards in 1997. He received the Outstanding Filipino Award for Business and Entrepreneurship in 1997. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Dean Airo Salvador E. Dancel

KANLAON BROADCASTING SYSTEM / RADIO PHILIPPINES NETWORK 9 (KBS / RPN 9, later known as New Vision 9, C/S9, Solar TV, Entertainment Channel, Solar News Channel, 9TV, Cable News Network Philippines) KBS / RPN 9 has been the broadcaster and affiliate of Cable News Network (CNN) Philippines. The Philippine Congress approved the franchise of the station on 19 Jun 1960. Roberto S. Benedicto, the owner of the station and a close ally of former president Ferdinand Marcos, chose for the station the call letters KBS, with “K” standing for Kanlaon, an active volcano on Negros Island, Benedicto’s home province. The headquarters of CNN Philippines are in the Worldwide Corporate Center on Shaw Blvd corner EDSA in Mandaluyong City in Metro Manila. Its free TV transmitter is located in the RPN Compound on Panay Ave in Diliman, Quezon City.

 

KBS first operated as radio station DZBI in Manila. By 1967, it had grown into a full network of eight radio stations, composed of DZBI, DZRR, and DZAX in Manila, DZAH and DZBS in Baguio, DZTG in Tuguegarao, DZRL in Laoag, and DXDX in General Santos City. It ventured into television in Nov 1969, launching KBS 9 in Manila and KBS 12 in Baguio City. The station changed its name to Radio Philippines Network in 1975. During the martial law period, RPN 9 operated in Broadcast City at Old Balara in Quezon City, together with broadcast stations Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation (IBC) Channel 13 and Banahaw Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) Channel 2, all under Benedicto.

 

KBS/RPN 9, under the management of Benedicto’s daughter Kitchie, was the dominant media network during the height of the martial law period in the 1970s and the first half of the 1980s before its TV and radio stations were taken over by the post-1986 EDSA administration. It has undergone several rebranding since then: New Vision 9 in 1989, back to RPN 9 in 1994, C/S9 in 2008 when it entered into a partnership with Solar Entertainment Corporation, Solar TV in 1999 when it expanded its ventures with Solar, as Entertainment Central (ETC) in 2011 when the government started privatizing the network’s assets, Solar News Channel in 2013 and 9TV in 2014 when ownership of majority shares to the station changed rapidly from one corporation to another, and finally CNN Philippines on 16 Mar 2015, becoming the third CNN affiliate in Asia; the other two are in Indonesia and India.

 

KBS/RPN 9 was the first station to go on full color broadcast. The network’s launch in 1969 carried the identification tag “Accucolor 9.” Accucolor was the color technology used by the station. The station was also the first to employ an outside broadcast (OB) van in its news operations, having acquired in 1970 a color-ready OB van for the remote broadcasts of major news events and sports coverage.

 

KBS/RPN 9 was the first Philippine network to go on full satellite broadcast daily. The Benedicto group, having drawn loans from the government-owned Philippine National Bank, expanded the operation of the station to 12 regions of the country. On 21 Sep 1977, the fifth anniversary of the declaration of martial law, Benedicto inaugurated domestic satellite communications or DOMSAT, with RPN 9 serving as its transmitting network of 11 satellite earth stations nationwide and for all special broadcasts from the Office of the President. RPN 9 also served as the relay station of IBC’s 12 TV and 18 radio stations, as well as those of BBC and the government broadcast station GTV Channel 4. DOMSAT went full blast in its operation in Jan 1980 in preparation for the provincial and municipal elections during the same year, which made possible the national coverage of candidates under Marcos’s political party, the Kilusang Bagong Lipunan. It also made possible the influx into the network of many foreign entertainment programs and specials. Through DOMSAT, the daily noontime variety program Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!) of RPN 9 was able to expand its viewership, enabling the program to dislodge from the top spot its rival program Student Canteen of RBS-GMA 7. RPN 9 also attracted top transnational corporations for its advertisements—namely, Unilever’s Philippine Refining Company, Procter & Gamble, Colgate-Palmolive, Consolidated Foods Corporation, Nestle’s Filipro, San Miguel Corporation, Pepsi Corporation, Radiowealth, and Johnson & Johnson. The lone fully domestic corporation advertiser it had was Banco Filipino.

 

RPN 9 also enjoyed other benefits from the Marcos administration. In 1978, Marcos gave control of the television industry to RPN 9 by overturning a law that encouraged domestic production of TV receivers and, through Letter of Instruction 640, gave Nivico, a Japanese-Benedicto joint TV manufacturing venture, sole tax- and duty-free component import rights. Nivico’s principal foreign partner was the Japanese transnational conglomerate Marubeni, a television manufacturer, which became the major supplier of RPN 9 and DOMSAT. Other major television manufacturers protested the decree, but nothing came out of the protest.

 

By 1976, RPN 9 was the highest earner among broadcast stations of the period. It had a total TV sales recorded at 67.4 million pesos. In 1977, RPN enjoyed a whopping 50 percent audience market share. By 1978, RPN had 13 TV stations and at least 31 radio stations.

 

RPN 9 was the network where Marcos declared the imposition of martial law in Sep 1972. The station absorbed some programs of ABS-CBN during the martial law period, under new titles. Examples were Si Tatang Kasi (Blame It on Father), which became Naku Po, Tatang (Oh No, Father), and Mrs. Milyonarya (Mrs Millionaire), which was given the title Ginang Milyonarya (Madam Millionaire). RPN 9 produced some of the most highly rated programs of the martial law period until the early years of the post-EDSA administration, such as the weekly music variety show Superstar, 1971-89; the comedy series John en Marsha (John and Marsha), 1973-90, Cafeteria Aroma, 1979, Duplex, 1982-84, and Buddy en Sol, 1990-95; the gag show Champoy, 1981-85; the daily soap operas Mga Kuwento ng Pag-ibig (Stories of Love), 1977, Flordeluna, 1979-84, Heredero (Heir), 1984-87, and Agila (Eagle), 1987-89; the drama anthologies Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora), 1974-79, Coney Reyes-Mumar Drama Studio, 1984-89, and Hilda Drama Specials, 1989; the children’s programs Clubhouse 9, 1977-78, and Kaluskos Musmos (Kiddie Noise), 1979-89, produced by presidential daughter Imee Marcos; the game show Spin-a-Win, 1975-85; and the talk show Tell the People, 1981-97. RPN 9 aired Malayo Pa ang Umaga, 1979, based on the novel Without Seeing the Dawn, 1947, by Stevan Javellana and produced by Armida Siguion-Reyna, which could be considered the first miniseries on Philippine television, later to be billed telenovela in the 2000s. A two-hour special was the animation version of the Iluko epic Biag ni Lam-ang (Life of Lam-ang), which aired on 21 Sep 1979. It was an unusual project because animation was rarely pursued in Philippine television, particularly during this period. RPN 9 was the original home of the noontime variety show Eat Bulaga! from 1979 to 1989 before the show moved to ABS-CBN, 1989-94, and finally settled on GMA beginning in 1994.

 

The station innovated on news programs, such as having two editions of the daily English newscast NewsWatch: the evening edition at 7:00 pm and the final edition at 10:00 pm, hosted in pair and alternately by Harry Gasser, Caloy Prieto, Ernie Fresnido, Pat Lazaro, Cielo Villaluna, Cathy Santillan, and Eric Eloriaga. NewsWatch was the first ever live TV newscast aired nationwide via satellite. NewsWatch added in its programming the weekly NewsWatch: Junior Edition, 1976-93, with children, like Janice de Belen and Cathy Babao, reading the news or talking about the issues of the day in a freewheeling discussion portion presided over by producer Agnes Caballa.

 

RPN could be considered one of the early networks that ushered in the concept of live global satellite programming in local television. Important global events it covered live included the 1972 Munich Olympics, the early Muhammad Ali fights, the Aloha from Hawaii concert of Elvis Presley in 1973, and the 1974 Miss Universe pageant in Manila.

During the days of the EDSA Revolt, RPN 9 covered a parallel presidential inauguration of Marcos, the same network where he announced the declaration of martial law in 1972, and then the last media outlet still in the control of the Marcos government in 1986. The coverage of the inauguration was interrupted. Rebel forces had taken over RPN. The Corazon Aquino administration sequestered RPN in the aftermath of the EDSA Revolt, but it was allowed to continue its operations.

 

The station managed to bounce back a bit in 1996 when it offered the daily Mexican telenovela Marimar, dubbed in Filipino. The program became a monster hit, which dislodged the newscast TV Patrol of ABS-CBN from its number one ranking in the ratings game. The program significantly altered the landscape of the late afternoon and evening primetime programming. The success of Marimar provided the impetus for broadcast networks to produce daily drama serials in the early evening primetime programming. By the late 1990s, the daily drama serials, either locally produced or imported, had started to flood the airwaves, with Latin American telenovelas dominating the evening programming. With the phenomenal popularity of Marimar, RPN offered more Mexican telenovelas.

 

RPN 9, however, continued to suffer from complicated legal tussles, conflicts in the switching ownership of shares from one private interest to another, and the intensely competitive field of commercial broadcasting. CNN took over the station in 2015.

 

Many top TV network executives, entertainers, and media professionals in the post-1986 broadcast and media industries, particularly in the GMA, ABS-CBN, and ABC 5 networks, trained and honed their creative, technical, journalistic, and managerial talents at KBS/RPN 9. article.value: KANLAON BROADCASTING SYSTEM / RADIO PHILIPPINES NETWORK 9 (KBS / RPN 9, later known as New Vision 9, C/S9, Solar TV, Entertainment Channel, Solar News Channel, 9TV, Cable News Network Philippines) KBS / RPN 9 has been the broadcaster and affiliate of Cable News Network (CNN) Philippines. The Philippine Congress approved the franchise of the station on 19 Jun 1960. Roberto S. Benedicto, the owner of the station and a close ally of former president Ferdinand Marcos, chose for the station the call letters KBS, with “K” standing for Kanlaon, an active volcano on Negros Island, Benedicto’s home province. The headquarters of CNN Philippines are in the Worldwide Corporate Center on Shaw Blvd corner EDSA in Mandaluyong City in Metro Manila. Its free TV transmitter is located in the RPN Compound on Panay Ave in Diliman, Quezon City.

KBS first operated as radio station DZBI in Manila. By 1967, it had grown into a full network of eight radio stations, composed of DZBI, DZRR, and DZAX in Manila, DZAH and DZBS in Baguio, DZTG in Tuguegarao, DZRL in Laoag, and DXDX in General Santos City. It ventured into television in Nov 1969, launching KBS 9 in Manila and KBS 12 in Baguio City. The station changed its name to Radio Philippines Network in 1975. During the martial law period, RPN 9 operated in Broadcast City at Old Balara in Quezon City, together with broadcast stations Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation (IBC) Channel 13 and Banahaw Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) Channel 2, all under Benedicto.

KBS/RPN 9, under the management of Benedicto’s daughter Kitchie, was the dominant media network during the height of the martial law period in the 1970s and the first half of the 1980s before its TV and radio stations were taken over by the post-1986 EDSA administration. It has undergone several rebranding since then: New Vision 9 in 1989, back to RPN 9 in 1994, C/S9 in 2008 when it entered into a partnership with Solar Entertainment Corporation, Solar TV in 1999 when it expanded its ventures with Solar, as Entertainment Central (ETC) in 2011 when the government started privatizing the network’s assets, Solar News Channel in 2013 and 9TV in 2014 when ownership of majority shares to the station changed rapidly from one corporation to another, and finally CNN Philippines on 16 Mar 2015, becoming the third CNN affiliate in Asia; the other two are in Indonesia and India.

KBS/RPN 9 was the first station to go on full color broadcast. The network’s launch in 1969 carried the identification tag “Accucolor 9.” Accucolor was the color technology used by the station. The station was also the first to employ an outside broadcast (OB) van in its news operations, having acquired in 1970 a color-ready OB van for the remote broadcasts of major news events and sports coverage.

KBS/RPN 9 was the first Philippine network to go on full satellite broadcast daily. The Benedicto group, having drawn loans from the government-owned Philippine National Bank, expanded the operation of the station to 12 regions of the country. On 21 Sep 1977, the fifth anniversary of the declaration of martial law, Benedicto inaugurated domestic satellite communications or DOMSAT, with RPN 9 serving as its transmitting network of 11 satellite earth stations nationwide and for all special broadcasts from the Office of the President. RPN 9 also served as the relay station of IBC’s 12 TV and 18 radio stations, as well as those of BBC and the government broadcast station GTV Channel 4. DOMSAT went full blast in its operation in Jan 1980 in preparation for the provincial and municipal elections during the same year, which made possible the national coverage of candidates under Marcos’s political party, the Kilusang Bagong Lipunan. It also made possible the influx into the network of many foreign entertainment programs and specials. Through DOMSAT, the daily noontime variety program Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!) of RPN 9 was able to expand its viewership, enabling the program to dislodge from the top spot its rival program Student Canteen of RBS-GMA 7. RPN 9 also attracted top transnational corporations for its advertisements—namely, Unilever’s Philippine Refining Company, Procter & Gamble, Colgate-Palmolive, Consolidated Foods Corporation, Nestle’s Filipro, San Miguel Corporation, Pepsi Corporation, Radiowealth, and Johnson & Johnson. The lone fully domestic corporation advertiser it had was Banco Filipino.

RPN 9 also enjoyed other benefits from the Marcos administration. In 1978, Marcos gave control of the television industry to RPN 9 by overturning a law that encouraged domestic production of TV receivers and, through Letter of Instruction 640, gave Nivico, a Japanese-Benedicto joint TV manufacturing venture, sole tax- and duty-free component import rights. Nivico’s principal foreign partner was the Japanese transnational conglomerate Marubeni, a television manufacturer, which became the major supplier of RPN 9 and DOMSAT. Other major television manufacturers protested the decree, but nothing came out of the protest.

By 1976, RPN 9 was the highest earner among broadcast stations of the period. It had a total TV sales recorded at 67.4 million pesos. In 1977, RPN enjoyed a whopping 50 percent audience market share. By 1978, RPN had 13 TV stations and at least 31 radio stations.

Examples were Si Tatang Kasi (Blame It on Father), which became Naku Po, Tatang (Oh No, Father), and Mrs. Milyonarya (Mrs Millionaire), which was given the title Ginang Milyonarya (Madam Millionaire). article_title: Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP)
text:
KAPISANAN NG MGA BRODKASTER NG PILIPINAS (KBP) The Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas is a private, nonstock, nonprofit association of broadcast media owners that was formed on 27 Apr 1973. Romeo Jalosjos figured prominently in its creation and the organization’s subsequent concept of self-regulation. Then connected with Bob Stewart’s Republic Broadcasting System, the precursor company of GMA 7, Jalosjos rallied several media owners to commit themselves to an organization that would serve as the voice of the industry to government. Media owners were apprehensive of full government control of the broadcast industry under martial law, which suppressed the basic freedom of expression and endangered broadcast media owners’ business interests. Thus, the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (Association of Broadcasters in the Philippines) was born, renamed after the EDSA Revolt as Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (Association of Broadcasters of the Philippines).

The first general membership meeting and the election of the board took place on the day of its formation. The 29 original KBP member networks are as follows: Allied Broadcasting Center, Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP), Bayanihan Broadcasting Corporation, Eagle Broadcasting Corporation, East Visayas Broadcasting Corporation, Eastern Broadcasting System, Far East Broadcasting Company, Fairwaves Broadcasting Network, Filipinas Broadcasting Network (FBN), Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation, Insular Broadcasting System (IBS), Hypersonic Broadcasting Center (HBC), Mabuhay Broadcasting System (MBS), Manila Broadcasting Company, Nation Broadcasting Corporation (NBC), Northern Broadcasting (NB), Pedro N. Roa Broadcasting, People’s Broadcasting Network, Philippine Broadcasting Service / Bureau of Broadcast Services (PBS/BBS), Radio Mindanao Network (RMN), Radio Philippines Network (RPN), Republic Broadcasting Network, Trans-Radio Broadcasting Corporation (TRBC), United Broadcasting Network (UBN), University of Mindanao Broadcasting Network (UMBN), Vanguard Radio Network, Victory Broadcasting System, Zambales Broadcasting and Development Corporation, and Zamboanga TV Corporation.

The first KBP Board Officers were Emil Jurado of RPN as president; Raul N. Choa of the Visayan Broadcasting Corporation as executive vice-president and vice-president (VP) for the Visayas; Romeo Jalosjos of RPN as VP for Greater Manila; Antonio C. Barreiro of NB as VP for Luzon; Abelardo L. Yabut Sr of NBC as VP for Mindanao; Jose D. Hinlo of the AFP as treasurer; Don Lee of IBS as board secretary; and Hernadez Baldo of HBC, Roberto V. Gozum of FBN, Emilio Tuazon of TRBC, and Antonio Ilustre as directors. Except for Tuazon and Ilustre, nine were part of the original 15 incorporators of the association. The other six original incorporators were Andre Khan of TRBC, Wilfredo Camomot of RMN, Arcadio Carandang of MBS, Rebueno Hodreal of UBN, Guillermo Torres Sr of UMBN, and Jose Borromeo of PBS/BBS.

Another media personality who figured prominently in the life of the KBP was newspaper columnist Teodoro Valencia who at that time had the ears of President Marcos.In Jun 1974, he was elected president of KBP. Valencia led KBP board members in convincing Marcos that the broadcast industry, now united under one umbrella, was ready to professionalize and regulate its ranks. The government then was mainly overseeing sizeable concerns of telecommunications and media, through the Department of Public Information, the Media Advisory Committee (MAC), the Bureau of Standards for Mass Media (BSMM), the Telecommunications Control Bureau, and the Board of Communications. A devolution of media regulation was seen as advantageous to the broadcast industry. The mission proved successful. On 8 Nov 1974, one-and-a-half years after KBP was formed, Marcos signed Presidential Decree (PD) 576 abolishing the MAC and the BSMM, and creating the Broadcast Media Council (BMC) and the Print Media Council (PMC). Before the end of 1974, KBP officers were appointed as members of the BMC, a move that laid the foundation for the self-regulatory nature of the Philippine broadcast industry, which is expressed in one of the provisions of PD 576: “the various sectors of mass media have shown capability for self-regulation and internal discipline within its ranks and have demonstrated responsibility for maintaining standards for professional conduct and excellence … and the prevailing national situation has become appropriate for taking a further step toward removal of government participation in policy determination and news dissemination activities of mass media.”

When martial law was lifted in Jan 1981, the BMC and the PMC were abolished through PD 1784, which gave the broadcast and print media the power to establish other self-regulatory bodies of their own. The role of the BMC to set industry standards and discipline broadcasters was subsequently given to the KBP, which ultimately formed its own enforcement body, the KBP Standards Authority, thereby strengthening broadcast self-regulation in the country.

The policymaking body of KBP is an 11-member Board of Trustees elected by the general membership during the annual Top Level Management Conference. The board is composed of a chair, a vice chair, president, an executive vice president, a vice president each for television and radio, a secretary, a treasurer, and three directors.

Membership in the KBP is open to any natural or juridical grantee of a congressional franchise or a permit or license to operate given by the National Telecommunications Commission. There are three membership classifications: charter member, an original KBP member at the time of the approval of the association’s by-laws; regular member, any natural or juridical person who represents a grantee of a franchise or a permit or certificate to operate, holds the position of chair, president or its equivalent in the network, and has the authority to bind the regular member he or she represents in the KBP; and associate member, any radio or TV station operated by a regular member as represented by its station manager. Only charter and regular members have the right to vote and be elected to office.

From an original 29 member networks, the KBP, as of Oct 2014, had 128 member networks. Under each member network are several individual radio and TV stations. As of 2014, KBP’s membership covers 775 broadcast stations nationwide: 415 FM radio stations, 248 AM radio stations, and 112 TV stations. This represents about 90 percent of the total number of radio and television stations nationwide. As of Jan 2015, KBP has 35 active local chapters nationwide, which initiate and manage local projects, coordinate national-initiated programs, monitor broadcasters, and hear and solve cases filed against practitioners.

The activities, projects, and daily operations of the KBP are coordinated and managed by a national secretariat headed by an executive director who oversees four departments: projects and administrative, credit and collection, finance and accounting, and standards authority. It holds office on the sixth floor of the LTA Building in Legaspi Village, Makati City.

KBP has made its mark in the industry. One of its major accomplishments was its designation, by Republic Act 9369, to receive a copy of the electronically transmitted election returns from the Commission on Elections (Comelec) in the automated elections in 2003. The act enabled KBP member stations to have immediate and direct access to election returns. In 2014, with KBP as one of the petitioners against a revised Comelec ruling, the Supreme Court decided on the allowable number of political advertising load in all broadcast media. Instead of the aggregate number of 120 minutes for all TV and 180 minutes for all radio political advertisements per candidate, the Supreme Court upheld Comelec’s original ruling of 120 minutes per individual TV station and 180 minutes per individual radio station for every candidate for national offices. This decision was favorable to KBP members’ business interests. KBP also got the court’s approval for broadcast networks to cover high-profile cases, which normally media would have been banned to cover, which included the live coverage of Pres Joseph Estrada’s plunder case in 2001 and the Ampatuan massacre trial in 2011. KBP has protected its members from advertisers who reneged on their financial obligations to member stations. It has implemented self-discipline among its members, banning broadcasters found committing unethical practices from going on the air. It made major revisions in its Broadcast Code, particularly on the coverage of crime, crisis situations, and children, resulting from incidents such as the Rizal Park hostage-taking by a policeman of several Chinese tourists on 23 Aug 2010 and the Janjan macho dance controversy on TV5’s program Willing Willie on 12 Mar 2011.

A new challenge confronts KBP now. With new media platforms, specifically the Internet, competing with the broadcast industry, the KBP has to reinvent itself anew to sustain its authority and credibility in the field and continue its role to guide and serve its members and, more importantly, its multiple publics. Written by Rosa Maria T. Feliciano

Sources: Feliciano 2007, 2012, 2013; KBP 1989, n.d.; Malacañan Palace 1974, 1981.

text: KBS (See Kanlaon Broadcasting System.)

KEITHLEY, JUNE (June Keithley-Castro) b. Manila 10 Mar 1947. d. Quezon City 24 Nov 2013. Actor, program host, comedian, producer, broadcast journalist. She was the daughter of a Filipino mother and an American father. She was married to Angelo Castro Jr, an actor and broadcast journalist. Their son Diego is also an actor and broadcaster. She attended St Paul College where she met Jesuit priest James Reuter, who became her lifelong confessor, mentor, and friend.

Beginning in college, Keithley acted and sang in Reuter’s theater productions, such as The Sound of Music, where she took on the lead role of Maria, and Man of La Mancha. Her exposure to a wider public began in 1969 when she joined the cast of the comedy-gag show Super Laff-In on ABS-CBN. The show lasted until martial law was declared in 1972. She then hosted several short-lived television programs: Lollipop Party, a children’s show, and the talk shows Changes and Total Woman, later renamed Over the Saya. In 1976-78, she produced and hosted the weekly evening talk show The Late Hour with June and Johnny on Channel 7. She also acted in films, including Durog (Crushed), 1971; Blood Compact, 1972; and Lunes, Martes, Miyerkoles, Huwebes, Biyernes, Sabado, Linggo (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday), 1976.

Keithley transformed from an entertainment media personality into a news and public affairs broadcaster when she played a significant part in the popular bloodless revolt that ousted President Marcos in 1986, variously called the EDSA Revolt and People Power Revolution, a demonstration of an estimated three million people on EDSA. She was then in the announcing staff of DZRV Radio Veritas, which had taken a critical stance toward Marcos following the assassination of Marcos’s political rival Sen Benigno Aquino Jr on 21 Aug 1983, allegedly by military men. When Marcos called for snap elections for president, which took place on 7 Feb 1986, the opposition party fielded Aquino’s widow Corazon. DZRV stood out as the media organization that most closely followed the progress of the polling. The Commission on Elections declared Marcos winner based on its tabulation, which did not tally with the count of the National Citizens Movement for Free Elections. Namfrel’s count indicated Aquino won the election. Popular sentiment believed this, proven by the ensuing massive rallies called by Aquino, calling for civil disobedience.

Marcos’s hold on power broke when two weeks later Defense MinisterJuan Ponce Enrileand Armed Forces of the Philippines Vice Chief of Staff and Philippine Constabulary Chief Fidel V. Ramos announced in a press conference in Camp Aguinaldo on EDSA their withdrawal of support from Marcos. Enrile made sure DZRV was among the media organizations around to cover the announcement. He and Ramos blockaded themselves with their men and requested the public to surround them to press Marcos to yield power to Aquino. Archbishop of Manila Jaime Cardinal Sin responded to his request by calling people on the air via DZRV to go to EDSA to protect Enrile and Ramos. The mammoth demonstration that grew in number over the next four days quickly followed. When the transmitter of DZRV, the only broadcast station covering the event live, was bombed allegedly by Marcos loyalists, Reuter and Keithley moved the broadcast to DZRJ.

KZBU KZBU was the second radio station to open in Cebu, next to KZRC, after World War II. Both were the only stations operating outside Manila at this time. Broadcasting on the AM band, it began operations in 1948 under the Philippine Broadcasting Corporation (PBC), the new name of the prewar Far East Broadcasting Corporation (FEBC) under new owners. When radio call signs in the Philippines shifted from K to D on 1 Jan 1949, the station became DYBU, with the last two call letters from the last two letters of Cebu. Its studios were first located on the third floor of Gotiaoco Building on M. C. Briones St. In 1950, when the Cebu government acquired the building, DYBU moved to the Lim Bon Fing Building on P. Lopez St, where DYRC was also housed. By this time, both stations, including PBC’s sister station in Manila, KZPI, had been bought by Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC).

The station is remembered for the evangelistic program produced by the Bradford Church, the first Evangelical Church in the province. However, DYBU is better known as a music station. In 1975, it moved to the FM band and became part of MBC’s Love Radio network, called Love Radio Cebu. It now broadcasts from the Eggling Subdivision, Busay Hills, Cebu City. Written byStephanie Ledesma

Sources: AIJC 2015; Bradford Church Cebu 2014; CBC 2015; Enriquez 2003, 2008c; Gabii sa Kabilin 2012.

text:
KZEG KZEG was one of the stations operated in Manila during the American colonial period by the Erlanger & Galinger Department Store, the others being KZRM, also in Manila, and KZRC in Cebu. Airing on 780 kHz, KZEG began broadcasting on 11 Jul 1932, following Erlanger & Galinger’s purchase of KZRM (for Radio Manila) and KZRC (for Radio Cebu) from the Radio Corporation of the Philippines. It brought to three the number of radio stations operating in Manila in the early 1930s, with KZIB as the third. Named after the department store that owned it, KZEG advertised the products, promotional offers, and events inside the store. Music and entertainment programs, such as bodabil, aired between commercials.

KZEG programming was sometimes relayed on KZRM and KZRC, expanding its audiences to Southern Philippines. However, KZRC experienced technical difficulties in relaying broadcast from Manila, so it may have been closed down after 1935 as there is no evidence that it was broadcasting after that year until it was bought by H. E. Heacock Co in 1939.

On 1 Jul 1938, Far East Broadcasting Corporation, owned by J. Amado Araneta, bought KZEG and KZRM from the department store and changed KZEG’s call letters to KZRF (for Radio Filipinas). Written byGene Paolo Gumagay

Sources: Berg 2013b; Enriquez 2008a; Lent 1968; Medija 2006; PCCF 2015.
