text:
KZFM/DZFM KZFM was the first permanent radio station established in Manila following the end of World War II in the Philippines. When Gen Douglas MacArthur landed in Leyte on 20 Oct 1944, he went on the air using a portable transmitter to announce to the Filipinos that he had returned. He called the station the Voice of Freedom, after the resistance station that aired from Corregidor from Jan to May 1942 as the combined Filipino and American forces fought to fend off the Japanese at the beginning of the Japanese occupation of the Philippines. The new Voice of Freedom was later given the call letters WVLC, whose transmitter was one of 10 MacArthur brought back to blanket the Philippines with news about the end of World War II and with American programming. The transmitters were scattered throughout the Philippines to operate as temporary radio stations. Five months later, WVLC and its transmitter were sent to Manila. On 26 Mar 1945, it began broadcasting from a radio ship named Apache, which was moored in the Pasig River near Jones Bridge. Another transmitter, which was set up as station WVTM operating in Polo, Bulacan, was also moved to Manila at around the same time. It broadcast from the sixth floor of what remained of the Insular Life Building in downtown Manila. Shortly thereafter, MacArthur sent most of the transmitters, including that of WVLC, to Japan together with the American forces that invaded Japan. The transmitters that remained were consolidated into one station with the call letters KZFM.

 

KZFM was named after Frederic Marquardt, an American newsman in the prewar Philippines Free Press and a close friend of MacArthur. He was with MacArthur’s forces that landed in Leyte to retake the Philippines from the Japanese. KZFM was first operated by the US Department of National Defense Office of War Information, and then turned over to the United States Information Service (USIS) at the end of the war. On 4 Jul 1946, KZFM, together with newly opened radio stations KZRH and KZPI, covered live the declaration of Philippine independence from the Unites States and the inauguration of the Second Republic of the Philippines, with Manuel Roxas as president. Three months later, the USIS turned the station over to the Philippine government on 20 Oct 1946, exactly two years after the Leyte landing. At first it was supervised by the office of Vice Pres and foreign affairs secretary Elpidio Quirino. Pres Roxas initiated a fund of 100,000 US dollars for its operation, and then moved the station under his supervision in 1947. KZFM became the nucleus of a network of government radio stations established under the Philippine Broadcasting System (PBS). On 1 Jan 1949, call letters in the Philippines shifted from K to D; thus, KZFM became DZFM.

 

Among the first KZFM staff were Bill Sanford and Abigail Jacobs. Jacobs later established a radio station for Silliman University in Dumaguete. Francisco “Koko” Trinidad joined KZFM’s staff almost from its beginning, then became its manager once it was turned over to the Philippine government. Among the Filipinos he recruited to join the production and announcing staff were Johnny Arville, Jess Fernandez, Gene Ildefonso, Mon Ylanan, Eddie Avelino, Gabby Tabuñar, and Gumsy Alba.

 

KZFM relayed signals from the Voice of America, the newly organized radio system operated by the US government. As DZFM, the station was affiliated with American networks in the beginning, and thus had access to popular American programs. The local programs in the 1950s included news, music, and variety shows. One program, the Radio Newsreel, was about the news, presented using the drama format. Trinidad and his announcers as well as voice actors simulated the voices of world leaders and other newsmakers. The station’s most popular program was the variety show Edong Mapangarap (Edong the Dreamer), with Eddie San Jose, Pugo, Tugo, Joan Page, and Eddie Avelino, written by Beer Flores. Edong Mapangarap became the model of variety shows in rival stations, such as Tuloy ang Ligaya (On with the Fun), which in turn inspired later variety shows on television. The sitcom Pitong Pasikat (Seven Braggarts) featured Lopito and Lopita and real-life brothers Ferdie and Corky Trinidad. Another popular show was the music program Harana ni Ruben Tagalog (Ruben Tagalog’s Serenade), with guitarist Ruben Torres and bass player cum comic Ading Fernando. The Big Top, with Leopoldo Salcedo, Joan Page, Ben Rubio, and Pugo, was another variety show that often had film stars as guests.

 

When Pres Ferdinand Marcos declared martial law in 1972, PBS was abolished. The following year, the Bureau of Broadcast under the Department of Information was organized. DZFM and the other PBS stations were revived but with different call letters and formats.Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez, with notes from Lucia Isabel G. Macaventa

 

Sources: Aganan 2012; Berg 2013b; Enriquez 2008a; Habon 2014; Lent 1968; Pilipinas DX Weblog 2010.

text:
KZIB KZIB became the second radio broadcast station to operate in the Philippines when it began airing on 9 Nov 1925 in Manila. It was put up by American department store owner Isaac Beck to provide entertainment and to advertise his merchandise, including radio sets and Gramophone-brand phonographs. Bearing his initials, it started broadcast at a low power of 20 watts from the Crystal Arcade on Escolta Ave, where department store IBeck Escolta was located, then increased to one kilowatt in 1931, on 900 kc longwave and 49.67 M. and 31.58 M. shortwave. Beck, also the local distributor of the American music recording company Columbia Records, used the station to promote Columbia’s musical recordings, including Filipina diva Nati de Arellano’s Paalam sa Pagkadalaga (Farewell to Maidenhood) and Ang Dalagang Pilipina (The Filipino Maiden) pressed in California.

While KZIB was managed by an American, Al Naftaly, most of the staff were Filipinos, including his assistants. Hernandez and announcers Encarna Bascaran and Filipino-American Ira Davis. Beck himself directed some of the music programs that featured Arellano aka Tinay Arellano, Fernando Poe, Ding Yalung, Koko Trinidad, Remigio Mat Castro, Katy dela Cruz, Atang de la Rama, and other vaudeville stars who were making the transition from the vaudeville stage to radio. Half of KZIB’s programming was musical, including popular and classical music, popular dance numbers, and other foreign music such as those from Spain, South America, and China. The rest of the programs included literary readings, lectures, news, business reports, sports, religious services, and programs from the United States such as comedies and dramas.

The popularity of Filipino music such as the kundiman (love song) and the entry of Filipino blocktimers who bought airtime and produced their own programs with the support of local businesses brought Tagalog into wide circulation on radio. In the 1930s, five of the six sponsored programs on KZIB were in Tagalog and only one was in English. By 1940, most of KZIB’s entire programming was in Tagalog (Trinidad, n.d.; General Records of the Department of State, RG 59).

Like other stations operating during the period, KZIB ceased broadcasting on the final days of Dec 1941 as the Japanese advanced toward Manila, involving the Philippines in World War II. Written byElizabeth L. Enriquez

Sources: Broadcast Media Council and KBP 1979; General Records of the Department of State, RG 59; Lent 1973; Records of the Bureau of Insular Affairs, RG 350; Tribune 1941; Trinidad, n.d.; Yson 2005.

text:
KZKZ This was the surviving station out of the first three commercial radio broadcast experiments in the Philippines put on air by Henry Herman in Jun 1922. The test broadcasts via 50-watt transmitters emanated from Manila, Pasay, and a mobile station. The last two probably served to relay the signals from the Manila station. An American veteran of the Philippine-American war, Herman opened the Manila Electrical Supply Company where the merchandise included radio sets. Like radio set manufacturing companies in the United States, Herman broadcast news and music to boost the sale of radio sets he imported from the United States and to advertise his store. In 1924, two years into the experiment, he consolidated the three experimental stations with a single 100-watt station with the call letters KZKZ. He set up the KZKZ studio at the Monte de Piedad building on Plaza Santa Cruz across the Santa Cruz Church and nicknamed it Krazy Krazy, but transferred it shortly to his home in Pasay.

A few months later, on 4 Oct 1924, Herman transferred KZKZ to his other company, the Radio Corporation of the Philippines (RCP), which he organized both for broadcasting and the wireless telegraphy business. RCP increased the station’s power to 500 watts within two months, then merged with its rival, the Far Eastern Radio Inc, on 3 Sep 1925, which was already in the wireless telegraph traffic between ships and shore. The name RCP was retained but the following year, in 1926, it was purchased by and made a subsidiary of the Radio Corporation of America, by then a leading broadcasting and telegraph company in the United States that also manufactured and sold radio sets and equipment. When it obtained a license to operate KZRM—for Radio Manila—with a more powerful transmitter beginning on 3 Sep 1927, KZKZ was put off the air. Elizabeth L. Enriquez

Sources: Almario 1972; Herman 2003; Lent 1973; Records of the Bureau of Insular Affairs, RG 350.

text:
KZND KZND was the first government station, established during the Commonwealth period on the eve of World War II. Its creation was unplanned, made possible by the opportunity presented by a one-kilowatt transmitter confiscated by the government from an alien whose loyalty was to the enemy of the United States and its allies—Nazi Germany. After Commonwealth president Manuel L. Quezon registered the station with the International Union of the Telegraph in Switzerland, KZND first went on the air on 30 Apr 1941, seven months before Japan attacked and subsequently invaded the Philippines. Operated by the Office of Publicity and Propaganda of the Civil Emergency Administration (CEA), KZND’s last two call letters stood for “national defense.” Broadcasting on shortwave at 3790 kilocycles, it prepared people for the war by conducting emergency drills and instructing people on how to behave during air raids, and updated listeners on the progress of the war already raging in Europe.

text:
KZPI KZPI was one of the first radio stations to go on the air in the Philippines after World War II. It was operated by the prewar Far East Broadcasting Corporation (FEBC) under a new owner. With a power of 10 kilowatts on 800 kHz airing from the sixth floor of Filipinas Insurance Co Building in Plaza Moraga, Manila, with transmitter in Bulacan, KZPI went on test broadcast on 1 Jul 1946. Three days later, it covered live the Jul 4 declaration of Philippine independence and the inauguration of the second Philippine Republic, with Manuel Roxas as president, at Luneta Park. It was one of only three radio stations on the air, the others being KZRH and KZFM.

 

When American broadcaster Norman Paige bought FEBC from J. Amado Araneta, operator of the prewar KZRF and KZRM, he hired another American, Henry Miller, as production manager and put up KZPI—PI for Philippine Islands. He then opened another station in Manila, KZOK, and one in Cebu, KZBU. In 1948, Paige sold FEBC to the Philippine Broadcasting Company (PBC) owned by Jack Preysler, Leo Prieto, J. Amado Araneta, Jose Avelino, and Andres Soriano. Before the decade was over, Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC), owned by the Elizalde family, bought PBC. By this time call letters of Philippine radio stations had shifted from K to D, so KZPI, KZOK, and KZBU became DZPI, DZOK, and DYBU, respectively. With MBC’s DZRH, DZMB, and DYRC, DZPI and its sister stations joined what was then the largest network of radio stations. It then moved to Ramon Roces Building on Soler St, Santa Cruz, Manila, with Simoun Almario and Angelo Castro replacing general manager Ray Spencer and assistant Paul Smith, respectively. DZPI became one of the three most commercially successful radio stations in the 1950s, along with DZRH and DZMB, with top advertiser support and the most popular programs and broadcasters.

 

In the 1940s, KZPI’s programming was in English. In the 1950s, already called DZPI, its programs in Tagalog began to go on the air. Among the memorable programs were the game shows Double Your Money, similar to Who Wants to Be a Millionaire, and Parker Pens Quiz Show, which gave away Parker pens as prize. Its other programs included the radio dramas Mercedes Cruz, Recuerdo (Memento), Freedom Theatre, and Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang) before it was moved to KZRH; and the variety-musicals Melody Club, Stairway to the Stars, Pundemonium, Radio Schoolhouse, San Miguel Brewery Hour, Jamboree Musical Filipina, Huwag Naman (Please Don’t), and Drama Musikal (Drama Musical).

 

Among the station’s announcers, many of whom also worked in television, film, and advertising, were Bob Stewart, Vero Perfecto, Jess Fernandez, Arling Gonzales, Norman Reyes, Ben Ildefonso, Denny Alejandro, Dick Taylor, Simeon Bonzon, Ray Cordova, Cris de Vera, Bill Martinez, Virginia Ildefonso, Frankie Wenceslao, Doreen Ma, Letty Liboon, Bessie Castañeda, Tony Yatco, Leila Benitez, Tita Muñoz, Louie Garcia, Ben Aniceto, Don Lee, Ira Davis, Ester Ilagan, Pinggoy Penson, and Eddie Mercado.

In 1972, Aliw Broadcasting Corporation, owned by Antonio Cabangon Chua, bought DZPI and changed its call letters to DWIZ. It adopted a different format, which focused on news and local music. Written by Alyssa Jean E. Alano

 

Sources: AmericanRadioHistory.com 1947; Aniceto 2007; Broadcast Media Council and KBP 1979; Chanco 1946; Enriquez 2003, 2008a.

text:
KZRC/DYRC KZRC, for Radio Cebu, was the first broadcast station to operate outside Manila in the early days of radio during the American colonial period. Following the Japanese occupation of the country in World War II, during which all radio was under Japanese control, KZRC was again first to operate outside the Philippine capital. It was put up in Oct 1929 by the Radio Corporation of the Philippines (RCP), then owned by the Radio Corporation of America (RCA), to serve as a one-kilowatt relay station for RCP’s Manila station KZRM (for Radio Manila), transmitting the latter’s programs to the rest of the Visayas and Mindanao. From its first studio on Colon St in Cebu City, it moved to the Lim Bon Fing Building on Carmelo St, today P. Lopez St.

Experiencing technical difficulties in its first two months, RCP replaced its equipment and continued its operation until it was sold in 1931 to Manila department store Erlanger & Galinger, along with KZRM. The store used the stations, along with another station in Manila, KZEG (for Erlanger & Galinger), mainly to promote its merchandise. KZRC then continued to relay programming from Manila, this time not only from KZRM but also from KZEG. However, Erlanger & Galinger may have discontinued operation of KZRC in 1935 as no records of the station’s broadcasts exist from this year until it was bought by H. E. Heacock Co in 1939. Before this sale, Erlanger & Galinger sold KZRM and KZEG to Far Eastern Broadcasting Corporation. Owned by Samuel Gaches, Heacock put up another station in Manila, KZRH (for Radio Heacock) in the same year that it purchased KZRC. KZRC’s inaugural broadcast under its new owner was heard from the Heacock Building on Magallanes St, Cebu City, on 2 Mar 1940.

At the end of the following year, 1941, all Manila-based radio stations discontinued broadcasting when the United States Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE) destroyed their equipment as the Japanese invaded the Philippines. This made KZRC the lone commercial station that operated in the country until the Japanese Army took Cebu in early May 1942. It carried the signal of the Voice of Freedom, a short-lived resistance radio broadcasting from Corregidor and operated by the USAFFE, the joint Filipino-American forces that after a brutal four-month siege surrendered to the Japanese.

Following the end of the war in 1945, Heacock sold its stations to a new broadcast firm, the Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC) owned by brothers Joaquin and Manuel Elizalde. On 21 Sept 1947, MBC reopened KZRC. When all Philippine stations changed their initial call letter to D on 1 Jan 1949, with Luzon taking Z as its second call letter, Visayas Y, and Mindanao X, KZRC became DYRC.

As a relay station for Manila programs in its first several years of operation, KZRC’s airtime was dominated by popular and classical music, with live singing, live band music, and dance music. The station also transmitted foreign programs. However, when Heacock took over KZRC, programs produced in Cebu were introduced to the programming. Two of these were Amateur Hour, produced and hosted by composer-actor Ben Zubiri aka Iyo Karpo, and Sunday Night Serenata, also a music program. The news-and-music programming of the station was delivered in three languages: Spanish, Cebuano, and English. Jose del Mar and Gaudencio Peña were in charge of Spanish programming, while Jose Bautista handled the shows delivered in Cebuano. KZRC had a resident comedian, Leonardo Gutierrez.

MBC staffed the postwar KZRC, later DYRC, with Simoun Almario as program director and Angelo Castro as production manager, ushering in a new programming of news, music, drama, and variety shows. DYRC continues to operate today with the same call sign DYRCRadyo Cebu 648kHz, broadcasting from Fuente Osmeña, Cebu City. Currently owned by the Pacific Broadcasting Systems, a subsidiary of the Manila Broadcasting Company, its programming is now dominated by news and talk, with Cebuano as the principal language. Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez and Izzy Kay F. Castillo

Sources: Aniceto 2007; Enriquez 2008a; Peterson 2010; Shortwave Central 2010.

text:
KZRF For Radio Filipinas, KZRF broadcast both on long wave (at 780 kHz) and shortwave (at 6140 MHz), like all stations in the Philippines in the 1930s. It had the call letters KZEG from 1932 until its owner, Erlanger & Galinger Department Store, sold it, along with its sister station KZRM, to Far East Broadcasting Corporation (FEBC) in Jul 1938. FEBC, owned by J. Amado Araneta, making the corporation the first to be wholly Filipino-owned, then changed its call letters to KZRF but retained the call letters of KZRM (for Radio Manila). Powered by a one-kilowatt transmitter, it operated from the Royal Room on the eight floor of the Marco Polo Hotel, and later moved atop the Insular Life Insurance Building in Plaza Cervantes in Manila.

Several languages were heard on KZRF. The news was broadcast in Tagalog, English, and Spanish. Apart from English and Tagalog shows, two programs were in Chinese and three were in Spanish. It was also common to mix Tagalog and English in variety shows, such as in the San Miguel Brewery Hour and the University of the Air, both produced by blocktimer Andoy Balun-balunan. KZRF aired the religious program Tagalog Gospel Hour, but most of its shows broadcast different genres of music, such as in the programs Tagalog Music, Songs of the Islands, Concert Echoes, With the Classics, Hit Parade, Latin American Airs, Sweet Music, and Manila Night Hawks.

Like all Manila stations, KZRF ceased broadcast at the end of 1941, just before the Japanese overran Manila in World War II. After the war, FEBC was sold, along with stations KZRF and KZRM, to American Norman Paige, who did not revive the stations and instead put up KZPI. Written byDivine Marie Joanne P. Endriga

Sources: Berg 2013a; Enriquez 2008a; Gugliotta 1984.

text:
LA TORRE, SYLVIA (Sylvia Reyes La Torre) b. Manila 4 Jun 1933. Radio, television, and film actor and singer. She is the daughter of Sampaguita Pictures film director Olimpio “Olive” La Torre and kundiman (love song) and opera singer Leonora Reyes, from whom she first learned to sing. She studied music and voice under scholarship at the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music in 1948. In 1954, she married dentist Celso de Tagle, with whom she has three children. Her youngest daughter, Che Che, was a child actor. Her granddaughter, Anna Maria Perez de Tagle, is a Hollywood actor. Her niece, Marissa Flores, is an executive at GMA Network.

La Torre began her career at the age of five in 1938 by joining singing contests in Manila. In her first competition, she defeated much older competitors with her version of Ako Ay Bulaklak ang Kawangis (I Am Like a Flower), a kundiman, at the Savoy Theater where a gong rang when a contestant was deemed undeserving and a long stick with a hook pulled the contestant off the stage. At age seven, she starred in the film Ang Maestra (The Teacher), produced by RDR Productions in 1941. At age nine, during the Japanese occupation, she performed on stage shows at the Life Theater with Pugo, Togo, Tony Santos Sr, and Rogelio de la Rosa. Si Petite Mon Amour (My Little Love) was her first recording under Bataan Records in 1950. After recording 400 songs from 1950 to 1970, she was tagged “Queen of Kundiman.” Among her most popular renditions were “Sa Kabukiran” (In the Fields), “Mutya ng Pasig” (Muse of Pasig), “Waray-Waray” (referring to natives of Leyte-Samar area), “Hahabol-habol” (In Pursuit), “Dadaldaldaldal” (You Keep on Blabbering), and “Galawgaw” (Restless). In 1983, she performed in a concert with Conching Rosal, where she gave a memorable rendition of Levi Celerio’s “Tanging Ikaw” (Only You).

Upon her father’s prodding, she joined the movies in the mid-1950s, beginning with minor roles, then in lead roles in Sampaguita Pictures’ Ulila ng Bataan (Orphan of Bataan), Ang Asawa Kong Amerikana (My American Wife), Buhay Pilipino (Filipino Life), and Takas sa Bataan (Escape from Bataan). She made a string of movies for LVN Pictures with Pugo, Bentot, Rosa Aguirre, and Eddie San Jose, including My Little Kuwan (My Little Thing), 1958; Puro Utos–Puro Utos (Orders No End), 1959; Yantok Mindoro (Rattan from Mindoro) and Nukso nang Nukso (Always Teasing), 1960; Oh’ Sendang!, 1961; and Tang-Tarang-Tang, 1962. She starred in other films like Sakay and Moy under Larry Santiago Prductions Inc, 1963; Oh Margie Oh, 1974; Jack & Jill, 1987; M&M: Incredible Twins and One Two Bato, Three Four Bapor (One Two Stone, Three Four Ship), 1989; Biyudo si Daddy, Biyuda si Mommy (Daddy Is a Widower, Mommy Is a Widow), 1997. She also appeared in the Regal Films-produced movie Ligaw-Ligawan, Kasal-Kasalan, Bahay-Bahayan (Playing Lovers, Playing Married Couple, Playing House), 1993. La Torre ghost-sang for nonsinger stars of LVN Pictures, such as Nida Blanca in Waray-Waray and Gloria Romero in Lawiswis Kawayan (Sound of Bamboo Trees).

It was on radio and television that audiences followed La Torre’s performances every day. She was a regular performer in five radio shows including Edong Mapangarap (Edong the Dreamer). She made her first television appearance in Caltex Star Caravan. In 1960, she joined the radio program Tuloy ang Ligaya (On with the Fun) on DZRH, flagship station of the Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC), with Lita Gutierrez and Oscar Obligacion. It became so popular that in 1961, MBC head Federico Elizalde produced it for MBC’s television station Channel 11, with the title The Big Show, the first variety show on television. La Torre hosted the daily noontime show with Cris de Vera and Oscar Obligacion, until the trio moved in 1965 to Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour) on ABS-CBN Channel 2, which aired until 1972.

Also in the 1960s, La Torre became a regular in the famous DZRH radio program Tang-Tarang-Tang with Pugo, Bentot, and Leroy Salvador, which was also produced for television with the same cast.

Better known in comedy roles, La Torre starred in the live comedy radio program Edong Mapangarap with Eddie San Jose. The hit series spun off other hit shows including Sebya (a nickname for “Sylvia”), Sebya, Mahal Kita (Sebya, I Love You), and Nukso nang Nukso (Always Teasing). Now retired in California, USA with her husband, she occasionally returns to the Philippines to guest on television.

In 1964, La Torre received the Best TV Performer Award from the Citizens’ Awards for Television. She also received awards and recognition from award-giving bodies in the field of entertainment such as Aliw Awards, the Tandang Sora Awards, and the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit. Written by Cynthia Cruz-Paz and Ramon Jocson; updated by Crisanti L. Macazo

Sources:

Aguilar 2010; Asian Journal SF Magazine 2009; Baldovino 2015; IMDb, n.d.c; Lo 2010; Logarta 2002b; La Torre, n.d.; Video 48 2012.

Now retired in California, USA with her husband, she occasionally returns to the Philippines to guest on television.

In 1964, La Torre received the Best TV Performer Award from the Citizens’ Awards for Television. She also received awards and recognition from award-giving bodies in the field of entertainment such as Aliw Awards, the Tandang Sora Awards, and the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit. LAZARO, CHECHE (Cecilia Aldaba Lim-Lazaro) b. Los Angeles, California 8 Sep 1946. TV broadcast journalist. She is the eldest daughter of psychologist and former secretary of the Department of Social Welfare and Development Estefania Aldaba and chemical engineer Luis Lim. Lazaro is the eldest of six children. Her grandmother, Pilar Hidalgo Lim, was the third president of Centro Escolar University, a co-founder of the Girl Scouts of the Philippines, a line producer for the Manila movie production company Parlatone Hispano-Filipino Studios, and a member of the Board of Censors for Motion Pictures during the term of Pres Elpidio Quirino from 1948 to 1953. Her grandfather, Gen Vicente Lim, was the first Filipino graduate from West Point with the class of 1914. Her sister Cristina “Nina” Lim-Yuson is the president of the Museo Pambata Foundation. She is married to Delfin Lazaro, who served as secretary of the Department of Energy from 1992 to 1994 during the Fidel Ramos administration. They have two children.

 

She finished her elementary education at the Jose Abad Santos Memorial School of the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) and her secondary education at the PWU High School. She obtained a bachelor’s degree in speech and drama from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1966. While in UP, she won a seat in the student council of the then College of Arts and Sciences. She obtained a master’s degree in radio and television at the University of Michigan in 1968. She gave up her US citizenship and chose to be legally Filipino when she applied for a scholarship in Michigan. She was a member of the Bayanihan Dance Company from 1961 to 1966.

 

Lazaro taught courses in radio and television at the UP Department of Broadcast Communication from 1972 to 2000, and chaired the department in 1992-95. She began working in the broadcast industry with the American Broadcasting Corporation in 1985. She was director and manager of the Public Affairs Department of ABS-CBN from Jul 1986 to Dec 1987, and headed the reporting team that covered Pres Corazon Aquino’s state visit to Singapore and Indonesia in 1986. In 1987, she received an offer to manage, direct, and host Probe, a monthly late-evening public affairs program on ABS-CBN, which featured a discussion of current events and insightful conversations with newsmakers.

 

In 1988, she set up her own production company, Probe Productions Inc, with the help of Maria Ressa, Angie Cruz, and former student Luchi Cruz-Valdes. They produced the weekly program The Probe Team, 1988-2010, the first and longest-running Filipino investigative news magazine on local TV. Soon after, Lazaro’s company began producing other programs, such as the children’s program 5 & Up, 1992-2002; the agricultural-entrepreneurial magazine show AgriLink, 1993-99; the sports and leisure program Game Plan, 1995-2008; and the magazine and travel show Cheche Lazaro Presents, started in 1999, which developed into a one-hour documentary program. Lazaro is known for her hard-hitting interviews, especially with politicians and personalities embroiled in controversial issues. She presents a compassionate, caring persona, however, when interviewing ordinary folk. One story that she continues to tell is about Victor, a street urchin, whose struggle to survive on the streets of Manila became a moving portrait of the neglected and marginalized sectors of society that she and her team strove to document.

 

Lazaro was named TV Journalist of the Year by theRotary Club of Manila in 1988. She received the Golden Jubilee Citation in Broadcast Media by the Girl Scouts of the Philippines in 1990; the KBP Golden Dove Awards for Best Female Public Affairs Host for The Probe Team in 1993 and for i-Witness in 2001; the Ka Doroy Broadcaster of the Year award from the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) in 1997; the Hall of Fame Award at the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 2009; and the Excellence in Broadcasting Award from the Philippine Movie Press Club in 2010 for having won 10 times as Best News Magazine Show Host in the Star Awards for TV in 1991, 1992, 1994, 1996-2001, and 2009. The programs she produced and/or hosted have won about 120 awards, such as those from the New York Festivals, the Asian Television Awards, the Prix Jeunnesse International, the Japan Prize, the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon, the KBP Golden Dove Awards, the Catholic Mass Media Awards, and the PMPC Star Awards for TV.

 

She was one of the Ten Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service in 1988, a recipient of theUP Alumni Association Professional Award in 1991, the Ninoy Aquino Fellow for Professional Development given by the US government in 1994, the Most Outstanding Daughter of Malolos from the Malolos Heritage Foundation in 1997, an awardee of the Dangal ng Lipi para sa Sining at Kultura from the provincial government of Bulacan in 2003,a recipient of the Gawad CCP para sa Sining in 2004, UP Gawad Plaridel awardee in 2007, and Marshall McLuhan Fellow of the Embassy of Canada in 2014.

 

Lazaro is one of the founding editors of Rappler, an Internet news organization in the country. She sits as a member or trustee of the UNESCO National Commission of the Philippines, the Philippine Cancer Society, the Ramon Magsaysay Awards Foundation, the Philippine Center for Population and Development, the National Council for Children’s Television, and the Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism. Lazaro has served as a member of the Board of Trustees and board secretary of the International Institute of Communication based in London and vice chair of the steering committee of WETV, a global access TV project of the International Development Research Centre of Canada. Lazaro has been invited as speaker or lecturer to various international conferences of UNESCO, the Voice of Germany, and the International Documentary Congress in the United States. The academic student conference of the annual Sining del Pilar of the UP Department of Broadcast Communication, which started in 2011, honors her contributions by naming the festival “The Cheche Lazaro Kritika Series.” In 2013, the Institute of Plant Breeding of UP Los Baños gave the name “Cheche Lazaro” to a new gumamela hybrid, Hibiscus rosa-sinensis, in recognition of her contributions as an outstanding broadcast journalist. Written by Daphne-Tatiana T. Canlas and Eulalio R. Guieb III

Alba 2004; Cabalza 2011; Cheche Lazaro Blog 2014; De Sequera 2002; Diaz-Wilson 2002; Diola 2013; Gonzales 2012b; Llamas 2002; Manila Bulletin 2014a; Ressa 2011; Wikipedia2014d, 2014q; Zoominfo 2014.

LEGARDA, KATRINA (Maria Carolina Trinidad Legarda) b. Manila 10 Sep 1954. Lawyer, educator, broadcaster, columnist, writer, women’s and children’s rights activist. Katrina is the daughter of stage and film actor Juan Antonio Carrion and Carmen “Carmita” Fernandez Legarda. She has three children, one of whom is independent filmmaker Rafael “Rafa” Santos.

Katrina Legarda spent her childhood and teenage years in England, where her mother Carmita was the first Filipino woman academician at the University of Oxford. She was educated in the Notre Dame Convent in Oxford, and graduated from the University of Bristol, England, with a bachelor’s degree in history in 1975. She obtained her law degree from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1980, and was admitted to the Bar in 1981.

Legarda was with the Angara, Abello, Concepcion, Regala, and Cruz Law offices (ACCRALAW) from 1981 to 1992. One prominent case she handled for the firm was the criminal case for libel filed by Pres Corazon Aquino against Philippine Star publisher Max Soliven and columnist Luis Beltran. After leaving ACCRALAW, she handled litigation relevant to her advocacy on the rights of women and children. She acted as lead counsel in the defense of an 11-year-old girl in the statutory rape case against Zamboanga del Norte Representative Romeo G. Jalosjos in 1997 that led to his conviction in 2001, but the penalty was commuted during the Arroyo administration in 2007. Legarda persuaded the Philippine Supreme Court to recognize the “battered woman syndrome” as a defense in a parricide charge in the landmark case People vs Marivic Genosa, which the Supreme Court promulgated three months after the Legislature passed the Anti-Violence Against Women and Their Children Act of 2004. After handling these high-profile legal cases, Legarda was invited to host legal programs on TV.

Legarda began her stint in media when she went on board DZRJ-FM100.3 in 1975 under the moniker “Katrina.” This was during the martial law years when the station’s programs were anchored by female deejays, predating the all-female deejay lineup of ABS-CBN’s DWRR-FM Radio Romance 101.9, which aired in 1989. She worked with radio personalities Brother Becky, Little Rock, Stoneyburk, Howlin’ Dave, and The Big A Alan Austria on DZRJ-FM until 1978.

Legarda co-hosted On Trial, the daily coverage of the impeachment proceedings against Pres Joseph Estrada in 2000-1 on ABS-CBN News Channel 21 (ANC). She hosted By Demand, a weekly talk show that presented legal analyses of current events and social problems, on ANC in 2001-3, and co-hosted with Randy David the weekly news and current affairs talk show Off the Record on ABS-CBN in 2001-2. She anchored every Monday a segment about legal concerns in the daily morning show Umagang kay Ganda (Beautiful Morning) on ABS-CBN, 2011-12, and “Legal Log,” an hourly legal segment on Radio Crossover 105.1 DWBM-FM, 1998-99. Katrina co-anchors with Alvin Elchico the Friday edition of the daily one-hour tele-radio program Suriang Bayan sa SRO: Suhestiyon, Reaksiyon at Opinyon (Public Analysis at SRO: Suggestion, Reaction, and Opinion), 2000-14, on DZMM Teleradyo Sky Cable Channel 26, where they examine various social issues and their legal implications.

Her book A Time to Love, A Time to Leave, 1998, which she co-authored with Jullie Yap-Daza, is about marriage and divorce “Philippine style.” Her essays were anthologized in Women on Fire, 1997, edited by Lorna Kalaw-Tirol, and in Pinay: Autobiographical Narratives by Women Writers, 1926-1998, 2000, edited by Cristina Pantoja Hidalgo. She co-authored with Ma. Soledad Deriquito-Mawis and Flordeliza Vargas the book Family Law in the Philippines, 2014, published by LexisNexis Singapore. She wrote columns for the Sunday Times, Manila Times, SAVVY Magazine, K Magazine, Business World, and People’s Tonight. Legarda writes a public interest column in InterAksyon, the online news portal of TV5.

She lectures in family law at UP, De La Salle University, Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila, Jose Rizal University, and Lyceum of the Philippines University as its special consultant. She also teaches medical jurisprudence at the UP College of Medicine. Legarda is with the Child Protection Network Foundation Philippines, assisting children through the legal system.

Off the Record won a KBP Golden Dove Award for Best Talk Show in 2001. Legarda received two Soroptimist International Awards: “Woman Helping Women” and “Woman Advancing the Status of Women.” She received a Parangal ng Bayan Award in 1999, considered one of the Leaders of the Millennium by the Philippine Year Book in 2000, and recognized by Rotary International as Outstanding Peace Advocate in 2011. Written byBeia Santos-Florete, with notes from Maria Angelica D. Abad

Sources: Legarda 2014; UP College of Law website.

LEGARDA, LOREN (Lorna Regina Bautista Legarda) b. Potrero, Malabon 28 Jan 1960. She is the eldest of three children of Antonio Cabrera Legarda of San Pablo, Laguna, and Bessie Gella Bautista of Antique and Malabon. Her paternal grandfather, Jose P. Bautista, was an editor of the pre-martial law newspaper The Manila Times. She has two children from her annulled marriage with former Batangas governor Jose Antonio Leviste.

She attended Assumption College from elementary to high school, where she graduated valedictorian. She entered the University of the Philippines (UP) in Diliman in 1977 and graduated with a bachelor of arts in broadcast communication, cum laude, in 1981. In college, she became president of the UP Broadcasting Association. She obtained a master’s degree in national security administration from the National Defense College of the Philippines in 1992. Legarda is a reserved officer in the Armed Forces of the Philippines with the rank of lieutenant colonel.

She appeared in her first television commercial for Close-up at age 15, and the following year for Pond’s cold cream. She also endorsed Blue Clinic, Kodak, Lagerlite, Shell, and, later in her career, Swift Hotdogs, Ariel, Hapee Toothpaste, and National Book Store. She started her broadcast career on GMA in What’s Up?, 1980-83, a program of Orlando “Orly” Mercado, her mentor-professor at the UP Institute of Mass Communication and who would also become a senator. Her first job as a disc jockey came in 1981 on GMA’s Discorama with Bobby Ledesma and the Apo Hiking Society, and later with the comedic trio of Tito, Vic, and Joey. She became news anchor for RPN 9’s Newswatch: Late Night Edition, 1981-85, with Pat Lazaro, and produced and hosted the TV magazine Manila Envelope on US television via KSCI-Channel 18 in Los Angeles, 1982, which features the Filipino community in the West Coast. She also hosted RPN 9’s weekly public affairs program Street Pulse, 1986. She then moved to ABS-CBN where she anchored the news program The World Tonight, 1986-99, with Angelo Castro Jr, and hosted the magazine program PEP Talk, 1986-90, the investigative program The Inside Story, 1990-98, the environmental program EarthLink, 1996, the docudrama Kabalikat (Shoulder to Shoulder), 2001-3, the special documentary Sa Mata ng Balita: 50 Taong Pamamahayag sa Telebisyon (In the Eye of the News: 50 Years of Television Broadcast Journalism), 2003, and the youth drama program Tara Tena (Come, Let’s Go), 2003-4. On ABC 5, she hosted the public affairs program Real Stories Kasama si Loren (Real Stories with Loren), 2004-7.

Legarda is also a writer, actor, and media producer. She wrote a cover story on National Artist Vicente Manansala for the Daily Express Weekend Magazine, 1982, and regular columns for the Manila Bulletin, 1993. She had a cameo role in the film Markova: Comfort Gay, 2000, that starred Dolphy. She narrated and produced the 25-minute animated feature Ligtas Likas (Save the Environment), 2009, with the Creative Media and Film Society of the Philippines; the documentary Buhos (Downpour), 2010, directed by Brillante Mendoza, which is about the tragedy brought about by typhoon Ondoy; and the docudrama Ulan sa Tag-araw (Rain in the Dry Season), 2011, which is about climate change.

She topped the senatorial race in the 1998 and 2007 elections. Her 1998 campaign advertisements were a series of 30-seconders, written by Salvii Casino, which featured her interviewing famous world leaders. She presents herself in politics as an advocate for issues concerning the environment, gender, and indigenous peoples. Among the major laws she authored are the Clean Air Act of 1999; the Ecological Solid Waste Management Act of 2000; the Anti-Trafficking in Persons Act of 2003; the Anti-Child Labor Law of 2003; the Anti-Violence Against Women and Children Act of 2004; the Magna Carta of Women of 2008; the Renewable Energy Act, 2008; the Climate Change Act, 2009; the Disaster Risk Reduction andManagement Act of 2009; and the Expanded Senior Citizens Act of 2010.

She received more than 30 awards for her work as a broadcast journalist. PEP Talk was recognized as one of the 10 Best Television Programs in the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon in 1997 and 1998, and her hosting of the program won for her five Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) in the 1980s, which elevated her to the CMMA Hall of Fame in 1989. The World Tonight won the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon in 1996, Earth Link garnered a finalist citation in the New York Festivals in 1996, and Real Stories Kasama si Loren won the KBP Golden Dove Award in 2004. The Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards for Television conferred on her the Excellence in Broadcasting Lifetime Achievement Award in 2008. She received the Ten Outstanding Young Men and Women award in 1992, the Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service award in 1993, and the Benigno Aquino Award for Journalism in 1995. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III and Laya Boquiren

Boquiren 2013; Ivote.com 2013; Loren Legarda Homepage 2013; Rappler 2013; Rimban 1999c; Rogue Rules 2013a, 2013b; Senate of the Philippines 2013b, 2013c; Umbao 2013.

Among the major laws she authored are the Clean Air Act of 1999; the Ecological Solid Waste Management Act of 2000; the Anti-Trafficking in Persons Act of 2003; the Anti-Child Labor Law of 2003; the Anti-Violence Against Women and Children Act of 2004; the Magna Carta of Women of 2008; the Renewable Energy Act, 2008; the Climate Change Act, 2009; the Disaster Risk Reduction andManagement Act of 2009; and the Expanded Senior Citizens Act of 2010.

She received more than 30 awards for her work as a broadcast journalist. PEP Talk was recognized as one of the 10 Best Television Programs in the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon in 1997 and 1998, and her hosting of the program won for her five Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) in the 1980s, which elevated her to the CMMA Hall of Fame in 1989. The World Tonight won the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon in 1996, Earth Link garnered a finalist citation in the New York Festivals in 1996, and Real Stories Kasama si Loren won the KBP Golden Dove Award in 2004. The Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards for Television conferred on her the Excellence in Broadcasting Lifetime Achievement Award in 2008. She received the Ten Outstanding Young Men and Women award in 1992, the Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service award in 1993, and the Benigno Aquino Award for Journalism in 1995. LINDENBERG, JAMES (James B. Lindenberg) b. Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA 21 Dec 1921. d. 28 Apr 2009. Soldier, engineer, businessman, broadcast media owner, and Philippine television pioneer. He was married to Soledad S. Lindenberg.

Lindenberg was the first to acquire a Philippine franchise to operate a television station for his Bolinao Electronics Company (BEC). A US Air Force officer who was part of the American troops who fought the Japanese and ended the war in the Philippines in 1945, he established the BEC in 1946 upon discharge from the US military and after marrying Soledad S. Lindenberg of Bolinao, Pangasinan. With his wife, Patrocinio Hennings, John Hennings, and Jose Calado, he first set up a local radio transmitter manufacturing operation using surplus war communications equipment. In 1949, he applied for a television franchise, which Congress granted on 14 Jun 1951. Unable to import equipment necessary to go on the air due to import restrictions at the time, he shifted to radio and established DZBC.

In 1952, Judge Antonio Quirino bought the majority shares of BEC and renamed it Alto Broadcasting System (ABS). His goal was to use television to help campaign for his brother Elpidio, who was seeking reelection to the Philippine presidency. With help from the Radio Corporation of America, the new company sent Arcadio Carandang, Romualdo Carballo, Harry Chaney, and Jose Navarro to the United States for technical training and import equipment to put the first Philippine television station on air on 23 Oct 1953. Lindenberg remained part-owner, executive vice president, and chief operating officer of ABS.

Elpidio Quirino was not reelected. ABS then suffered from financial difficulties due to the high cost of production of local programs and weak advertiser support given the low number of households with television sets. The station relied mostly on imported canned shows. In 1957, Eugenio Lopez and his brother Fernando acquired ABS from Lindenberg and Quirino. The Lopezes then already owned Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN). In 1961, the Lopezes combined the two companies and called it ABS-CBN.

Lindenberg is often called the “Father of Philippine Television,” but the same honor is also accorded Antonio Quirino. Written by Gian Carlo C. Librojo

LIZASO, NICK (Arsenio de Jesus Lizaso) b. Santa Maria, Bulacan 14 Dec 1934. TV, film, theater director, actor. His parents are Arcadio Lizaso Jr and Natividad de Jesus. He went to San Beda College for his high school education, 1949-53. He took up prelaw at the University of the Philippines (UP), 1954-56, and a bachelor of arts in English, major in speech and drama, at the University of the East, 1958-65.

 

He taught television, film, and theater directing, scriptwriting, and acting at San Sebastian College, 1963-65; San Beda College, 1969; Maryknoll College, now Miriam College, 1973; Assumption College, 1974; UP, 1990-91; St. Paul University in Quezon City; and La Consolacion College, 2008-10. He received the British Council Grant Attachment with the Nottingham Playhouse and the Royal Shakespeare Company in London and Stratford-on Avon, as well as a Fullbright-Hayes Travel Grant to the USA for Theater Arts, 1966. He has attended various international conferences on theater, film, and arts education in Italy, Romania, Turkey, United States, United Kingdom, Spain, PROC, Belgium, and Korea. He was a founding officer and member of the board of governors of the Directors Guild of the Philippines, in which he also served as president from 1983 to 1985. He has been a trustee of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) since 2013, an appointment he first held in Oct 1972. He is vice president of the International Theater Institute of UNESCO and executive director of the Asia-Pacific Bureau of the International University Theater Association. Through his advocacy project called Sining Sigla (Arts Alive), he has brought the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO) to communities outside the CCP, such as the free public concert by the PPO to the Philippine General Hospital in 2014 to bring the healing touch of music to patients, including children, stricken with cancer.

 

He directed the television social satire sitcom Tisoy (Mestizo), 1968-69, ABC-TV Channel 5. He was stage director of the pre-martial law drama anthology Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), some episodes of which he also directed, 1969-72, ABC-TV Channel 5. He was again in the pool of directors of the post-martial law reincarnation of Balintataw, 1987 to early 2000s, PTV 4. He also directed the music program Carmen on Camera,1967, topbilled by singer Carmen Soriano, with the Tiongco Brothers as mainstays. Lizaso directed episodes of the television drama anthologies Salaghati (Heartache), 1970-72, ABS-CBN; Obra Maestra (Masterpiece), 1971-72, ABS-CBN; Dahong Ginto (Golden Page), 1973, IBC 13; Nang Dahil sa Pag-ibig (Because of Love), 1979-80, RPN 9; Mga Kuwento ng Pag-ibig (Love Stories), 1981, PTV 4; Hiyas (Jewel), 1985-87, GMA; Lovingly Yours, Helen, 1980-96, GMA; Ipaglaban Mo (Fight for It), 1989-92, IBC 13, 1992-99, ABS-CBN, and 2003-4, RPN 9. He directed the films Markadong Anghel (Marked Angel), 1976, Kapangyarihan ni Eva (The Power of Eve), 1977, Flor de Liza, 1981, Ulo ng Gapo (aka The Outlaw Inferno), 1981, and Anak ng Dilim (Child of Darkness), 1997. Among the plays he directed were Julius Caesar, Oedipus Rex, Cyrano de Bergerac, A Flea in Her Ear, The Fantasticks, Man of La Mancha, and Rosecrantz and Guilderstern Are Dead.

 

As an actor, he was a mainstay in the telenovela dramas Alyna, 2010-11, Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14, and Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw (You’re the One I Need), 2013, and the horror series Oka2Kat (I Am Afraid), 2012, all on ABS-CBN. In theater, he played Prof Henry Higgins in My Fair Lady, 1965, directed by Fr James Reuter, SJ, staged at the Assumption Convent at San Lorenzo, Makati. He played a lead role in Bayaning Huwad (Straw Patriot), the first play to be staged at the Fort Santiago Theater in Intramuros. He has acted in over 50 plays in a span of almost a decade, from 1964 to 1975. In films, he appeared in Ishmael Bernal’s Broken Marriage, 1983; Diego Cagahastian’s Ben Tumbling, 1985; Ronwaldo Reyes’s Muslim .357, 1986; Pablo Santiago’s Operation: Get Victor Corpuz, the Rebel Soldier, 1987; and Sari Dalena’s Dahling Nick, 2015.

 

Carmen on Camera won Best Musical in the Citizens’ Awards for Television (CAT), 1967. Balintataw and its writers, performers, and directors, including episodes directed by Lizaso, won 18 CATs, 1967-72. The revived Balintataw received the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon in 1988 and 1991. Ipaglaban Mo won the Hall Fame Award of the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA), 1993. Balintataw won Best Drama and Best Entertainment Program, both in 2014, at the CMMA. His other awards include the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Award by the city of Manila, 1995; the Gawad Dangal ng Lipi ng Bulacan for theater arts, 1999; and the Bedan Achievers Award of San Beda College, 2003. Currently, Lizaso is the president of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Written by Edgardo Ray G. Pedroche, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

 

Sources: Avena 1983a; CCP 2015; Degalen.com 2015; Garcia 2015; Lizaso 2014; Philippine Daily Inquirer 2003; Video 48 2008a.

text:
LOPEZ, EÑING (Eugenio Hofileña Lopez Sr) b. Jaro, Iloilo City 20 Jul 1901. d. San Francisco, California, USA 5 Jul 1975. Founder of ABS-CBN, El Tiempo, Iloilo Times, and the Manila Chronicle. He was the eldest among the 16 children of Iloilo governor Benito Villanueva Lopez and Presentacion Javelona Hofileña. His brother Fernando was vice president of the country during the terms of Elpidio Quirino, 1949-53, and Ferdinand Marcos, from 1965 until the latter declared martial law in 1972. He had five children with Pacita Moreno: Eugenio Jr, aka Geny and Kapitan, who succeeded his father in running ABS-CBN until the network was turned over to Geny’s son Eugenio Gabriel III, aka Gabby, in 1997; Oscar, who took over the Lopez Group when his father went into exile in 1972; Presentacion Psinakis, aka Presy, who, together with her family, went into exile in the United States during the martial law period; Manuel, aka Manolo, who took charge of Meralco in 1965-72 and beginning in 1986; and Roberto.

Eñing studied at Ateneo de Manila where he graduated cum laude in 1919, obtained a bachelor of laws degree from the University of the Philippines in 1923, and passed the bar in the same year. He went on a one-year postgraduate study in law at Harvard University and returned to Iloilo in 1929.

Alfred McCoy (1994) states that the Lopez family’s rise in rent-seeking businesses, especially that of Eñing as a media magnate, was the result of the family’s skillful building up of political and personal alliances, ably supported by close kinship ties, strengthened by a dexterous reading of the intersection of social and economic conditions, fortified by a clever handling of the playing field, and made firm by personal and management values and entrepreneurial skills. All these enabled Eñing to mobilize resources, acquire interests in a series of interlocking businesses, and keep their resources and power intact.

The wealthy Jalandoni-Lopez line had interests in the sugar industry and regional politics as early as the 19th century. Iloilo was then the sugar bowl of the Philippines. When Eñing’s father Benito, a reelected governor of Iloilo, was gunned down by his political opponents in 1908, young Eñing and brother Fernando inherited and ran their family’s share of the sugar plantation Hacienda Calasagan, a printing press that published El Tiempo, and other properties.

The brothers revived the Spanish-language daily El Tiempo, the first issue of which came out on 1 Jun 1929. The newspaper waged a crusade against jueteng, an illegal numbers game, that implicated then Iloilo governor Mariano Arroyo and resulted in the governor’s removal from office in 1930. They also founded the English-language daily Iloilo Times, the first issue of which came out on 1 Mar 1932. Eñing’s entry into the press industry established him as a force to reckon with in Iloilo politics.

Eñing’s and Fernando’s concerns expanded to businesses in land, sea, and air transport beginning in the 1930s, dominating the provincial, regional, and national transport. Their investments included the bus and taxi company Iloilo Transportation Company, the regional ferry service Iloilo Shipping, both in 1931, and the first Filipino airline, the Iloilo-Negros Air Express Company (INAEC), in 1932. The brothers bought out the Panay Autobus Company, a major competitor of their bus company that they purchased at 80,000 pesos, way below the original owners’ investment capital of 300,000 pesos, in 1938.The brothers also invested in real estate in Baguio and acquired the Philippine Portland Cement Company.

The Lopez businesses were devastated during the Japanese occupation. INAEC’s planes were destroyed by the Japanese on an air raid in 1941. El Tiempo was taken over and renamed Panay Shu-ho by the Japanese in 1942, which the occupying forces used for propaganda. Panay Autobus’s 300 buses were commandeered by the Japanese also in the same year. Eugenio and his family moved to Baguio in 1943, and funneled funds to support the guerrillas while playing cordial politics with the Japanese.

Business and politics intertwined like siblings during this crucial period and onward. Eugenio moved to Manila after World War II. The brothers resumed their transport business, foremost of which was their commercial aviation operation of the Far Eastern Air Transport Inc (FEATI) in 1945, which established itself as the country’s first international airline that had its first flight service to San Francisco, California, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Bangkok, and India. Eñing, however, was forced to sell FEATI to its rival Philippine Airlines in 1947, which was well supported by government funds.

Fernando entered politics as Iloilo mayor in 1945, a time of postwar reconstruction. A close alliance with then president Sergio Osmeña was advantageous to Eñing’s business interests. Fernando became senator in 1947, then secretary of agriculture, which made easier the granting of special privileges to the businesses led by his brother. During this time, local politicians who desired power needed the capital of the elite. Fernando’s position as vice president of Quirino in the 1940s and later Marcos in the 1960s entrenched the influence of the Lopez family, who likewise provided funds for the political campaigns of their political allies.

A significant move by Eñing was when he moved to public utilities like communication and power generation, beginning with the acquisition of the news daily Manila Chronicle in 1947, which ran in 1949 a series of exposés on Senate president Jose Avelino. He, together with either brother Fernando or other partners, embarked on a series of buyouts and acquisitions beginning in the 1950s, mainly in the sugar industry, such as substantial shares to control the country’s and Asia’s largest sugar mill, Binalbagan-Isabela Sugar Company (Biscom), in 1951; the New York-based Sugar Brokers Inc in 1956, which handled the sale of Biscom sugar to the US market; and the Pampanga Sugar Mills Inc (Pasumil), also in 1956. They withdrew from the sugar industry when they sold Biscom and Pasumil to Trans-Philippine Investment Corporation in 1962, which proved to be a wise move when the industry started showing signs of a decline. Eñing and allies also put up the Philippine Commercial and Industrial Bank in 1959, earning a third spot among the biggest banks in the country in a span of one year.

Eñing acquired the Manila Electric Company (Meralco), through the Meralco Securities Corporation (MSC), from General Public Utilities of New York in 1961, which became the centerpiece of the Lopez Group. Meralco’s power plant construction and pipeline projects in 1967 were propelled in 1964 by its selling of eight million US dollars worth of Meralco bonds, the first time a private Filipino corporation sold bonds to the US market way before government did so. Its building in Pasig was inaugurated on 14 Mar 1969. Meralco was named best managed firm in 1996 by Asiamoney. The MSC created the Philippine Petroleum Corporation, the pioneer producer of lubricating oils for industry, and the Philippine Engineering and Construction Company, which designs and builds power plants, power lines, substations, and pipelines.

Eñing started his venture into the broadcast industry when he established the Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN) in 1956, which began airing on Channel 9 in 1958, featuring the daily noontime show Student Canteen and the singing talent search program Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage). He acquired Alto Broadcasting System (ABS) and Bolinao Electronics from Justice Antonio Quirino and James Lindenberg in 1957, which operated the radio station DZAQ and Channel 3, the country’s first TV station. He consolidated the broadcast companies on 1 Feb 1967 into what would be known as ABS-CBN, and bought a 44,027 square meter lot on Bohol Ave in Quezon City, which became its home when it was inaugurated on 18 Dec 1968. ABS-CBN became the first media conglomerate and biggest broadcasting network in the country, with the most advanced broadcasting center in Asia during the period. In telecommunications, the Lopezes acquired the Philippine Telegraph and Telephone Company (PT&T).

Eugenio’s contributions in culture cannot be ignored. The Lopez Museum was inaugurated in 1960 to house art collections, maps of colonial-era Philippines, and rare Filipiniana books. It was considered a tribute to Eñing’s parents, Benito and Presentacion. As a philanthropic initiative, the Lopez Foundation was also established on 17 Jun 1968.

Relations between the Lopezes and Marcos soured in Jan 1971. McCoy reports that Marcos was asking for shares in the Lopez businesses, to which the Lopezes did not accede. It also did not help that the Lopezes were closely associated with Sergio Osmeña Jr, who ran for the presidency but lost against Marcos in 1969. The relationship between the Lopezes and Marcos got worse when ABS-CBN and the Manila Chronicle exposed Marcos’s corruption in 1971.

When Marcos declared martial law in 1972, the military shut down media outlets, among which were ABS-CBN and the Manila Chronicle. Eñing went into exile in the United States. His eldest son Geny was among those incarcerated for allegations of subversion. Under pressure and with the promise of his son’s release, Eñing ceded control of ABS-CBN, which was taken over by Roberto Benedicto, a Marcos crony. He also handed over the control of Meralco, MSC, and PCI Bank to the Marcoses through the Meralco Foundation, brokered by Benjamin “Kokoy” Romualdez, First Lady Imelda Marcos’s brother, on 9 Nov 1973. He was diagnosed with terminal cancer in 1974 while in exile in the United States. He requested Marcos to allow him to make a final visit to his son, and he was summoned to the Philippines but was denied his request. In spite of his physical condition, he made final visits to relatives in Manila, a few public appearances in Iloilo where he dedicated a hospital to his father’s memory, and returned to the United States. Realizing that the promise of his son’s release was a way for Marcos to blackmail him, he gave several interviews to the press in the United States, the most important of which was with Parade Magazine, in which he said: “I, Eugenio Lopez Sr, an old man, now appeal to public opinion. I have no other source to help me regain my son.” Eñing died in 1975 in San Francisco, California, with his son Geny still in prison.

Eñing was elected president of the Iloilo Chamber of Commerce in 1939, and received the Pro Patria Award from Pres Ferdinand Marcos in 1969 and a Distinguished Service Award from Harvard University in 1972. Written byLaya Boquiren and Eulalio R. Guieb III

Sources:

The brothers resumed their transport business, foremost of which was their commercial aviation operation of the Far Eastern Air Transport Inc (FEATI) in 1945, which established itself as the country’s first international airline that had its first flight service to San Francisco, California, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Bangkok, and India. Eñing, however, was forced to sell FEATI to its rival Philippine Airlines in 1947, which was well supported by government funds.

Fernando entered politics as Iloilo mayor in 1945, a time of postwar reconstruction. A close alliance with then president Sergio Osmeña was advantageous to Eñing’s business interests. Fernando became senator in 1947, then secretary of agriculture, which made easier the granting of special privileges to the businesses led by his brother. During this time, local politicians who desired power needed the capital of the elite. Fernando’s position as vice president of Quirino in the 1940s and later Marcos in the 1960s entrenched the influence of the Lopez family, who likewise provided funds for the political campaigns of their political allies.

A significant move by Eñing was when he moved to public utilities like communication and power generation, beginning with the acquisition of the news daily Manila Chronicle in 1947, which ran in 1949 a series of exposés on Senate president Jose Avelino. He, together with either brother Fernando or other partners, embarked on a series of buyouts and acquisitions beginning in the 1950s, mainly in the sugar industry, such as substantial shares to control the country’s and Asia’s largest sugar mill, Binalbagan-Isabela Sugar Company (Biscom), in 1951; the New York-based Sugar Brokers Inc in 1956, which handled the sale of Biscom sugar to the US market; and the Pampanga Sugar Mills Inc (Pasumil), also in 1956. They withdrew from the sugar industry when they sold Biscom and Pasumil to Trans-Philippine Investment Corporation in 1962, which proved to be a wise move when the industry started showing signs of a decline. Eñing and allies also put up the Philippine Commercial and Industrial Bank in 1959, earning a third spot among the biggest banks in the country in a span of one year.

Eñing acquired the Manila Electric Company (Meralco), through the Meralco Securities Corporation (MSC), from General Public Utilities of New York in 1961, which became the centerpiece of the Lopez Group. Meralco’s power plant construction and pipeline projects in 1967 were propelled in 1964 by its selling of eight million US dollars worth of Meralco bonds, the first time a private Filipino corporation sold bonds to the US market way before government did so. Its building in Pasig was inaugurated on 14 Mar 1969. Meralco was named best managed firm in 1996 by Asiamoney. The MSC created the Philippine Petroleum Corporation, the pioneer producer of lubricating oils for industry, and the Philippine Engineering and Construction Company, which designs and builds power plants, power lines, substations, and pipelines.

Eñing started his venture into the broadcast industry when he established the Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN) in 1956, which began airing on Channel 9 in 1958, featuring the daily noontime show Student Canteen and the singing talent search program Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage). He acquired Alto Broadcasting System (ABS) and Bolinao Electronics from Justice Antonio Quirino and James Lindenberg in 1957, which operated the radio station DZAQ and Channel 3, the country’s first TV station. He consolidated the broadcast companies on 1 Feb 1967 into what would be known as ABS-CBN, and bought a 44,027 square meter lot on Bohol Ave in Quezon City, which became its home when it was inaugurated on 18 Dec 1968. ABS-CBN became the first media conglomerate and biggest broadcasting network in the country, with the most advanced broadcasting center in Asia during the period. In telecommunications, the Lopezes acquired the Philippine Telegraph and Telephone Company (PT&T).

Eugenio’s contributions in culture cannot be ignored. The Lopez Museum was inaugurated in 1960 to house art collections, maps of colonial-era Philippines, and rare Filipiniana books. It was considered a tribute to Eñing’s parents, Benito and Presentacion. As a philanthropic initiative, the Lopez Foundation was also established on 17 Jun 1968.

Relations between the Lopezes and Marcos soured in Jan 1971. McCoy reports that Marcos was asking for shares in the Lopez businesses, to which the Lopezes did not accede. It also did not help that the Lopezes were closely associated with Sergio Osmeña Jr, who ran for the presidency but lost against Marcos in 1969. The relationship between the Lopezes and Marcos got worse when ABS-CBN and the Manila Chronicle exposed Marcos’s corruption in 1971.

When Marcos declared martial law in 1972, the military shut down media outlets, among which were ABS-CBN and the Manila Chronicle. Eñing went into exile in the United States. His eldest son Geny was among those incarcerated for allegations of subversion. Under pressure and with the promise of his son’s release, Eñing ceded control of ABS-CBN, which was taken over by Roberto Benedicto, a Marcos crony. He also handed over the control of Meralco, MSC, and PCI Bank to the Marcoses through the Meralco Foundation, brokered by Benjamin “Kokoy” Romualdez, First Lady Imelda Marcos’s brother, on 9 Nov 1973. He was diagnosed with terminal cancer in 1974 while in exile in the United States. He requested Marcos to allow him to make a final visit to his son, and he was summoned to the Philippines but was denied his request. In spite of his physical condition, he made final visits to relatives in Manila, a few public appearances in Iloilo where he dedicated a hospital to his father’s memory, and returned to the United States. Realizing that the promise of his son’s release was a way for Marcos to blackmail him, he gave several interviews to the press in the United States, the most important of which was with Parade Magazine, in which he said: “I, Eugenio Lopez Sr, an old man, now appeal to public opinion. I have no other source to help me regain my son.” Eñing died in 1975 in San Francisco, California, with his son Geny still in prison.

Eñing was elected president of the Iloilo Chamber of Commerce in 1939, and received the Pro Patria Award from Pres Ferdinand Marcos in 1969 and a Distinguished Service Award from Harvard University in 1972. Written byLaya Boquiren and Eulalio R. Guieb III

text:
LOPEZ, GABBY (Eugenio Gabriel La’O Lopez III) b. Boston, Massachusetts, USA 23 Sep 1952. Broadcast media owner and executive. He belongs to the Lopez clan of Iloilo. He is the son of business tycoon and former ABS-CBN chairman Eugenio “Geny” Moreno Lopez Jr and Conchita La’O. He has six siblings: Regina Paz, who heads ABS-CBN Foundation, now Lingkod Kapamilya Foundation, Maria Rosario, Rafael Kevin, Roberta Pilar, Ernesto Miguel, and Ramon Javier. He married Panjee Gonzalez Tapales with whom he has four children. His uncles Oscar, Manuel, and Federico hold various positions in ABS-CBN. Oscar is president, chief executive officer (CEO), director, and chair of ABS-CBN Holdings Corporation. Manuel and Federico are members of the boards that control ABS-CBN under the Lopez Holdings Corporation and First Philippine Holdings Corporation, respectively. Lopez III finished his bachelor of arts in political science at Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Maine, in the United States in 1974. He received his master of arts in business administration from Harvard University School of Business in 1980. He was director of finance, 1986-87, general manager, 1987-93, president and CEO, 1993-2008, and chair of the board of directors since 1997 of ABS-CBN Corporation. He is also director and treasurer of Lopez Holdings Corporation, formerly Benpres Holdings Corporation, the Lopez family’s ventures in broadcasting, telecommunications, banking, and power.

Lopez III held key positions in ABS-CBN beginning in 1986, aiding his father in the expansion efforts of their company. In 1986, ABS-CBN Broadcasting Corporation only had one television and radio station, ABS-CBN Channel 2 and DZMM 630 kHz, as they were returned back to the Lopezes after the EDSA Revolt. Father and son ventured into cable distribution with SKY Cable, which provided Cinema One and Sarimanok News Network (SNN). SKY is now also an Internet provider. SNN, now ABS-CBN News Channel (ANC), was then launched as the Philippines’ first 24/7 news channel. On 24 Sep 1994, ABS-CBN launched the country’s first international channel with The Filipino Channel (TFC), which brought locally produced shows to Filipino expatriates. ABS-CBN Global was later made as a separate subsidiary as TFC developed. In Oct 1996, ABS-CBN acquired another free television channel, which was named Studio 23. In 1993, Star Cinema was established as the filmmaking arm of the company. Star Records was established to offer recorded music since Feb 1995. In 1997, Lopez III created the Lopez Communications Group, which is the management committee that oversees the development and implementation of convergence strategies of ABS-CBN, BayanTel, Sky Cable, and the investments of the Lopezes in telecommunications, cable, and data warehousing. With the advent of the Internet, ABS-CBN Interactive (ABSi) was launched in Feb 1999 as the new media subsidiary of ABS-CBN.

After the death of his father on 29 Jun 1999, Lopez III continued as president and CEO of the company. He spearheaded the establishment of more channels under ABS-CBN Broadcasting Corporation. These include cable channels Lifestyle Network, Knowledge Channel, MYX, Hero TV, DZMM Teleradyo, and Balls TV. MYX and DZMM Teleradyo were as groundbreaking as ANC. MYX is the first Filipino 24/7 music channel while DZMM Teleradyo is among the first television channels that provide a televised radio broadcast in the country.

During Lopez III’s leadership, ABS-CBN aggressively diversified into other ventures. It went into publication via ABS-CBN Publishing, sports programming and licensing under ABS-CBN Sports, and telecommunications with Bayan Telecommunications and ABS-CBN Mobile under ABS-CBN Convergence. When Lopez III stepped down as CEO of ABS-CBN in 2013, he announced the strengthened diversification of the company, which included investments in the development of a family entertainment center in Bonifacio Global City in Taguig through ABS-CBN Corporation subsidiary Play Innovations.

Lopez III received the Tanglaw ng Araw Award for promoting good Filipino values at the 9th Araw Values Awards given by the Advertising Foundation of the Philippines in 2014. He was awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award by the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas in 2014 for his contributions in the media industry.

Written by Gian Carlo C. Librojo, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III
