text:
LOPEZ, GENY (Eugenio Moreno Lopez Jr) aka Kapitan. b. Iloilo City 4 Nov 1928. d. Hillsborough, California, USA 29 Jun 1999. He was the eldest child of Eugenio “Eñing” Lopez Sr and Pacita Moreno. He married Conchita “Chita” La’O, with whom he had seven children: Eugenio “Gabby” Lopez III, who inherited from him the management of ABS-CBN; Regina Paz, who put up ABS-CBN Foundation; Ernesto; Rosario; Ramon; Roberta; and Rafael. His loving companion for 10 years until his death was former fashion model and Camay girl Susan Reyes. Geny completed his elementary school at San Beda College in 1942, and high school at Ateneo de Manila in 1946. He attended Ateneo de Manila for a year in 1947, but transferred to Virginia Military Institute in the United States in 1948, where he completed a bachelor of arts degree in 1950. He pursued graduate studies in Madrid in 1950, then went back to the United States for a master in business administration from Harvard Business School, which he completed in 1953.

Geny was assigned by his father Eñing to run the family-owned newspaper Manila Chronicle in 1953. He was responsible for the merger in 1957 of Alto Broadcasting System (ABS), which his father bought from Antonio Quirino in 1956, and the Lopez-owned radio station Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN), which Eñing established in 1956, into ABS-CBN Channel 3. Quirino’s ABS, formerly Bolinao Electronics Corporation (BEC), had DZAQ TV Channel 3, the first television network in the country that began operating in 1953. ABS subsidiary Bolinao Broadcasting System had radio stations DZBC in San Juan, Rizal, DZRI in Dagupan, Pangasinan, and DZRB in Naga, Camarines Sur. The Lopezes incorporated the media conglomerate under the name BEC Channel 3, officially changed it to ABS-CBN Channel 3 in 1963, then ABS-CBN Broadcasting Corporation in 1967. The call sign “Channel 2” was first introduced into the network’s logo in 1986 after the Lopezes regained possession of the station, which was shut down by Marcos when he declared martial law in 1972, with its facilities seized and taken over by Marcos crony Roberto Benedicto.

Geny propelled ABS-CBN to being the Philippines’ largest network. In 1961, he got the rights for ABS-CBN to cover and air the 1962 and 1966 ASEAN Games. In 1966, the network started telecasting color programs and introduced the Sarimanok logo. In 1967, its programs Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life), 1964, Wild, Wild West, 1965, The Nida-Nestor Show, 1965, Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), 1958, and Your Evening with Pilita, 1965, were on top of the ratings charts. In 1968, he and his father built the most technologically advanced broadcast center in Asia on Bohol Ave in Quezon City, and established Nuvue Cablevision, the country’s first cable company. In 1969, ABS-CBN covered Apollo 11’s historic landing on the moon, the country’s first telecast of an event via satellite. By 1972, ABS-CBN was a giant network, with television Channels 2 and 4, seven radio stations in Metro Manila, three provincial TV stations, 14 radio stations, and three radio affiliate stations.

Geny was among those detained in a maximum security prison in Fort Bonifacio during martial law. In Nov 1972, the military arrested him “on trumped-up charges of conspiring to assassinate the dictator” (Rodrigo 2006, 4). The price of Geny’s freedom was “his family’s handing over to Marcos the major Lopez companies” (Rodrigo et al. 2008, 38). On 24 Jan 1975, he was asked to sign a letter agreeing to the confiscation of their properties, admitting their involvement in the alleged plot to assassinate Marcos, and endorsing martial law. He refused to sign, and the negotiations with Marcos collapsed. He and fellow detainee Sergio Osmeña III, whose father was a Marcos political rival, staged a hunger strike inside their prison cell in 1974 to call attention to their plight. In 1977, the two escaped from their detention cell by crawling beneath barbed wires, beyond the fenced-in perimeter of Fort Bonifacio, and off via a chartered aircraft to the United States where they sought political asylum. He returned to the Philippines on 28 Feb 1986, two days after the fall of the dictator.

The post-EDSA conditions worked to the advantage of the Lopezes. Through Augusto Almeda Lopez and intermediaries in the administration of newly installed president Corazon Aquino, he recovered the Lopez companies commandeered by Marcos’s cronies, including the Manila Chronicle, Meralco, First Holdings, PCIBank, and ABS-CBN’s Channel 2 and two radio stations. The Lopezes filed a case against Marcos crony Roberto Benedicto, who took over their network during martial law. With help from brothers Oscar and Manuel, Geny revived and rebuilt ABS-CBN Corporation.

Geny enlisted experts who formed the executive body of the network, which steered the station to its growth and expansion. One of them was Federico Garcia, who was into sales for the second Lopez-owned station Channel 9 before martial law. Garcia’s marketing strategies propelled the post-martial law ABS-CBN from the bottom five in the ratings to the number one position in a span of only one year and a half. Geny tapped the likes of Charo Santos-Concio, Johnny Manahan, and Salvii Casino to strengthen the station’s productions and programming. He invested in the latest communications technology and infrastructure, such as state-of-the-art electronic news gathering vans. ABS-CBN’s tag line “In the service of the Filipino” was introduced in 1988. It resumed its provincial operations, beginning with DYCB-TV Channel 3 in Cebu, also in 1988. It started to penetrate the international market, beginning with the launch of ABS-CBN International in Daly City in 1992, the ABS-CBN Televideo rental market in the United States in 1993, and The Filipino Channel (TFC), also in 1993. It ventured into other operations, such as UHF broadcasting through Studio 23, television subscriptions through Sky Cable, 24-hour news programming in the Sarimanok News Network, local and international film productions through Star Cinema, music recordings through Star Records, consumer merchandising through Star Magic, and basketball franchise through the Metropolitan Basketball Association.

Television programming changed when Geny regained the network in 1986. There was a clamor for infotainment with a strong local and mass-oriented bent. Its entertainment programs—specifically, Martin & Pops, 1987-88, Palibhasa Lalake (Because They Are Guys), 1987-89, Luv Ko si Kris (I Love Kris), 1990-92, The Sharon Cuneta Show, 1986-88, Sa Linggo nAPO Sila (The APO Are Now on Sunday), 1990-95, Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 1991 to present, Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Wait for the Next Chapter), 1991-97, Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad), 1992-2003, Ang TV (The TV), and Oki Doki Dok (Okay, Doc), 1993—and news and public affairs programs TV Patrol, 1987 to present, The World Tonight, 1986-99, Magandang Gabi, Bayan! (Good Evening, Nation!), 1988-2005, Mel & Jay, 1988-96, and Balitang K (K News), 1996-2001, dominated the ratings game.

Critics observed, however, that public affairs programming of ABS-CBN under Geny’s management shifted from a serious social and political tone to one that was peppered with the sensationalism of the everyday. These programs were staged to make the anchors look sleek and glamorous. Entertainment became as important as news. The personal lives of movie stars were highlighted as much as news on the government or the stock market. News platforms and media personalities associated with hard news presented tidbits on supernatural occurrences, scandals, intrigues, heinous crimes, and comic relief. Real-life domestic conflicts were spiced up, similar to those in soap opera melodrama.

Geny remained the president of the network until 1997 when he turned over the chairmanship of the broadcast network to son Gabby, who had been tasked by his father the day-to-day management of the network since 1993. Geny received the KBP Lifetime Achievement Award in 1998. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III and Laya Boquiren

Sources:

text:
LOPEZ, GINA (Regina Paz La’O Lopez) b. Manila 27 Dec 1954. d. Makati City 19 Aug 2019. Broadcast executive. She was the second child of Eugenio Lopez Jr, aka Geny and Kapitan, owner of ABS-CBN Corporation, and Conchita La’O. Her brother Eugenio III, aka Gabby, has chaired the board of directors of ABS-CBN since 1997. She married Sona Roy with whom she has two sons. She studied at Assumption College and at the Newton College of Sacred Heart in Boston where she took up liberal arts. While in college, she joined the spiritual organization Ananda Marga. She earned a master’s degree in development management at the Asian Institute of Management, 1993. She was conferred a doctor of humanities, honoris causa, by Ateneo de Naga University, 2011.

 

Lopez spent 20 years of her life with Ananda Marga, serving the poor in India, Kenya, Zambia, Ghana, and Nigeria.When she came back to Manila after the EDSA Revolt in 1986, she served as managing director of ABS-CBN Foundation, the public service arm of ABS-CBN Broadcasting Corporation. One of her first initiatives was the production of curriculum-based television programs under the Foundation’s E-media project, in cooperation with the Department of Education, Culture, and Sports. The programs were required-viewing materials during school hours in selected public schools. Lopez launched a fund-raising campaign to gather funds for the donation of television sets and disc players to schools, which partly addressed the book shortage in public schools and their students’ low ranking in national examinations, especially in science and math.

 

The first of these educational TV programs was the science show Sineskwela (School on Air) which premiered in Jun 1994. Other programs soon followed, each focusing on a particular subject: Bayani (Hero) on Philippine history, Hiraya Manawari (Reaching One’s Dreams) on values education, Mathtinik (Math Wiz) on mathematics, Epol/Apple on English, Pahina (Pages) on Philippine literature, and Art Jam on the arts. The programs were broadcast on ABS-CBN Channel 2 and sister stations Studio 23 and Knowledge Channel. Though new episodes are no longer produced, reruns of these programs continued to be aired on Knowledge Channel.

 

The foundation changed its name to ABS-CBN Lingkod Kapamilya Foundation in 2013. Projects include the child assistance program Bantay Bata 163, the emergency humanitarian assistance program Sagip Kapamilya (Save Fellow Family Members), the environmental programs Bantay Kalikasan (Environment Watch), No to Mining Campaign, Green Initiative, and Kapit Bisig para sa Ilog Pasig (Together for Pasig River), and the community development program Bayanijuan.

 

She was the founding chair of the Southeast Asian Foundation for Children’s Television in 1996, which she now serves as chair emeritus. Now known as Anak TV Foundation, it gives out the Anak TV Seal Awards to child-sensitive and family-friendly television programs and broadcast personalities. It conferred honors on 15 awardees in 2000 and has grown to 109 in 2014.

 

Lopez received numerous awards for public service, which include the International Public Relations Award for Excellence for the Environment, 1997; the UNESCO Kalinga Prize, 1998; Rotary Peace Award, 2003; Asian Institute of Management Alumni Achievement Award (Triple A), 2008; Outstanding Manilans Award for the Environment, 2009; Go Negosyo Philippine Commission on Women Inspiring Women of the Year Award, 2010; Gawad Apolinario Mabini Awards, 2010; Communication Excellence in Organizations Award for Corporate Foundation, 2010; Gintong Palad Public Service Awards, 2013; SKAL Tourism Personality Awards for Environment and Agri-tourism, 2014; and the ASEAN Tourism Association Best ASEAN Cultural Preservation Effort Award, 2015. Written by Alyssa Jean E. Alano

LOY, TINA (Cristina Santiago Tolentino) b. Manila 24 Jul 1936. Radio soap opera, TV, and film actor, singer, radio variety show producer and host, drama coach, program director. She is the daughter of Manuel Monroy Tolentino, former official photographer of Malacañang, and movie actor Segundina “Dina” Santiago. She was married to Ruben de Leon Ilagan of the show business clan, with whom she had five children, only one of whom survives. She has three children by TV newscaster Bobby de Veyra, including daughter Yani de Veyra, a television drama child actor in the 1970s. She attended La Concordia College and Arellano University, 1946-57, and thereafter studied journalism at the University of Santo Tomas. Already a movie child actor even before she entered primary school, she abandoned college to focus on her show business career.

At age nine, she joined the musical comedy drama Eskuwelahang Munti (Little Schoolhouse) on Republic Broadcasting System’s DZBB as its youngest talent. In her teen years, she acted in several radio soap operas on Manila Broadcasting Company’s (MBC) DZRH, including Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), where she voiced both the lead female character Prinsesa Dragona and the witch Buruka, and Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate). Soon she was writing scripts, directing, and producing soaps for DZRH until she became drama supervisor, 1966-68.

Loy was a child actor before she joined radio, carrying the screen name Tina Loy, after the Hollywood actor Myrna Loy. She was only three when she first appeared in a movie, Sakay, 1939, followed by Tinig ng Pag-ibig (Voice of Love), 1940, with Fernando Poe for Parlatone Films; Hiyas ng Dagat (Jewel of the Sea), 1941, for LVN Pictures; Sagur, 1949, for Lebran Inc; The 13th Sultan, 1949, for X’Otic Films; He Promised to Return, 1950; The Pirates Go to Town, 1950; and Ang Maestra (The Teacher), 1953, for Filippine Films. In 1948, she recorded the song Tatanga-tanga (Stupid) for Mico Recording Company.

She began producing, directing, and acting in television dramas in the 1960s, including ABC Channel 5’s Masayang Pamilya (Happy Family), 1964; MBC Channel 11’s Pamilya Impaktum (Devil Family), 1966; Radio Philippines Network (RPN) Channel 9’s Flordeluna, 1984-86, and Teenage Diary, 1986-88; ABS-CBN Channel 2’s The Sharon Cuneta Show, 1989; and GMA Channel 7’s Kadenang Rosas (Chain of Roses), 1989-90.

In the 1970s, Loy served as drama supervisor and program director of Kanlaon Broadcasting System’s DWWW, voice coaching such actors as Susan Roces in Paano Kung Wala Ka? (What If You Are Gone?). She later became the station manager of DWWW and launched several soap operas, including Rosa Violeta (Violet Rose) and Bakit Iisa Lang ang Puso? (Why Is There But One Heart?). It was also during this period that she was Grant Advertising Agency’s radio-television director and supervisor of its various broadcast productions.

Loy was active again in cinema from the 1960s until the 1990s, when she appeared in Ginagabi Ka Na Naman (You Are Late Again), 1979; Mahal … Saan Ka Nanggaling Kagabi? (Honey … Where Were You Last Night?), 1979; Manedyer … Si Kumander (The Manager … Is Commander), 1982; Ang Padrino (The Godfather), 1984; No Retreat … No Surrender … Si Kumander (No Retreat … No Surrender … My Commander), 1987; M&M: The Incredible Twins, 1989; Kahit Wala Ka Na (Even If You’re Gone), 1989; and Walang Matigas na Tinapay sa Mainit na Kape (There’s No Hard Bread in Piping-Hot Coffee), 1994. She wrote the screenplays for FPJ Productions’ Ito ang Maynila (This Is Manila), 1963; Sampaguita Pictures’ Tindahan ni Aling Epang (Madam Epang’s Store), 1961; and Rosas Films’ To Susan with Love, 1968. Written byEdgardo Ray G. Pedroche

Sources: Aniceto 1997; Loy 2014.

MAGPAYO, DELY (Fidela Mendoza Magpayo Reyes) aka Tiya Dely. b. Manila 29 Oct 1920. d. Manila 1 Sept 2008. Radio host, commentator, drama scriptwriter and actor, newscaster, program producer and director, singer, radio program scriptwriter. Her parents were Vicente Calayag Magpayo and Amanda de Leon Mendoza. She was married to Philippine Constabulary colonel Leonor Reyes I, a veteran of the United States Army Forces in the Far East–Bataan and the Korean War, with whom she had a son and two daughters, including Didi, who is also a radio announcer. Her sisters Dolores and Sermanita were also radio singers. She attended Araullo High School, took a secretarial course at Gregg Business College in 1939, and earned a degree in political science from Far Eastern University in 1950.

To date, no one has equaled Magpayo’s length of service to the broadcast industry, which lasted 70 years, almost without interruption. She was 18 and in high school in 1938 when she auditioned and was offered by popular kundiman (love song) singer and sarsuwela actor Atang de la Rama a regular spot in the latter’s daily blocktime program on KZRF. She then sang popular hits with accompanists Jerry Brandy and his Romancers to alternate with de la Rama’s kundiman. Within a year she was pirated by the husband-and-wife team of blocktimers Andoy Balun-balunan and Dely Atay-atayan. Apart from singing, she developed announcing skills while with the team, which included Chichay. In 1941, just before World War II broke out in the Philippines, she joined the program Malayan Radio Stars produced by another blocktimer, Frankie Gomez.

With the Japanese occupying the country, Magpayo sang Tagalog songs on the Japanese-controlled KZRH, which was later renamed PIAM, from 1942 until the end of 1944, leaving the station before the Japanese began to lose control of it at the end of 1944. While working at PIAM, she also performed in stage musicals, including Nasaan Ka Irog? (Where Are You, Beloved?) with Angel Esmeralda at the Manila Grand Opera House, and Magkaibigang Putik (Mud Buddies) with Pugo and Tugo. Roughly a year after the war ended in 1945, she returned to radio and sang in the blocktime show of Luz Mat. Castro on the new KZRH while serving as special assistant to the secretary of foreign affairs and then vice president of the newly independent Republic of the Philippines, Elpidio Quirino, and pursuing a degree in political science. In the meantime, radio soap operas and serials began to go on the air in 1949. Magpayo was cast in several, including Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love), Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), and Camay Theater of the Air, with fellow veteran dramatist Esther Chavez.

In 1952, DZRH production manager Ray Oliver gave her her own daily noontime music program Tugtugin Natin (Our Music) and a year later a slot in the program Reyna ng Vicks (Queen of Vicks) and the letter-and-advice program Mga Liham kay Tiya Dely (Letters to Aunt Dely). The latter quickly evolved to include dramatizations of the life stories of letter senders, later becoming the model for similar programs both on radio and television. Under a different title when she moved to ABS-CBN’s DZXL in 1957, the show lasted roughly two decades and the name Tiya Dely, which she gave herself, became her permanent moniker on and off the air. While working at DZXL until the declaration of martial law in 1972, program director Ben Aniceto made her deliver the news in Tagalog in the daily newscasts Dely Balita (Dely News) as well as in English in Dely News, a rarity at a time when only male newscasters were believed to give the news credibility. In addition, she was producer and narrator of the drama shows Ang Tangi Kong Pag-Ibig (My Only Love), Kaputol ng Lumipas (A Piece of the Past), Bakas ng Kinabukasan (Trace of the Future), and Buhay (Life); and hosted music programs, including Serenatang Kumbidahan (Serenade by Invitation), which featured kundiman and other Filipino songs. During this period, she also recorded songs for several recording companies including Bataan Records, for which she pressed Tagalog ditties such as “Una Kong Pag-Ibig” (My First Love) and “Pamaypay ng Maynila” (Manila Fan). She also appeared in films including Sebya, Mahal Kita (Sebya, I Love You), 1958, where her radio drama serial was written into the movie. On television, she is credited with reviving the rondalla, a band playing only stringed instruments, when she organized a rondalla competition in the program Hamon sa Kampeon (Challenge to the Champion) on Channel 3.

Magpayo continued her radio programs on Radio Veritas, DZBB, and DWWW during martial law when ABS-CBN was shut down. When ABS-CBN reopened in 1986 following the ouster of Pres Ferdinand Marcos and the end of martial rule, she returned to ABS-CBN, this time on station DZMM. In 1990, she rejoined DZRH where she stayed until her death in 2008.

Colleagues and fans often called Magpayo the “First Lady of Philippine Radio.” A staunch adherent of Lope K. Santos’s Balarila, which prescribes correct and proper use of the Tagalog language, she was recognized twice by the Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino, 2003 and 2005, for her contribution to the propagation of the language. Among her numerous other awards were the Outstanding Woman Artist Lifetime Achievement Award for Broadcast Arts from UNESCO, 1994; the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas, 2002; the Centennial Award for Broadcast, 100th Year of Feminist Movement of the Philippines from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, 2005; the Gawad Plaridel from the University of the Philippines, 2006; and several posthumous citations, including the Senate Resolution “Honoring and Remembering Tiya Dely, the First Lady of Philippine Radio, for her unparalleled achievement and contribution in the history of Philippine broadcast media,” 2008. Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez and Michael B. Makri

MANAHAN, JOHNNY (Juan Ledesma Manahan) aka Mr M. b. Quezon City 11 Feb 1947. Talent manager; television and film actor, director, and writer; visual artist. He is the son of Dr Constantino Manahan and Elvira Ledesma Manahan, a television host and film actor popularly known for her talk show program Two for the Road. He has one sibling. He is married to Lilia Rosa Manahan, aka Tats, a writer and interior designer. One of their daughters, Lilianna, is a visual and design artist. Manahan completed his secondary education at Ateneo de Manila High School, 1964. He completed a bachelor of arts in history at the University of California Berkeley, 1969. He is the senior vice president of ABS-CBN.

He started as a production assistant at ABS-CBN immediately after graduating from college. Beginning in 1971, he became guest director for Two for the Road, GMA, and Kaluskos Musmos (Kiddie Noise), RPN 9. He took on the directorial job from Ading Fernando of the comedy Chicks to Chicks, 1980-86, IBC 13, when the latter died from a heart attack in 1983.

When MBS Channel 4 was taken over by rebel groups and civilian supporters during the height of the 1986 EDSA Revolt, Manahan directed an improvised public affairs show in one of Channel 4’s studios on 24 Feb 1986 at 1:25 pm to make it known to the public that the government television station had been taken back. The show’s on-air talents were Orly Mercado, June Keithley, Maan Hontiveros, Noel Trinidad, Subas Herrero, and Fr Efren Dato, with backstage support coming from Salvii Casino, Mariol Alberto, Enrico Santos, Charie Villa, and Joanna Gomez. An important clip of the program was a Mitos Villareal-directed aerial footage shot of the crowd on EDSA that was beamed live from the liberated Channel 4.

Manahan became one of the resident directors of ABS-CBN when the network reopened in 1986. He directed several station-produced comedy shows like Chika Chika Chicks (Chatty Chicks), 1987-91, Palibhasa Lalake (Because They Are Guys), 1987-89, Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad), 1992-2003, Oki Doki Dok (Okay, Doc), 1993-2000, Kaya ni Mister, Kaya ni Misis (What the Husband Can Do, The Wife Can Too), 1997-2001, Da Pilya en da Pilot (The Naughty Girl and the Pilot), 2001, Eto Na ang Susunod na Kabanata (Here Is the Next Chapter), 2001-3, and Bora: Sons of the Beach, 2004-6; the children’s fantasy drama Wansapanataym (Once upon a Time), 1997-2005; and the youth-oriented program Klasmeyts (Classmates), 2002. He also directed music programs, noontime variety shows, and reality TV programs, such as Tonight with Dick and Carmi, 1988-91; ASAP, which premiered in 1995; Masayang Tanghali Bayan! MANAR, MARILOU C. (Marilou Cadeliña Manar) b. Cotabato City 8 Aug 1968. Journalist. She is the daughter of Patrocinio Ramis Cadeliña and Carmencita Gapac-Roa. She is married to Rey Salvador Manar with whom she has two children. She graduated with a bachelor of science degree in accountancy, magna cum laude, from the Notre Dame University in Cotabato City, 1989. As a member of the Peace and Conflict Journalists Network, she completed a peace and journalism course at the University of Sydney in Australia, 2005 (Feria 2006). She trained in peace and conflict reporting, humanitarian reporting, and corporate social responsibility.

She heads the research and production department of DXND in Kidapawan City, one of the broadcast media outfits run by the Oblates of Mary Immaculate (OMI), after serving as its program director. She produces, writes, and hosts radio documentaries and specials on issues that affect Mindanao. She also writes for MindaNews, an online news site on Mindanao that focuses on conflict areas.

In 2013, Manar received the International Committee of the Red Cross 2013 Humanitarian Reporting Awards for two radio documentaries, Tudok Firiz (Mount Firiz), first prize, and Mga Bakwits: TNT (Takbo nang Takbo) sa Maguindanao (Evacuees: The Perennial Refugees of Maguindanao), second prize. Her other radio documentaries and program specials that won awards in 2013 include Bida Specials, on indigenous peoples, Gawad Agong sa Mahusay na Pag-uulat sa Radyo tungkol sa Kalagayan ng Katutubong Mamamayan (Agong Award for Excellence in Reporting on the Life of Indigenous Peoples) given by the Indigenous Voices in Asia; Secretary Jessie Robredo, about the late Department of Interior and Local Government secretary, Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) Golden Dove Award for Best Special Program; Bangis ng Dengue (Wrath of Dengue), first place, and Cholera Outbreak, second place, Parangal sa mga Kwentong Kalusugang Pangkalahatan (Excellence in Public Health Programs) given by Probe Media Productions, Department of Health, and Lakbay Kalusugan.

Her work won for DXND the 1993 and 1995 Best Documentary Awards from the Cultural Center of the Philippines; the 1993 Eduardo Salanga Excellence Award in Peace Reporting; the 1997 Best Radio Reportage, Philippine AIDS/STD/HIV Media Awards from the Department of Health; Best Culture and Arts Program, 2005 KBP Golden Dove Awards; and the 2011 Best Humanitarian Reporting Award for Radio from the International Committee of the Red Cross. Written by Fraulein A. Oclarit and Ariel Marco T. Oclarit

Sources: Feria, Manar, and Lim 2006; Manar 2014, n.d.; Unson 2013a, 2013b.

MANICAD, JIGGY (Rodrigo Defeo Manicad Jr)b. San Pablo City, Laguna 15 Nov 1974. Broadcast journalist. His parents are Rodrigo Manicad Sr and Luzviminda Defeo Manicad, both from San Pablo. His wife, Maria Nicola Pulumbarit Manicad, is a film and TV director and multimedia producer with whom he has two daughters. He completed a bachelor of arts in communication Arts at the University of the Philippines Los Baños (UPLB) in Laguna, 1994. He obtained a postgraduate course in international broadcast journalism from Cardiff University in Wales and completed his practicum at the British Broadcasting Corporation in Norwich, England, 2004. He holds the position of news producer and reporter for GMA.

He anchors the daily news program News TV Quick Response Team: QRT, which premiered in 2011, on GMA News TV and 24 Oras Weekend (24 Hours Weekend), since 2011, on GMA. He has been anchoring with co-reporter Maki Pulido the weekly news magazine Reporter’s Notebook since 2004.

After graduating from UPLB, Manicad first worked as assistant editor in a publication of the International Rice Research Institute. Months later, he applied to be a production assistant and driver in GMA’s radio station, DZBB, but was not accepted. He started working as a writer in the public affairs magazine Magandang Gabi, Bayan (Good Evening, Nation), ABS-CBN, hosted by Noli de Castro, but left the show after only a few weeks on the job for a simple reason: the network was far from the bus stop where he got off from his daily ride from Laguna. He immediately went back to GMA, was interviewed by Jessica Soho, and accepted as a beat reporter and writer for the night shift of GMA Balita (GMA News). He has since then risen from the ranks, joined the team of other news programs of GMA, such as i-Witness, Brigada Siete (News Brigade at Seven), and GMA Balita (GMA News), and covered risky beats that tested his mettle as a young reporter.

Two of the most memorable news coverage during the early years of his career were the chaotic march to Malacañan on 1 May 2001 of supporters of then Pres Joseph Estrada during which he injured his head after having been hit by a rock while reporting on-cam; and the rescue of Chinese kidnap victim Dominga Chu in Pasay City in 2004, which was related to the kidnap-slay case of business executive Betty Chua Sy in late 2003. He covered stories that made marks in the history of Philippine television. International assignments included the hunt for Osama bin Laden in Jalalabad in Eastern Afghanistan, 2001; the war in Iraq, 2003; the funeral of former US president Ronald Reagan, 2004; the Filipino hostage crisis in Iraq and Dubai, 2004; the Al-Qaeda bombing of London, 2005; the Hezbollah-Israel war, 2006; the Filipino exodus report in Syria/Lebanon, 2006; the first Filipino attempt to climb the summit of Mount Everest in Nepal, 2006; the inauguration of Barack Obama, 2009; the Haiti earthquake coverage, 2010; and the canonization of St Pedro Calungsod during which he anchored live from the Vatican, 2012. Some local assignments included the exclusive surrender in Zamboanga City of Buhari Jamiri, one of the suspects in the beheading of 10 marines in Basilan, 2007; the coverage of Marine Corporal Angelo Abeto’s story, which raised discussions on the military’s incapacity to evacuate wounded soldiers from the battlefield, 2008; the remarkable documentation of the miserable situation of the residents of Fuga Island, 2008; the plight of overseas Filipino workers in Malaysia doubling as drug couriers, 2010s; the surrender of Comelec official Lintang Bedol, who was linked to the controversial 12-0 Maguindanao senatorial elections, 2011; and supertyphoon Yolanda’s devastation of Leyte that caught him and his team in the path of the storm, 2013.

His investigative documentaries in Reporter’s Notebook always hit a raw nerve with their expose of the many ills in society. Examples are “Batang Hit Man” (Child Hit Man), 2006, on child assassins ensnared in clan wars in Abra province; “Gatilyo” (Trigger of a Gun), 2007, about the illegal arms trade; “Pulong Diablo” (Evil Island), 2007, describing the criminality in an impoverished island on a river in Manila; and “Puslit Droga” (Drug Smuggling), 2011, on the illegal drug trail from Luzon to Puerto Galera in Oriental Mindoro.

His works were recognized by international award-giving groups. “Sa Pusod ng Iraq (In the Navel of Iraq), his war coverage in Baghdad together with Mike Enriquez and Howie Severino, won the Silver Screen Award at the 37th US International Film and Video Festival, 2004. His news coverage in 24 Oras of the encounter and death of Marine Corporal Angelo Abeto against the Moro Islamic Liberation Front in Basilan won the World Gold Medal at the New York Film and TV Festival, 2008. GMA’s coverage, of which Manicad is a part, of supertyphoon Yolanda in 2013 won for the network its fourth George Foster Peabody Award, 2014. His documentaries in Reporter’s Notebook won several awards. “Giyera sa Lebanon” (War in Lebanon), about how Filipinos cope with the crisis in Lebanon, won Best Current Affairs Program at the Asian Television Awards, 2008. “Pinays for Export: The Asian Sex Trafficking Trail,” about traffickers sneaking Filipinas into neighboring Asian countries, won the World Bronze Medal for Best Public Affairs Program at the New York Festivals, 2009. “Lunok Droga” (Swallowed Drugs), about international drug smuggling syndicates employing Filipinos as drug mules, won the Silver Screen Award for Best Documentary / Social Issues at the US International Film and Video Festival, 2009.

For his work in journalism, Manicad was chosen as one of the Ten Outstanding Young Men of the Philippines, 2012. He was also one of the three first awardees of the Metrobank Journalists of the Year, 2013. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Dean Airo Salvador E. Dancel

Sources:

ABS-CBN.com 2008; Freeman 2012; GMA Network 2006; GMA Records Releases 2012; Manicad 2012; Roces 2013; San Pablo City 2015; Showbiz Portal 2011; TOYM 2015; UPLB 2015.

text:
MANILA BROADCASTING COMPANY (MBC) The largest in the country, MBC is a network of around 260 radio stations scattered throughout the Philippines and one cable television news channel. It is owned by the FJE Group of Companies, with headquarters on Sotto St, Cultural Center of the Philippines Complex, Pasay City. Several networks, some fully owned while others partly owned by MBC, actually comprise the larger MBC network under several brands. The most well-known of these is DZRH Nationwide, composed of an originating station in Manila and 20 relay stations throughout the country, all broadcasting on AM but connected to the Manila station via satellite. DZRH’s programming is mainly news, public affairs, and soaps. MBC’s other brand, Love Radio, is a network of 28 stations on FM, with a programming of popular music and entertainment talk.

MBC’s subsidiaries, which own its other networks, are Cebu Broadcasting Company (CBC), Pacific Broadcasting Systems (PBS), and Radyo Natin Network (RNN). CBC’s nine stations, all on FM, air soft rock music. PBS has 10 stations on AM, with the brand name Aksyon Radyo (Action Radio), and 11 stations on FM, with the brand name Yes FM. Aksyon Radyo’s programming is similar to that of DZRH, with news, talk, and drama, but in regional Filipino languages. It has an Internet-based Aksyon Radyo station originating from Garden Grove, California, USA. The programming of Yes FM, on the other hand, includes entertainment news and features and popular music.

RNN (“Radyo Natin” translates to Our Radio) has under its wing 52 stations on FM, with the brand Hot FM, whose programming is similar to those of Love Radio and Yes FM. Its morning programming, however, begins with a feed of news programs from DZRH. In addition, RNN has 130 stations, also on FM, broadcasting at a low transmitting power of 100-500 watts. Like Hot FM, these low-powered stations relay the early morning national news program from DZRH, which they receive via satellite, but shift to local news and talk the rest of the morning using the regional languages. The stations simulcast music programs in the afternoon, back to local programs in the early evening, and then end with a simulcast of a late evening entertainment program.

MBC is also on television via the 24-hour cable news channel DZRH News Television. Using the format of teleradyo (portmanteau of television and radio), it televises the news and talk programs of DZRH delivered by its announcers inside the radio booth. Both DZRH and DZRH News Television, as well as MBC’s other stations, livestream online with live chat rooms that allow listeners and viewers to participate in discussions on the air.

MBC’s history may be traced to prewar KZRH, which first aired on 14 Jul 1939 from the Heacock’s Department Store on Escolta, Binondo, Manila. KZRH (RH for Radio Heacock) brought to four the number of stations in Manila in the 1930s when the Philippines was still under American colonial rule and radio broadcasting in the country was in its infancy. It was owned by American Samuel Gaches, who a few months later bought KZRC in Cebu from its former owners, the Erlanger & Galinger Department Store. Station manager Bertrand Harold Silen and program director John Harris tagged the stations the Voice of the Philippines, with their signals reaching most of the archipelago. However, the programs, all in English, were meant to give the Americans a strong voice in the country.

The coming of World War II to Philippine shores disrupted commercial broadcasting. Gen Douglas MacArthur, commander of the United States Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE), ordered the destruction of all radio equipment just before the end of 1941 as the USAFFE forces retreated from Manila to Bataan and Corregidor. This move was meant to prevent the Japanese forces, who marched into Manila on the eve of the new year, from using radio broadcasting for propaganda. However, Silen and his chief technician Simeon Cheng salvaged some equipment to bring to Corregidor, while other pieces of equipment were stored in the basement of the Jai-Alai Building on Taft Ave.

Corregidor was thus able to address Filipinos via radio beginning 5 Jan 1942 until early May 1942 to urge them to remain loyal to the Americans. MacArthur named the station the Voice of Freedom. In the meantime, the Japanese found the equipment hidden in the Jai-Alai Building, which they used to begin broadcasting their own propaganda on 14 Jan 1942. They used the call letters KZRH until 14 Oct 1943 when they changed the call letters to PIAM. Both stations used salvaged equipment from prewar KZRH, which is why DZRH today traces its lineage to both stations, and further back to prewar KZRH. KZRC, meanwhile, relayed the signal of the Voice of Freedom to Visayas and Mindanao and broadcast its own anti-Japanese propaganda until the Japanese forces reached Cebu in early May and closed it down.

At war’s end in 1945, a new station, KZFM, the first of the government-owned network, the Philippine Broadcasting Service, went on the air, built from equipment MacArthur brought upon his return to the archipelago. The commercial stations, including KZRH, did not reopen until the following year, in Jul 1946. Silen sought new investors when Gaches appeared uninterested in reopening the station. He found them in the businessmen brothers Joaquin Miguel Elizalde and Manuel Elizalde, who bought the station from Gaches. Silen set up the new KZRH studios at the Insular Life Building in Plaza Moraga, Manila. The Elizaldes called their new business venture the Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC). Meanwhile, J. Amado Araneta renamed his prewar Far East Broadcasting Corporation (FEBC, which owned prewar KZRM and KZRF) the Philippine Broadcasting Corporation (PBC), took on new business partners, and launched a new station, KZPI. Isaac Beck attempted to reopen KZIB but quietly withdrew from the business. When Philippine independence was declared on 4 Jul 1946, a new Republic proclaimed, and a new president sworn in, KZND, KZRH, and KZPI covered the event live (Enriquez 2008a, 160-75; Aniceto 2007, 121-23).

The following year, on 21 Sep 1947, KZRC, operated by MBC affiliate Cebu Broadcasting Company, went on the air while PBC inaugurated KZBU (Lent 1973, 83; Aniceto 2007, 123). MBC then acquired a franchise for another station in Manila, KZMB. PBC, on the other hand, put up KZOK in addition to KZPI. Not long after the inaugural broadcast of KZOK, the Elizaldes acquired PBC and its three stations from Araneta. On 1 Jan 1949, following a conference of the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) in Atlantic City in New Jersey, USA, in 1947, all Philippine stations shifted to a new set of call letters—DZ—from the American KZ. Later, DZ and DW were assigned to Luzon-based radio stations, DY for Visayas, and DX for Mindanao.

MBC stations, as with the other stations that began to go on air after the war, resumed the prewar programming of music and variety shows while the language was again English. However, news and commentary enjoyed more airtime, and a new program genre captivated audiences, the soap opera, and in the process shifted the broadcasting language of many stations, including DZRH, to Tagalog. The first soaps were Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home) written by Liwayway Arceo and Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate) by Lina Flor, which went on air on DZRH within a week of each other in Mar 1949. Other DZRH dramas followed suit, many combined with counseling, such as in Ang mga Kasaysayan sa Liham kay Tiya Dely (Stories from Letters to Aunt Dely), or with variety shows, such as in Reyna ng Vicks (Queen of Vicks). There were fantasy dramas such as Kapitan Kidlat (Captain Lightning), detective dramas such as Johnny Davao, horror drama such as Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror), courtroom drama such as Ginang Hukom (Madam Judge), medical drama such as Dr. Ramon Selga, and sitcoms such as Tang-Tarang-Tang.

It suffered from technical problems so it tried to solve the problem by moving its studios to J. P. Rizal St in the Project 4 district of Quezon City in early 1972. However, the operation in the new studio was short-lived as Pres Ferdinand Marcos declared martial law within a few months. It was allowed to resume broadcast several weeks later but MBC decided to abandon television and focus on radio.

In the later years of martial rule, following the assassination of Marcos rival Sen Benigno Aquino Jr in 1983 and the increasing social discontent among many Filipinos, several radio stations, including DZRH, increased airtime devoted to news, commentary, and other public affairs programs while drama maintained a presence. This trend continued beyond Marcos’s ouster in 1986, and until the present, with talk shows not only on politics but also on health, the law, the environment, arts, and entertainment. In the 1990s, MBC began expanding aggressively into the vast network it is today.

MBC, its programs, and its broadcasters have received numerous awards, including the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) Golden Dove Awards for Best AM station in Manila for DZRH in 1992 and 1993; Best FM Station in Manila for DZMB in 1993, 1995, and 1997; 2007 Ka Doroy Broadcaster of the Year for veteran DZRH news director and station manager Joe Taruc; Posthumous KBP Lifetime Achievement Award for former MBC vice president Eduardo Montilla in 2011; and Best FM Station in the provincial category for RNN in 2012, 2013, and 2014. Written byElizabeth L. Enriquez

article.value: MANILA BROADCASTING COMPANY (MBC) The largest in the country, MBC is a network of around 260 radio stations scattered throughout the Philippines and one cable television news channel. It is owned by the FJE Group of Companies, with headquarters on Sotto St, Cultural Center of the Philippines Complex, Pasay City. Several networks, some fully owned while others partly owned by MBC, actually comprise the larger MBC network under several brands. The most well-known of these is DZRH Nationwide, composed of an originating station in Manila and 20 relay stations throughout the country, all broadcasting on AM but connected to the Manila station via satellite. DZRH’s programming is mainly news, public affairs, and soaps. MBC’s other brand, Love Radio, is a network of 28 stations on FM, with a programming of popular music and entertainment talk.

MBC’s subsidiaries, which own its other networks, are Cebu Broadcasting Company (CBC), Pacific Broadcasting Systems (PBS), and Radyo Natin Network (RNN). CBC’s nine stations, all on FM, air soft rock music. PBS has 10 stations on AM, with the brand name Aksyon Radyo (Action Radio), and 11 stations on FM, with the brand name Yes FM. Aksyon Radyo’s programming is similar to that of DZRH, with news, talk, and drama, but in regional Filipino languages. It has an Internet-based Aksyon Radyo station originating from Garden Grove, California, USA. The programming of Yes FM, on the other hand, includes entertainment news and features and popular music.

RNN (“Radyo Natin” translates to Our Radio) has under its wing 52 stations on FM, with the brand Hot FM, whose programming is similar to those of Love Radio and Yes FM. Its morning programming, however, begins with a feed of news programs from DZRH. In addition, RNN has 130 stations, also on FM, broadcasting at a low transmitting power of 100-500 watts. Like Hot FM, these low-powered stations relay the early morning national news program from DZRH, which they receive via satellite, but shift to local news and talk the rest of the morning using the regional languages. The stations simulcast music programs in the afternoon, back to local programs in the early evening, and then end with a simulcast of a late evening entertainment program.

MBC is also on television via the 24-hour cable news channel DZRH News Television. Using the format of teleradyo (portmanteau of television and radio), it televises the news and talk programs of DZRH delivered by its announcers inside the radio booth. Both DZRH and DZRH News Television, as well as MBC’s other stations, livestream online with live chat rooms that allow listeners and viewers to participate in discussions on the air.

MBC’s history may be traced to prewar KZRH, which first aired on 14 Jul 1939 from the Heacock’s Department Store on Escolta, Binondo, Manila. KZRH (RH for Radio Heacock) brought to four the number of stations in Manila in the 1930s when the Philippines was still under American colonial rule and radio broadcasting in the country was in its infancy. It was owned by American Samuel Gaches, who a few months later bought KZRC in Cebu from its former owners, the Erlanger & Galinger Department Store. Station manager Bertrand Harold Silen and program director John Harris tagged the stations the Voice of the Philippines, with their signals reaching most of the archipelago. However, the programs, all in English, were meant to give the Americans a strong voice in the country.

The coming of World War II to Philippine shores disrupted commercial broadcasting. Gen Douglas MacArthur, commander of the United States Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE), ordered the destruction of all radio equipment just before the end of 1941 as the USAFFE forces retreated from Manila to Bataan and Corregidor. This move was meant to prevent the Japanese forces, who marched into Manila on the eve of the new year, from using radio broadcasting for propaganda. However, Silen and his chief technician Simeon Cheng salvaged some equipment to bring to Corregidor, while other pieces of equipment were stored in the basement of the Jai-Alai Building on Taft Ave.

Corregidor was thus able to address Filipinos via radio beginning 5 Jan 1942 until early May 1942 to urge them to remain loyal to the Americans. MacArthur named the station the Voice of Freedom. In the meantime, the Japanese found the equipment hidden in the Jai-Alai Building, which they used to begin broadcasting their own propaganda on 14 Jan 1942. They used the call letters KZRH until 14 Oct 1943 when they changed the call letters to PIAM. Both stations used salvaged equipment from prewar KZRH, which is why DZRH today traces its lineage to both stations, and further back to prewar KZRH. KZRC, meanwhile, relayed the signal of the Voice of Freedom to Visayas and Mindanao and broadcast its own anti-Japanese propaganda until the Japanese forces reached Cebu in early May and closed it down.

At war’s end in 1945, a new station, KZFM, the first of the government-owned network, the Philippine Broadcasting Service, went on the air, built from equipment MacArthur brought upon his return to the archipelago. The commercial stations, including KZRH, did not reopen until the following year, in Jul 1946. Silen sought new investors when Gaches appeared uninterested in reopening the station. He found them in the businessmen brothers Joaquin Miguel Elizalde and Manuel Elizalde, who bought the station from Gaches. Silen set up the new KZRH studios at the Insular Life Building in Plaza Moraga, Manila. The Elizaldes called their new business venture the Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC). Meanwhile, J. Amado Araneta renamed his prewar Far East Broadcasting Corporation (FEBC, which owned prewar KZRM and KZRF) the Philippine Broadcasting Corporation (PBC), took on new business partners, and launched a new station, KZPI. Isaac Beck attempted to reopen KZIB but quietly withdrew from the business. When Philippine independence was declared on 4 Jul 1946, a new Republic proclaimed, and a new president sworn in, KZND, KZRH, and KZPI covered the event live (Enriquez 2008a, 160-75; Aniceto 2007, 121-23).

The following year, on 21 Sep 1947, KZRC, operated by MBC affiliate Cebu Broadcasting Company, went on the air while PBC inaugurated KZBU (Lent 1973, 83; Aniceto 2007, 123). MBC then acquired a franchise for another station in Manila, KZMB. PBC, on the other hand, put up KZOK in addition to KZPI. Not long after the inaugural broadcast of KZOK, the Elizaldes acquired PBC and its three stations from Araneta. On 1 Jan 1949, following a conference of the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) in Atlantic City in New Jersey, USA, in 1947, all Philippine stations shifted to a new set of call letters—DZ—from the American KZ. Later, DZ and DW were assigned to Luzon-based radio stations, DY for Visayas, and DX for Mindanao.

MBC stations, as with the other stations that began to go on air after the war, resumed the prewar programming of music and variety shows while the language was again English. However, news and commentary enjoyed more airtime, and a new program genre captivated audiences, the soap opera, and in the process shifted the broadcasting language of many stations, including DZRH, to Tagalog. The first soaps were Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home) written by Liwayway Arceo and Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate) by Lina Flor, which went on air on DZRH within a week of each other in Mar 1949. MARCELO, BERT “TAWA” (Norberto de Joya Marcelo) b. Baliuag, Bulacan 6 Jun 1936. d. Manila 16 Dec 1995. Radio, television, film comedian and host. He was the ninth among 10 children of Jose Marcelo and Alejandra de Joya. He studied grade school at Baliuag Elementary School, high school at Baliuag Academy, and finished bachelor of arts in mass communication at Far Eastern University in Manila in 1965. He sold pork in the market to sustain his studies. He was married to Alicia Marcelo with whom he had a son.

Marcelo acted in stage plays during high school, which earned for him many school acting awards. His talent for humor was discovered by accident. Every time the lead actor for a certain play would not be able to perform, Marcelo was asked to take his place. This incident became frequent, until he was able to establish a reputation for himself. He continued his comic acting even when he was already in college.

His first television appearance was in Tang-Tarang-Tang, 1966, ABS Channel 3, a sitcom about a dysfunctional Filipino family and its patriarch. His real break came when an executive from ABC 5 got him to be among the cast of the weekly television satire Tisoy (Mestizo), 1968-69, in which he played the role of Tikyo, a character fashioned after Placido Penitente of Jose Rizal’s novel Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not). Tisoy was a witty commentary on the culture of the urban youth of the 1960s, and Marcelo’s Tikyo character represented the intelligent youth of the period who, because of the humiliation inflicted on them by those in authority, especially the religious, have lost their drive to pursue higher dreams and go back home. He was also a frequent guest in TV shows by ABS Channel 3, like the TV fantasy show Ang Mahiwagang Daigdig ni Doray (The Magical World of Doray), 1968, and the dance program The Nida-Nestor Show, 1965-72. He appeared in two important comedy programs produced by GMA, as the janitor in Baltic & Co., 1974-76, and the title role in Prinsipe Abante (Prince Forward), 1977-80. He hosted the singing talent shows Ang Bagong Kampeon (The New Champion), 1985-88, RPN 9, and Tanghalan ng Kampeon (Stage of the Champion), 1988-93, GMA, both with Pilita Corrales, the daily noontime variety show Kalatog Pinggan (Clattering Plates), 1985-87, BBC 2, then 1987-89, ABS-CBN, and 1989, ABC 5, with Herbert Bautista and Joey Marquez, and several special events programs. He anchored the entrepreneurship shows of GMA, Negosiyete (Business on Seven), 1991-95, and Agrisiyete (Agriculture on Seven), 1991-95, the latter with entertainment host German Moreno. In many roles that he played and the hosting he did for variety shows, he delivered his lines with the sing-song lilt of a Bulakeño, which indicated a gullible promdi (someone from the province), followed by a laughter that was simultaneously exaggerated, innocent, mocking, and burlesque. The lilt and the laughter became his brand of humor.

Because of his popularity in the 1970s, then Philippine Advertising Counselor Tony Gloria invited him to become the mainstay of many San Miguel Beer television advertisements. His “Mag-beer muna tayo!” (Let’s first have a beer!) became a famous advertising catch line, and many San Miguel beer ads had him as one of the lead endorsers through the 1990s.

In film, Marcelo reprised the role of Tikyo in the eponymous movie versions of the sitcom Tisoy in 1969, directed by Lauro Pacheco, and in 1977, directed by now National Artist Ishmael Bernal. He acted in many comedy films, which included Pomposa: Ang Kabayong Tsismosa (Pomposa: The Squealer Horse), 1968; Padre, si Eba (Father, This is Eve), 1971; Oh, Margie, Oh, 1974; Wanakosey (I Have Nothing More to Say), 1977; Kapten Batuten and His Super Batuta (Captain Batuten and His Super Baton), 1977; and Isang Platitong Mani (A Saucer of Peanuts), 1986, which was from a famous line in one of his San Miguel beer TV advertisements.

Because of his good-natured humor and sensitive comic ad-libbing, he won four Aliw Awards: Best Solo Performer in 1977, Best Emcee-Comedian in 1978, Best Comedian in 1980, and Entertainer of the Year in 1980.

Marcelo died when he suffered a fatal stroke, shortly after losing the 1995 gubernatorial election for the province ofBulacanon 16 Dec 1995. Written byCynthia Cruz-Paz and Eulalio R. Guieb III

Sources: Gotera 1980; Macapendeg 2014; Orendain 2002; Pabico 2002; Sicam 2011; Silverio 1969.

MARECO BROADCASTING NETWORK INC (MBNI) Founded in 1963, MBNI began as the radio station DZBM, aimed only at airing the recorded music under its labels Mabuhay Records and Villar Records as well as dozens of foreign record labels it distributed in the Philippines. The station’s call letters stood for “Broadcast by Mareco.” When its audience grew, it accepted commercial advertising. It then moved from the AM to the FM band on 105.1 MHz and changed its call letters to DWLM. In the 1970s, it played only OPM music and had the brand name Super Tunog Pinoy 105.1. It then shifted to a format of new wave music (pop/rock music of the 1970s and the 1980s) and rebranded itself as Power 105 FM. In 1994, it again reformatted to a mix of classic and new jazz music and acquired the brand name 105.1 Crossover. The station also aired news, including international news from BBC World, as well as traffic reports from its studios in Santa Mesa Heights, Quezon City.

DWLM continued as the flagship station of MBNI, which grew into a nationwide network of radio stations that also streamed their programs live online. The network includes 16 FM radio stations such as DYAC 90.7 in Cebu, DYBM 99.1 in Bacolod, and DXLR 93.1 in Davao, all branded as Crossover. Nine of MBNI’s 12 AM radio stations, with a format of news, entertainment, and religious programs, bear the brand name Radyo Krimen, including DZAZ 1233 in Baguio, DWCR 1332 in Dagupan, and DYIA 821 in Iloilo. Written by Lia Gabriele A. Ballesteros

Sources: Crossover 105.1, n.d.a, n.d.b; Crossover Cebu, n.d.; House of Representatives, n.d.; Wikipedia, n.d.a, n.d.d; Wikipilipinas, n.d.b.

MATUTINA (Evelyn Santos Bontogon-Guerrero)b. Caloocan City 10 Jul 1946. Television actor, voice talent, radio drama director. She is the daughter of Federico Villaruel Bontogon and Emilia Simpaoco Santos. She is married to businessman Henry Guerrero, with whom she has two children, including Shiela Mary Ann who is a commercial voice talent. She finished her primary and secondary education at Caloocan City High School, where she served as assistant editor and columnist of the campus school organ Ang Tinig (The Voice) in 1963.

Matutina earned her catchy moniker in the early 1970s from a TV ad campaign for a laundry soap tagged Matutina, Gaya-Gaya (Matutina, the Imitator), whose sales pitch claimed that the quality of the soap was imitated but never equaled by other brands. She then appeared in the sketch comedy television show Super Laff-In on ABS-CBN, patterned after the Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In TV show from the United States. Catching the attention of producer-director-scriptwriter Ading Fernando, he cast her as the shrill-voiced house help Matutina in the sitcom John en Marsha (John and Marsha) on the defunct Radio Philippines Network (RPN) Channel 9, 1973-90, the role for which she is best remembered. She also acted in the television drama Valiente (Valiant), 1996-97, created by TAPE Productions for GMA Channel 7, and hosted her own show At Your Serbis, Matutina (At Your Service, Matutina), 1983-84, on BBC Channel 2.

On radio, Matutina hosted personality programs, acted in soaps, and directed drama productions on Radio Veritas, 1975-83; Radio Mindanao Network, 1979-83; Rajah Broadcasting Corporation’s DZRJ, 1984-86; Nation Broadcasting Corporation’s DZAM, 1987-92; and ABS-CBN’s DZMM, 1966-72 and 1992-94.

In 1997, Matutina began dubbing for local audiences foreign films and television shows such as Penelope, Romeo and Juliet, Why Me, Yugioh, Passion, The X Family, Peter Pan and Wendy, Tim Thaler, Santa Apprentice, Zorro, Godzilla, Jumanji, Akuel and Gatchinpo, Inosente de Ti, Steal Hearts, and Butterfly Fly Fly. She was the first to dub and direct the dubbing of Mexican telenovelas, beginning with the first telenovela on local television, Marimar, 1996, on RPN Channel 9. Written byEdgardo Ray G. Pedroche

Sources: Cesario, n.d.; Matutina 2014.

MAYLAS, LUCIO d. Manila 12 Jan 2014. Sound designer, music scorer, dubbing director, radio and television voice actor and director. He was married to radio, television, and film voice actor Gloria de Guzman, with whom he had five children, including John, voice actor; Lucito, music spinner; and Jeng, video editor.

 

Maylas is noted for his work in sound design, sound effects, and music scoring of radio and television dramas. At 15, he apprenticed with producer Ben Pangan, who let him create sound effects for Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante) on DZRH in the early 1950s. It was a time when special sound effects were not yet canned and had to be made by manipulating various materials before a live microphone. For example, Maylas simulated the sound of trotting horses by knocking coconut shells together and of medieval swordplay by hitting a garden tool with another for Prinsipe Amante. He also used his voice to create animal sounds. After mastering sound and music design for radio, he became a dubbing director, and later drama director, both for radio and television.

 

As dubbing director, he coached voice actors who dubbed imported programs in foreign languages to Filipino, such as animated shows. Among the animations that aired on ABS-CBN that he dubbed were Huckleberry Finn, 1994; Romeo and the Black Brothers, 1995; His and Her Circumstances and Robin Hood, 1998; and Shoukoushi Ceddie (Little Prince Cedie) and Princess Sarah, both in 1993 and rerun in 2014. In Huckleberry Finn, Maylas also voiced the main character. He also dubbed telenovelas, among them the Mexican telenovela Solita Mi Amor (Solita My Love), 2003, and the Koreanovelas Smile Again and Three Dads and a Woman, 2008.

article.value: MAYLAS, LUCIO d. Manila 12 Jan 2014. Sound designer, music scorer, dubbing director, radio and television voice actor and director. He was married to radio, television, and film voice actor Gloria de Guzman, with whom he had five children, including John, voice actor; Lucito, music spinner; and Jeng, video editor.

Maylas is noted for his work in sound design, sound effects, and music scoring of radio and television dramas. At 15, he apprenticed with producer Ben Pangan, who let him create sound effects for Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante) on DZRH in the early 1950s. It was a time when special sound effects were not yet canned and had to be made by manipulating various materials before a live microphone. For example, Maylas simulated the sound of trotting horses by knocking coconut shells together and of medieval swordplay by hitting a garden tool with another for Prinsipe Amante. He also used his voice to create animal sounds. After mastering sound and music design for radio, he became a dubbing director, and later drama director, both for radio and television.

As dubbing director, he coached voice actors who dubbed imported programs in foreign languages to Filipino, such as animated shows. Among the animations that aired on ABS-CBN that he dubbed were Huckleberry Finn, 1994; Romeo and the Black Brothers, 1995; His and Her Circumstances and Robin Hood, 1998; and Shoukoushi Ceddie (Little Prince Cedie) and Princess Sarah, both in 1993 and rerun in 2014. In Huckleberry Finn, Maylas also voiced the main character. MERCADO, ABNER (Abner Pangilinan Mercado) b. Olongapo City, Zambales 17 Apr 1970. Broadcast journalist, writer, and instructor. He is the son of Santos Yumul Mercado and Milagros Pangilinan. He finished grade school at Olongapo City Elementary School and secondary education at Christ the King High School in Olongapo. He obtained a bachelor of arts degree in communication, major in film and audiovisual arts, from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, 1993. In 1997, broadcast network GMA sent him to Atlanta, Georgia, to study how international media outfits conduct their broadcast journalism. He lectures in the College of Mass Communication and the College of Arts and Letters at UP.

He started his career in broadcast journalism as a news researcher in GMA. In 1995, he became a segment producer for the weekly news magazine program Brigada Siete (News Brigade on Seven), hosted by Luis Beltran. From 1995 to 1999, he became an on-camera reporter in the daily primetime newscast, GMA Balita (GMA News).

He accepted an offer in 1999 from ABS-CBN to join broadcast journalists of the investigative documentary program The Correspondents, 1998-2010. The episodes he handled highlighted environmental, social, and political issues. His most memorable documentaries in The Correspondents are “Laya,” about persons aged 70 and over who were languishing in the country’s prisons; “Mount Cook Chronicles: The Road to Everest,” about the preparations of the first Philippine Mount Everest expedition starting from its members’ training in New Zealand; and the Mount Everest expeditions of Leo Oracion in 2006 and Pastour Emata in 2007. Oracion became the first Filipino to climb the summit of Mount Everest.

Since 1999, Mercado has been an on-camera reporter for ABS-CBN’s primetime newscast TV Patrol and late-night newscast Bandila (Flag). He also reports for news programs on ABS-CBN News Channel (ANC). From 2010 to 2012, Mercado made documentaries for another investigative show on ABS-CBN, Krusada (Crusade), 2010-13. His episode “Laya” (Freedom), aired on 23 Jun 2011, again highlighted the sad conditions of elderly women prisoners whose expected parole has yet to be granted.

He wrote the book Sa Bubungan ng Mundo (On Top of the World), 2007, a personal journal of his documentation of the first Philippine Mount Everest expedition in 2006.

“Mt. Cook Chronicles: The Road to Everest” won the Special Jury Prize at the Moscow International Festival of Mountaineering and Adventure Films, 2005. “Mga Kampana sa Balangiga” (The Bells of Balangiga), also an episode of The Correspondents, was awarded Best Documentary at the Catholic Mass Media Awards, 2006. His documentaries for The Correspondents received the best TV documentary award from the Population Development Media Awards, 2009. Krusada’s “Laya” received the World Bronze Medal at the New York Festivals, 2011. Mercado received the Ninoy and Cory Aquino Fellowship for Professional Development, 2012, which entitled him to attend the US Embassy’s annual Visitor Leadership Program in Washington, DC, and New York City. Written byGian Carlo C. Librojo, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

Sources: ABS-CBN News 2009; Mercado 2014.

MERCADO, ORLY (Orlando Sanchez Mercado) b. Paco, Manila 26 Apr 1946. Broadcaster, professor, politician, diplomat. He is the second among five children of public school teacher Guillermo P. Mercado of Dagami, Leyte, and Adriana Sanchez of Bacoor, Cavite. He has three children with his first wife, the late Dorothy Jane Douglas, and a son with second wife Dr Susan Pineda, a former undersecretary of health. He grew up in the depressed area of Fabie St in Paco, Manila.

Mercado graduated valedictorian at Celedonio Salvador Elementary School and with honors at Manuel A. Roxas High School. He was the first public school student to represent the country in the New York Mirror Youth Forum in 1961. He supported his college education by working as a casual laborer at Manila’s City Engineer’s Office and later as a clerk at City Hall. He earned a bachelor of arts in political science in 1968, a master of arts in communication in 1983, and a doctorate in political science in 1997, all from the University of the Philippines (UP) in Diliman. He was a member of the progressive youth group Kabataang Makabayan during his undergraduate days at UP, and a member of the UP Student Council in 1967.

While still in college, he entered the broadcast industry in 1966 as a radio-TV announcer with Republic Broadcasting System (GMA 7), working at DZBB and DZXX, but lost the job when he helped organize a labor union that later declared a strike. He moved to ABS-CBN where he worked first as a reporter, taking the night shift to cover the police beat for Radyo Patrol (Patrol Radio), which he later headed, on DZAQ, and ABS Channel 3’s news program The World Tonight, then anchored CBN Channel 9’s Apat na Sulok ng Daigdig (Four Corners of the World), and produced the network’s TV debate program Pakikibaka (Struggle), all from 1968 to 1971. After visiting China in 1967 and 1971, he produced the video documentary Where a Thousand Flowers Bloom, which won a Citizens Award for Television in 1971.

He went into hiding in the Cordilleras from 1971 to 1973, disguised as a forester at a logging concession owned by Lepanto Mining, where his father-in-law was head of security. He was detained in Fort Bonifacio in 1973 for almost nine months under an anti-subversion law, and released from prison in November of the same year. He went back to GMA 7, covered the news beat of the foreign affairs and justice departments and the Supreme Court, and co-produced what is now considered the longest-running public service show on Philippine television, Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love My Fellowman) in 1975, with co-hosts Cielito del Mundo, Boots Anson-Roa, and kidney specialist Dr Antonio Talusan, and later Rosa Rosal. The program continued to help those who need medical attention, still hosted by Mercado, with wife Dr Susan Pineda and Quezon City councilor Connie Angeles. He produced and hosted the public affairs program Tipunang Bayan (Public Assembly), 1974-75, the noontime variety show Lunchdate, 1986-87, the entertainment program What’s Up?, 1980-83, and the cooking program Lasang Pinoy (Filipino Taste), 1980-84, all on GMA; and Network Line, The Public Eye, Sixty Minutes Plus, all on PTV 4. Mercado left the broadcast industry when he ran as an opposition candidate on the Laban ticket and topped the senatorial elections for the Batasang Pambansa in 1984. When he was in the Batasang Pambansa from 1984 to 1986, he produced a video documentary on the hidden wealth of Pres Ferdinand Marcos, which was shown on GMA 7 in 1984. He was among the panel of TV personalities, composed of June Keithley, Noel Trinidad, and Subas Herrero, assembled by director Johnny Manahan to go on air when rebel forces seized the government TV station at the height of the EDSA Revolt in Feb 1986.

He returned to broadcasting in Dec 2007 when he became RPN 9’s president and chief executive officer, and anchored its news program Newswatch in 2008. He also served as a board member of IBC 13 while in Japan during the second half of the 2010s. He began hosting ABC 5’s TV weekly public affairs shows Kontak 5, with wife Susan, and Reach, and the daily morning radio news commentary program All Ready on Radyo5 92.3 News FM in 2013.

Mercado became a member of the Batasang Pambansa in 1984. After the EDSA Revolt, he was elected to and served for three terms in the Senate from 1987 to 1998, during which he served as majority and assistant majority leader. He was one of the 12 senators who voted against the extension of US military bases in the country on 16 Sep 1991. He served as chair of the National Parks Development Committee during Corazon Aquino’s presidency, secretary of national defense during Joseph Estrada’s term in 1999 during which he exposed the corruption in the Armed Forces of the Philippines, ambassador to China under the Gloria Macapagal Arroyo administration in 2008, and the first permanent representative of the Philippines to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in 2009. As senator, he authored important bills, which include the Children’s Media Act of 1996 or Republic Act (RA) 8370, the Consumer Act of the Philippines or RA 7394, the AFP Modernization Act or RA 7898, the Magna Carta for Disabled Persons or RA 7277, and the Generic Drugs and Medicines Act of 1988 or RA 6675.

He was head of the Communication Arts Department of Maryknoll College (now Miriam College) during the waning years of the Marcos dictatorship, and professorial lecturer for communication theory, radio-TV production, management, political science, and public administration at the University of the Philippines, Asian Institute of Journalism, Ateneo de Manila University, Assumption College, and University of Santo Tomas. He was with the faculty of Kobe College in Japan when his wife was assigned there by the World Health Organization during the mid-2010s. He currently serves as dean of the Development Academy of the Philippines graduate school.

Mercado is also known for his environmental advocacy. He chaired the Green Coalition; represented the Senate in the Earth Summit of the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development in Rio de Janeiro in 1992; served as an active member of the New York-based Parliamentarians for Global Action, a New York-based organization; and became secretary-general of the Eastern Regional Organization for Public Administration.

Mercado received a Ten Outstanding Young Men award in 1978 for public service and the broadcast media. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III and Joan Dizon

Sources: Ager 2008; Aguila 2008; Department of National Defense 2014; EROPA 2014; PCCF 2014a.

MICHAEL V. (Beethoven del Valle Bunagan) aka Bitoy. b. Malate, Manila 17 Dec 1969. Actor, comedian, impersonator, director, composer, singer. He is the son of Cesar Felix Bunagan and Melba Balonzo del Valle, both of Irosin, Sorsogon. He is married to Carolina Borromeo, with whom he has four children. He finished his elementary education at Tenement Elementary School in Taguig in 1983 and his secondary education at Manila Science High School in 1987. He graduated with a degree in mass communication from the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila in 1991. His high school alias, Bitoy, which he uses to the present, was taken from a character played by comedian Bentot when he guested in the television sitcom Iskul Bukol (School Bumps), 1977, IBC 13. He has portrayed more than 200 television, film, and commercial advertisement characters and personalities.

He joined but lost in singing and sing-alike contests at noontime shows Student Canteen and Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!), both on GMA. His rap composition entry in Eat Bulaga!, “Maganda ang Piliin: Ayoko ng Panget” (Look for Someone Beautiful: I Don’t Like Someone Ugly), a response to rap singer Andrew E.’s “Humanap Ka ng Panget” (Find Someone Ugly), was chosen by OctoArts among demonstration tapes it received for possible recording in 1991. OctoArts released his first music album, The Story of Michael V.: The Ultimate OPM Collection, in 1991, which contained original compositions or parodies of English and Filipino songs that made fun of contemporary Filipino popular culture.

On television, he started as one of the hosts of the game show Ready, Get Set, Go, 1992, ABS-CBN. In 1994, he was a mainstay of the weekly gag show Tropang Trumpo (Troop of Tops), 1994-99, ABC 5, with Ogie Alcasid, Earl Ignacio, Smokey Manaloto, Gelli de Belen, and Carmina Villaroel, each of whom is known as either an actor or a singer but not as a comedian, but proved in the show that they could also excel in comedy.

Michael V., together with Alcasid, moved to GMA in 1995 to write, create music, co-direct, and head the cast of the weekly comedy sketch program Bubble Gang, which copied the format of Tropang Trumpo. In Bubble Gang, Michael V. parodies celebrities, politicians, superheroes, television programs, advertisements, popular music, current events, ethnicities, languages, genders, traditions, and the daily lives of Filipinos. In the segment “MTB: Myusik Tagalog Bersyon” (MTV: Music Tagalog Version), he composed and did music videos, like “Kama ni Rosanna” (Bed of Rosanna, a lampoon of “Bed of Roses” by Jon Bon Jovi), “Pustahan Aysus Naku!” (literal translation, Betcha by Golly Wow! by Prince), and “Sinaktan Mo ang Puso Ko” (You Broke My Heart, a parody of “You Don’t Love Me Anymore” by Weird Al Yankovic). He did popular spoofs of music videos in “MEV: Music English Version,” which include “Bathroom Dance” from “Bad Romance” by Lady Gaga and “DJ Bumbay” (Indian DJ), a comical take on Indian merchants in the Philippines. The compositions from these two segments of the program were included in a music collection, The Bubble G Anthology, 2006, GMA Records. He performs single, double, or multiple characters, either as a male or a female or both, in one scene, or impersonates popular personalities, such as the mother in “Ikaw at ang Ina” (You and Mother); a gay broadcast news commentator in “Sumbong-Sumbong kay Bonggang Bongbong” (Report It to Gay Bongbong); the awkward broadcast host Junie Lee who interviews real-life celebrities in “Yours Truly, Junie Lee,” the lady babysitter of a spoiled child in “Yaya and Angelina” (The Babysitter and Angelina); as psychic Madam Rocha; and as Mr. Assimo, a mockery of people’s idiocy. In Bitoy’s Funniest Videos, 2004-9, GMA, he was the siblings Etoy, Betong, and Bebang, all in one scene. He hosted the comedy talent search program Bitoy’s Showwwtime, 2009-10, and leads the cast of the weekly television comedy program Pepito Manaloto: Ang Tunay na Kwento (Pepito Manaloto: The Real Story), which premiered on 28 Mar 2010, both on GMA. He has also established himself as an endorser of consumer products, the most popular of which is the contemporary version of the classic subconscious “woman” ghost-guardian in Procter & Gamble’s Safeguard antibacterial soap.

He voiced television animal characters such as that of the dog Fulgoso in Marimar, 2007-8, another dog named Bantay in Bantatay (aka The Guardian), 2010-11, both on GMA, and other film voice characters, like that of a horse in Enteng Kabisote 3: Okay Ka, Fairy Ko … The Legend Goes On and On and On (Enteng Kabisote 3: You’re Okay, My Fairy … The Legend Goes On and On and On), 2006; the pet rat Kukut in the animated film of Pangasinan warrior princess Urduja, 2008; and the cool rocker tikbalang (horse demon) Narsi in the first Filipino all-digital full-length animation film Dayo: Sa Mundo ng Elementalia (The Wanderer in the Land of Elementalia), 2008.

In film, he portrayed his television characters in Bitoy ang Itawag Mo sa Akin (Call Me Bitoy), 1998; Yaya and Angelina: The Spoiled Brat Movie, 2009; Boy Pickup: The Movie, 2012; and the local hero Rubberman in Rubberman: Up, Up, and Away, 1996.

For the show Bubble Gang, he won Best Comedy Actor at the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards in 2000, 2002, 2003, 2005, and 2013; and Best Comedy Performance at the Asian Television Awards in 2005 and 2006. He was featured on the cover of Reader’s Digest, the second Filipino, after Pres Corazon Aquino, to have graced the cover of the popular magazine, in its 5th Annual Humor special issue released on 23 Aug 2008. Written byJonalou S. J. Labor and Eulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Mary Rose Magbujos and Leonor Hernando

He performs single, double, or multiple characters, either as a male or a female or both, in one scene, or impersonates popular personalities, such as the mother in “Ikaw at ang Ina” (You and Mother); a gay broadcast news commentator in “Sumbong-Sumbong kay Bonggang Bongbong” (Report It to Gay Bongbong); the awkward broadcast host Junie Lee who interviews real-life celebrities in “Yours Truly, Junie Lee,” the lady babysitter of a spoiled child in “Yaya and Angelina” (The Babysitter and Angelina); as psychic Madam Rocha; and as Mr. Assimo, a mockery of people’s idiocy.
