PEDROCHE, RAY (Edgardo Ray Gomez Pedroche) b. Tarlac, Tarlac 29 Nov 1936. d. 7 Jul 2015. Announcer, broadcast journalist, broadcast executive, teacher. He was the son of Conrado Villegas Pedroche, aka C. V. Pedroche, short story writer, poet, painter, sculptor, potter, and Avelina Pecson Gomez, and the brother of artist Danilo and broadcast and print journalist Alfonso. He was married to Maria Luisa Soller Orevillo, with whom he had seven children, including graphic designer Dino and photographer and graphic artist Louella Francia. He attended Burgos Elementary School and Mapa High School and earned the degree bachelor of arts in English from Far Eastern University in 1957.

He worked briefly in 1955 as announcer in Republic Broadcasting System DZBB and DZXX before joining the government station DZFM in 1956, where he wrote and read the news, conducted man-on-the-street interviews, covered special events, and produced and annotated music programs from pop to classical. By 1958, he was chief of announcers, and soon also head of news and special events. In 1967, he became production manager, but the following year he left the government station and joined the commercial broadcast network Kanlaon Broadcasting System (KBS), the forerunner of Radio Philippines Network, where he was first program director of DZRR and DZAX, then rose to assume positions that put him in charge of operations, programming, sales, engineering, and administration of both television Channel 9 and KBS radio stations throughout the country until 1997. During this period, he continued to host public affairs programs.

He was active in the self-regulatory organization of broadcasters Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas, serving in various official capacities, including vice chairman, in 1979-98. He was board director of the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board, 1992-97. While still active in broadcasting, he began lecturing in 1972 to broadcastingstudents in the University of the Philippines Diliman, Assumption College, Far Eastern University, Philippine Women’s University, and St Paul University. Written byElizabeth L. Enriquez

article_title: People's Television Network Inc/Philippine Broadcasting Service-Radyo ng Bayan
text:
PEOPLE’S TELEVISION NETWORK INC/PHILIPPINE BROADCASTING SERVICE–RADYO NG BAYAN (PTNI, aka People’s Television Channel 4 / PBS, The National Radio) PTNI is the flagship television broadcast station network of the Philippine government, while PBS-DZRB Radyo ng Bayan 738 kHz AM is the government’s radio station. Both PTNI and PBS-RB’s headquarters and 500-foot transmitter are located at the Broadcast Complex on Visayas Ave in Diliman, Quezon City. PTNI has 32 provincial stations, while PBS-RB has 30 stations and 16 affiliate stations all over the country. PBS also owns DZRP Radyo Pilipinas, aka Voice of the Philippines, which has been airing since 1965 on both AM and short-wave radio and was under the National Media Production Center (NMPC) during martial law. PTNI and PBS-RB are under the management of the Presidential Communications Operations Office, which also handles the Philippine Information Agency (PIA), the Bureau of Communication Services, the Presidential Broadcast Staff–Radio TV Malacañang, Media ng Bayan Television and Radio Networks, the News and Information Bureau, National Printing Office, and the OP Web Development Office.

The Radio Board (RB) was created by Pres Manuel L. Quezon on 3 Sept 1937 to nationalize radio stations in the colony, an idea that was not well received by the Americans, especially those invested in radio. Quezon was smarting from newspaper criticisms, so he wanted to use and control radio to counter newspaper articles unfavorable to him. He was not able to do this, anyway, due to a number of factors, such as financial requirement to acquire the stations, his failing health, and the coming of World War II. RB was abolished in 1942 by the Japanese imperial forces. Meanwhile, Gen Douglas MacArthur, as commander of the United States Army Forces in the Far East, brought several radio transmitters when he took the country back from the Japanese. He used the transmitters to let Filipinos know of his return. Toward the end of the war, he sent several of the transmitters to Japan, then integrated the remaining few radio stations’ transmitters in Manila into one network: a radio station with the call letters KZFM, first managed by the US Department of National Defense Office of War Information, then turned over to the newly organized United States Information Service (USIS) under the US State Department. On 20 Oct 1946, the second anniversary of MacArthur’s landing on Leyte, the USIS turned over KZFM to the new Philippine government’s Department of Foreign Affairs. In Aug 1947, KZFM was moved to the Philippine Broadcasting Service, which was a newly created unit under the Office of the President. PBS then grew into a nationwide network of government broadcast stations. On 1 Jan 1949, KZFM’s call letters were changed to DZFM.

PTNI, on the other hand, began operations in 1974. Its first name was Government Television Channel 4 (GTV 4). When NMPC gained full control of the station, GTV 4 was renamed Maharlika Broadcasting System (MBS), with a new programming on 1 Jan 1980. MBS was given the name People’s Television Channel 4 (PTV 4) in 1986 upon the assumption into office of Pres Corazon Aquino after the EDSA Revolt, then rebranded as National Broadcasting Network in 2001, and finally as PTNI in 2010 but retaining its more popular brand PTV as its secondary name during Pres Benigno Aquino III’s term.

In the 1960s, DZFM aired mainly news and public affairs programs, with some entertainment-cultural shows, which included PBS Final Newscast, PBS News Bulletin, Alam Ba Ninyo? (Did You Know?), Nacida Program, SEATO Calling, UNESCO Features, Midday Jamboree, and Rondalla Musical. PBS sent its staff, like Ray Pedroche, Esperanza Plata, Ernesto Madrid, and Marcial Aguila, to broadcast trainings abroad through the Colombo Plan and UNESCO.

Meanwhile, the NMPC, with its original headquarters on Santa Potenciana St in Intramuros, Manila, acquired in 1965 the facilities of Voice of America at Malolos, Bulacan, which then became the Voice of the Philippines. Beginning in 1974, the Marcos government started operating GTV 4, the airtime of which was shared by NMPC, the Bureau of Broadcast (BB, under then Ministry of Public Information, which dissolved DZFM), which was the former PBS, and Roberto Benedicto’s Kanlaon Broadcasting System (KBS, later RPN). Thus, the station had a rather split personality. There was also rivalry between NMPC, then headed by Gregorio Cendaña and identified with Imelda Marcos, and BB, then controlled by Public Information Minister Francisco “Kit” Tatad and identified with Ferdinand Marcos. Because there were three sharing the airtime of Channel 4, there were also three studios—NMPC in Intramuros, BB in its former offices on Arroceros, and KBS in the ABS-CBN facilities—at what was then called Broadcast Plaza in Quezon City. Only when NMPC, by creating MBS, took full control of the airtime did it move its operations to Broadcast Plaza.

In 1975, NMPC obtained DWIM-FM, which started airing in 1976. Although the “FM” in the call letters meant to identify the station as airing on the FM band, it was a clever way of associating the call letters with Imelda Marcos and Ferdinand Marcos. It had the strongest radio transmitter in the country at that time. DWIM played easy listening mellow music. During the post-EDSA period, both the NMPC and BB were reorganized, and their combined network was put under the administrative roof of the Office of Media Affairs, created by Pres Corazon Aquino during the early years of the post-EDSA period. This process, which resulted in the present-day PTNI and Bureau of Broadcast Services (BBS)–PBS, took several years and beyond the Cory administration. The name PBS was resurrected and attached to BBS. Also during the post-EDSA period, DZFM’s call letters became DZRB, for Radyo ng Bayan, created under the BBS-PBS. Tracing its roots to MacArthur’s KZFM, DZRB is the oldest postwar radio station in the country. PTV was granted its own charter through Republic Act 7306 in 1987.

PTV gained the notoriety of being the propaganda station of the government, from Marcos to the present. Pulong-Pulong sa Kaunlaran (Public Forum for Development) was a talk program mainly about the accomplishments of the New Society under Marcos. In spite of this image, however, GTV 4 during the martial law period produced some of the best shows, such as the public service program Damayan (In Sympathy With), revived in 1976, with film actor Rosa Rosal calling on various organizations to help alleviate the plight of indigent people going to the program to seek help; The Morning Show, which was a pioneer of daily morning talk-magazine programs; the music programs Concert at the Park, Paco Park Presents, Rondalla sa Telebisyon, and Return Engagement; the comedy program Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), revived in 1979, starring now National Artist Manuel Conde; Ang Mamimili (The Consumer), 1979, about consumer rights; development communication programs Ating Alamin (Let Us Know) and Tele-aralan ng Kakayahan (Knowledge Educational TV); sports programs Chess Today and Blow by Blow; and the drama anthologies Anino (Shadow), 1974, Huwaran (Model), 1974-80, Brocka Presents, 1977-80, Tipanan (Rendezvous), 1979, and Neneng Magtanggol, 1979. The evening talk show Face the Nation committed a huge error for President Marcos; it interviewed presidential aspirant Benigno Aquino Jr while incarcerated in Fort Bonifacio on 10 Mar 1978, and for the first time, someone openly criticized Marcos and his martial law regime on live television.

Noteworthy productions of DZRB Radyo ng Bayan during the post-EDSA period were the programs Daigdig ng mga Bata (World of Children) and Kulay at Anyo (Color and Form), which were both about local culture. PTV 4 resurrected the drama anthology Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) in 1987 and also produced Sa Direksiyon ni Lino Brocka (Under the Direction of Lino Brocka), 1990. The Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) created the drama anthologies Handog ng PETA (An Offering of PETA), 1990-92, and PETA-bisyon (PETA Vision), 1993, which examined relevant sociopolitical issues. The Women’s Media Circle produced the talk magazine show Woman Watch, which also aired on Radyo ng Bayan, 1986-88.

PTNI covered the Olympic Games in 1988, 1992, 1996, 2008, and 2012. It was the carrying station of the South East Asian Games in 1991, 1995, 2005, and 2007; the Asian Games from 1986 to 2006; and the IAAF World Championships in Athletics in 2007 and 2009.

Among PTNI’s personalities were Cendaña, who headed NMPC; Tatad, who was information minister of Marcos; Rod Reyes, Emil Jurado, and George Viduya, who managed GTV 4; Betsy Enriquez, Joe Sobrino, Romy Sager, Dell Villanueva, Lito Gorospe, Ismael Reyes, Bon Vibar, and Ronnie Nathanielsz, who anchored the news and public affairs programs of GTV 4; Jess Decolongon, who was with DWIM-FM; Benjamin Lozare, first director-general of PIA; Mia Concio, who headed NBN; and Maria Montelibano, who headed Radio TV Malacañang.

PTNI earned the Hall of Fame Award for Best Station and for Most Balanced Programming from the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 1987. Some programs of PTV, like Handog ng PETA, Balintataw, Ating Alamin, Daigdig ng mga Bata, and Kulay at Anyo won the Gawad CCP para sa Radyo at Telebisyon in the 1990s. It received a presidential citation from Pres Fidel V. Ramos for its coverage of the Atlanta Olympic Games in 1996. Its station ID won the Best TV Station ID at the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards for Television in 1996. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III and Elizabeth L. Enriquez, with notes from Victor C. Avecilla

Tracing its roots to MacArthur’s KZFM, DZRB is the oldest postwar radio station in the country. PTV was granted its own charter through Republic Act 7306 in 1987.

PTV gained the notoriety of being the propaganda station of the government, from Marcos to the present. Pulong-Pulong sa Kaunlaran (Public Forum for Development) was a talk program mainly about the accomplishments of the New Society under Marcos. In spite of this image, however, GTV 4 during the martial law period produced some of the best shows, such as the public service program Damayan (In Sympathy With), revived in 1976, with film actor Rosa Rosal calling on various organizations to help alleviate the plight of indigent people going to the program to seek help; The Morning Show, which was a pioneer of daily morning talk-magazine programs; the music programs Concert at the Park, Paco Park Presents, Rondalla sa Telebisyon, and Return Engagement; the comedy program Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), revived in 1979, starring now National Artist Manuel Conde; Ang Mamimili (The Consumer), 1979, about consumer rights; development communication programs Ating Alamin (Let Us Know) and Tele-aralan ng Kakayahan (Knowledge Educational TV); sports programs Chess Today and Blow by Blow; and the drama anthologies Anino (Shadow), 1974, Huwaran (Model), 1974-80, Brocka Presents, 1977-80, Tipanan (Rendezvous), 1979, and Neneng Magtanggol, 1979. The evening talk show Face the Nation committed a huge error for President Marcos; it interviewed presidential aspirant Benigno Aquino Jr while incarcerated in Fort Bonifacio on 10 Mar 1978, and for the first time, someone openly criticized Marcos and his martial law regime on live television.

Noteworthy productions of DZRB Radyo ng Bayan during the post-EDSA period were the programs Daigdig ng mga Bata (World of Children) and Kulay at Anyo (Color and Form), which were both about local culture. PTV 4 resurrected the drama anthology Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) in 1987 and also produced Sa Direksiyon ni Lino Brocka (Under the Direction of Lino Brocka), 1990. The Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) created the drama anthologies Handog ng PETA (An Offering of PETA), 1990-92, and PETA-bisyon (PETA Vision), 1993, which examined relevant sociopolitical issues. The Women’s Media Circle produced the talk magazine show Woman Watch, which also aired on Radyo ng Bayan, 1986-88.

PTNI covered the Olympic Games in 1988, 1992, 1996, 2008, and 2012. It was the carrying station of the South East Asian Games in 1991, 1995, 2005, and 2007; the Asian Games from 1986 to 2006; and the IAAF World Championships in Athletics in 2007 and 2009.

Among PTNI’s personalities were Cendaña, who headed NMPC; Tatad, who was information minister of Marcos; Rod Reyes, Emil Jurado, and George Viduya, who managed GTV 4; Betsy Enriquez, Joe Sobrino, Romy Sager, Dell Villanueva, Lito Gorospe, Ismael Reyes, Bon Vibar, and Ronnie Nathanielsz, who anchored the news and public affairs programs of GTV 4; Jess Decolongon, who was with DWIM-FM; Benjamin Lozare, first director-general of PIA; Mia Concio, who headed NBN; and Maria Montelibano, who headed Radio TV Malacañang.

PTNI earned the Hall of Fame Award for Best Station and for Most Balanced Programming from the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 1987. Some programs of PTV, like Handog ng PETA, Balintataw, Ating Alamin, Daigdig ng mga Bata, and Kulay at Anyo won the Gawad CCP para sa Radyo at Telebisyon in the 1990s. It received a presidential citation from Pres Fidel V. Ramos for its coverage of the Atlanta Olympic Games in 1996. Its station ID won the Best TV Station ID at the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards for Television in 1996. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III and Elizabeth L. Enriquez, with notes from Victor C. Avecilla

PIMENTEL, PEPE (Jose Gonzales Pimentel Sr) aka Tito Pepe. b. Ermita, Manila 30 Apr 1929. d. Quezon City 24 Jan 2013. Producer, television and radio host, comedian, singer, actor. He was married to Cecilia Labusan with whom he had six children. Actor Lito Pimentel was his nephew.

Pimentel debuted in broadcast in 1955 as host and singer in the program Melody Club on DZPI. In the same year, he became the first national champion of the popular amateur singing contest Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage). In 1958, he became singer and co-host of the noontime television variety show Student Canteen with Eddie Ilarde, Bobby Ledesma, and Leila Benitez until 1965 on CBN Channel 9, and with Ilarde, Ledesma, Helen Vela, and Coney Reyes in 1975-86 on GMA Channel 7. It was in Student Canteen where he showed his comedic side, often joking about his mother-in-law. He also appeared in Student Canteen’s rival Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!) on ABS-CBN Channel 2 as guest host in 1986-89 when his former show took a hiatus. In 1964-72, Pimentel co-hosted another noontime singing competition show Darigold Jamboree on CBN Channel 9 with Bobby Ledesma and Leila Benitez. Darigold Jamboree aired immediately after Student Canteen.

He was best known as the producer and host of the first and longest-running television game show Kuarta o Kahon (Money or Box), which aired on KBS Channel 9 in 1962-69 and BBC Channel 2 in 1973-84. When it moved to RPN Channel 9 in 1984-2000, its name was expanded to Family: Kuarta o Kahon. The show was inspired by the radio program Mahiwagang Kahon (Magical Box) on DZRH, which, in turn, was inspired by the American game show in the 1950s Bidding the Box. The game show invited families from around the country to participate. His co-hosts were his nephew Lito, Plinky Marquez, Encar Benedicto, and Marissa Sanchez.

Another singing competition program Pimentel hosted was Hamon sa Kampeon (Challenge to the Champion) from 1963 with Fidela “Tiya Dely” Magpayo on DZAQ-TV Channel 3, simulcast over DZAQ and DZXL radio stations. In 1965, Hamon sa Kampeon was turned into a movie bearing the same title with Gloria Romero, Luis Gonzales, Susan Roces, Eddie Gutierrez, Pimentel, and Magpayo. He also hosted the television variety show The Pepe Pimentel Show. He played roles in films such as Ang Tatay Kong Kalbo (My Bald Father), 1963, with Pugo and Gloria Sevilla; Ang Babaeng Isputnik (The Lady Sputnik), 1963, with Nida Blanca; and I Won, I Won: Ang Swerte nga Naman (I Won, I Won: What Luck), 1985.

Pimentel received the Citizen’s Award for Television in 1967. He served as barangay chairman of Brgy Laging Handa in Quezon City from 1997 to 2007. Written byGian Carlo C. Librojo

PROGRESSIVE BROADCASTING CORPORATION (PBC) PBC is a network of AM and FM radio stations and broadcast and cable television stations. Its headquarters are at 907 EDSA Quezon City. It began with one station, DWNU at 107.5 kHz on the FM band in 1987, playing new wave (pop/rock music of the 1970s and 1980s) and so-called alternative rock music with no commercials or deejay spiels for over a month without identifying itself. Building an audience in the process, it finally named itself the Home of New Rock, NU 107, with “new” pronounced as “nu.” Based on a concept by PBC founder Atom Henares and veteran FM broadcasters Mike Pedero and Cris Hermosisima, NU 107 became the stepping stone of Filipino rock bands of the late 1980s and 1990s, like Eraserheads, Rivermaya, and Parokya ni Edgar. The station aired unsigned amateur bands in the program In the Raw and college bands in University Rock. Fans remember the station most for organizing and hosting the annual NU Rock Awards beginning in 1994 until 2010. It was an annual gathering of the rock community, which recognized the contribution of bands to original Pilipino music (OPM).

 

After 23 years, NU 107 signed off at midnight on 8 Nov 2010 with Eraserheads’ “Ang Huling El Bimbo” (The Last El Bimbo) as the final song. Listeners, musicians, and former and current staff stood vigil outside its studios during its final hours with candles lit to mourn its passing, including then current and former DJs Francis Brew, Pontri Bernardo, Dylan Vizcarra, Russ Davis, Andie Aguirre, Trish Cabral, Jay Santiago, Cyrus Fernandez, and Zach Lucero. The station was reportedly financially unsustainable so Henares decided to try a more popular approach. It was then reformatted and rebranded as 107.5 Win Radio, with middle-of-the-road OPM and more talk that appealed to a bigger market. However, it had a relatively short run.

 

In 2014, the station was again rebranded as 107.5 Wish FM, which airs a broader range of popular music from as far back as the 1920s. Guest artists perform live in a program called The Roadshow, while The Wish List plays requested songs. Oldies are played on weekends in the programs Saturday Hit-Back and Golden Sunday. As its name implies, Wish FM, later Wish 107.5, grants not only song requests but some personal wishes of listeners such as a birthday party, a trip to the theme park Enchanted Kingdom, and a live singing performance. The station delivers live performances to its listeners through a mobile radio bus driving around Metro Manila and nearby provinces. It also streams live online.

 

PBC’s other FM stations are DYNY in Iloilo, DYNU in Cebu, DXNU in Davao, DXNY in Cagayan de Oro, and DXNV in General Santos. It also operates an AM radio station, DWUN, which broadcasts from Manila. Branded as UNTV Radio La Verdad (The Truth Radio), DWUN airs mainly religious programs like Ang Dating Daan (The Former Path), A Song of Praise, Balita Kada Ora (News Every Hour), and Itanong Mo kay Soriano (Ask Soriano).

 

The TV station UNTV Channel 37 is part of PBC. It is a 24-hour public service, news, and religious TV station affiliated with the religious group Members Church of God International, led by Eli Soriano. UNTV is also transmitted via cable. Some of its programs are Tulong Muna Bago Balita (Help Before News), UNTV Cup, Ito ang Balita (This Is the News), Good Morning Kuya (Good Morning, Elder Brother), Get It Straight with Daniel Razon, Bread n’ Butter, and Manibela (Steering Wheel). Written by Lia Gabriele A. Ballesteros and Alyssa Jean E. Alano

text: PTV 4 (See People's Television Network, Inc)

Pugo (Mariano Contreras), also known as Mang Nano, was a stage, film, radio, and television actor, and film director. He was born on 12 Jul 1910. He died on 12 Dec 1978. Considered the “Original King of Philippine Comedy,” he began acting on stage as one-half of the comedy team Pugo and Togo (also spelled Tugo, real name Andres Solomon) in the 1930s. Before World War II, they appeared in a dozen movies including Ang Lihim ng Lumang Simbahan (The Secret of the Old Church), 1940, and Binibiro Lamang Kita (I Was Only Joking), 1941. During the war, when Japan occupied the Philippines, the duo had to change their names to Puging and Tuging because of the similarity of the name Togo to Tojo, the Japanese prime minister. They performed a comedy sketch on stage imitating Japanese soldiers who wore several wristwatches at the same time. As a result, they were reportedly brought into Fort Santiago for questioning.

After the war Pugo and Togo resumed their film career, appearing together in several movies until Togo’s death in 1952. Without a partner, Pugo’s movie roles were as sidekick to other actors such as Nestor de Villa or as father to Lou Salvador Jr and Luz Valdez. Moviegoers, however, did not appreciate his comedy routines as much as when he was with Togo until he met the actor Bentot in the late 1950s, whose standard role for the rest of his career was as Pugo’s overgrown dim-witted son. Pugo and Bentot became the new comedy duo. The two then ventured into radio and later into television.

Pugo and Bentot were first cast in the DZRH sitcom Sebya, Mahal Kita (Sebya, I Love You) with Sylvia La Torre in the title role, Eddie San Jose, and Rosa Aguirre. The popular radio program, where Pugo played the role of Sebya’s father, Don Mariano Batekabesa, was made into a film with the same title in 1957. The film version had Pugo and Bentot as supporting actors to Nida Blanca and de Villa. The original radio cast was then used in the movie My Little Kuwan (My Little Something), 1958, with the same storyline. Following the success of Sebya, DZRH produced the sequel Tang-Tarang-Tang, 1961-74, where Pugo played the central character of Don Mariano. The show was also produced for television in 1963, airing on ABS-CBN Channel 3. A later offshoot was Si Tatang Kasi (Blame It on Father), 1974, which again starred Pugo in the title character, this time with the character name of Mang Nano.

Pugo's other sitcoms were Wanted: Boarders, Alright, Okay, and My Son, My Son. He also hosted the amateur radio and television singing contest Tawag ng Tanghalan in the 1960s with comedian Patsy after the demise of Patsy’s co-host Lopito. In 1962, he directed "Sepulturero" (Gravedigger), a segment in the comedy-horror movie Kababalaghan o Kabulastugan? (Mystery or Mischief?). Pugo appeared in at least 30 more movies after Togo’s death, including the film versions of his popular sitcoms, but it was through his radio and television shows that audiences heard and watched him regularly.  Written by Gian Carlo C. Librojo

QUINTO, LUCY (Lucy Manuel Quinto de Guzman) aka Lucy de Guzman. b. Malolos, Bulacan 7 Feb 1939. Voice talent, dubbing director, and dialogue coach. She is the daughter of Emilio Quinto and Alfonsa Manuel and sister of movie actor Rosa Mia and disc jockey Emilio Jr aka Charlie Brown. She is married to Carlito de Guzman, with whom she has two children. She studied accountancy at Far Eastern University, 1956-60.

 

She was seven when her older sister Rosa Mia, already a movie actor and director and talent on radio drama at the time, brought her to DZRH in 1946. Thus began her voice-acting career in radio soap operas in the late 1940s. Among the more memorable soap operas in which she acted were Dr. Ramon Selga, Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love), Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), and Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate). Like most radio drama talents in the 1950s and 1960s, she was self-taught and grew into other roles like producer, director, and dialogue coach. From the late 1970s until the early 1980s, she produced, directed, and acted in some of the 20 Cebuano soap operas translated into Tagalog that aired on Radio Mindanao Network’s DZXL, including In Aeternum Walang Hanggan (Eternal) and Manok ni San Pedro (Saint Peter’s Chicken). In 1998, she formed her own company, Digi-8 Studios, a fully digital recording-dubbing studio.

 

As voice talent and director, she with her pool of voice actors dubbed numerous foreign programs into Tagalog as well as substituted their voices for those of local actors in television programs and full-length films. She supervised the dubbing of foreign animation programs, such as the anime series Sailor Moon and Transformers for Channel 5 and Inuyasha for GMA Channel 7. She worked with film directors Lino Brocka, Ishmael Bernal, Peque Gallaga, Marilou Diaz-Abaya, and Laurice Guillen to coach actors in voice and dialogue, including veteran actors Charito Solis, Nora Aunor, Vilma Santos, Sharon Cuneta, Aga Muhlach, Maricel Soriano, Dina Bonnevie, and Herbert Bautista, and younger ones including Lea Salonga, Angel Locsin, Rudy Fernandez, Bong Revilla, Ace Vergel, Gretchen Baretto, Deither Ocampo, Jericho Rosales, Piolo Pascual, and Sam Milby. Quinto also created sound effects with voices, such as the vocal sounds created by the emotions of the throng watching a miracle take place in Bernal’s Himala (Miracle) and the crowd sounds in Gallaga’s Oro Plata Mata (Gold Silver Death). Written by Edgardo Ray G. Pedroche, with notes from Cynthia Cruz-Paz

article.value: QUINTO, LUCY (Lucy Manuel Quinto de Guzman) aka Lucy de Guzman. b. Malolos, Bulacan 7 Feb 1939. Voice talent, dubbing director, and dialogue coach. She is the daughter of Emilio Quinto and Alfonsa Manuel and sister of movie actor Rosa Mia and disc jockey Emilio Jr aka Charlie Brown. She is married to Carlito de Guzman, with whom she has two children. She studied accountancy at Far Eastern University, 1956-60.

She was seven when her older sister Rosa Mia, already a movie actor and director and talent on radio drama at the time, brought her to DZRH in 1946. Thus began her voice-acting career in radio soap operas in the late 1940s. Among the more memorable soap operas in which she acted were Dr. Ramon Selga, Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love), Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), and Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate). Like most radio drama talents in the 1950s and 1960s, she was self-taught and grew into other roles like producer, director, and dialogue coach. From the late 1970s until the early 1980s, she produced, directed, and acted in some of the 20 Cebuano soap operas translated into Tagalog that aired on Radio Mindanao Network’s DZXL, including In Aeternum Walang Hanggan (Eternal) and Manok ni San Pedro (Saint Peter’s Chicken). In 1998, she formed her own company, Digi-8 Studios, a fully digital recording-dubbing studio.

As voice talent and director, she with her pool of voice actors dubbed numerous foreign programs into Tagalog as well as substituted their voices for those of local actors in television programs and full-length films. She supervised the dubbing of foreign animation programs, such as the anime series Sailor Moon and Transformers for Channel 5 and Inuyasha for GMA Channel 7. She worked with film directors Lino Brocka, Ishmael Bernal, Peque Gallaga, Marilou Diaz-Abaya, and Laurice Guillen to coach actors in voice and dialogue, including veteran actors Charito Solis, Nora Aunor, Vilma Santos, Sharon Cuneta, Aga Muhlach, Maricel Soriano, Dina Bonnevie, and Herbert Bautista, and younger ones including Lea Salonga, Angel Locsin, Rudy Fernandez, Bong Revilla, Ace Vergel, Gretchen Baretto, Deither Ocampo, Jericho Rosales, Piolo Pascual, and Sam Milby. Quinto also created sound effects with voices, such as the vocal sounds created by the emotions of the throng watching a miracle take place in Bernal’s Himala (Miracle) and the crowd sounds in Gallaga’s Oro Plata Mata (Gold Silver Death). Written by Edgardo Ray G. Pedroche, with notes from Cynthia Cruz-Paz

RADYO SAGADA Radyo Sagada is the first community radio station in Sagada, Mountain Province, established in 2011. Broadcasting on the FM band at 104.7 MHz, it airs programs that support the concept ipeyas nan amay, or “working for the common good” in Kankanaey, the ethnic group and language of Sagada, through programs that spread public awareness of issues that affect health, agriculture, climate change, human rights, indigenous people’s rights, women, and culture. Resting on the high ranges of the Cordilleras, the station is managed by indigenous groups of the Cordilleras. It relies on community volunteer work but accepts advertising to help support operations.

Radyo Sagada is the brainchild of Mary Carling, now its station manager, and Bianca Miglioretto of the World Association of Community Radio Broadcasters, an international nongovernment organization that supports community radio, who conducted seminars and workshops on radio production in 2009 in Sagada. The following year, a community assembly gave birth to the Sagada Community Media Network Inc, later recognized by the Securities and Exchange Commission as the owner of Radyo Sagada. After months of test broadcast in 2011, it went on the air, its signals covering Sagada as well as Benguet, Baguio, Kalinga, and the provinces of Nueva Vizcaya, Quirino, and Ilocos Sur.

Among Radyo Sagada’s programs are Pinagpagan (Woven Blanket), which tackles women’s rights, Health Hour, Farming School On-Air, and programs of indigenous music such as Cordillera Liwliwa (Cordilleran Chanted Love Songs) and La-ing di Ganduyan (Good about Ganduyan [former name of Sagada]). Written byEarl John M. Orio

Sources: Carling 2014a, 2014b.

RAMSEY, ELIZABETH (Elizabeth Indino Ramsey-Johnson) b. San Carlos, Negros Occidental 3 Dec 1931. d. Metro Manila 8 Oct 2015. Singer and TV, film, and stage actor and comedian. She was the daughter of Arturo C. Ramsey, a Jamaican merchant marine, and Marcelina Rivera Indino, a Filipina of Spanish descent. She had three children with her first husband, and a daughter, Maria Luisa “Jaya” Ramsey, in her second marriage, with Ray Kagahastian. Jaya is a singer, dancer, record producer, TV host, and actor. Ramsey attended grade school in San Carlos, Negros Occidental.

Ramsey started singing at 16 years old touring around Negros with a 26-piece band earning about three to four pesos a night to help pay for her mother’s medications. She first caught the public’s attention when she entered the amateur singing competition in 1958 in the noontime variety television program Student Canteen on CBN Channel 9. With her raspy, soulful voice peppered with a distinct Visayan accent, coupled with her comedic timing when interacting with the show’s hosts, she was a hit. She was the undefeated champion of the amateur singing competition with a sassy rendition of the novelty song “Ragmop.” She then performed onstage at the Manila Grand Opera, then at its rival theater, Clover, where she earned the moniker “Queen of Rock and Roll,” bestowed on her by the National Press Club.

On television she performed with the ReyCard Duet, Eddie Mesa, Aruray, Casmot, and Balut. She also appeared in the television drama Dyesebel (Jezebel) in 2008 on GMA Channel 7, where she played the role of “Mother of Pearls,” and in the first kantaserye (musical series) Diva in 2010, also on GMA starring Regine Velasquez, where Ramsey played the role of Tita Turner.

Ramsey appeared in 26 films over a span of 40 years, including her first, the 1958 movie based on the radio program Mga Liham kay Tiya Dely (Letters to Aunt Dely). She played the perfect antagonist in the 1959 Prinsesa Naranja (Princess Naranja), where she played the vain queen who tricked a prince played by actor Fernando Poe Jr to kiss her a thousand times in order to break the spell that made her skin dark. She was also nominated for Best Supporting Actress at the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards for her role in Ang Bukas Ay Akin! (Tomorrow Is Mine!) (IMDb 2015g). Ramsey starred in television commercials, the most memorable of which was her 1976 spoof on Cleopatra for Superwheel Detergent Bar, where her tag line “Magapatuka na lang ako sa ahas!” (I’ll just let the snake bite me!) became so popular that it spun off a movie of the same title starring Chiquito, with her soundtrack that became a record single in 1977.

Ramsey made people laugh by making fun of herself, her dark color and Afro hair, and by making faces and performing barefoot (ABS-CBN News 2014). Between the gags, she belted out jazzy and soulful tunes and her distinctive renditions of “Razzle Dazzle” and the Visayan tune “Waray-Waray.” Written by Maria Angelica D. Abad

Sources: ABS-CBN News 2015; Asis 2015; ForeverEatBulaga 2013; IMDb 2015g; Logarta 2002a; Mommyjoyce 2015; Policarpio 2015; Sallan 2015.

RESSA, MARIA (Maria Angelita Lourdes Delfin Aycardo Ressa) b. Manila 2 Oct 1963. Broadcast journalist. She is the daughter of Manuel Phil Aycardo and Hermalina Delfin, and adopted by her mother’s second husband, an Italian-American named Pedro Ressa. Her family moved to the United States when martial law was declared in 1972.

She began her elementary education at St. Scholastica’s College in Manila in 1970 and continued at a public school in Toms River, New Jersey, in the United States in 1973. She graduated with a bachelor of arts in English literature, cum laude, with a minor in molecular biology, from Princeton University in 1986. She received in the same year a one-year Fulbright Fellowship to do research about political theater in Manila that enabled her to return to the country to explore her Filipino roots. She enrolled in the master of arts in theater program in the University of the Philippines in Diliman but was unable to finish the course because of her workload for Fulbright.

Her career in broadcast journalism started in the government station PTV 4 as director of the daily evening newscast in 1986. A year later, she was invited by Cheche Lazaro to join Probe Productions. She directed and produced documentaries for The Probe Team, 1988-2010, ABS-CBN, and GMA. In 1987-95, she worked as a news correspondent for the Cable News Network (CNN) and later as the Manila bureau chief. While covering news in Southeast Asia for CNN and working with Probe, she taught at the Department of Broadcast Communication of the University of the Philippines in Diliman. She continued directing some of PTV 4’s programs, such as Surveys and Trends, 1988, and No Nonsense with Dr. Margie Holmes, 1991-93, a 30-minute late-night weekly program that discussed a range of issues mainly on psychology, sex, and relationships.

She moved to Jakarta to serve as CNN’s Jakarta bureau chief in 1995, later as bureau chief for Southeast Asia until 2005. She made documentaries that investigated the Al-Qaeda and its networks in Asia, the struggle for independence of East Timor, and the political shift of the Indonesian government from Tommy Suharto’s regime. She returned to Manila in 2005 and became the senior vice president of ABS-CBN Broadcasting, heading its News and Current Affairs Division and serving as managing director of ABS-CBN News Channel until 2011.

She wrote Seeds of Terror: An Eyewitness Account of Al-Qaeda’s Newest Center of Operations in Southeast Asia published by The Free Press, 2011, and From Bin Laden to Facebook: 10 Days of Abduction, 10 Years of Terrorism published by Anvil, 2012. She also served as an author in residence and senior fellow of the International Center for Political Violence and Terrorism Research of the S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore, from Jan 2011 to Jan 2012, and as the Southeast Asia visiting scholar of the Common Operational Research Environment Laboratory at the Naval Postgraduate School in Monterey, California, from Jun 2011 to Feb 2012.

In Jan 2012, she founded Rappler, a news network that utilizes social media in producing news stories using traditional journalism in order to prompt social change. Its aim, as implied in its name, is to discuss (“rap”) events to make waves (“ripple”) among readers and in society. Through its citizen journalism arm called MovePH, Rappler pursues advocacies in education, governance, climate change, gender, health, and disaster risk reduction and management. One of Rappler’s pioneering features is the mood meter, a crowd-sourcing initiative that enables readers from all forms of social media to tell how they feel about a story or an issue. For this, Rappler bagged the bronze medal in the Brand Experience Boomerang Awards by the Internet and Mobile Marketing Association of the Philippines (IMMAP) in 2012.

Her contributions and those of her colleagues in The Probe Team were recognized in the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon from 1988 to 1997. They also won several awards from the Golden Dove Awards of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas, and the Star Awards of the Philippine Movie Press Club. Her documentaries East Timor: Struggle for Independence won in the Asian Television Awards in 1999 and the Crystal Award of the SAIS-Novartis International Journalism Award in 2000. Seeds of Terror, about terrorism in Southeast Asia, earned a nomination for outstanding investigative journalism in the Emmy Awards in 2002. She received the Ferris Professorship of Journalism at Princeton University in 2001, the National Headliner Award for Investigative Journalism of the Press Club of Atlantic City in 2002 for her news coverage of Indonesia, a Judges’ Citation for best documentary from the US Overseas Press Club, the Philippines’ Ten Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service in 2007, and the Journalist of the Year Award by the Rotary Club of Manila in 2014. Written byChristine A. Palattao, with notes from Olivia L. Cantor and Eulalio R. Guieb III

REVILLA, TINA (Maria Christina Roces Revilla Valencia) b. 2 Feb 1955. Host and actor for television and film. Revilla is part of a prominent show business clan. She was born to Jose Revilla, aka Armando Goyena, a matinee idol in the 1950s who was dubbed as the “Last Golden Boy of Philippine Movies,” and Francisca Roces aka Paquita, the original Camay beauty soap girl of the TV commercial that defined the concept of the Caucasian-looking Filipino beauty. She is the second of eight children. Her sisters Maritess, also an actor, and Cita were Camay girls in the 1970s and 1980s. Maritess’s daughter, Bianca Araneta-Elizalde, is a model, actor, and TV host, and also became a Camay girl in the 1990s. Tina’s sister Pita married Bernardo Palanca Sr and is the mother of actors Bernard and Mico Palanca. Her sister Cecilia is the mother of TV host Lexi Schulze. Her brother Johnny Revilla, an actor and a former party-list representative, is married to singer Janet Basco.

Tina has two children from her marriage with Sergio O. Valencia, chair of the board of the Philippine Charity Sweepstakes Office during the latter part of the presidency of Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. Valencia is the son of Elpidio Valencia, the country’s health secretary from 1958 to 1961, and grandson of Sergio Osmeña Sr, who was Philippine president in 1944-46. Revilla completed her primary education, high school, and college at St. Paul’s College in Manila. Her daughter Jordana, aka Jana, a graduate of a bachelor of arts in psychology, 2010, at the University of the Philippines, obtained one of the university’s highest weighted average grades at 1.08.

Revilla started her career on TV at age 17 as a host in the program Turn On with Tina, 1971, RPN 9, then on the variety shows Stop, Look, Listen and The Wow Generation, both in 1971-72 and both on MBS Channel 4. She then starred in the weekly sitcom My Family Three, also in 1971, ABS-CBN, with Frankie Navoa Jr and Jingle as orphaned siblings living in an abandoned bus with Ramon Zamora as their guardian. She went back to hosting on 12 O’Clock High, 1972, ABS-CBN, with another young talent Marilen Martinez, and with Ariel Ureta as the executive producer; and Ariel con Tina (Ariel with Tina), 1972, IBC 13, then 1972-74, RBS Channel 7, a noontime show written by Lyca Benitez and directed by Maria Montelibano, and which she co-hosted with Ariel Ureta. She made her mark as one among three young and intelligent hosts of the talk magazine program Ms. Ellaneous, 1976-81, GMA, also by Montelibano.

Together with co-hosts Maan Hontiveros and Yogi Dominguez-Zaragosa, she pushed the reimaging of the Filipina as modern, urban, and assertive, an image that countered the dominant image then of women as martyr and submissive. She also had her own drama anthology, Christina, 1975, BBC 2, directed by Marcial Sanson. After the EDSA Revolt, she was one of the hosts of the daily noontime show Lunch Date, 1986-93, GMA, with co-host Randy Santiago. She was a co-lead actor with friends Helen Vela, Coney Reyes, and Vilma Santos in a rare episode of the drama series Lovingly Yours, Helen, GMA, which was shown sometime in 1990; and a lead member of the cast of Prinsipe Abante (Prince Abante), 1977-80, GMA, with Bert “Tawa” Marcelo, directed by Ading Fernando. She was also the TV and print product endorser of Alpine full cream evaporated milk in the 1980s and 1990s, and hosted the lotto draws of the Philippine Charity Sweepstakes, PTV 4, in the 2000s.

In films, she appeared in the comedies My Funny Girl, 1971, alongside Sajid Khan; Ayos Lang Pare Ko (It’s Okay, My Friend), 1972, with Rod Navarro and Nida Blanca; Ang Anting-Anting ni Ompong (The Amulet of Ompong), 1975, with Dolphy, Panchito, and Coney Reyes; Jack of All Trades, Master of None, 1975, with Chiquito and Eddie Garcia; and Wonder Boy, 1976, with child superstar Niño Muhlach. She was in the film dramas The Sisters, 1972, with sister Maritess, and Hello, Goodnight, Goodbye, 1975, with Hilda Koronel, and Christopher de Leon. Film action stars got her as their leading lady, like Fernando Poe Jr in Pagbabalik ng Lawin (Return of the Hawk), 1975, Tatak ng Alipin (Mark of a Slave), 1975, and Pagbabalik ng Panday (Return of the Blacksmith), 1981; Tony Ferrer, George Estregan, and Rey Malonzo in Homicide, 1977; and Lito Lapid in Pedro Tunasan, 1983.

Revilla, together with Hontiveros and Dominguez-Zaragosa, won the award for Best Magazine Show Hosts at the Philippine Academy for Television Arts and Sciences Awards, 1977. She received the Star Award as Best Female TV Host for Lunch Date from the Philippine Movie Press Club, 1989 and 1991. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III and Divine Marie Joanne P. Endriga

REYES, CONEY (Constancia Angeline Reyes Nubla) b. Manila 27 May 1954. Television and film actor and host. She has two children with ex-husband and former basketball player Lawrence Mumar, and one child from ex-partner and TV host and actor Vic Sotto. She finished bachelor of arts in communication arts at Maryknoll College, now Miriam College. Coney is an active member and the disciple group leader of Victory Christian Fellowship.

 

Her work in show business started with the movie The Return of the Dragon, 1974. However, she became noted for her hosting and acting on television. Reyes was chosen to co-host with Eddie Ilarde, Bobby Ledesma, and Helen Vela when the noontime show Student Canteen was revived on 6 Jan 1975 on GMA. The pre-martial law Student Canteen on television first aired on CBN Channel 9, 1959-64. In 1982, she left Student Canteen after having been given the walking papers. She was seen a month later co-hosting with Pepe Pimentel, a former Student Canteen host, the pre-noontime show Daigdig ng mga Misis (World of Wives), BBC 2. Also in the same year, one of the surprises of the battle of noontime shows was the transfer of Reyes to Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!), then airing on RPN 9, rival noontime show of Student Canteen, hosted by Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, and Joey de Leon. Reyes’s move to Eat Bulaga! coincided with the show’s switch to domestic satellite or DOMSAT, which made possible its nationwide simulcast on all the regional stations of RPN 9, the first in Philippine broadcast history. Reyes stayed in Eat Bulaga! until 1992.

 

While still with GMA, co-host Ilarde produced for Program Philippines the first weekly drama anthology of Reyes, the Coney Reyes-Mumar Drama Studio, GMA, which aired every Saturday after Student Canteen. The program was given a new title, Coney Reyes-Mumar on the Set, 1984, this time produced by BSH Productions for her new station, RPN 9. When she separated from husband Mumar, she dropped her husband’s surname from the show’s title, renaming the program Coney Reyes on Camera, which she herself produced under CAN Television (CAN stood for her real name, Constancia Angeline Nubla). Reyes’s drama anthology moved to ABS-CBN, together with Eat Bulaga!, in 1989, a time when RPN 9 was under sequestration from the post-EDSA government. Her show stayed on ABS-CBN, in spite of the transfer of Television and Production Exponents (TAPE), producer of Eat Bulaga!, to GMA in 1995, a time when ABS-CBN was buying out all its blocktimers.

 

As an actor in her own drama anthology, Reyes had a chance to showcase her acting talents with the best actors of the industry, like Vilma Santos, Jaclyn Jose, and Gina Alajar. One of the most memorable episodes was the reunion episode with friends Vilma Santos and Tina Revilla Valencia in 1994 as a special tribute to the late Helen Vela, her co-host in Student Canteen and Eat Bulaga!. In the show’s latter years, the show ended with a phrase from the Bible that related to the episode. Also later, Reyes stopped acting on her show, doing only the opening and closing spiels, and relying on guest performers. The program’s theme song was “It’s My Turn” by Diana Ross, the song she rendered on her first appearance in Eat Bulaga! after having been fired from Student Canteen. Reyes on Camera ended its run in 1999.

 

In 1996, Reyes began hosting the program The 700 Club Asia on GMA. She had leading roles in a number of television drama serials, like ABS-CBN’s Ang Munting Paraiso (The Little Paradise), 1999; Sa Puso Ko Iingatan Ka (I Will Cherish You in My Heart), 2001; Ysabella, 2007; Rubi, 2010; 100 Days to Heaven, 2011; and Huwag Ka Lang Mawawala (Against All Odds), 2013. She made a comeback to her home network GMA in the telenovela Ang Dalawang Mrs. Real (The Two Mrs Real), 2014, in time for her 40th year in show business. In 2015, she appeared in the inspirational fantasy series Nathaniel, ABS-CBN.

 

Reyes also acted in films, which include Basta’t Isipin Mong Mahal Kita (Always Remember I Love You), 1975; Nagbabagang Asero (Burning Steel), 1977; Ang Agila at ang Falcon (The Eagle and the Falcon), 1980; Pedring Taruc, 1982; Bago Kumalat ang Kamandag (Before the Venom Spreads), 1983; Daddy’s Little Darlings, 1984; Lovingly Yours, Helen: The Movie, 1984; Ang Padrino (The Godfather), 1984; Muling Buksan ang Puso (Open the Heart Once Again), 1985; Bomba Arienda, 1985; Good Morning Titser (Good Morning, Teacher), 1988; Biyudo si Daddy, Biyuda si Mommy (Daddy Is a Widower, Mommy Is a Widow), 1997; And I Love You So, 2009; and Four Sisters and a Wedding, 2013.

 

Reyes bagged the Best Actress award for Bago Kumalat ang Kamandag in the Metro Manila Film Festival, 1983. She won the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Award for TV Best Drama Actress for her performance in Coney Reyes on Camera in 1987, 1990, 1991, 1994, and 1995. The drama anthology won the Star Awards for Best Drama Series in 1996, 1997, and 1988. Nathaniel won best children and youth program at the 27th Catholic Mass Media Awards, 2015. Reyes was one of the 10 women who got the Mary Kay Philippines Woman with a Heart Award in 2001, which recognized successful women for their integrity, service, leadership, and the balance of faith, family, and career. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III and Alyssa Jean  E. Alano

REYES, NORMAN (Normando Ildefonso Brackman Reyes) b. Manila Feb 1922. d. San Pablo City, Laguna 1996. War correspondent, radio announcer, broadcast journalist. He was the son of diplomat and newspaperman Ildefonso Reyes and Grace Brackman. He was married to Farida A. Gomez. He attended Bordner School, the American school in Manila in the 1930s, and the University of the Philippines (UP). He later earned a bachelor of arts degree in English from Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tennessee, USA.

Reyes was 16 and in high school when he began a radio career at KZIB in 1938.

He handled music shows and annotated live the college basketball games at the Rizal Stadium. In the following year, 1939, as World War II erupted in Europe, he learned to write and announce the news. In 1940, he began his college education at UP and at the same time moved from KZIB to KZRM. He got more involved in news and current affairs programs as Manila anticipated war and particularly when Japan bombed Pearl Harbor in Hawaii, then the Philippines, on 8 Dec 1941. On 31 Dec 1941, all Manila stations ceased broadcast following the blowing up of all large radio transmitters, ordered by the United States Army Forces of the Far East commander Gen Douglas MacArthur. Reyes joined MacArthur’s contingent as it withdrew to Corregidor while the Japanese entered Manila.

In Corregidor, Reyes was among the group of announcers, writers, and radio engineers who organized the makeshift radio station Voice of Freedom, which broadcast anti-Japanese propaganda while the combined Filipino and American troops in Bataan fought off the advancing Japanese. He is best remembered for his dramatic reading on the air of the piece “Bataan Has Fallen,” written by Salvador P. Lopez, to announce the fall of Bataan on 9 Apr 1942.

The Japanese reached Corregidor in early May and captured the remaining Filipinos and Americans on the island. The following year, they took Reyes to Tokyo to produce and host the program Zero Hour on Radio Tokyo. At the war’s end in Aug 1945, American forces who invaded Japan arrested him for collaborating with the Japanese, but he was exonerated.

He subsequently worked in radio and television in Hawaii in the late 1950s until 1964. Written byElizabeth L. Enriquez

Sources: Enriquez 2008a, 2013; Reyes 1995; Reference.com 2012.

SAMSON, BARR (Ibarra Macam Samson) b. Calumpit, Bulacan 11 Jan 1932. d. 24 Jun 2012. Radio announcer, disc jockey (DJ), variety show host, comedian, singer, scriptwriter, journalist. He was the son of Federico Samson Sr and Serafia Macam. He married three times and had 14 children. He attended high school at Calumpit Institute in Calumpit, Bulacan, and studied electrical engineering at the Mapua Institute of Technology, 1951-54.

 

Samson’s 63-year career in radio and television began in 1949 as a DJ on DZBB, the radio station of the Republic Broadcasting System, now GMA Network, introducing songs and singers of the era, including Frank Sinatra, Nat Cole, Vic Damone, Dick Haymes, and Perry Como. Soon he co-hosted the Tita Betty’s Children’s Show with Betty Mendez on Philippine Broadcasting Corporation’s DZPI playing the child named Itik-Itik, miming the voice of Disney’s Donald Duck. He is credited for writing the lyrics of the ditty “May Pulis sa Ilalim ng Tulay” (There’s a Policeman under the Bridge), based on the English children’s song “There’s a Hole in the Bottom of the Sea,” and recording it as “Itik-Itik” with the D’ Big 3 Sullivans.

 

In the late 1950s, he pioneered the daily stock market report delivered live by remote broadcast on Manila Broadcasting Company’s DZRH. Samson was among the first field reporters on ABS-CBN’s DZAQ Radyo Patrol in the 1960s, which was noted for its bold live reporting on street unrest prior to the declaration of martial law in 1972 by then president Ferdinand Marcos. At the same time, he took the police and sports beats in the then newspaper arm of ABS-CBN, the Manila Chronicle, while writing comedy and drama scripts with Ading Fernando for radio and television and playing bit parts in both television and film.

 

When the declaration of martial law forced the closure of ABS-CBN and several commercial media organizations, Samson moved to the government station Voice of the Philippines where he wrote and read the news and hosted radio programs. He later joined the United States Information Service in the Philippines. Until his passing, he hosted for a few years the Sunday musical program You and the Past and the Music on DWBR Business Radio of the government broadcast network Philippine Broadcasting Service, where he played standards and all-time favorites. While teaching broadcasting at the Manila Times College School of Journalism in 2008-9, Samson began writing a book to serve as a manual for aspiring broadcasters. Titled Radio Broadcasting: Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow, it was published in 2012. Written by Edgardo Ray G. Pedroche, with notes from Cynthia Cruz-Paz

 

Sources: Pedroche 2012; Samson 2005; Wikipilipinas 2014a; Yahoo News 2014b.

SANSON, MARCIAL (Marcial Sanson Manubag Fernan) b. Cebu. d. 4 Feb 1999. Television and film director and writer, music composer and lyricist, pianist, singer. He was one of the five children of Pablo Fernan and Paz Manubag. The clan of his father includes former Supreme Court chief justice Marcelo Briones Fernan, 1927-99. He studied television and film production at the University of California at Los Angeles in the second half of the 1950s. He was program manager of ABS-CBN’s Channel 4 from the mid-1960s to 1972 and assistant general manager for programs of BBC 2 during the martial law period. Like Freddie M. Garcia, Rino Basilio, and Rod Reyes, Sanson returned to ABS-CBN after martial law.

His career in entertainment started in the early 1950s as a musician and radio talent. He first directed music variety programs on ABS-CBN Cebu in 1965. He directed the daily drama soap Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), 1977-85, BBC 2, for which he became famous. He directed the weekly drama anthologies of BBC 2: Dulambuhay ni Rosa Vilma (Life Story of Rosa Vilma), 1975, starring Vilma Santos; Christina, 1975, showcasing Tina Revilla; Ito Ako, Pinky (This Is Me, Pinky), 1975, featuring Pinky de Leon; Alindog (Allure), 1976-79, with mainstay Alma Moreno; Peping: Ang Munting Anghel (Peping: The Little Angel), 1976-79, starring Gulong ng Palad child star Romnick Sarmenta; Sanyugto (Episode), 1978, featuring Eddie Rodriguez; and Ulila (Orphan), featuring Rosa Rosal, 1978. During the second half of the 1970s, he directed Ora Engkantada (Enchanted Hour), a fantasy drama, with Luz Fernandez as the storyteller; Kutob (Hunch), a drama series about the supernatural; and Direk (Director), about the ins and outs of show business. On KBS-RPN 9, he directed, with Lupita Concio, the drama anthology Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora), 1970s-1980s, starring Nora Aunor. In 1975, he directed two historical dramas for television, Pag-ibig at Pahimakas ni Dr. Jose Rizal (The Life and Testament of Dr Jose Rizal), which employed editing techniques that rendered the rhythm of the narrative less dry than the more common extended sequences of the period, and The Life of Emilio Aguinaldo, which was shot without a set, all done in limbo, and with the use of symbols to create an impressionistic imagery of the visuals (Bondoc 1979).

In film, he directed Ito ang Gulong ng Buhay (This Is the Wheel of Life), 1979, an adaptation of the radio-TV drama series Gulong ng Palad, the theme song of which he himself composed, released by OctoArts International and Emi Philippines and sung by Eva Eugenio. He played the piano in his recording of the albums Handumanan: A Piano Anthology of Immortal Cebuano Songs (Remembrance: A Piano Anthology of Immortal Cebuano Songs), 1996, Star Records, and Handumanan 2, 1997.

His single “Pobreng Alindahaw” (Poor Dragonfly) won for him the Awit Awards for Best Traditional Recording, 1998, given by the Philippine Association of the Record Industry.

Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III

Sources: Abelardo 1975a; Bondoc 1979; Film Academy of the Philippines 2015; Ledesma-Aguirre 1976b; Pinoy Comics TV Movies 2009; Sagisag 1976.

SANTOS, JON (Jonathan Adriano Santos) b. Quezon City 18 Jan 1966. Writer, actor for TV, film, theater, and live entertainment. His parents are Joselito Lucero Santos and Zenaida Adriano. He graduated in 1987 with an economics degree from the University of the Philippines (UP), where he joined the theater group UP Repertory Company in 1982.

 

He began his broadcasting career as a co-host of the weekly comedy variety show Gabi ni Dolphy (Dolphy’s Night), 1988-89, and the main host of the weekly gag show Hoy! (Hey!), 1990-91, both on RPN 9. He appeared on television as a co-host of the daily noontime show Lunchdate, 1988-92, on GMA. From 1988 to 1996, he became segment host and writer of the public affairs program Hoy Gising! (Hey, Wake Up!), main host of the children’s program Sineskwela (School on Air), and co-host of the daily noontime show Sang Linggo nAPO Sila (The Apo Now Runs for a Week), all on ABS-CBN, and co-host of M.A.D.: Martin after Dark, a musical variety that ran on GMA, 1988-93, and ABS-CBN, 1993-98. Santos also appeared on television as a commercial endorser of consumer products and services ranging from food, telecommunications, and money transfer. His film credits include mainstream and independent productions: Tangga and Chos (Stupid and Whatever), 1992; Big Time, 2005; D’ Lucky Ones, 2006; Hanggang Dito na Lamang at Maraming Salamat (This Is as Far as I Go, and Many Thanks), 2007; and Moron 5, 2012.

 

Santos has been actively performing before overseas and local audiences in theater and varied live entertainment spaces since 1994. His most acclaimed performances involve those that infuse sharp critical parody upon the foibles of political figures such as former presidents Gloria Macapagal Arroyo and Joseph Estrada, and Sen Miriam Defensor-Santiago. For example, in Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata, he lampooned top political personalities who mingle with the character Anding Tengco (Noel Trinidad), a corrupt and lascivious congressman.

 

This deftness at delivering comedic political commentary is demonstrated in events such as Jon Santos: Live and in Persons, 1999-2000, 2002-3, 2007-10, 2013; Jon Santos: Spooftacular, 2001; Tongue-in-a-Mood, 2003, a pun on a Filipino expletive with sexually obscene undertones; Rock da Vote (Rock the Vote), 2007; Kilitikal Condition (Tickling/Serious Condition), 2007; Kuring, Gluring, Syerrap, Dyuning … Eleksyon Is Nearing: For Voters or for Worse (Kuring [broadcaster Corina Sanchez], Gluring [President Gloria], Syerrap [President Erap], Dyuning [Pacquiao’s mother Mommy Dionisia] … The Elections Are Near: For Voters or for Worse), 2009-10; 101 JonJemons: Da Pinoy Powerlist (101 Jon’s Jejemon Language: The Pinoy Power List), 2010; Jon Santos Live, 2011; Jon Santos … In PersoNation, 2012; Man of Steeletos, 2013; and The Jon Santos Show, 2014. His other stage performances include lead roles in Dogeaters, 2007, and Priscilla: Queen of the Desert, 2014.

 

Santos authored I Vote This Book: The Cornicles of Jon Santos (I Bought/Vote This Book: The Corny Jokes of Jon Santos), Anvil Publishing, 2010. He was recognized as Best Male Comedian at the Aliw Awards in 2012. Written by Maria Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

SANTOS-RELOS, GEL (Maria Angelina Concepcion Santos Relos) b. Manila 1 Dec 1962. Journalist, broadcaster. She is the eldest of the five children of lawyer Jose Maria Santos and Angelita Quintana Concepcion. She is married to physician Rene P. Relos with whom she has four children. She graduated with a bachelor of arts degree in broadcast communication, cum laude, from the University of the Philippines Diliman. She hosts Balitang America (News from America) on The Filipino Channel (TFC), a cable and satellite television station based in Redwood, California, which is a subsidiary of ABS-CBN.

From 1989 to 2001 she anchored Relos Reports and Dear Ate Gel on DZMM, the radio station of ABS-CBN on the AM band. At the same time, she hosted the weekly cultural magazine television show Tatak Pilipino (Filipino Trademark) with Jim Paredes on ABS-CBN Channel 2 until 1994. In 1998-99, the show was revived on ABS-CBN News Channel.

From 1994 to 2000, Santos Relos was part of the anchor team of ABS-CBN’s news programs TV Patrol,Balita Ngayon (News Now), Pulso (Pulse), Aksyon Balita (Action News), and Headlines.She also joined Ted Failon and Korina Sanchez in hosting the public service program Hoy, Gising! (Hey, Wake Up!). Her radio interview of lawyer Rene Cayetano in 1994 forged a partnership that produced the legal education and public service program Compañero y Compañera (Male and Female Colleagues) that also had a television counterpart, both of which lasted until 1998 when Cayetano ran for the Senate and won.

In 2001, she quit broadcasting and migrated to the United States. In 2005, she rejoined ABS-CBN by co-hosting with lawyer Michael Gurfinkel the immigration show Citizen Pinoy on TFC. In 2007, she began anchoring Balitang America, the first daily newscast for Filipinos in North America. She also began writing a column for the Asian Journal titled “The Fil-Am Perspective.”

Santos Relos won Best Cultural Magazine Show Host awards at the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards for TV for Tatak Pilipino for four years, 1991-94. A program she produced and hosted, Compañero y Compañera: The Drama, was awarded the Best Radio Drama at the Catholic Mass Media Awards and Best Drama Program at the KBP Golden Dove Awards in 1998. In 2009, she was included in the list of 100 Most Influential Filipino Women in America by the Filipina Women’s Network. Written byCamille S. Intal

Sources: Lo 2001d; Pecayo 2007.

SARMENTA, ROMNICK (Romeo Nicolas Sarmenta Tejedor) b. Quezon City 28 Apr 1972. Film, television, theater actor. His parents are Adonis F. Tejedor and Julie C. Sarmenta. He is married to film, television, and theater actor and producer Harlene Bautista with whom he has five children. His brothers-in-law, Quezon City mayor Herbert and Hero, are film and television actors, and his father-in-law was film director Herminio, aka Butch. He completed his elementary and high school education at Angelicum. He took up architecture at the University of Santo Tomas.

He started on television at the age of four to play the role of the child Peping in the hit daily soap Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), 1977-85, BBC 2, for which he became famous. Gulong, directed by Marcial Sanson, was about a young couple’s daily struggles in life. From 1976-79, he was given the lead roles for the drama anthologies Peping: Ang Munting Anghel (Peping: The Little Angel), Bata (Child), True Story, and Señor Santo Niño, all on BBC 2 and all directed by Sanson. Mario O’Hara directed the child actor in Marcelino, Pan y Vino: Alamat o Milagro? (Marcelino, Bread and Wine: Legend or Miracle?), 1979, BBC 2, about a child who encounters Christ in the form of imaginative prayers. Directors, writers, and staff cued Sarmenta on his dialogue for the TV dramas in which he starred because he had yet to learn how to read then.

During his teen years, he belonged to the Friday, then the Wednesday, group of the highly popular daily late afternoon youth-oriented variety show That’s Entertainment, 1986-96, GMA, where he was paired with Sheryl Cruz, with whom he would appear in 10 movies produced by Seiko Films. He was a mainstay of the youth drama Young Love, Sweet Love, 1987-93, RPN 9.

He appeared in nearly 20 episodes of the weekly drama anthology Maalaala Mo Kaya (MMK, Will You Remember), which premiered in 1991, ABS-CBN. His memorable performances were in the episodes “Rubber Shoes,” MMK’s very first episode, 1991; “Kasulatan” (Agreement), 1995; “Kandila” (Candle), 2005; “Pedicab” (Bike Cab), 2009; and “Internet Shop,” 2011.

He played major roles in the daily drama series Esperanza, 1997, Sa Puso Ko Iingatan Ka (I Will Cherish You in My Heart), 2001, and Bituin (Star), 2002, all of ABS-CBN; Daisy Siete (Young Daisy), 2006, Bakekang, 2006, Impostora (Impostor), 2007, Luna Mystika, 2008-9, All My Life, 2009, First Time, 2010, and Iglot, 2013, and the telemovie Bakla (Gay), 1999, all on GMA. He appeared in the daily fantasy-adventure programs Mulawin, 2004, and Encantadia, 2005, both on GMA.

As a child actor in films, he played the child Ding in Bira, Darna, Bira (Strike, Darna, Strike), 1979. This was followed by more serious roles in movies directed by Mario O’Hara, like Condemned, 1984, and Tatlong Ina, Isang Anak (Three Mothers, One Child), 1987. Some of his films with screen partner Sheryl Cruz were Puso sa Puso (Heart to Heart) and Langit at Lupa (Heaven and Earth), both in 1988; Everlasting Love and Ubos Na ang Luha Ko (I Have No More Tears to Shed), both in 1989; and Sagot ng Puso (Answer of the Heart), 1990. He was later packaged as an action star in Mario Sandoval: Kahit Ako’y Lupa (Mario Sandoval: Even If I’m of Lowly Origins), 1993, directed by Abbo Q. de la Cruz. He played more serious roles in Stella Magtanggol, 1983, directed by Chito Roño, about the dangerous lives of society’s outcasts; Damong Ligaw (Wild Grass), 1997, directed by Jose Mari Avellana, about the Philippine Revolution of 1896 from the perspective of ordinary people; Miguel/Michelle, 1998, directed by Gil Portes, about a transwoman seeking love and acceptance from family and friends; Tirad Pass: The Story of General Gregorio del Pilar, 1997, directed by Carlo J. Caparas, about the life of the Filipino hero; Prinsesa (Princess), 2007, directed by Lawrence Fajardo, about a father whose work abroad affects his relationship with his only daughter; and Hustisya (Justice), 2014, directed by Joel Lamangan, about criminals and syndicates in the city.

In theater, he appeared in Judy Ick’s Screen: Macbeth, 2011, directed by Anton Juan Jr and essayed the role of national hero Andres Bonifacio in Tim Dacanay’s Teatro Porvenir, 2013, directed by Floy Quintos for Dulaang UP.

He and wife Harlene own the production outfit Heaven’s Best Entertainment, which produced Burgos, 2013, about missing young journalist Jonas Burgos, and Hustisya, 2014.

Sarmenta won Best Actor at the Asian Television Awards, 1999,for his performance in the GMA telemovie Bakla. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III

Sources: Aquino 2014; Lo 2013a; Pinoy Comics TV Movies 2000; Sarmenta 2015; Video 48 2009b.

SEGUERRA, AIZA (Cariza Yamson Seguerra) aka Ice. b. Calauag, Quezon 17 Sep 1983. Singer, songwriter, actor. The only child of Decoroso Seguerra from Calauag, Quezon, and Caridad “Mommy Caring” Yamson-Seguerra from Bicol, Seguerra completed his elementary and high school education at the Operation Brotherhood Montessori Center, 1990-2000, and enrolled in the Conservatory of Music of the University of Santo Tomas in 2001. Seguerra shifted to the industrial fine arts program at the same university in 2002 but did not finish a bachelor of arts degree. Seguerra is married to actor Liza Diño.

Seguerra was discovered as a child star at three years old when he won runner-up in the segment “Little Miss Philippines” of the daily noontime show Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!), then on RPN 9, in 1987. He became part of the show for 10 years, performing funny antics that endeared him to audiences. He was a mainstay in the TV fantasy comedy series Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), 1987-97, first with IBC 13, then on ABS-CBN and finally on GMA, led by Eat Bulaga! host Vic Sotto. He hosted two kiddie shows, It Bulingit (Small It), 1990-91, and Eh Kasi Bata (Because They Are Children), 1991-95, both on ABS-CBN. Seguerra hosted Bodytalk, 2003-4, on Knowledge Channel, a weekly 30-minute television magazine program for high school students about adolescent reproductive health and topics like menstruation, masturbation, genital and other viruses, first sex, dating, and violence,

As a child actor, he starred in about 35 comedy films, the first of which was Wake Up, Little Susie, 1988, with the Eat Bulaga! trio of Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, and Joey de Leon. He then conquered the music industry with her first album, Little Star, 1995, but it was the hit single “Pagdating ng Panahon” (When the Time Comes), 2001, composed by Edith Gallardo and Moy Ortiz for Vicor Music, that fully brought Seguerra back into the limelight. The single garnered five platinum record sales, officially recognized by the Philippine Association of the Record Industry. Seguerra subsequently came out with a series of hit music albums, like Pinakamamahal (The Most Loved), 2002, A First! Live in Concert, 2003, Sabi ng Kanta (The Song Says), 2003, and Covers Uncovered, 2004, all from Vicor; Para Lang sa ’Yo (Only for You), 2007, and Open Arms, 2012, both from Star Records; and Araw-Gabi: Mga Awit ni Maestro Ryan (Day-Night: The Songs of Maestro Ryan), 2015, a collaboration with Ryan Cayabyab under Universal Records.

At the spike of Seguerra’s career in music, he went back to television, taking on more challenging roles and delivering more nuanced performances, such as that of a lesbian in the episode “Song Book” of the drama anthology Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2001, ABS-CBN, and as a lesbian again in the highly popular daily pre-noontime teleserye (TV series) Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14, ABS-CBN. He also went into theater and played Eddie and Dr Scott in the science fiction The Rocky Horror Show, 2002, and as Gary Coleman in the Singapore Repertory Theater adult version of Sesame Street-turned-into-a-musical, Avenue Q, 2007 and 2010, all staged at the RCBC Towers in Makati; and as the city planner opposed to investors’ and the local government’s plan to clean up the seedy strip of the city in the musical Rak of Aegis, 2014-15, inspired by the songs of the all-female rock band Aegis, produced by the Philippine Educational Theater Association.

Seguerra came out publicly as a transgender man in 2007. He married twice his partner Liza Diño. Their first wedding was in a Christian ceremony in San Francisco, California, on 8 Dec 2014. The second was a symbolic ritual in the Philippines, without pastors or ministers, only close friends, with Carelle Mangliag officiating the wedding in San Juan, Batangas, on 8 Jan 2015. Diño’s daughter, Amara, calls him Baba. Since then, Seguerra was featured in the documentary Pinoy Transkings, 2015, the first Filipino video about transmen and their advocacies, which premiered in Sining del Pilar, Mar 2015, of the Department of Broadcast Communication of the University of the Philippines, and later screened in the Pink Film Festival in Quezon City, 2015. Seguerra and wife Diño founded One Love Zaza, named after the last syllable of the name of Aiza, a support group for the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer community, on 20 Jul 2015.

Seguerra won the award for Best Dramatic Performance by an Actress at the Asian Television Awards in 2002 for his role in “Song Book” in Maalaala Mo Kaya. For film, he won the title Box Office Queen from the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Scholarship Foundation (GMMSF) Box Office Entertainment Awards in 1987 for the huge success of the film Wake Up, Little Susie. Seguerra won five Best Child Performer awards: for Aso’t Pusa from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), 1989; for the two movie adaptations of the TV comedy Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! in the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF), 1991, and in FAMAS, 1991 and 1992; and for Aswang, from the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards for Movies, 1992. He won Best Supporting Actress for My Little Bossings in the MMFF, 2013.

The single “Pagdating ng Panahon” won for him several Awit Awards in 2002: Best Performance by a Female Recording artist, Best Pop Recording, Best Produced Record of the Year, and Song of the Year. The song won Best Theme Song for the eponymous movie in the FAMAS, 2002.

Other awards include the Quezon Medalya ng Karangalan Special Award from the provincial government of Quezon in 2001 for his contribution in the field of music and the arts; Favorite MYX Live Performance in the MYX Music Awards, 2009; Acoustic Artist of the Year for the music album Open Arms in the PMPC Star Awards for Music, 2009; and Best Performance by a Female Recording Artist for Open Arms and the song “With a Smile” in the Awit Awards, 2009 and 2013, respectively. The song “Ano’ng Nangyari sa Ating Dalawa” (What Happened to the Two of Us), composed by Jovinor “Joven” Tan, which he interpreted in the Himig Handog P-Pop Love Songs, 2013, was declared the grand winner in the competition, and won him the award for Best Female Recording Artist of the Year in the GMMSF Box Office Entertainment Awards, 2013. Written by Dean Airo Salvador E. Dancel, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

The single garnered five platinum record sales, officially recognized by the Philippine Association of the Record Industry. Seguerra subsequently came out with a series of hit music albums, like Pinakamamahal (The Most Loved), 2002, A First! Live in Concert, 2003, Sabi ng Kanta (The Song Says), 2003, and Covers Uncovered, 2004, all from Vicor; Para Lang sa ’Yo (Only for You), 2007, and Open Arms, 2012, both from Star Records; and Araw-Gabi: Mga Awit ni Maestro Ryan (Day-Night: The Songs of Maestro Ryan), 2015, a collaboration with Ryan Cayabyab under Universal Records.

At the spike of Seguerra’s career in music, he went back to television, taking on more challenging roles and delivering more nuanced performances, such as that of a lesbian in the episode “Song Book” of the drama anthology Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2001, ABS-CBN, and as a lesbian again in the highly popular daily pre-noontime teleserye (TV series) Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14, ABS-CBN. He also went into theater and played Eddie and Dr Scott in the science fiction The Rocky Horror Show, 2002, and as Gary Coleman in the Singapore Repertory Theater adult version of Sesame Street-turned-into-a-musical, Avenue Q, 2007 and 2010, all staged at the RCBC Towers in Makati; and as the city planner opposed to investors’ and the local government’s plan to clean up the seedy strip of the city in the musical Rak of Aegis, 2014-15, inspired by the songs of the all-female rock band Aegis, produced by the Philippine Educational Theater Association.

Seguerra came out publicly as a transgender man in 2007. He married twice his partner Liza Diño. Their first wedding was in a Christian ceremony in San Francisco, California, on 8 Dec 2014. The second was a symbolic ritual in the Philippines, without pastors or ministers, only close friends, with Carelle Mangliag officiating the wedding in San Juan, Batangas, on 8 Jan 2015. Diño’s daughter, Amara, calls him Baba. Since then, Seguerra was featured in the documentary Pinoy Transkings, 2015, the first Filipino video about transmen and their advocacies, which premiered in Sining del Pilar, Mar 2015, of the Department of Broadcast Communication of the University of the Philippines, and later screened in the Pink Film Festival in Quezon City, 2015. Seguerra and wife Diño founded One Love Zaza, named after the last syllable of the name of Aiza, a support group for the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer community, on 20 Jul 2015.

Seguerra won the award for Best Dramatic Performance by an Actress at the Asian Television Awards in 2002 for his role in “Song Book” in Maalaala Mo Kaya. For film, he won the title Box Office Queen from the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Scholarship Foundation (GMMSF) Box Office Entertainment Awards in 1987 for the huge success of the film Wake Up, Little Susie. Seguerra won five Best Child Performer awards: for Aso’t Pusa from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), 1989; for the two movie adaptations of the TV comedy Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! in the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF), 1991, and in FAMAS, 1991 and 1992; and for Aswang, from the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards for Movies, 1992. He won Best Supporting Actress for My Little Bossings in the MMFF, 2013.

The single “Pagdating ng Panahon” won for him several Awit Awards in 2002: Best Performance by a Female Recording artist, Best Pop Recording, Best Produced Record of the Year, and Song of the Year. The song won Best Theme Song for the eponymous movie in the FAMAS, 2002.

Other awards include the Quezon Medalya ng Karangalan Special Award from the provincial government of Quezon in 2001 for his contribution in the field of music and the arts; Favorite MYX Live Performance in the MYX Music Awards, 2009; Acoustic Artist of the Year for the music album Open Arms in the PMPC Star Awards for Music, 2009; and Best Performance by a Female Recording Artist for Open Arms and the song “With a Smile” in the Awit Awards, 2009 and 2013, respectively. The song “Ano’ng Nangyari sa Ating Dalawa” (What Happened to the Two of Us), composed by Jovinor “Joven” Tan, which he interpreted in the Himig Handog P-Pop Love Songs, 2013, was declared the grand winner in the competition, and won him the award for Best Female Recording Artist of the Year in the GMMSF Box Office Entertainment Awards, 2013.
