SEVERINO, HOWIE (Horacio Gorospe Severino) b. Manila 18 Jul 1961. Broadcast journalist, documentarist. Howie Severino is the son of retired ambassador Rodolfo Severino Jr and Tati Gorospe Severino, a schoolteacher and administrator. He completed his grade school in 1975 and secondary education in 1979 at Ateneo de Manila. He has a bachelor of arts in history, magna cum laude, from Tufts University in Massachusetts in 1983. He earned a master’s degree in environment, development, and policy from Sussex University in England in 1993. He is married to environmental lawyer Ma. Paz Luna with whom he has a son.

 

In Massachusetts, Severino met political exile Benigno Aquino Jr, who fired up his interest in Philippine contemporary politics. A few months after Aquino was assassinated in Aug 1983, he went home to the Philippines and taught English and coached the debate team at his alma mater, Ateneo de Manila High School. He joined the anti-Marcos movement and was arrested in 1985 and detained in solitary confinement for a week in Fort Bonifacio. After Marcos was overthrown in 1986, Severino worked for the administration of Pres Corazon Aquino as a speechwriter of Health Secretary Alfredo Bengzon. He left government service in 1988 to begin his journalism career at age 27.

 

Severino wrote for the Manila Chronicle from 1988 to 1991 and co-founded the Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism (PCIJ) in 1989. He joined Cheche Lazaro’s The Probe Team as a reporter-producer in 1997, where he first developed TV magazine stories into 45-minute documentaries. Among his most acclaimed stories are “Pagbabalik sa Tribo” (Return to the Tribe), 1999, about filmmaker Auraeus Solito’s discovery of his Palawan indigenous roots and the group’s struggle against mining; “No Story Is Worth Dying For,” 2001, about journalists caught in the cross fire between soldiers and the bandit group Abu Sayyaf in Lamitan, Basilan; and “Lolo ng San Franciso” (aka “Little Brown Man in San Francisco”), 2001, about a homeless Filipino war veteran in the United States. Despite Severino’s struggles with the Filipino language, he successfully lobbied for the program’s switch from English to Filipino. In the late 1990s, Severino taught himself to use the first-generation consumer digital video cameras and to edit nonlinear video on the first version of Final Cut Pro. He became one of the first TV reporters to regularly shoot his own stories and edit his own video footage.

 

Severino left The Probe Team in 2001, and became one of the hosts and writers of the weekly documentary program i-Witness on GMA. He produced a twice weekly news segment, “Sidetrip,” which reported offbeat aspects of Filipino life and culture, and helped produce special public affairs programs for GMA, including Iraq: Sa Bingit ng Digmaan: The GMA News and Public Affairs Documentary Special (Iraq: On the Throes of War: The GMA News and Public Affairs Documentary Special), 2003, and 20 Taon ng GMA Public Affairs Documentary Special (20 Years of GMA Public Affairs Documentary Special), 2007.

 

In 2009, Severino was appointed GMA Network’s vice president for multimedia journalism and editor in chief of GMA News Online, and led a widely commended media campaign for Internet safety, Think before You Click. In 2014, Severino became GMA’s vice president for professional development, designing journalism training programs and helping refine the network’s news policies and standards, while continuing to host and co-write monthly i-Witness documentaries and co-anchor with Kara David GMA News TV’s weekday morning show News to Go.

 

For nearly two decades, he worked closely with the late cameraman Egay Navarro, who spent the latter part of a long TV career capturing the images for many of Severino’s documentary productions. In 2007, GMA Network released Ten Years of Howie Severino, a DVD compilation of 10 of his most memorable documentaries in the first decade of his TV career.

 

Among his awards are the Davis-Latch Memorial Award, given annually in Bangkok to one young journalist in the Asia Pacific region, in 1991; the Manila Rotary Club’s Broadcast Journalist of the Year Award in 2003 and 2008, and the Investigative Journalist of the Year Award in 2007 and 2006, entitling him to a Hall of Fame Award from the organization; and the Titus Brandsma Award for Leadership in Journalism from the Carmelite religious order in 2009.

 

Documentaries he produced for i-Witness won awards. “Unggoy,” about a community living harmoniously with wild monkeys in a village in Mindanao, won third place for creative excellence at the US International Film and Video Festival in 2006. “Huling Hala Bira” (The Last Ati-Atihan Dance), about the last Ati-Atihan Festival of a community of informal settlers facing the demolition of their houses, won second prize at the UN Asia-Pacific Millennium Development Goals Media Awards in 2007 and the Silver World Medal at the New York Festivals in 2008. Severino won the Jaime V. Ongpin Award for Investigative Reporting for the anthology Hard Times: The Challenge to President Ramos, which he co-wrote and edited with his PCIJ colleagues, in 1992, and for his article “Chemical Giant Evades Ban on Deadly Products,” about the pesticide poisoning of Filipino farmers, in 1994. His works also received honors from the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas Golden Dove Awards, the Catholic Mass Media Awards, the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards for Television, and all the university student awards for broadcast. Written by Daphne-Tatiana T. Canlas and Eulalio R. Guieb III

SOHO, JESSICA (Maria Jessica Aspiras Soho) b. Agoo, La Union 27 Mar 1964. Broadcast journalist, producer. She is the daughter of Abelardo Soho Sr and Maura Aspiras. She has three siblings. She finished her primary and secondary education at Christ the King College in San Fernando City, La Union. She first enrolled in political science at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman to pursue a career in law, 1981, but, after having been inspired by a talk by veteran journalist Luis “Louie” Beltran, shifted to bachelor of arts in communication, major in journalism, also at UP, from which she graduated in 1985. She then worked for GMA as a news reporter up to 1988. She was promoted as production news manager, 2000, acting news director, 2002, and vice president for news and public affairs, 2004, all on GMA, then for both GMA and QTV 11, which became GMA News TV, 2008, until her retirement in 2014. She continues to host programs on GMA.

She started as a beat reporter at GMA for education, police, Malacañan, justice, and defense in 1985. Her first voice-over feature story was the inauguration of the Light Rail Transit from Baclaran to Monumento. She co-hosted the radio program Kape at Balita (Coffee and News), 1991-93, on GMA’s DZBB. She produced and hosted many of the network’s weekly investigative news and public affairs magazine programs on television, such as Emergency, 1995-2009, Brigada Siete (News Brigade on Seven), 1993-2001, i-Witness, which premiered in 1991, and Kapuso Mo, Jessica Soho (One with You at Heart, Jessica Soho) aka KMJS, which premiered in 2004, all on GMA; and Jessica Soho Reports (JSR), 2001-5, Brigada (Brigade), Reunions, 2005-11, and the daily news and commentary program State of the Nation, which first aired in 2011, all on GMA News TV. She supervised the news programs 24 Oras (24 Hours), Saksi (Witness), Flash Report, Unang Balita (First News), Balitanghali (News at Noon), News to Go, Balita Pilipinas (Philippine News), and GMA News TV Live.

Soho is remembered for her reporting of the Desert Storm operation in Afghanistan in 2002, when an ambulance bringing the dead to a hospital ran over a land mine and exploded near her and her team. She has covered several hostage-taking incidents, foreign wars, coup attempts, presidential state visits, the Vatican and papal visits, social issues like health, education, and poverty, and natural disasters like earthquakes, typhoons, and volcanic eruptions. She has reported extensively on the plight of overseas Filipino workers in Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, and South Korea.

Soho won the bronze in the New York Festivals, 1991, for her coverage of the hostage crisis in Cagayan Valley, the first Filipino to have won in the festival. Kape at Balita won the grand prize in the Asia-Pacific Broadcasting Union, 1994. She won the Gold Camera Award for her specials Philippine Agenda: Education and the Silver Screen Award for KMJS from the US International Film and Video Festival, both in 2008; and the Institutional Award for Investigative Reporting for i-Witness for the episode “Kidneys for Sale,” about poor people selling their kidneys, and Brigada Siete for “Kamao” (Fist), about a deadly underground sport, both in 1999, and for the GMA news team’s coverage of super typhoon Yolanda by 24 Oras, Saksi, State of the Nation, and KMJS, 2013.

From the Golden Dove Awards of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas, Soho received the first Ka Doroy Valencia Journalist of the Year Award, 1991; the Best Public Affairs Program for Kape at Balita, 1992, Brigada Siete, 1997 and 2000, and JSR, 2002; Best Magazine Show for JSR, 2004; and Best Public Affairs Host for JSR, 2002. From the Philippine Movie Press Club, she received the Star Awards for Television for Best Documentary for i-Witness, 2001; Best News Magazine for JSR, 2002, and KMJS, 2009 and 2010; Best Public Affairs Program and News Magazine Host for JSR, 2002, Hot Seat, 2008, and KMJS, 2009 and 2010; and the Excellence in Broadcasting Lifetime Achievement Award, 2011. In the Catholic Mass Media Awards, she and her programs won Best TV News Magazine for i-Witness, 2001, KMJS, 2007, and State of the Nation, 2010 and 2011; Best Public Affairs Host and Program for JSR, 2002; and Best Public Service Program for Reunions, 2009. From the Southeast Asian Foundation for Children and Television (SEAFCTV), KMJS received the Anak TV Seal Awards in 2004, 2008, 2009, and 2011. The SEAFCTV also chose her as one of the 10 Most Admired Female Personalities in 2007 and 2008, and included her in the Roster of Makabata Stars in 2009. From the Cultural Center of the Philippines, she received the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon for Best TV Special for the documentary Anatomy of Rape, 1993, and the Gawad Natatanging Parangal sa Telebisyon, 1989 and 1990.

Among other several awards she won were the British Fleet Street Award for Investigative Journalism by the British Embassy in Manila, 1998; Ten Outstanding Young Men, 1993; Outstanding Broadcaster of the Year Award and Award for Continuing Excellence and Service from the Metrobank Foundation, 2001 and 2009, respectively; the Hall of Fame from the Rotary Club of Manila, 2003, for having won the TV Journalist of the Year Award in 1989 and 1990; the Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service award, 2001; the UP Alumni Association Distinguished Alumni Awards, 2008; People of the Year Award from People Asia magazine, 2009; the Hildegarde Awards for Women in Media and Communication, 2011 and 2012; and Most Trusted News Presenter by Reader’s Digest Asia, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, and 2015. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III and Lily Grace A. Tabanera, with notes from Ericka Vernadette Sallador

Sources: GMA News Online 2014a, 2014b, 2014c, 2015; Lo 2001a; PCCF 2014b; Raquel 2014; Red 2014a; Soho, n.d.

STEWART, BOB (Robert La Rue Stewart) aka Uncle Bob. b. 19 Nov 1918. d. Phoenix, Arizona, USA 6 Apr 2006. News correspondent, television and radio network founder, program host. He was married to Filipina Loreto Feliciano-de Hemedes.

Stewart was an American war correspondent sent by the United Press International to the Philippines in 1943 to cover World War II. After the war, he settled in the country and married Feliciano in 1948. He then established the Republic Broadcasting System (RBS) on 1 Mar 1950 with the first of its radio-television network, station DZBB, with studios at Calvo Building, Escolta, Manila. Stewart aired the company’s first newscast on the same day. In 1951, he and the station covered extensively the Mount Hibok-Hibok eruption and, in 1953, the presidential elections. DZBB was the first station to use telephone patch for live interviews. In 1955, he launched RBS’s second radio station, DZXX, the first in the country to devote its broadcast to popular music. It was followed in 1957 by DYSS Cebu and DYOO Iloilo.

On 29 Oct 1961, Stewart expanded to television with RBS Channel 7. The following day, on 30 Oct 1961, he went on air to deliver the news in The News with Uncle Bob, which lasted until 1972. Low ratings led RBS to the brink of bankruptcy in its first few years, with only the show Dancetime with Chito helping the company stay afloat. Then ratings picked up when he began airing canned American programs, including Combat!, The Flying Nun, Mission: Impossible, 77 Sunset Strip, and The Untouchables, as well as cartoons such as Popeye and Gumby.

Stewart is best remembered for the children’s show Uncle Bob’s Lucky 7 Club, which he produced and hosted until 1984. Children joined him in the studio as participants and as audience, interacting with the puppets Spanky the Elephant and Pancho. In 1961, the Diosdado Macapagal administration accused RBS of supporting presidential rival Carlos P. Garcia in the 1960 elections and threatened Stewart with deportation. Children and their parents rallied behind Stewart until the government backed down.

In 1974, two years after Marcos declared martial law, a new law restricted ownership of media to Filipino citizens and corporations. Stewart and the American Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), which owned 25 percent of RBS, sold the company to Marcos ally Gilberto M. Duavit, lawyer Felipe L. Gozon, then Stewart’s legal adviser, and Menardo R. Jimenez. RBS then became GMA Radio-Television Arts. However, the company name was not changed to GMA Inc until 1996. GMA at first stood for Greater Manila Area, Channel 7’s initial coverage area. Today it stands for Global Media Arts.

Even when he no longer owned the network, Stewart continued to host Uncle Bob’s Lucky 7 Club until 1984 and a late-night musical show, The Maestro and Uncle Bob, 1978-79, with Spanish-Filipino pianist, composer, and conductor Federico Elizalde on the piano. When Elizalde died in 1979, the show was renamed The Bob Stewart Show, then Uncle Bob and Friends, 1979-86, with pianist Joselito Pascual. Written by Gian Carlo C. Librojo

Sources: Banal-Formoso 2001; Las Piñas 2014; Pinoy Nostalgia Atbp. 2010.

Low ratings led RBS to the brink of bankruptcy in its first few years, with only the show Dancetime with Chito helping the company stay afloat. Then ratings picked up when he began airing canned American programs, including Combat!, The Flying Nun, Mission: Impossible, 77 Sunset Strip, and The Untouchables, as well as cartoons such as Popeye and Gumby.

Stewart is best remembered for the children’s show Uncle Bob’s Lucky 7 Club, which he produced and hosted until 1984. Children joined him in the studio as participants and as audience, interacting with the puppets Spanky the Elephant and Pancho. In 1961, the Diosdado Macapagal administration accused RBS of supporting presidential rival Carlos P. Garcia in the 1960 elections and threatened Stewart with deportation. Children and their parents rallied behind Stewart until the government backed down.

In 1974, two years after Marcos declared martial law, a new law restricted ownership of media to Filipino citizens and corporations. Stewart and the American Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), which owned 25 percent of RBS, sold the company to Marcos ally Gilberto M. Duavit, lawyer Felipe L. Gozon, then Stewart’s legal adviser, and Menardo R. Jimenez. RBS then became GMA Radio-Television Arts. However, the company name was not changed to GMA Inc until 1996. GMA at first stood for Greater Manila Area, Channel 7’s initial coverage area. Today it stands for Global Media Arts.

Even when he no longer owned the network, Stewart continued to host Uncle Bob’s Lucky 7 Club until 1984 and a late-night musical show, The Maestro and Uncle Bob, 1978-79, with Spanish-Filipino pianist, composer, and conductor Federico Elizalde on the piano. When Elizalde died in 1979, the show was renamed The Bob Stewart Show, then Uncle Bob and Friends, 1979-86, with pianist Joselito Pascual. Written by Gian Carlo C. Librojo
Sources: Banal-Formoso 2001; Las Piñas 2014; Pinoy Nostalgia Atbp. 2010.

TAGALOG, RUBEN (Roberto La Valle Tagalog) b. La Paz, Iloilo 18 Oct 1922. d. Anaheim, California, USA 9 Mar 1985. Singer, composer, actor, radio announcer. His parents were Pedro Tagalog and Martina La Valle. He was married to Zoila Silva, with whom he had five children. His two siblings, Pacita and Clarita, were singers.

In spite of his name, Tagalog was an Ilonggo who was encouraged by popular sarsuwela actor and kundiman (love song) singer Atang de la Rama, later proclaimed National Artist for theater and music, to sing professionally after hearing him sing as a teenager in his hometown of La Paz, Iloilo. In 1937, he and his sisters Pacita and Clarita went to Manila to try their luck in singing and performed in bodabil and radio musical shows. Pacita played the ukulele, Clarita the guitar, and Ruben the violin. They were discovered by showman Lou Salvador who introduced them as the Wandering Trio. When his sisters married, Tagalog went solo and joined radio blocktimer Frankie Gomez’s program called Malayan Radio Stars. During World War II, he performed in stage shows.

After the war, Tagalog teamed up with Tony Cayado, Eddie San Jose, and Oscar Obligacion to perform in cocktail lounges. He also sang as soloist on the Malayan Sampaguita Radio Stars on postwar KZRH. In the late 1940s, he began hosting his own radio program, Harana ni Ruben Tagalog (Serenade by Ruben Tagalog), with Cely Bautista on DZFM on Sunday evenings, singing songs like “Ramona, Sayang” (Ramona, What a Pity), “Azucena, Nahan Kaya Ikaw?” (Azucena, Where Might You Be?), “Barong Tagalog” (The Tagalog Shirt), and “Nasaan Ka Ngayon?” (Where Are You Now?) delivered in his baritone voice, with Ruben Torres as guitarist and Ading Fernando as bass player. The latter also provided comic lines. His other radio program in the early 1950s was Ang Tibay Show on DZRH, and on ABS television, Pista ng Bayan (Town Fiesta), Pista ng Caltex (Caltex Fiesta), and Fantasia Musicale. Soon he was singing with the most popular female vocalists, such as Sylvia La Torre, Conching Rosal, Carmen Camacho, and Cely Bautista.

Through some informal coaching on Tagalog enunciation by Levi Celerio, who became a close friend and who wrote lyrics for his numerous hits, such as “O, Pag-ibig na Makapangyarihan” (Oh, Love That Is So Powerful), “Sayang” (Tough Luck), “Pandanggo sa Ilaw” (Fandango in Light), and “Caprichosa” (Capricious), he became at ease in singing the kundiman, danza, balitaw (folk song), and other popular Tagalog song forms of the day. His baritone voice and his emotional rendition of songs earned him the title “Hari ng Kundiman” (King of Kundiman). His radio programs were so popular that when the Philippine recording industry was born at around the same time, Tagalog was among the first to be recorded, at first by the Riego label. When the public began buying records in the early 1950s, he signed up under Villar Recording Company and its sister label Mabuhay Records. For a time he joined the singing group formed in 1958 by Villar, the Mabuhay Singers, which for decades popularized traditional Filipino music in the major Philippine languages. Including the songs he recorded for Bataan Recording and Mico’s, his records number around 200, including the revival of classic pieces like “Dalagang Pilipina” (Filipina Maiden) by Jose L. Santos and Jose Corazon de Jesus, “Bakit Ka Lumuluha” (Why Are You Crying), “Buntong-Hininga ng Puso” (Sigh of the Heart), and “Sa Pinto ng Langit” (At the Door of Heaven) by Leon Ignacio, and “Ulila sa Pag-ibig” (An Orphan of Love) by Juan de Hernandez and Deogracias Rosario.

Tagalog put up the recording company Tagalog Records, waxing his own compositions sung by Cely Bautista, “Pag-ibig sa Pag-ibig” (Love for Love) and “Panaginip” (Dream). He penned and recorded the popular Christmas songs “Sa Maybahay ang Aming Bati” (To the Homeowner Go Our Holiday Greetings), whose original title was “Namamasko” (Christmas Visit), “Tatlong Haring Mago” (Three Magi), and “Sino si Santa Klaws?” (Who Is Santa Claus?). In the early 1950s, he recorded the Tagalog version of the Visayan Christmas carol “Kasadya Ning Taknaa” as “Ang Pasko Ay Sumapit” (Christmas Is Here), with lyrics by Levi Celerio. He was the first to record the patriotic song “Bayan Ko” (My Country) in 1961.

Among Tagalog’s other memorable recordings heard on the air are “Ang Tapis Mo, Inday” (Inday, Your Skirt), “Bukid Ay Basa” (The Field Is Wet), “Halina, Neneng” (Come, Neneng), “Kay Bango-Bango” (How Sweet It Smells), “Kay Lungkot Nitong Hatinggabi” (What a Lonely Midnight), “Labandera Ko” (My Laundrywoman), “O, Ilaw” (Oh, Light), “O, Pag-ibig” (Oh, Love), “Pandanggo ni Neneng” (Neneng’s Fandango), “Pista ng Nayon” (Town Fiesta), “Tubig sa Batisan” (Water in the Brook), “Umaga Na, Neneng” (It’s Morning, Neneng), and the Visayan songs “Ang Tanan Natapos” (Everything Is Ended), “Dalagang Tabunon” (The Brown Maiden), “Gibunsod” (Fishnet), “Gugma” (Love), “Ikaw Day Na-ingnan” (I Tell Only You), “Kalaay” (Lonely), “Kasing-Kasing” (Heart), “Katamis Mo Ba” (How Sweet You Are), “Lang-yaw” (The One Who Left), “Kahibulongan” (Amazing), “Higugma” (Love), “Akong Gugma” (My Love), “Natahap Ako” (I Doubt You), “Pinangga” (Favorite), and “Tungod Kanimo” (Because of You).

His voice was also heard on film, including Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo (Python in the Old Dome), 1952, while he had supporting roles in Divisoria Quiapo, 1955, and Sintu-sinto (Crazy), 1955. In the films Ikaw ang Buhay Ko (You Are My Life), 1954, and Lupang Kayumanggi (Brown Land), 1955, he played the role of a singer.

In 1985, he received the Gintong Award for his achievement in Philippine music at the first Cecil Awards. Written byElizabeth L. Enriquez and Michael B. Makri

Sources: Aniceto 2007; Gerona 1956; Quirino 1955; Ruben Tagalog: King of Philippine Kundiman Song, n.d.; Wikipedia, n.d.c, n.d.f, n.d.g; Wikipilipinas, n.d.g.

TAGASA, GINA MARISSA (Ava Marissa Tagasa Garcia-Gil) aka Manay Gina. b. Manila 22 Feb 1956. Radio, film, and television scriptwriter and director. She is the daughter of radio-television writer and actor Mely Tagasa and Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage) director Maximiano Garcia. She is married to David Gil Jr with whom she has a daughter. She attended grade school and high school at Paco Catholic School until 1972 and earned the degree bachelor of arts in mass communication with honors at the Philippine Women’s University in 1975.

In 1972, Tagasa began voice-acting on radio soaps when she was 16. At the same time, she occasionally took on her mother’s radio drama scriptwriting chores at DWWW. When the scriptwriter for the daily drama program Alaala (Memory) was sick one day, Mely Tagasa asked her daughter, then 18, to write the script. The producer and director of the show liked what she wrote and her career in scriptwriting was launched. She then began writing scripts for the soaps Isagani, Batumbuhay (Living Stone), and Amor Seco (Dry Love) at DZRH while still in college. She took the first name of her grandmother Gina, her second name, and her mother’s last name as her radio name.

In the 1980s, she briefly wrote for the television soap opera Flordeluna on RPN Channel 9, directed by Mario O’Hara, under the supervision of Orlando Nadres, and for the drama anthology Connie Reyes on Camera. For 10 years, 1982-92, Tagasa wrote the scripts of the television drama show Lovingly Yours, Helen. At the same time, she wrote, the scripts for the soap opera Heredero (Heir) for three years, for the production company TAPE Inc under Tony Tuviera.

In the 1990s, she continued writing for popular television soap operas such as Aguila (Eagle) for four years and Valiente for five years, and was head writer of the shows Labs Ko si Babes (I Love Babes) and Judy Ann Drama Special of ABS-CBN.

In 1994, Tuviera sent her to the Rockport (Maine, USA) Film and Video Photographic Workshop to study basic directing and basic photography. Upon her return, she began directing television dramas, including GMA Love Stories for GMA Channel 7, and Star Studio Presents and Flames for ABS-CBN Channel 2. She transferred to GMA Network in 2002 where she worked as head writer of several drama programs, including the soap opera Ang Iibigin ay Ikaw (I Will Love You), 2002; Marinara, 2004; and Mga Mata ni Angelita (Angelita’s Eyes), 2007. For the movies, she wrote the scripts of Lovingly Yours, Helen (The Movie), 1984; Nakagapos na Puso (Shackled Heart), 1986; Kung Aagawin mo ang Lahat sa Akin (If You Will Take Everything From Me), 1987, co-written by Jose Javier Reyes and Orlando Nadres; Huwag Mong Itanong Kung Bakit (Don’t Ask Why) and Natutulog ba ang Diyos? (Is God Sleeping?), 1988; Kung Tapos Na ang Kailanman (If Forever is Finished), 1990; Kislap sa Dilim (Spark in the Dark), 1991; Moments of Love, 2006; “Ukay-Ukay” (Secondhand Apparel) episode of Shake, Rattle and Roll XI, 2009; and The Adventures of Pureza: Queen of the Riles (The Adventures of Pureza: Queen of the Railroad Tracks), 2011. She returned to ABS-CBN in 2008 where she worked as creative manager for a number of primetime drama series including Dyosa (Goddess), 2008; Nasaan Ka, Elisa? (Where are You, Elisa?), 2011-12; and Maria Mercedes, 2013.

The television soap Sa Kandungan ng Langit (Heaven’s Cradle), which she wrote and directed, won the Best Drama Feature award in the New York International Independent Film and Video Festival in 2004. Written byCynthia Cruz-Paz, with additional notes from Elmer L. Gatchalian

Sources: Mangubat 2007; Socorro 2004; Tagasa 2014.

TAGASA, MELY (Abimaela Palomo Tagasa) b. La Paz, Tarlac 16 Apr 1935. d. San Juan City, Metro Manila 24 Mar 2018. Radio, television, and film actor, writer, sound editor, and line producer. She was the daughter of Gabriel Bate Tagasa and Francisca Antonio Palomo. Her daughter Gina is a film and television writer for ABS-CBN while her Chicago-based daughter Melanie “Lani” Tagasa Montreal-Bermudez was a writer for the Philippine Daily Inquirer and is also a playwright.

She attended La Paz Elementary School in Tarlac until grade 4, then finished primary schooling at Regina Regente Elementary School in Santa Cruz, Manila, when her family moved to the city. She finished High School at Bethel Girls High School in Lope de Vega along Avenida Rizal. She took up journalism as a freshman in the University of Santo Tomas, but shifted course to education when she transferred to the Philippine Women’s University a year later.

Tagasa was 16 when she auditioned for a role in the DZBC soap Katarungan ng Isang Ina (Justice for a Mother) in 1952, where she played the role as a kontrabida (antagonist) waitress for three months. The show’s writer-producer cast her without pay for the soap and other DZBC dramas. Producer-directors Artemio Marquez and Jose Miranda Cruz then put her in DZBC’s top-rated dramas of the time, Mahal Kita Inay (I Love You Mother) and Sepulturero sa Lumang Libingan (Undertaker in the Old Cemetery), this time with pay. She was then top-billed in the highly popular primetime DZBC drama Panata ng Puso (The Heart’s Promise). The show’s success led to a role in a program Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love) on DZRH, written by Genoveva Edroza-Matute and sponsored by the Philippine Manufacturing Company (PMC), now Procter and Gamble. When it ended, she moved to DZRH where she was cast this time with pay of 120 pesos a month in one of her rare roles as a kindhearted woman in Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love) written by Genoveva Edroza-Matute. By this time, the mid-1950s, radio dramas were sweeping the nation. She was also in DZAQ’s blockbuster Hanggang Wakas (Until The End) written by Jose Miranda Cruz, where she played the role of harsh Doña Claudia opposite actor Ben David.

Her most memorable television role is as “Liwayway Gawgaw Tapia” or “Miss Tapia,” the professor of Wanbol University in the sitcom Iskul Bukol (School Bumps) on IBC Channel 13, 1977-90. Unbeknownst to many, Miss Tapia was the name of Tagasa’s character in her first television program Baltic & Co., a workplace situation comedy directed by Ricky Manalo and aired on GMA 7 from 1974 to 1976, which was based on the cartoon serial on Bulletin Today (now Manila Bulletin) created by Roni Santiago. “Miss Tapia” in Baltic & Co. was a cashier, but her iconic strictly no-nonsense character was so popular that it was reprised in Iskul Bukol, but this time as a schoolmarm. The success of the television program Iskul Bukol spun off the films Iskul Bukol: The Movie, 1978; Iskul Bukol Freshmen, 1980; The Best of Iskul Bukol: The Movie, 1987; and Iskul Bukol 20 Years After, 2008. In all she reprised her role as Miss Tapia. As a true testament to the enduring power of her Miss Tapia character, Tagasa again resurrected her role in two separate television commercials: Lucky Me Supreme Noodles, 2007, and Davies Sun and Rain Elastomeric Paint, 2013, with “Bossing” Vic Sotto of Iskul Bukol.

Tagasa appeared in supporting roles in television dramas including Lola Conching in Star Magic Presents: Abt Ur Luv (About Your Love), 2006-8, ABS-CBN Channel 2; Tiya Magda in Daisy Siete (Daisy Seven), 2003-10, GMA Channel 7; and Miling inAng Iibigin Ay Ikaw(I Will Love You), 2003, GMA Channel 7.

Tagasa wrote radio scripts, one of which Mario O’Hara turned into a screenplay, Kastilyong Buhangin (Sand Castle), 1980, starring Nora Aunor and Lito Lapid. She then wrote the stories and screenplays for the films Uhaw sa Pag-ibig (Thirsty for Love), 1984, and To Mama with Love, 1983. Her radio play Hatol ng Tadhana (Judgment of Fate) was the foundation story for the screenplay of Insiang, 1976, written by Mario O’Hara and directed by Lino Brocka. Insiang, starred Hilda Koronel in the titular role as the daughter raped by her mother’s lover set in Manila slums. It was the first Filipino feature film to be screened in the Cannes Film Festival in 1978 and is regarded as one of Brocka's best films.

She also wrote for television such as for the program Yan ang Misis Ko (That’s My Wife), starring Rosal Rosal and Ronald Remy, as well as Kristal (Crystal), starring Lani Mercado in the lead role, both aired on Banahaw Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) Channel 2. Tagasa was also the first writer for the drama anthology of Tirso Cruz III, Ngayon sa Buhay Ko (Now in My Life), which was aired on RBS Channel 7.

She was also credited as dubbing supervisor for the films Patient X, 2009; and I.T.A.L.Y. (I Trust and Love You), 2008. Tagasa was an accomplished sound editor and line producer for television programs, starting out with the Tagalized Men in Black animated series, 2007, on ABS-CBN 2 with voice actors Raymond Bagatsing as Agent J (originally voiced by Will Smith) and Dante Rivero as Agent K (originally voiced by Tommy Lee Jones). She has also line-produced teleseryes (TV series) and Koreanovelas for Alta Productions, a subsidiary of GMA Network. Written byIzzy Kay F. Castillo, with notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez, Maria Angelica D. Abad, and Kim Mae Catungal

Sources:

Aniceto 2007; Davies Paint 2013; IMDb 2015l; JayLu’s Vids 2008; Spot.ph 2015; Tagasa 2015; Wikipedia 2014g.

The show’s success led to a role in a program Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love) on DZRH, written by Genoveva Edroza-Matute and sponsored by the Philippine Manufacturing Company (PMC), now Procter and Gamble. When it ended, she moved to DZRH where she was cast this time with pay of 120 pesos a month in one of her rare roles as a kindhearted woman in Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love) written by Genoveva Edroza-Matute. By this time, the mid-1950s, radio dramas were sweeping the nation. She was also in DZAQ’s blockbuster Hanggang Wakas (Until The End) written by Jose Miranda Cruz, where she played the role of harsh Doña Claudia opposite actor Ben David.

Her most memorable television role is as “Liwayway Gawgaw Tapia” or “Miss Tapia,” the professor of Wanbol University in the sitcom Iskul Bukol (School Bumps) on IBC Channel 13, 1977-90. Unbeknownst to many, Miss Tapia was the name of Tagasa’s character in her first television program Baltic & Co., a workplace situation comedy directed by Ricky Manalo and aired on GMA 7 from 1974 to 1976, which was based on the cartoon serial on Bulletin Today (now Manila Bulletin) created by Roni Santiago. “Miss Tapia” in Baltic & Co. was a cashier, but her iconic strictly no-nonsense character was so popular that it was reprised in Iskul Bukol, but this time as a schoolmarm. The success of the television program Iskul Bukol spun off the films Iskul Bukol: The Movie, 1978; Iskul Bukol Freshmen, 1980; The Best of Iskul Bukol: The Movie, 1987; and Iskul Bukol 20 Years After, 2008. In all she reprised her role as Miss Tapia. As a true testament to the enduring power of her Miss Tapia character, Tagasa again resurrected her role in two separate television commercials: Lucky Me Supreme Noodles, 2007, and Davies Sun and Rain Elastomeric Paint, 2013, with “Bossing” Vic Sotto of Iskul Bukol.

Tagasa appeared in supporting roles in television dramas including Lola Conching in Star Magic Presents: Abt Ur Luv (About Your Love), 2006-8, ABS-CBN Channel 2; Tiya Magda in Daisy Siete (Daisy Seven), 2003-10, GMA Channel 7; and Miling inAng Iibigin Ay Ikaw(I Will Love You), 2003, GMA Channel 7.

Tagasa wrote radio scripts, one of which Mario O’Hara turned into a screenplay, Kastilyong Buhangin (Sand Castle), 1980, starring Nora Aunor and Lito Lapid. She then wrote the stories and screenplays for the films Uhaw sa Pag-ibig (Thirsty for Love), 1984, and To Mama with Love, 1983. Her radio play Hatol ng Tadhana (Judgment of Fate) was the foundation story for the screenplay of Insiang, 1976, written by Mario O’Hara and directed by Lino Brocka. Insiang, starred Hilda Koronel in the titular role as the daughter raped by her mother’s lover set in Manila slums. It was the first Filipino feature film to be screened in the Cannes Film Festival in 1978 and is regarded as one of Brocka's best films.

She also wrote for television such as for the program Yan ang Misis Ko (That’s My Wife), starring Rosal Rosal and Ronald Remy, as well as Kristal (Crystal), starring Lani Mercado in the lead role, both aired on Banahaw Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) Channel 2. Tagasa was also the first writer for the drama anthology of Tirso Cruz III, Ngayon sa Buhay Ko (Now in My Life), which was aired on RBS Channel 7.

She was also credited as dubbing supervisor for the films Patient X, 2009; and I.T.A.L.Y. (I Trust and Love You), 2008. Tagasa was an accomplished sound editor and line producer for television programs, starting out with the Tagalized Men in Black animated series, 2007, on ABS-CBN 2 with voice actors Raymond Bagatsing as Agent J (originally voiced by Will Smith) and Dante Rivero as Agent K (originally voiced by Tommy Lee Jones). She has also line-produced teleseryes (TV series) and Koreanovelas for Alta Productions, a subsidiary of GMA Network. Written byIzzy Kay F. Castillo, with notes from Elizabeth L. TITO, VIC, AND JOEY (TVJ) The comedy trio is composed of Tito Sotto (Vicente Castelo Sotto III) b. 24 Aug 1948, Vic Sotto (Marvic Valentin Castelo Sotto) b. 28 Apr 1954, and Joey de Leon (Jose Maria Ramos de Leon Jr) b. 14 Oct 1946.

When the three first got together in 1975, Tito Sotto was the vice-president for artist and repertoire of Vicor Music Corporation, Vic Sotto was a young recording artist of Vicor, and de Leon was a radio host dubbed as radio’s local version of David Cassidy. The three were cast in the gag show OK Lang (It’s OK), IBC 13, doing spoofs of hit songs. At the time, de Leon was also hosting the dance show Discorama, GMA 7. De Leon invited the brothers to join Discorama and the three popularized the segment called “Tough Hits,” a rendition of Top 40 songs with wacky lyrics by de Leon. Soon, Tito, Vic, and Joey recorded parodies of foreign hit songs in at least 10 Tough Hits albums. Their success saved Discorama from being cancelled by the network. This also led to the trio’s inclusion as cohosts in the noontime variety show Student Canteen in 1976 over GMA 7.

TVJ’s turning point was when they were cast in the sitcom Iskul Bukol (School Bumps), 1978, IBC 13, which galvanized their position as a comedy trio with nationwide following. The trio accepted the offer to host the noontime show Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!) in 1979 over RPN 9, in competition with Student Canteen, the leading noontime show at the time. Soon, Eat Bulaga!defeatedStudent Canteenin the ratings game.

To date, Eat Bulaga! is the longest-running noontime variety show in Philippine TV broadcasting, making Tito, Vic, and Joey the comedy trio with remarkable staying power despite scandals and gossip that hounded them. One of these was in 1982 with the reported rape of 14-year-old bold star, Pepsi Paloma, allegedly by Eat Bulaga! hosts Vic Sotto, de Leon, and comedian Richie D’Horsey. Paloma, with lawyer Rene Cayetano, filed a rape case against the three TV hosts that was dismissed later when the alleged perpetrators begged Paloma for forgiveness. Purportedly, the complainant dropped the charges also due to some pressure from Tito Sotto.

Tito, Vic, and Joey were likewise confronted with repeated warnings from the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board in the wake of serious complaints regarding the hosts’ toilet humor, sexual overtones in dialogue, and insulting treatment of guests and participants in the noontime show. Amazingly, TVJ weathered the scandals and controversies in the past 40 years and their resiliency as a team led to victories for the individual career of each member—Tito Sotto as a traditional politician, Vic Sotto as a bankable TV and movie star and producer, and Joey de Leon as a formidable TV host and comedian. Written byRosalie S. Matilac

Sources: Cruz 2002; Gil 2016; Rodis 2014; Tito, Vic and Joey Lines Facebook page 2017; Video 48 2009.

TOMAS, TESSIE (Teresita Laforteza Hermosa) aka Teysi T, TT, Tessie Pullin. b. Samar 31 Oct 1950. TV, movie, theater actor, writer, comedian. She is the eldest of six children of Fernando Tobalico Hermosa and Laura Dizon Laforteza aka Laura Hermosa, veteran radio talent and director. She has one child from her first marriage, Robert Martin Tomas II aka Robin Tomas, a fashion designer. Tessie is currently married to Roger S. V. Pullin, a marine biologist and musician. She finished her elementary education at Espiritu Santo Parochial School on Tayuman St, Manila, and her high school in Far Eastern University Girls High School. She started college at Far Eastern University but transferred to the University of the Philippines Diliman where she graduated cum laude with a bachelor’s degree in broadcast communication at the Institute of Mass Communication.

Tomas started her broadcast career as a nine-year-old voice talent when she used to tag along with her mother who worked in the radio station. As a young college graduate, she forayed into advertising where she created a name for herself in firms like Ace Compton and McCann Erickson. She was a member of Walanghiya Talaga, a group of advertising executives who packaged shows for the advertising circle and specialized in doing gags and spoofs of TV commercials. After a few years, she decided to heed the call of her performing roots.

She left her thriving corporate career as advertising creative director to become a stand-up comedian. She spearheaded the concept of one-woman shows, which featured different characters, both real and fictitious, which became a mirror of the times. Her humor included funny, slapstick yet intelligent commentaries on relevant social issues, taking a jab at corrupt politicians and the Filipino’s unusual and remarkable ways of living and celebrating life.

Tessie wrote most of her materials but also relied on talented writer-friends Peque Gallaga, Lore Reyes, and Enrico Santos. In her shows, she took on different characters, like Boni Buendia, the bold star; Sakura Bitsu-Bitsu, a Japanese geisha working in the Philippines; Kona’na, the barbarian; Charito Calubaquib, a social worker; Lady ’Day, princess of Leyte Gulf; Teysi Abuvaquer, an ever-pregnant housewife; Mimay Timtiman, a Saudi wife; SM ng ST Queen (Stage Mother of Sex Titillating Queen), a Filipina worker stranded in Saudi Arabia; Bunny Elsa, a Playboy rabbit; Nora Lasa, a culinary expert; Nastassia Kiski, a sex-crazed therapist; Loren, the TV reporter; and the multiple characters of the Little Red Riding Hood, the wolf, and the grandmother.

Her one-woman shows include T. Tillations, 1984, directed by Boy Abunda; followed in 1985 by Miss Margarida’s Way, All Laffs Reserved, Teysintertainment, Passion Play: A Woman Named Desire Wants You to Play with Fire, directed by Rene Hinojales, Boni Buendia: Ang Bituing Matapang (Boni Buendia: The Bold Star), directed by Peque Gallaga, and From Gags to Stitches, directed by Rene Hinojales; Komedi Tonayt (Comedy Tonight), 1988, directed by Leo Martinez; and Unclogged, 1996, directed by Ed Murillo. At the height of the anti-Marcos sentiment, Tomas created her most famous and lasting character in Meldita, 1986, directed by Kokoy Jimenez. The colorful persona is obviously a take on then First Lady Imelda Marcos. The show treated audiences “to the lurid madness that was Malacañang: her stormy relationships with Macoy and rebel child Imee, her fantasies about royalty, her obsessive-compulsive drive to make the Philippines great again.” Meldita became Manila’s longest-running theater act. It started its run at the Rizal Theater in Makati, then for a year and a half toured all over the country and in Filipino communities in Los Angeles, San Francisco, New York, and Washington in the United States. The character earned for Tomas an Aliw Award in 1986 as Best Performer and helped her land the role of Imelda Marcos in the six-hour Australian TV miniseries on the EDSA Revolt, A Dangerous Life, 1988, distributed by Home Box Office (HBO), for which she got an HBO Best Actress nomination.

She is best remembered for her TV character Amanda Pineda, which she debuted in RPN 9’s gag show Champoy, 1979-85. Amanda Pineda, modeled after GMA’s weather forecaster Amado Pineda, reports on the weather but at the same time spoofs the state of the nation under a repressive regime. She portrayed Barbara, the schizophrenic, pill-popping, and shopaholic wife of the greedy, corrupt, and lascivious congressman Anding Tengco in ABS-CBN’s weekly sitcom Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Wait for the Next Chapter), 1991-97, and Eto Na ang Susunod na Kabanata (Here Is the Next Chapter), 2001-3. She hosted ABS-CBN’s daily lifestyle talk show Teysi ng Tahanan (Tessie of the Home), 1991-97, and Teysi, 2003-4; and IBC 13’s Joey & Teysi, 2013. She co-hosted ABS-CBN’s Compañero y Compañera (Male and Female Colleagues), 1997-98. Teysi ng Tahanan was one of the 10 best programs in the 8th Gawad CCP para sa Radyo at Telebisyon in 1994.

She wrote the screenplay of Chito Roño’s Separada (Separated), 1984. Some of the important films in which she appeared are Ishmael Bernal’s Broken Marriage, 1983; Jose Javier Reyes’s Pare Ko (Hey Dude), 1995; Mark Meily’s La Visa Loca (Crazy Visa), 2005; Conni Macatuno’s Rome and Juliet, 2006; Chris Martinez’s 100 and Dante Nico Garcia’s Ploning, 2008; Gil Portes’s Two Funerals, 2010; Siegfried Barros Sanchez and Racquel Zaballero-Sanchez’s Huling Biyahe (Last Trip), 2012; and Lemuel Lorca’s Water Lemon, Cia Hermosa’s Old Skool, and Ara Chawdhury’s Miss Bulalacao, 2015. She is regularly seen on television portraying mother roles in the primetime soaps and drama anthologies of ABS-CBN and GMA Network. Written by Irma Mutuc, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

 

Sources:

Castro 2008; Inquirer.net 2007; Tomas 2013; Wikipedia 2014f.

TORRE, NESTOR U. (Nestor Angel Urbina Torre Jr) Broadcast, theater, and film critic, director, writer, actor; TV host. He graduated from Ateneo de Cagayan and pursued graduate studies in communication arts at Ateneo de Manila University. He completed a master of arts degree in radio-TV-film at Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois, and postgraduate studies at the Center for Educational Television Overseas in London on a Colombo Plan grant. TV, film, and theater actor and director Laurice Guillen is a second cousin.

Torre helped establish the Department of Speech and Drama at the University of the Philippines (UP) in the early 1960s (Cervantes 2011). He was the founding chair of the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino in 1976.

Torre is one of the few critics who have consistently reviewed broadcast media works and films through his newspaper columns over a span of nearly half a century. One of his early columns was On Television, Manila Chronicle, late 1960s. It provided critical analyses of broadcast programs and in-depth assessments of the industry. He also wrote a column called “Mmmmedia” for Woman’s Home Companion starting in 1972, then the column “Anak ng Mmmmedia” for Mr. & Ms. magazine beginning in 1975. Both talked about personalities and issues in the media. He later wrote for the Philippine Daily Inquirer (PDI) after it was founded in 1985. The Manila Chronicle, Woman’s Home Companion, Mr. & Ms., and PDI were all published by Eugenia D. Apostol. He wrote sharp-witted observations of blunders by television personalities in his column Boob-Tube Booboos, which first appeared in the 1970s in the Philippine Daily Express and Weekend, and television, film, theater reviews in his column Viewfinder in PDI since 1986.

In broadcasting, he did radio productions in the 1960s at Radio Mindanao Network (RMN) in Cagayan de Oro. After his graduate studies abroad, RMN owner Henry Canoy tapped him to direct many TV shows on IBC 13, also in the 1960s. He then worked as production manager and eventually director for the video broadcast productions of the Ateneo Educational Television in the second half of the 1960s. Torre went on to write and direct a number of shows on the pre-martial law ABS-CBN, including the talk show Two for the Road, which he eventually co-hosted with Elvira Manahan when it was revived in 1979 on GMA; the show ended when Manahan died in 1986. He directed Henrik Ibsen’s Kaaway ng Bayan (An Enemy of the People), 1970, ABS-CBN, and Pasyong Pilipino, 1975, PTV-4, an adaptation by Bienvenido Lumbera of the narrative poem by Gaspar Aquino de Belen.

In theater, Torre played the Moor in Wallace Bacon’s oral interpretation of William Shakespeare’s Othello at UP in the early 1960s. Torre played lead roles in more than 40 plays by Rolando Tinio for Teatro Pilipino. He was Konde de Rocca Marina in Carlo Goldoni’s Ang Abaniko (The Fan), 1975, Marat in Alexei Arbuzov’s Kawawang Marat (The Promise), 1976, and Jorgen Tesman in Henrik Ibsen’s Hedda Gabler, 1977. He also acted in plays directed by Zeneida Amador for Repertory Philippines, Behn Cervantes, Joey Gosengfiao, Sarah Joaquin, Tony Espejo, Bill Kane, Wallace Bacon, Jonas Sebastian, and Jimmy Asencio. Plays he directed include Anton Chekhov’s Ang Bastos (The Boor), 1981, and Reuel Aguila’s Satirika (Satire), 1982.

Theater musicals he directed include Magsimula Ka (Begin All Over Again), 1988, 2010, 2013, and 2014; Katy, 1988 and 2013. He wrote and directed Magnificat, which premiered in 1996 and has been performed since then for more than 160 times; and Cory, 2008 and 2011. He directed the musical Sino Ka Ba, Jose Rizal? (Who Are You, Jose Rizal?), 2011-12. Dinner theater works he wrote and/or directed were Close Encounters with the Third Sex, 1980; Cabaret, early 1980s; Manila Vanilla, 2011; Laugh Out Loud, 2014-15; and With Love, Pope Francis, 2015.

In film, Torre wrote the story and screenplay of the dramas Dama de Noche (Woman of the Night), 1972, and May Isang Brilyante (There Was a Diamond), 1973; the comedy Inspiration, 1972; the action movie Dateline Chicago: Arrest the Nurse Killer, 1976; and the musicals Leron, Leron Sinta, 1972, and The Super Singer, 1973. He wrote the screenplay of the fourth segment of the omnibus historical movie Dugo at Pag-ibig sa Kapirasong Lupa (Blood and Love in a Piece of Land), 1975. He directed the films Crush Ko si Sir (I Have a Crush on Sir), 1971; As Long as There’s Music, 1973, and Ang Isinilang Ko Ba’y Kasalanan? (Did I Give Birth to Sin?), 1977. He also appeared as a minor character in the film Hari sa Hari, Lahi sa Lahi (King and Emperor), 1987, directed by Eddie Romero.

He wrote and published the children’s book Calypso: The Pig That Almost Became Lechon, 2011, illustrated by Araceli Limcaco Dans.

Torre’s video broadcast productions with the Ateneo Educational Television won Best Educational Program Series in the Citizens Award for Television, 1967. His plays won at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature: first prize for No Sadder Race, 1965, And a Happy Birthday, 1967, A Second Generation, 1968, and Dialogue, 1969; and third prize for Out of Darkness, 1964, and Apparitions, 1967. He was elevated to the Hall of Fame of the Catholic Mass Media Awards, 2010, after winning three Best Entertainment Column awards for his column Viewfinder in the PDI in 2003, 2007, and 2009. He received the Anak TV Broadcasters’ Award, 2011, and the Gawad Tanglaw sa Sining ng Mass Media, 2012. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Izzy Kay F. Castillo

He directed Henrik Ibsen’s Kaaway ng Bayan (An Enemy of the People), 1970, ABS-CBN, and Pasyong Pilipino, 1975, PTV-4, an adaptation by Bienvenido Lumbera of the narrative poem by Gaspar Aquino de Belen.

In theater, Torre played the Moor in Wallace Bacon’s oral interpretation of William Shakespeare’s Othello at UP in the early 1960s. Torre played lead roles in more than 40 plays by Rolando Tinio for Teatro Pilipino. He was Konde de Rocca Marina in Carlo Goldoni’s Ang Abaniko (The Fan), 1975, Marat in Alexei Arbuzov’s Kawawang Marat (The Promise), 1976, and Jorgen Tesman in Henrik Ibsen’s Hedda Gabler, 1977. He also acted in plays directed by Zeneida Amador for Repertory Philippines, Behn Cervantes, Joey Gosengfiao, Sarah Joaquin, Tony Espejo, Bill Kane, Wallace Bacon, Jonas Sebastian, and Jimmy Asencio. Plays he directed include Anton Chekhov’s Ang Bastos (The Boor), 1981, and Reuel Aguila’s Satirika (Satire), 1982.

Theater musicals he directed include Magsimula Ka (Begin All Over Again), 1988, 2010, 2013, and 2014; Katy, 1988 and 2013. He wrote and directed Magnificat, which premiered in 1996 and has been performed since then for more than 160 times; and Cory, 2008 and 2011. He directed the musical Sino Ka Ba, Jose Rizal? (Who Are You, Jose Rizal?), 2011-12. Dinner theater works he wrote and/or directed were Close Encounters with the Third Sex, 1980; Cabaret, early 1980s; Manila Vanilla, 2011; Laugh Out Loud, 2014-15; and With Love, Pope Francis, 2015.

In film, Torre wrote the story and screenplay of the dramas Dama de Noche (Woman of the Night), 1972, and May Isang Brilyante (There Was a Diamond), 1973; the comedy Inspiration, 1972; the action movie Dateline Chicago: Arrest the Nurse Killer, 1976; and the musicals Leron, Leron Sinta, 1972, and The Super Singer, 1973. He wrote the screenplay of the fourth segment of the omnibus historical movie Dugo at Pag-ibig sa Kapirasong Lupa (Blood and Love in a Piece of Land), 1975. He directed the films Crush Ko si Sir (I Have a Crush on Sir), 1971; As Long as There’s Music, 1973, and Ang Isinilang Ko Ba’y Kasalanan? (Did I Give Birth to Sin?), 1977. He also appeared as a minor character in the film Hari sa Hari, Lahi sa Lahi (King and Emperor), 1987, directed by Eddie Romero.
He wrote and published the children’s book Calypso: The Pig That Almost Became Lechon, 2011, illustrated by Araceli Limcaco Dans.

Torre’s video broadcast productions with the Ateneo Educational Television won Best Educational Program Series in the Citizens Award for Television, 1967. His plays won at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature: first prize for No Sadder Race, 1965, And a Happy Birthday, 1967, A Second Generation, 1968, and Dialogue, 1969; and third prize for Out of Darkness, 1964, and Apparitions, 1967. He was elevated to the Hall of Fame of the Catholic Mass Media Awards, 2010, after winning three Best Entertainment Column awards for his column Viewfinder in the PDI in 2003, 2007, and 2009. He received the Anak TV Broadcasters’ Award, 2011, and the Gawad Tanglaw sa Sining ng Mass Media, 2012. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Izzy Kay F. Castillo

TRINIDAD, FRANCISCO (Francisco Dacanay Trinidad) aka Koko Trinidad. b. Manila 10 Oct 1915. d. 21 Jan 2001. Radio broadcaster, TV, movie, and theater actor, and teacher. He was one of the six children of Macario Trinidad and Teodorica Dacanay. He married Carolina Flores, aka Lina Flor, columnist, scriptwriter, bilingual fictionist, biographer, lyricist, cartoonist, actress, and teacher. Their four children include Francisco “Corky” Flores Trinidad Jr, the first Asian editorial cartoonist to be syndicated in the United States, and Noel Flores Trinidad, TV, movie, and theater actor, comedian, writer, singer, and composer.

Koko Trinidad graduated from Manila North High School in 1931. In 1949, he earned a certificate for Government Executives In-Service Training. He passed the US Veterans Administration Special Qualifying Examination in 1952. In 1968, he earned a certificate from the Philippine Executive Academy of the College of Public Administration, University of the Philippines (UP). He was a fellow of the Smith Mundt-Fulbright, US Government, in 1951 and the Colombo Plan in 1956. He was a Special Visitor of the British Government in 1959 and the Australian Government in 1963. He received a study grant from the Federal Republic of Germany in 1962.

Trinidad is considered the “Father of Philippine Broadcasting.” One of the pioneers in radio announcing in the mid-1930s, he was the first Filipino newscaster to broadcast in English. His innovation in dramatizing radio news by impersonating voices of political personalities in the 1930s was considered groundbreaking at the time. He was also the first Filipino to be appointed manager of a radio station when broadcasting in the Philippines was dominated by Americans during the American colonial period.

Trinidad’s broadcasting career started at the Far East Broadcasting Company where he served as singer, announcer, program arranger, and production coordinator in 1932-41. When Japan occupied the Philippines during World War II, he refused to work in the Japanese-controlled radio station PIAM. Instead, he and Lamberto Avellana produced and directed stage presentations at the Avenue, Lyric, and Strand theaters in 1941-45. After the war, he returned to radio and worked as producer-announcer on KZFM under the US Office of War Information in Manila beginning in 1945. He became program director of the US Information Service in Manila in 1946-47.

When the US government turned over KZFM to the Philippine government in 1946 upon the declaration of Philippine independence, Trinidad became the station’s program director and later managing director when the station grew into the nationwide network of government radio stations called the Philippine Broadcasting Service (PBS), until 1970. As managing director of PBS, Trinidad pioneered the distance learning method, or the use of radio broadcast for education purposes. He also pioneered development broadcasting by airing agricultural and cultural programs. He entered PBS into regular program exchanges with Asian countries.

Trinidad taught broadcasting at the Institute of Mass Communication (now College of Mass Communication) in the University of the Philippines Diliman in 1967-80. While teaching, he was the program director for Radio Veritas Asia International Service. He retired from teaching and Radio Veritas in 1980 but served as secretary general of the UNESCO National Commission of the Philippines in 1986-90 as well as in various capacities in national and international professional and civic organizations.

Aside from his contribution to Philippine broadcasting, his body of work includes several stage performances including Arthur Koestler’s Darkness at Noon, 1955, and Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1955. He also acted in cinema until a year before his death in 2001. Among the 22 films where he performed supporting roles were the cinema version of A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965; Madrasta (Stepmother), 1996; and Lagarista (Film Biker), 2000. He earned a nomination as Best Supporting Actor for both Madrasta and Lagarista from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences.

Trinidad received several awards and recognition, including the Radio Man of the Year from the Citizens Council for Mass Media, 1965; Hall of Fame Award, Philippine Union of Broadcasters, 1986; Natatanging Parangal, Cultural Center of the Philippines Gawad Panradyo, 1991; Ka Doroy Achievement Award, 4th KBP Golden Dove Awards; Gawad ng Pagkilala, Samahan ng mga Mamamahayag sa Radyo, Telebisyon, Pahayagan at Pelikula, 1994; Vic Silayan Lifetime Achievement Award, Film Academy of the Philippines, 1996; and CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts, 1999. Written byIrma Mutuc

Sources: Enriquez 2008b; Kahimyang.com 2011; PCCF 2014b; Trinidad-Mapa 2013; Wikipedia 2013d.

Noel Trinidad (Noel Flores Trinidad) is a theater, television, radio, and film actor, singer, and composer. He was born in Manila on 20 Aug 1941. He is one of the four children of Francisco “Koko” Trinidad and Carolina Flores aka Lina Flor. His father Francisco, considered the “Father of Philippine Broadcasting,” was a veteran TV, movie, and theater actor. His mother Carolina was an acclaimed bilingual fictionist, screenwriter, society columnist, biographer, lyricist, cartoonist, actor, and journalism teacher. Noel married Lally Laurel with whom he has three children. Acting and writing run in his family. His son Joel is a stage actor, director, writer, and producer, and his aunt Loida F. Viriña is a veteran TV scriptwriter. He studied at Ateneo de Manila from grade school to college, and graduated with a bachelor’s degree in economics in 1962. He lists as his major influences his parents as well as his first year high school teacher, Onofre Pagsanghan, and Zeneida “Bibot” Amador, the last two being recognized and respected theater trailblazers. Trinidad started as a child actor in live radio programs. Back in those days, radio programs were performed with a live audience. At his young age, he performed with veterans like the legendary comedy duo Pugo and Togo.

In 1979, he created the TV gag show Champoy, which aired on RPN 9 until 1985. It won Best Comedy Show at the Catholic Mass Media Awards twice. He acted, wrote the lyrics and music of the show’s theme song and also the intro songs for two of its very popular segments, “Walang Sisihan” (No Blaming) and “Mr. Boomboom.” On television, he played Jimmy Ongpin in the TV movie A Dangerous Life, 1987. He is also remembered for his role as the greedy, corrupt, and lascivious congressman Anding Tengco in Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Watch for the Next Chapter), 1991-97, and in his other character portrayals in ABS-CBN’s drama special Maging Akin Muli (To Be Mine Again), 2005, and the teleserye (TV series) 100 Days to Heaven, 2011, Lorenzo's Time, 2012, Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14, and Bukas na Lang Kita Mamahalin (I Will Just Love You Tomorrow), 2013. He also appeared in several episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 1991-2009, as well as in the GMA Network drama series Let the Love Begin, 2015.

Trinidad played a myriad of major roles in movies like Sinta (Beloved), 1976; Batch ’81, 1982; Gangland, 1998; Got 2 Believe, 2002; Pangarap Ko ang Ibigin Ka (It's My Dream To Love You), 2003; La Visa Loca (Crazy Visa), 2005; Miss You Like Crazy, 2010; Huling Biyahe (Last Trip), 2012; Tuhog (Skewered), 2013; and You're My Boss, 2015.

In theater, he was part of the Barangay Theater Guild with Naty Crame-Rogers, Nick Agudo, and Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana. He played Shylock in The Merchant of Venice staged in 1957 by Ateneo High School and directed by Onofre Pagsanghan. He was one of the pioneers and a former board member of Repertory Philippines in 1967 and he graced a lot of its major productions, like Lysistrata and Rashomon. He acted together with his son Joel in The Miracle Worker by the Fringe Theater of the Philippines; Rivalry: Ateneo-La Salle, The Musical, 2012-13, an original Filipino musical by the 4th Wall Theater Company; and Over the River and Into the Woods, 1999, Charlie Brown, 2013, and The Producers, 2013, for Repertory Philippines.

As a singer, he won first place in the 5th Metro Manila Popular Music Festival, 1982, with the song “Kahit La La La Pwede Na” (A La La La Would Do) which he sang with his singing and comedy partner Subas Herrero. Noel received the Lifetime Achievement Award given by the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Scholarship Foundation during its 44th Box Office Entertainment Award in 2013.  Written by Irma Mutuc

 

Sources

Trinidad, Noel. 2013. Interview by Irma Mutuc through email through the help of his friend Ms Tessie Tomas. October.

TV5 (Associated Broadcasting Company) aka ABC 5, Channel 5, Kapatid. The present TV5 Network Incorporated has its headquarters at the TV5 Media Center on Reliance St in Mandaluyong City, Metro Manila. Its transmitter tower is located near its old studio complex in Novaliches, Quezon City. TV5 used to be ABC 5 before martial law.

ABC began its television operations on 19 Jun 1960, using the call letters DZMT and the Channel 5 slot. It was first owned and operated by the Roces family, who also published the Manila Times, the leading newspaper of the country in the two decades prior to the martial law period. The letters MT in DZMT stood for Manila Times. Joaquin “Chino” Roces, the helmsman of the daily, was also the top man in DZMT. ABC used to operate from its studio along Roxas Blvd in Pasay City until it moved to a new facility on Pasong Tamo Road in Makati, near EDSA. Its first transmitter tower was located in Antipolo in Rizal Province. In order not to be mistaken for the American Broadcasting Company in the USA, the ABC management identified itself first as ABC-RTV-DZMT and eventually simply as ABC-RTV.

Both ABC and the Manila Times were shut down by Pres Ferdinand Marcos when he declared martial law in 1972. After the EDSA Revolt in 1986, ownership of the station changed several times. Roces made representations with Pres Corazon Aquino to resume broadcasting. He died in 1988, however, without seeing the reopening of the station. His son Edgardo Roces, with new investor Edward Tan, took over the task of resuming broadcast. In 1990, ABC 5 inaugurated its new studio complex and transmitter tower in San Bartolome, Novaliches, Quezon City. It began its test broadcasts in late 1991.

It returned to the air on 21 Feb 1992 as Associated Broadcasting Company (not Corporation) with the call sign DWET-TV. It also operated its radio network Dream FM Network, with its flagship station DWET 106.7 FM Manila. ABC acquired a new franchise to operate on 9 Dec 1994. In Oct 2003, ABC was acquired by a group led by businessman Antonio “Tonyboy” Cojuangco Jr, former chair of the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company (PLDT) and owner of Dream Satellite Broadcasting; Cojuangco retained its ownership of Dream FM Network, but later sold it to Ultrasonic Broadcasting System and reformatted the radio station as Energy FM Manila. In Mar 2008, Cojuangco partnered with MPB Primedia Inc, a local company of Media Prima Berhad of Malaysia. The station was relaunched in 2008 as TV5, under ABC Development Corporation, with Cojuangco as its chief executive officer. In 2009, Media Prime sold its share to PLDT’s broadcasting division, Media Quest Holdings Inc, of business tycoon Manuel V. Pangilinan aka MVP. TV5 was rebranded as the Kapatid (Sibling) network; its radio station was branded as Radyo Singko / Radyo5. In 2013, the network began broadcasting from its current headquarters in Mandaluyong. In 2015, the network’s company changed its name from ABC Development Corporation to TV5 Network Inc.

As the television station of the Manila Times, the pre-martial law ABC 5 leaned toward news, headed by Ramy Diez. Its award-winning public affairs programs were its flagship English newscast, The Big News; the Tagalog news program Flashback; the sports programs Sports Review and International News Front; the commentary program Coffee with Valencia, hosted by Teodoro Valencia; the talk show J. V. Cruz Interviews, anchored by columnist and Ramon Magsaysay administration press secretary J. V. Cruz; special programs like The Documentary on Gemma Cruz and Sanggunian: The Seven-Nation Summit Conference (Consultation: The Seven-Nation Summit Conference); and its special events coverage of the 1965 and 1967 elections. Important and also award-winning programs included the drama soap Santa Zita and Mary Rose, the music programs For Men Only and Carmen on Camera, the variety program Showtime, the children’s programs Romper Room and Lollipop Party, the commentary programs Coffee and Order and The Gemma Commentary, the talk show News of the Times, the special coverage of the Tour of Luzon, the drama anthologies Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) and Salamisim (Reflections), and the sitcom Gorio and His Jeepney. Other popular shows were The Chiquito Show hosted by comedian Chiquito, Augusto Valdez Pangan in real life, and the talk entertainment show Seeing Stars with Joe Quirino.

The post-martial law ABC 5/TV5 leaned on comedy programs, such as the gag shows Tropang Trumpo (Troop of Tops), 1994-99, Lokomoko U (You Are Kidding Me), 2008-13, and Tropa Mo Ko Unli (I Am Your Faithful Troop Member), 2013-15; the prank show Wow Mali (Oh No, It’s a Mistake), 1996; the political sketch comedy show Ispup (Spoof), 1999-2004; the reality TV-sitcom programs The Misadventures of Maverick and Ariel, 2003-5, and Mommy Elvie’s Problematic Show, 2007-8; and the pseudo-investigative news-documentary Totoo TV: Walang Kinatatakutan, Walang Kinikilingan, Walang Hiya (Real TV: Fearless News, Balanced Views, Shameless), 2005. Other important shows were the music program Celeste: Musika at Iba Pa (Celeste: Music and More), 1999-2000; the talk show Ali by Ali Sotto, 2004-6; the magazine show Real Stories … Kasama si Loren (Real Stories… With Loren), 2004-7; the dance show Shall We Dance?, 2005-10; the talent variety program Talentadong Pinoy (Talented Filipino), 2008-14; the game show Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, 2009-15; the reality talk show Face to Face, 2010-13; the documentary USI (Under Special Investigation), 2010-12; the drama series Babaeng Hampaslupa (The Rich Heiress) and Sa Ngalan ng Ina (In the Name of the Mother), 2011; the reality talent search Artista Academy, 2012; and the rescue and public service program Rescue 5, which premiered in 2013.

A milestone in the history of Philippine FM radio was the entry of Media Quest Holdings Inc, led by telecommunications mogul MVP, into FM radio on 28 Nov 2010. It was a pivotal event in broadcasting in the sense that a network migrated what is traditionally an AM format into a predominantly music-oriented FM platform. Pangilinan’s group took over the frequency 92.3 after Francis Lumen’s All-Youth Channel’s lease expired, and converted the station into 92.3 News Radio, aka Radyo Singko / Radyo5, which became the news and talk-oriented radio component of TV5 and positioned itself as “Ang Bagong Tunog ng FM” (The New Sound of FM).

Beginning in 2012, TV5 Network partnered with Cignal Digital TV for their cable and satellite television broadcasting, which included Colours, devoted to lifestyle and reality shows; Hyper, the sports and entertainment channel of TV5; and Bloomberg TV, its business news channel. TV5 archived programs are aired on Fox Filipino.

The pre-martial law ABC 5 and its programs won several Citizens Awards for Television (CAT) from 1965 to 1972, including the station with best balanced programming in 1966 and 1967. Also awarded the CAT were some of its broadcasters and artists, including Bong Lapira, Paul Lacanilao, Fred Espaldon, Jose Mari Velez, Marita Manuel, Lupita Concio, Cecil Guidote, Marlene Dauden, Gigi Calero, and Carmen Soriano. The post-martial law ABC 5 / TV5 won the Golden Dove Awards of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) for Best Station in 2005. Some of its programs, broadcasters, and artists won in the KBP Golden Dove Awards, the Star Awards of the Philippine Movie Press Club, and the Golden Screen Awards for Television of the Entertainment Press Society. Recipient of the KBP Lifetime Achievement Award was Rino Basilio in 2008. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez and Marinela M. Aseron

Sources: Aseron 2012; Manila Chronicle 1967; Manila Chronicle Entertainment Guide 1965, 1967b, 1968a; Mirror 1968; TV5 2015; Wikipedia 2015m, 2015n.

In Oct 2003, ABC was acquired by a group led by businessman Antonio “Tonyboy” Cojuangco Jr, former chair of the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company (PLDT) and owner of Dream Satellite Broadcasting; Cojuangco retained its ownership of Dream FM Network, but later sold it to Ultrasonic Broadcasting System and reformatted the radio station as Energy FM Manila. In Mar 2008, Cojuangco partnered with MPB Primedia Inc, a local company of Media Prima Berhad of Malaysia. The station was relaunched in 2008 as TV5, under ABC Development Corporation, with Cojuangco as its chief executive officer. In 2009, Media Prime sold its share to PLDT’s broadcasting division, Media Quest Holdings Inc, of business tycoon Manuel V. Pangilinan aka MVP. TV5 was rebranded as the Kapatid (Sibling) network; its radio station was branded as Radyo Singko / Radyo5. In 2013, the network began broadcasting from its current headquarters in Mandaluyong. In 2015, the network’s company changed its name from ABC Development Corporation to TV5 Network Inc.

As the television station of the Manila Times, the pre-martial law ABC 5 leaned toward news, headed by Ramy Diez. Its award-winning public affairs programs were its flagship English newscast, The Big News; the Tagalog news program Flashback; the sports programs Sports Review and International News Front; the commentary program Coffee with Valencia, hosted by Teodoro Valencia; the talk show J. V. Cruz Interviews, anchored by columnist and Ramon Magsaysay administration press secretary J. V. Cruz; special programs like The Documentary on Gemma Cruz and Sanggunian: The Seven-Nation Summit Conference (Consultation: The Seven-Nation Summit Conference); and its special events coverage of the 1965 and 1967 elections. Important and also award-winning programs included the drama soap Santa Zita and Mary Rose, the music programs For Men Only and Carmen on Camera, the variety program Showtime, the children’s programs Romper Room and Lollipop Party, the commentary programs Coffee and Order and The Gemma Commentary, the talk show News of the Times, the special coverage of the Tour of Luzon, the drama anthologies Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) and Salamisim (Reflections), and the sitcom Gorio and His Jeepney. Other popular shows were The Chiquito Show hosted by comedian Chiquito, Augusto Valdez Pangan in real life, and the talk entertainment show Seeing Stars with Joe Quirino.

The post-martial law ABC 5/TV5 leaned on comedy programs, such as the gag shows Tropang Trumpo (Troop of Tops), 1994-99, Lokomoko U (You Are Kidding Me), 2008-13, and Tropa Mo Ko Unli (I Am Your Faithful Troop Member), 2013-15; the prank show Wow Mali (Oh No, It’s a Mistake), 1996; the political sketch comedy show Ispup (Spoof), 1999-2004; the reality TV-sitcom programs The Misadventures of Maverick and Ariel, 2003-5, and Mommy Elvie’s Problematic Show, 2007-8; and the pseudo-investigative news-documentary Totoo TV: Walang Kinatatakutan, Walang Kinikilingan, Walang Hiya (Real TV: Fearless News, Balanced Views, Shameless), 2005. Other important shows were the music program Celeste: Musika at Iba Pa (Celeste: Music and More), 1999-2000; the talk show Ali by Ali Sotto, 2004-6; the magazine show Real Stories … Kasama si Loren (Real Stories… With Loren), 2004-7; the dance show Shall We Dance?, 2005-10; the talent variety program Talentadong Pinoy (Talented Filipino), 2008-14; the game show Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, 2009-15; the reality talk show Face to Face, 2010-13; the documentary USI (Under Special Investigation), 2010-12; the drama series Babaeng Hampaslupa (The Rich Heiress) and Sa Ngalan ng Ina (In the Name of the Mother), 2011; the reality talent search Artista Academy, 2012; and the rescue and public service program Rescue 5, which premiered in 2013.

A milestone in the history of Philippine FM radio was the entry of Media Quest Holdings Inc, led by telecommunications mogul MVP, into FM radio on 28 Nov 2010. It was a pivotal event in broadcasting in the sense that a network migrated what is traditionally an AM format into a predominantly music-oriented FM platform. Pangilinan’s group took over the frequency 92.3 after Francis Lumen’s All-Youth Channel’s lease expired, and converted the station into 92.3 News Radio, aka Radyo Singko / Radyo5, which became the news and talk-oriented radio component of TV5 and positioned itself as “Ang Bagong Tunog ng FM” (The New Sound of FM).

Beginning in 2012, TV5 Network partnered with Cignal Digital TV for their cable and satellite television broadcasting, which included Colours, devoted to lifestyle and reality shows; Hyper, the sports and entertainment channel of TV5; and Bloomberg TV, its business news channel. TV5 archived programs are aired on Fox Filipino.

The pre-martial law ABC 5 and its programs won several Citizens Awards for Television (CAT) from 1965 to 1972, including the station with best balanced programming in 1966 and 1967. Also awarded the CAT were some of its broadcasters and artists, including Bong Lapira, Paul Lacanilao, Fred Espaldon, Jose Mari Velez, Marita Manuel, Lupita Concio, Cecil Guidote, Marlene Dauden, Gigi Calero, and Carmen Soriano. The post-martial law ABC 5 / TV5 won the Golden Dove Awards of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) for Best Station in 2005. Some of its programs, broadcasters, and artists won in the KBP Golden Dove Awards, the Star Awards of the Philippine Movie Press Club, and the Golden Screen Awards for Television of the Entertainment Press Society. Recipient of the KBP Lifetime Achievement Award was Rino Basilio in 2008. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez and Marinela M. Aseron

UNIVERSITY OF MINDANAO BROADCASTING NETWORK (UMBN)UMBN is a commercial broadcasting company founded in 1949 by lawyer Guillermo E. Torres Sr, who also served as its first manager. The first to establish a broadcast media presence in the Davao region, it grew from radio station DXB2 of the Mindanao Colleges, one of the first to offer tertiary education in Mindanao after World War II. DXB2’s call letters changed the following year to DXMC, for Mindanao Colleges. It broadcast from the Mindanao Colleges Gymnasium initially on shortwave, then shifted to a medium wave band.

Although DXMC was established to advertise and market Mindanao Colleges, the station provided news to a community hungry for postwar information. The station then grew into a network of AM and FM stations and in 1966, when the Mindanao Colleges acquired university status and became University of Mindanao (UM), the network became UMBN.

The UMBN operates seven AM stations—namely, DXUM, broadcasting from Davao City; DXDN, Tagum City; DXDS, Digos City; DXMV, Valencia, Bukidnon; DXCM, Cotabato City; DXDV, Butuan City; and DXME, Masbate. Its AM affiliates are DXLL, Zamboanga, and DXRF, Cebu City. It also operates seven FM stations—namely, DXWT, broadcasting from Davao City; DXRT, General Santos City; DXWB, Valencia, Bukidnon; DXBB, Butuan City; DXWB, Cagayan de Oro City; DXIL, Iligan City; and DYCD, Cebu City. Its FM affiliates are DXDJ, Makati City; DXKZ, Zamboanga City; DXKB, Pagadian City; DXME, Masbate; and DYQM, Kalibo, Aklan (San Pedro 2005, 98-103). Written by Fraulein A. Oclarit and Ariel Marco T. Oclarit

Sources: Raval, n.d.; San Pedro 2005.

UNTV CHANNEL 37 UNTV Channel 37 first operated as DWAO-TV in 1999, with studios at the AIC Gold Tower in Ortigas Center, Pasig City. It branded itself as UNTV Channel 37 when it was acquired by the Progressive Broadcasting Corporation as an ultra-high frequency television channel in May 2002. The station relocated to Damayan Lagi in Quezon City in 2007, then to PhilAm Homes on EDSA in 2008, with a transmitter located on Sumulong Highway in Antipolo. UNTV has 10 stations in different regions of the country.

UNTV started as a rock music television station, a counterpart to rock radio station NU107. During its early years, it gained a cult following through the eccentric comedy program Strangebrew: Ang Show na May Tama (Strangebrew: The Show That Gives a High) by comedians Tado and Erning. Under the management of Jay Sonza beginning in 2004, the station has become the home of the religious group Ang Dating Daan of Ely Soriano, paving the way for the airing of the program Ang Dating Daan (The Former Path), which reduced the airing time of rock music videos and extended its programming to 24 hours to accommodate news and public service programs. In 2007, Daniel Razon of Breakthrough and Milestones Productions International took over the management of the station, transforming it into a full-fledged public service channel. It produced more evangelical programs of Ang Dating Daan and new programs such as My OFW Story, Justice on Air, Pulis @ Ur Serbis (Police at Your Service), Doctors on TV, and Good Morning Kuya (Good Morning, Elder Brother). Its Dunong Gulong (Knowledge on Wheels) Mobile School Project, an educational partnership between UNTV, the Ang Dating Daan Group, and the Department of Education (DepEd), offers curriculum-guided functional literacy services to out-of-school youth before they are fully integrated into the formal education system. DepEd volunteer teachers, using innovative instructional media facilities in the project’s state-of-the-art buses, are sent to pilot areas in Masbate and Quezon.

UNTV’s web counterpart received the Best Website and the People’s Choice Awards at the 10th Philippine Web Awards in 2007. Good Morning Kuya won Best Morning Show, Bitag: Live (Trap: Live) won Best Public Service Program, and Daniel Razon won Best Male Newscaster at the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards for TV in 2010. Isang Araw Lang: Drug Infomercial (One Day Only: Drug Infomercial) and Caring for the Elderly won Best TV Public Service awards at the KBP Golden Dove Awards in 2010 and 2014, respectively. Seventeen UNTV programs received the Anak TV Seal Award in 2004. Written by Jonalou S. J. Labor

Sources: UNTV 2014a, 2014b; Wikipedia 2014g.
