URBANO, JUN (Manuel Salazar Urbano Jr) aka Mr Shooli, Direk Banong. b. Manila 8 Jun 1939. Director, actor, comedian, producer, writer. He is the eldest of the seven children of Manuel Urbano Sr and Julita Salazar. Jun Urbano married Victoria Sublay with whom he has four children. His father Manuel Sr, aka Manuel Conde, a popular director, actor, and producer during his time, was proclaimed National Artist in 2014. He considers his father one of his influences as well as another iconic director, Gerardo de Leon. He took up bachelor of science in journalism at Ateneo de Manila where he graduated in 1961. He unconsciously learned his father’s trade when he took him along during the shooting, editing, and scoring of film and TV projects. He wrote scripts for his father’s Under the Guava Tree with Juan Tamad, 1962, which aired 48 episodes on IBC 13. He got news stories from the week and wrote comedy skits based on these. In spite of his exposure to the media industry, he resisted joining it and worked on the police beat of the Manila Times as a fresh college graduate. He also tried selling insurance.

He entered the advertising industry as a copywriter and then as a production assistant in video film but he did not prosper in both capacities.His first break came in the 1970s, directing a 15-seconder ad for Nescafe. After that he became one of the most productive young directors of Image Films, one of the era’s busiest production companies. From there, he started a satellite production company called Filmex, which was the advertising industry’s perennial winner of the Advertising Production House of the Year of the period. He spent 35 years in the advertising industry as a television commercial director. In the 1980s, he was one of the most sought-after television commercial directors with a number of award-winning TV commercials credited to him. The advertising Pilak Awards, which is the roster of the country’s best ads of the last 20 years, lists down some of his iconic ads: San Miguel Beer’s Isang Platitong Mani (A Saucer of Peanuts), Pepsi’s Have a Pepsi Day, and Chiclet’s Chiclet-in Mo, Baby (Chew It with a Chicklet, Baby). Other popular San Miguel TV commercials he made were Isa Pa Nga (One More, Please), Ito ang Beer (This Is the Beer), and Iba ang May Pinagsamahan (Nothing Beats Friendship). His roster of work in the advertising industry earned him an Advertising Hall of Fame Award.

When he turned 50, he decided to turn his attention to TV appearances as the popular character Mr Shooli of the TV show Mongolian Barbecue, 1990-91, on IBC 13, and 1993-95, on RPN 9. Mr Shooli, a fictional character inspired by his father’s movie characters in Genghis Khan, 1952, critically comments on various social issues. Urbano envisioned Shooli as a vehicle for social and political change through entertainment. Mr Shooli’s sidekick is Kuhol, played by Philip Supnet. Mongolian Barbecue became so popular it gave birth to two movies: Juan Tamad at Mister Shooli sa Mongolian Barbecue: The Movie (Lazy Juan and Mister Shooli in Mongolian Barbecue: The Movie), 1991, and Ang M.O.N.A.Y. (Misteyks Obda Neysyon Adres Yata) ni Mr. Shooli (Maybe Mistakes of the Nation Address of Mr Shooli), 2007. The original television version won as one of the 10 best TV programs at the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon in 1990 and 1991, and garnered three awards at the Catholic Mass Media Awards in the 1990s.

In recent years, Urbano has been spending most of his time in the speaker’s circuit as Mr Shooli. He finds joy in tickling his audience to take notice and mull over what is happening in the country. Written by Irma Mutuc

Sources: Bukisa 2014; Pelikula Atbp. 2008; Urbano 2013; Wikipedia 2013f.

URETA, ARIEL b. 5 Nov 1946. Television, radio, film actor and host, and commercial jingles composer. He has four children with wife Lydia Roa, daughter of Dado, a former disc jockey (DJ) at Manila Broadcasting Company’s DZMB, and niece of film and television actor Boots Anson-Roa. He completed a degree in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas.

Ureta started his career in the first half of the 1960s in advertising as a copy and jingle writer with McCann Erickson and the Philippine Advertising Counselors. He was a DJ on Transit Radio, DZQL 830 kHz, 1963-65, playing jazz and Broadway music. He gained national attention with a mass wedding project at the Luneta “where everything, from the wedding ensembles down to the cakes, was sponsored by the advertising agencies’ clients” (Ledesma-Aguirre 1976a, 8). It was during this period when he composed jingles for commercials, like that of Himlayang Pilipino, sung by advertising executive Emily Abrera who would later become chair of McCann. He also did stand-up comedy with the group called Walanghiya Talaga Gang, composed of advertising people like Gary Lising, Jun Urbano, Noel Trinidad, Subas Herrero, and Tessie Tomas, who packaged shows for the advertising circle and specialized in doing gags and spoofs of TV commercials.

He began to work in 1966 at ABS Channel 3 as a director of live promo girls’ spots, the only programs then that were in color. He was executive producer of ABS-CBN programs, like the variety gag show Bigay Hilig (With All One’s Gusto), 1966, that had for its main cast comedians like Teroy de Guzman, Babalu, Cachupoy, Luz Valdez, Dely Atay-atayan, and singer Bobby Gonzales; and the music variety program Nine Teeners, 1966, directed by Mitos Villareal, which also became a film in 1969. He hosted the television noontime show Ariel con Tina (Ariel with Tina), 1971, IBC 13, then 1972-74, RBS Channel 7, with co-host Tina Revilla, written by Lyca Benitez and directed by Maria Montelibano. He then worked as executive producer and writer of the noontime variety show 12 O’Clock High, 1972, ABS-CBN. When the show had trouble gelling, Ureta was advised by network executive Jimmy Navarro to join lead hosts Marilen Martinez and Tina Revilla. It was here that he displayed his talent in humor, delivering one-liner jokes. He, like Willie Nepomuceno, then started guesting in the gag show Super Laff-In, which premiered in 1970, ABS-CBN, written by Ading Fernando and starring Ramon Zamora, Tange, Balut, Maya (now Mitch) Valdez, and June Keithley.

When martial law was declared in 1972, he was part of the group called Philippine Production Center Inc, composed of Romy Jalosjos, Jimmy Navarro, Leroy Salvador, and Millie Logarta, a company created to continue shows from ABS-CBN, which was shut down by the Marcos government, to networks KBS Channel 9 and RBS Channel 7. 12 O’Clock High became Noontime Matinee when the group brought the show to RBS, now GMA. Ureta hosted Metro Magazine, mid-1970s until early 1980s, with co-host Jaime Fabregas, produced by the Metro Manila Commission, an excellent magazine that combined talk, travelogue, and mini-documentaries. An episode was broadcast daily, each on a different day and time on each of all the five Metro Manila TV channels. A show he hosted that became very popular was the daily early evening music variety talk show Ariel & Co. After Six, premiered in 1975, BBC 2, with child superstar Niño Muhlach who was then barely three years old, and with alternating women hosts like Gloria Diaz, Pilar Pilapil, Chiqui Brosas, Maureen Ava Vieira, Guada Sanchez, Lotis Key, Carmen Pateña, Gina Pareño, and Eva Reyes. The show was written by Lyca Benitez and directed by Johnny Manahan. During the show’s first year anniversary, it handed out the “God’s Gift to Television Awards,” which honored the people who have accomplished dubious achievements in television. The trophies, designed and crafted by Manahan, were crude tin cups on a base made of scrap materials. In the 1970s until the 1980s, Ureta hosted many live shows, including televised beauty pageants.

During martial law, Ureta reportedly uttered the quote “Sa ikauunlad ng bayan, bisikleta ang kailangan” (For the country to progress, bicycle is necessary), a mockery of the New Society slogan “Sa ikauunlad ng bayan, disiplina ang kailangan” (For the country to progress, discipline is necessary). He was allegedly arrested, taken to Camp Crame, and made to ride a bicycle around the camp while shouting the correct slogan. Ureta has denied, only in recent years, having made that quip.

After the EDSA Revolt, Ureta worked again at the reopened ABS-CBN as production manager and creative director, together with newscaster Frankie Evangelista, under programming head Jimmy Navarro. Ureta left ABS-CBN in 1987 for Viva Films when Freddie M. Garcia moved back from GMA to ABS-CBN. He continued to do TV hosting in the music variety show RSVP, 1991-94, GMA, with Dawn Zulueta and Ai-Ai de las Alas; the late-night talk program My Favorite Show, 2005-6, ABS-CBN News Channel; and the game show Go for It, ABC/TV5. He has been hosting the teleradyo (television-radio) variety talk program Todo-Todo Walang Preno (All Bet at Stake, Without Limit) since 2008, DZMM, with Winnie Cordero, and a segment of the daily morning show Umagang kay Ganda (Beautiful Morning) since 2012, ABS-CBN. He played a lead role in the daily comedy-drama series Dream Dad, 2014-15, ABS-CBN.

In films, he starred in two trilogy comedy films: Zoom, Zoom, Superman and Si Popeye Atbp (Popeye and Others), both in 1973 and both with each episode directed by Joey Gosengfiao, Elwood Perez, and now National Artist Ishmael Bernal. Other comedy movies in which he appeared were Jack and Poy, 1977; Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo (Partner, Participant, Partaker), 2006; Kimmy Dora: Kambal sa Kiyeme (Kimmy Dora: Twins of Nonsense), 2009; Kimmy Dora and the Temple of Kiyeme (Kimmy Dora and the Temple of Nonsense), 2012; and Of All the Things, 2012.

In all the television, radio, and live stage shows that he hosted, he wrote his own gags or ad-libbed them. As a humorist, he is fond of transliterations and spoofed everything and anything that was fashionable. “He is at home both in ‘kanto’ (pedestrian corner) humor and subtle double entendres. He can mimic a little boy lost, looking at the world with unsettling naivete. Or be the adult-innocent doing double takes. Or the smart aleck trying not to laugh at someone else’s boo-boo” (Ledesma-Aguirre 1976a, 8).

He won the Star Awards given by the Philippine Movie Press Club for Best Male TV Host for RSVP in 1992 and he and the entire cast of Umagang kay Ganda were awarded Best Morning Show Hosts in 2012 and 2014. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III

Sources: Carballo 2012a; Del Mundo 2003; Ledesma-Aguirre 1976a; Roa 2007; Rodrigo 2006; San Diego 2010; Vanzi 2001; Video 48 2009a.

He, like Willie Nepomuceno, then started guesting in the gag show Super Laff-In, which premiered in 1970, ABS-CBN, written by Ading Fernando and starring Ramon Zamora, Tange, Balut, Maya (now Mitch) Valdez, and June Keithley.

When martial law was declared in 1972, he was part of the group called Philippine Production Center Inc, composed of Romy Jalosjos, Jimmy Navarro, Leroy Salvador, and Millie Logarta, a company created to continue shows from ABS-CBN, which was shut down by the Marcos government, to networks KBS Channel 9 and RBS Channel 7. 12 O’Clock High became Noontime Matinee when the group brought the show to RBS, now GMA. Ureta hosted Metro Magazine, mid-1970s until early 1980s, with co-host Jaime Fabregas, produced by the Metro Manila Commission, an excellent magazine that combined talk, travelogue, and mini-documentaries. An episode was broadcast daily, each on a different day and time on each of all the five Metro Manila TV channels. A show he hosted that became very popular was the daily early evening music variety talk show Ariel & Co. After Six, premiered in 1975, BBC 2, with child superstar Niño Muhlach who was then barely three years old, and with alternating women hosts like Gloria Diaz, Pilar Pilapil, Chiqui Brosas, Maureen Ava Vieira, Guada Sanchez, Lotis Key, Carmen Pateña, Gina Pareño, and Eva Reyes. The show was written by Lyca Benitez and directed by Johnny Manahan. During the show’s first year anniversary, it handed out the “God’s Gift to Television Awards,” which honored the people who have accomplished dubious achievements in television. The trophies, designed and crafted by Manahan, were crude tin cups on a base made of scrap materials. In the 1970s until the 1980s, Ureta hosted many live shows, including televised beauty pageants.

During martial law, Ureta reportedly uttered the quote “Sa ikauunlad ng bayan, bisikleta ang kailangan” (For the country to progress, bicycle is necessary), a mockery of the New Society slogan “Sa ikauunlad ng bayan, disiplina ang kailangan” (For the country to progress, discipline is necessary). He was allegedly arrested, taken to Camp Crame, and made to ride a bicycle around the camp while shouting the correct slogan. Ureta has denied, only in recent years, having made that quip.

After the EDSA Revolt, Ureta worked again at the reopened ABS-CBN as production manager and creative director, together with newscaster Frankie Evangelista, under programming head Jimmy Navarro. Ureta left ABS-CBN in 1987 for Viva Films when Freddie M. Garcia moved back from GMA to ABS-CBN. He continued to do TV hosting in the music variety show RSVP, 1991-94, GMA, with Dawn Zulueta and Ai-Ai de las Alas; the late-night talk program My Favorite Show, 2005-6, ABS-CBN News Channel; and the game show Go for It, ABC/TV5. He has been hosting the teleradyo (television-radio) variety talk program Todo-Todo Walang Preno (All Bet at Stake, Without Limit) since 2008, DZMM, with Winnie Cordero, and a segment of the daily morning show Umagang kay Ganda (Beautiful Morning) since 2012, ABS-CBN. He played a lead role in the daily comedy-drama series Dream Dad, 2014-15, ABS-CBN.

In films, he starred in two trilogy comedy films: Zoom, Zoom, Superman and Si Popeye Atbp (Popeye and Others), both in 1973 and both with each episode directed by Joey Gosengfiao, Elwood Perez, and now National Artist Ishmael Bernal. Other comedy movies in which he appeared were Jack and Poy, 1977; Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo (Partner, Participant, Partaker), 2006; Kimmy Dora: Kambal sa Kiyeme (Kimmy Dora: Twins of Nonsense), 2009; Kimmy Dora and the Temple of Kiyeme (Kimmy Dora and the Temple of Nonsense), 2012; and Of All the Things, 2012.

In all the television, radio, and live stage shows that he hosted, he wrote his own gags or ad-libbed them. As a humorist, he is fond of transliterations and spoofed everything and anything that was fashionable. “He is at home both in ‘kanto’ (pedestrian corner) humor and subtle double entendres. He can mimic a little boy lost, looking at the world with unsettling naivete. Or be the adult-innocent doing double takes. Or the smart aleck trying not to laugh at someone else’s boo-boo” (Ledesma-Aguirre 1976a, 8).

He won the Star Awards given by the Philippine Movie Press Club for Best Male TV Host for RSVP in 1992 and he and the entire cast of Umagang kay Ganda were awarded Best Morning Show Hosts in 2012 and 2014. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III
Sources: Carballo 2012a; Del Mundo 2003; Ledesma-Aguirre 1976a; Roa 2007; Rodrigo 2006; San Diego 2010; Vanzi 2001; Video 48 2009a.

VALDELLON, NESSA (Ianessa Soncuya Valdellon Balderas) b. Makati, Metro Manila 14 Jan 1973. Producer, broadcast executive, program manager. She is the second of three children of Vicente Romero Valdellon Jr and Conchita Soncuya Valdellon. She is married to Gil Balderas with whom she has a son. She finished her elementary and high school education at St Theresa’s College in Quezon City in 1989. She graduated with a degree in interdisciplinary studies, major in history and communication, at Ateneo de Manila University in 1993.

 

Valdellon’s career in media began in 1993 with the weekly investigative news program The Probe Team, GMA. She produced stories for hosts Cheche Lazaro and Luchi Cruz-Valdes for four years before taking over from Marga Ortigas and Ruben Canlas Jr as the show’s executive producer in 1997. Valdellon helmed the show for another four years before joining GMA as program manager for a number of news and public affairs programs. She became GMA’s vice president for public affairs in 2005.

 

She pioneered reality TV for GMA, where she produced the weekly wish-giving program Wish Ko Lang! (Just My Wish!), premiered in 2002; the daily reality program Extra Challenge, 2003-6; and the first season of the top-rating daily program Survivor Philippines, started in 2008. She produced the groundbreaking but short-lived first gay and lesbian rights program on Philippine television, Out!, 2004. ?In 2010, Valdellon was given the task to completely revamp GMA’s free-to-air sister channel, QTV 11, which her team reprogrammed and launched as GMA News TV, GMA’s all-news and public affairs channel, in 2011. As head of the new station, she led the production of documentary shows Reel Time and Front Row, and conceptualized, together with colleague Sheila Paras, the channel’s flagship news program, State of the Nation with Jessica Soho. In 2013, she created politically relevant teleseryes (TV series): Bayan Ko (My Country aka The Politician), directed by Adolf Alix Jr, a six-part drama about a young, idealistic, and principled politician who confronts his town’s social ills, such as patronage politics, government corruption and anomalies, gambling, poor social services, improprieties of government employees, and environmental destruction; Titser (Teacher), a 10-part drama she co-wrote with the teleserye’s director Alvin Yapan, which examines the state of public education in the Philippines; and Katipunan (Brotherhood), an eight-part historical docudrama written by Ian Victoriano and directed by King Marc Baco, about the struggles of the KKK or the Kataastaasang, Kagalang-galangang Katipunan ng mga Anak ng Bayan, the clandestine society founded by national hero Andres Bonifacio that waged the revolution against the Spanish colonization of the country at the close of the 19th century. Important projects in 2014 included the period drama Ilustrado (Educated Native), about national hero Jose Rizal’s enlightenment in his travels abroad; Sa Puso ni Dok (In the Heart of the Doctor), a medical drama about the state of public health in the country; and Cine Totoo: The First Philippine International Documentary Film Festival, a competition that awards grants to documentary filmmakers to produce their dream projects for airing in the station. The programs that Valdellon produced won several awards. Survivor Philippines won the PMPC Star Awards in 2009 and the Golden Screen Awards for TV by the Entertainment Press Society in 2011 and 2013. Reel Time won the George Foster Peabody Awards, the UNICEF Asia-Pacific Child Rights Awards for Broadcasting, a World Silver Medal in the New York Festivals, and the Ani ng Dangal Awards from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, all in 2013. Front Row won two World Silver Medals in the New York Festivals in 2012. State of the Nation with Jessica Soho won a World Silver Medal in 2013. Bayan Ko received the 12th Quill Award for Excellence from the International Business Communicators Philippines, and the Best Drama Series trophy from the Catholic Mass Media Awards, and was cited for Outstanding Achievement in the Broadcast Media at the 8thHildegarde Awards for Women in Media and Communications by the St Scholastica’s College in Manila, all in 2013. Bayan Ko also won Most Inspiring Drama at the 2014 Asia Rainbow TV Awards. Titser was cited for Outstanding Achievement in the Broadcast Media at the 8thHildegarde Awards for Women in Media and Communications in 2013 and for Best Drama in the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 2014. Written by Daphne-Tatiana T. Canlas, with notes from Ma. Criselda C. Sto. Domingo

 

Sources: GMA News Online 2013a; IMDbPro 2014; Manila Bulletin 2014b; PEP 2011a; Philstar.com 2013b.

Eula Valdez (Julia Amorsolo Valdez) is a television, film, and theater actor. She was born in Manila on 11 Dec 1968. She is the daughter of Estanislao Fermin Valdes and Gracia Amorsolo, daughter of National Artist for visual arts Fernando Amorsolo. She finished college at the University of Santo Tomas Faculty of Arts and Letters. She has two children with her former husband, actor Ronnie Quizon.

Valdez first appeared in the movie Dugong Buhay (Lifeblood), 1983, but only started to make a mark in the teen-oriented movie Bagets (The Young Ones), 1984. After playing mostly supporting roles in movies, she shifted to acting in television dramas. Her early teleseryes include Marinella, 1999, where she starred as Bebeng, and Mula Sa Puso (From the Heart), 1999. However, it was the hit teleserye Pangako Sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000, that popularized her due to her role as the antiheroine Amor Powers, alongside Kristine Hermosa, Jericho Rosales, and Jean Garcia. For this, she won the PMPC Star Awards for Television’s Best Actress in a Drama Series in 2001. She then went on to star in more teleseryes in ABS-CBN such as Darating Ang Umaga (Morning Will Come), 2003; Kampanerang Kuba (Hunchbacked Lady Bell Ringer), 2005; and Maria Flordeluna, 2007, as well as in GMA Network shows such as Kamandag (Venom), 2007; La Lola, 2008; All About Eve, 2009; and The Last Prince and Koreana (The Korean Lady), 2010. In 2011, she did a comeback role in ABS-CBN’s remake of the 1999 hit soap opera Mula sa Puso (From the Heart) as Selina Pereira-Matias (played by Princess Punzalan in the original version). As a contract artist of ABS-CBN, she became part of more shows like Mundo Man ay Magunaw (Even If the World Ends), 2012, and the hit series Walang Hanggan (My Eternal), 2012, before appearing again in GMA Network shows such as Ilustrado (The Enlightened), 2014, The Half Sisters and Princess in the Palace, 2015. Aside from soap operas, she has appeared in numerous episodes of ABS-CBN long-running drama anthology, Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), as well as GMA Network's Magpakailanman (Forever).

In 2006, Valdez played the role of the main heroine in the stage musical Zsazsa Zaturnnah: Ze Muzikal, based on the graphic novel by Carlo Vergara. For her performance, she won Best Stage Actress at the 19th Aliw Awards. The musical had been restaged several times by Tanghalang Pilipino until 2011 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Some of the films she appeared in include Sana Maulit Muli (Second Chances), 1995; Madrasta (Stepmother), 1996; Mula sa Puso: The Movie, 1999; Working Girls and Rosario, 2010; and Born to Love You and Si Agimat, Si Enteng Kabisote at Si Ako (Agimat, Enteng Kabisote, and Me), 2012. She also starred in Dagitab (Sparks), 2014, written and directed by Giancarlo Abrahan, and shown during the 2014 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. Her performance for that film won for her the Best Actress award from Cinemalaya (New Breed Category), the Young Critics Circle Best Performance award in 2015, and the 38th Gawad Urian Best Actress in 2015 from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino.  Written by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

VELA, HELEN (Helen Perez Vela Punzalan) b. Manila 31 Oct 1946. d. Rochester, Minnesota, USA 14 Feb 1992. Radio and television host, and film actor. She was the daughter of Florencio Vela and Virginia Perez. She was married to Orlando Punzalan, also a broadcaster, with whom she had three children, one of whom is television and film actor Princess Punzalan. She attended the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in the early 1960s, as an education major.

While in college she joined a comedy talent contest on Student Canteen, a noontime variety show, where she won the monthly title. The host, Eddie Ilarde, encouraged her to become a radio announcer, so she auditioned at DZRM in 1963 and began a career in broadcasting. She first played characters in radio comedies. In 1965, she also started writing radio drama scripts. In 1966, coached by station manager Ben Aniceto, she became one of the first female announcers to deliver the news. It was a time when news was expected to be delivered by men, and the audience was not ready to have female voices delivering the news, so the experiment was short-lived. In 1975, she moved to DWKW, and then transitioned to television in the mid-1970s.

Vela became a staple on live shows and dramas as host and narrator. She became Ate Helen to her audiences when she dominated the Sunday afternoon television block with Lovingly Yours, Helen, a drama series based on stories sent by viewers, aired in 1980-92 on GMA Channel 7. She hosted the public service program Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love My Fellowman), which also aired on Channel 7 in 1975-85. She hosted variety shows, including Student Canteen, in the same channel, 1975-85, and Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!), first on RPN Channel 9, later on ABS-CBN Channel 2, 1986-91. She acted in the dramas Heredero (Heir) on Channel 9, 1984-87, and Agila (Eagle) first on Channel 9, then on Channel 2, 1987-92. With Family 3 + 1 on Channel 7, 1989-92, she was back in comedy. With more women in the news anchor panel by this time, Vela also anchored GMA Balita (GMA News), 1986-1992.

In 1984, Lovingly Yours, Helen: The Movie was made. She also appeared in the films Roman Rapido (Quick-on-the-Draw Roman) in 1983, Puso sa Puso (Heart to Heart) in 1988, and Kung Tapos Na ang Kailanman (If Forever Is Finished) in 1990.

In 2004, the Golden Screen Awards honored Helen for her contributions in broadcasting through the institutionalization of the Helen Vela Lifetime Achievement Award. It is given to television personalities who have given significant contributions to the industry. Written byKim Mae B. Catungal

Sources: Aniceto 2007; Francisco 2003; IMDb 2015i; Sal 2015; Umbao 2014.

VICTORIANO, IAN (Jose Francisco Belinario Victoriano) b. San Juan, Manila 17 Aug 1965. Writer, visual artist. He is one of seven children of Isagani E. Victoriano and Antonia T. Belinario. He is married to Marie Melanie F. Manlogon with whom he has two children. In 1982, he finished his secondary school at the Philippine High School for the Arts, majoring in the visual arts, at Mount Makiling, Los Baños, Laguna. It was here that he met artists like the brothers Raymond and Jon Red with whom he would later work in film and TV productions. He took up fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, 1981-82, but shifted and finished instead a bachelor’s degree in journalism, also at UP, from 1982 to 1987. He is one of the founding members of the fictionist groups Katha and Naratibo.

 

He was a fellow in the 1988 UP National Writers Workshop. Victoriano’s first exposure to production work was during the early 1980s when he wrote, acted, co-directed, co-edited, and co-produced Super 8 mm short films Kabaka (Enemy), 1983, and Kamada (State of Being), 1984. In 1997, Raymond Red, with Victoriano as scriptwriter, remade Kamada, a film intended for television which focused on the life of the late musician Francis Magalona aka Francis M. In 1992, he made his 16 mm short film Bisperas (Eve). He wrote the screenplay of Raymond Red’s first full-length feature film, Sakay, 1993, about Filipino hero Macario Sakay.

 

Victoriano’s first job on television was as a researcher for the PTV 4 documentary, Rehimen: 20 Taon ni Marcos (Regime: 20 Years of Marcos), 1987. His first breakthrough in scriptwriting for television was for PTV’s documentary magazine program For Art’s Sake, 1988. He played a role in Alab ng Lahi (Fire of the Race), 2003, RPN 9, a Marcos biopic directed by Dindo Angeles and written by Pete Lacaba. He also wrote scripts for documentary films commissioned by nongovernment organizations and government agencies like the Department of Natural Resources, the Department of Health, and the Japan International Cooperation Agency.

 

His succeeding scriptwriting works for television focused on children’s educational programs produced by the ABS-CBN Foundation, such as the instructional program Mathtinik (Math Wiz), 1997-2000; the school-on-the-air program Sineskwela (School on Air), 1995-2000; the drama series about Philippine heroes Bayani (Hero), 2000; the drama-fantasy series Hiraya Manawari (Reaching One’s Dreams), 2002; the Mindanao peace advocacy program Salam (Peace), 2006-7, co-produced with Knowledge Channel; and the nutrition program Why Not?, 2010-13, co-produced by the National Nutrition Institute. He wrote programs about history, like Kasaysayan TV (History TV), 2001, Sky Foundation, and Katipunan, a TV drama series about the life of Philippine hero Andres Bonifacio, 2013, GMA. Victoriano has been able to bring in the sensibilities and aesthetics of independent filmmaking in his works on television. An example is how his approach in writing history employs the perspective of an ordinary individual rather than the point of view of heroes and the elite. His narratives also focus on the typical everyday lives of these small folks as they negotiate the localized dilemmas of a country undergoing profound historical changes. His scripts also reinvent so-called myths through which he examines the truths of Philippine society’s histories.

 

Victoriano’s short stories were published in Engkwentro: Kalipunan ng mga Akda ng Kabataang Manunulat (Encounter: An Anthology of Fiction by Young Writers), 1990, and Impetu (Impetus), 1991. Selected exhibitions in which his art works have been featured include Mga Senyas Kamay at Iba Pang Kuwentong Buhay (Hand Signals and Other Life Stories), 1987; Alas Onse y Media (Half Past Eleven), 1997; Biyaheng Makiling (Makiling Journey), 1998; Veinte (Twenty), 2001; Pito-Pito (Quickie), 2001-2; Tribute to the Horse, 2002; Recent Works 1, 2002; and his solo exhibition of paintings, Anak ni Taumariu, 2003.

 

The short films that he wrote for Raymond Red, Kabaka and Kamada, won second and first prizes in the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines short film competition in 1983 and 1984, respectively. Both films were also among the 25 Best Short Films in the Philippines in the First Quezon City International Short Film and Video Festival in 1986. Kamada won Best TV Special at the KBP Golden Dove Awards in 1997 and Best Dramatic Feature at the Southeast Asian Television Awards in Singapore in 1997. Written by Mae Urtal Caralde and Eulalio R. Guieb III

 

Sources: Kulay Diwa 2014; Victoriano 2014.

Victoriano’s first exposure to production work was during the early 1980s when he wrote, acted, co-directed, co-edited, and co-produced Super 8 mm short films Kabaka (Enemy), 1983, and Kamada (State of Being), 1984. In 1997, Raymond Red, with Victoriano as scriptwriter, remade Kamada, a film intended for television which focused on the life of the late musician Francis Magalona aka Francis M. In 1992, he made his 16 mm short film Bisperas (Eve). He wrote the screenplay of Raymond Red’s first full-length feature film, Sakay, 1993, about Filipino hero Macario Sakay.

Victoriano’s first job on television was as a researcher for the PTV 4 documentary, Rehimen: 20 Taon ni Marcos (Regime: 20 Years of Marcos), 1987. His first breakthrough in scriptwriting for television was for PTV’s documentary magazine program For Art’s Sake, 1988. He played a role in Alab ng Lahi (Fire of the Race), 2003, RPN 9, a Marcos biopic directed by Dindo Angeles and written by Pete Lacaba. He also wrote scripts for documentary films commissioned by nongovernment organizations and government agencies like the Department of Natural Resources, the Department of Health, and the Japan International Cooperation Agency.

His succeeding scriptwriting works for television focused on children’s educational programs produced by the ABS-CBN Foundation, such as the instructional program Mathtinik (Math Wiz), 1997-2000; the school-on-the-air program Sineskwela (School on Air), 1995-2000; the drama series about Philippine heroes Bayani (Hero), 2000; the drama-fantasy series Hiraya Manawari (Reaching One’s Dreams), 2002; the Mindanao peace advocacy program Salam (Peace), 2006-7, co-produced with Knowledge Channel; and the nutrition program Why Not?, 2010-13, co-produced by the National Nutrition Institute. He wrote programs about history, like Kasaysayan TV (History TV), 2001, Sky Foundation, and Katipunan, a TV drama series about the life of Philippine hero Andres Bonifacio, 2013, GMA. Victoriano has been able to bring in the sensibilities and aesthetics of independent filmmaking in his works on television. An example is how his approach in writing history employs the perspective of an ordinary individual rather than the point of view of heroes and the elite. His narratives also focus on the typical everyday lives of these small folks as they negotiate the localized dilemmas of a country undergoing profound historical changes. His scripts also reinvent so-called myths through which he examines the truths of Philippine society’s histories.

Victoriano’s short stories were published in Engkwentro: Kalipunan ng mga Akda ng Kabataang Manunulat (Encounter: An Anthology of Fiction by Young Writers), 1990, and Impetu (Impetus), 1991. Both films were also among the 25 Best Short Films in the Philippines in the First Quezon City International Short Film and Video Festival in 1986. Kamada won Best TV Special at the KBP Golden Dove Awards in 1997 and Best Dramatic Feature at the Southeast Asian Television Awards in Singapore in 1997. Written by Mae Urtal Caralde and Eulalio R. Guieb III

VILLAREAL, MITOS d. 1995. Television, film director. She studied TV production at Columbia College, an institution subsidized by the top TV networks of the United States of America, like NBC, ABC, and CBS.

She dropped out of school when she felt she had learned enough of television work, and worked as an assistant newscast director in a Hollywood TV station. She returned to the Philippines in 1958 to be at her sick father’s bedside. She directed the game show Guess My Living, 1958, DZAQ-TV Channel 5, but retired immediately from TV when she found the local TV scene not challenging enough. She ran a music lounge called Embers Club, where she also occasionally sang. She returned to TV when she was offered to direct the music variety show An Evening with Pilita, later changed to Your Evening with Pilita, 1964-71, ABS Channel 3, starring Pilita Corrales. At the heart of this program was Corrales’s performance with the singing group Lemons Three, composed of Nikki Ross, Angie Yoingco, and director Villareal herself, who performed serious and comedy songs in the show. The Lemons Three would be known as the Wing Duo when Villareal left the group to focus on her TV directing. She directed other popular music variety shows on ABS-CBN Channel 3, including The Nida-Nestor Show, 1965-72, starring Nida Blanca and Nestor de Villa; episodes of Stop, Look, and Listen, 1968-70, featuring Jeanne Young, alternating with directors Maria Montelibano, Raul Silos, and Heidi Sison; That Young Image, late 1960s, also with Young, and production design by Fiel Zabat; and This Girl Pilar, 1970, featuring then newly crowned Miss Philippines Pilar Pilapil. She again directed Young in another music variety show, Fantastic Jeanne in Motion, 1970-72, Channel 4.

While busy with musicals, she also went into drama. She directed and did the production design of the weekly drama anthology Salamisim (Reflections), 1966-68, ABC 5, starring Marlene Dauden. ABS-CBN acquired Salamisim (Reflections) from ABC 5 and renamed it Panagimpan (Dream), which started airing on ABS Channel 3 on Oct 1968 and ran until 1972. In 1968, Salamisim was adapted into film with the same.

Villareal explored the medium of television to the fullest, especially in editing, lighting, and production design. In An Evening with Pilita, she experimented on editing with the split-screen image of the “Three Pilitas”—a Visayan Pilita, an English Pilita, and a Spanish Pilita—each speaking to one another, an editing technique first seen on local television. When color TV was introduced in 1969, she was one of the first to meticulously play with the color schemes of the design of the studio and the wardrobe and makeup of the artists in her programs (Rodrigo 2006). In That Young Image, she extensively played with the then newly introduced electronic image imposition device called the chroma key.

The minimalist and sometimes lavish sets, novel lighting, surprising editing techniques, Villareal’s music variety programs on television became synonymous with elegance “in which the music and the songs were the stars” (Sioson-San Juan 1999, 132).

From 1973 until the late 1990s, Villareal continued to direct television shows of different genres: the revived music variety program Fantastik Jeanne in Motion, later retitled The Jeanne Young Show, RPN 9, again with Jeanne Young; the drama anthology Dulambuhay ni Rosa Vilma (Life Story of Rosa Vilma), BBC 2, starring Vilma Santos; the limited-run drama anthology Phillip, BBC 2, starring Phillip Salvador; the dance program Discorama, GMA, with Bobby Ledesma and the Apo Hiking Society, which introduced Loren Legarda and the comedy trio Tito, Vic, and Joey; the cooking show Cooking It Up with Nora, GMA, with Nora Daza; Aawitan Kita (I Shall Sing for You), RPN 9, by Armida Siguion-Reyna; a few beauty pageants; and live coverage of special events of then president Ferdinand Marcos as part of a contract she had with the government-owned National Media Production Center. Villareal directed again An Evening with Pilita as a one-airing special on 7 Oct 1977 on GMA. She also directed corporate productions during the martial law period.

In film, she directed in 1969 the teen musicals 9 Teeners, with a cast led by Rosemarie Sonora, Bert Leroy Jr, Ricky Belmonte, Jeanne Young, Nova Villa, and Nora Aunor; Boom! Bang-a-bang!, also with Young, Boots Anson-Roa, Roger Calvin, and Ed Finlan; Young Girl, again with Young, Belmonte, Villa, and Aunor; and Stop, Look, Listen, featuring Young, Leroy, Villa, Pepito Rodriguez, and Blanca Gomez. Other films she directed were the comedy Petrang Paminta (Petra Pepper), 1969, starring Young, Rodriguez, and Eddie Miller; the movie drama Siya’y Umalis, Siya’y Dumating (She Left, She Came), 1975, written by Orlando Nadres, starring Marlene Dauden, Nestor de Villa, and Pinky de Leon; and the melodrama Bukas, Sisikat Din ang Araw (Tomorrow the Sun Shall Rise Again), 1988, starring Vilma Santos, Gabby Concepcion, and Snooky Serna.

Villareal covered the millions of Filipinos who went out to join the Ninoy Aquino funeral procession on the streets of Manila on 31 Aug 1983. A video shot of the event, running only a few seconds, was aired on GMA. During the EDSA Revolt in 1986, Villareal hired a helicopter and took the aerial footage of the million-strong crowd on EDSA, which was aired on the government station Channel 4 when it was recaptured by the rebel forces and the civilians. She also covered the inauguration of Corazon Aquino as the new president of the country on 24 Feb 1986. These moving images have since then been included in many documentaries that would be produced and shown on several local and international television programs during the early years of the administration of Aquino.

Villareal won the Citizens Awards for Television for artistry in production for An Evening with Pilita in 1964; and as Best Director for An Evening with Pilita in 1966, 1967, and 1970, for The Nida-Nestor Show in 1965, for Salamisim in 1968, and for That Young Image in 1971. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III

Sources:

Encantada 1967; IMDb 2017; Manila Chronicle Entertainment Guide 1967a, 1968a; Mirror 1968; Rodrigo 2006; Sioson-San Juan 1999; Video 48 2008a; Yero 1976a

text:
VILLEGAS, ALEJANDRO aka Andoy Balun-balunan. b. 1909. d. 1944. Bodabil performer, radio broadcaster, comedian, recording artist, stage and movie actor. In 1934, Villegas married fellow comedian and radio personality Adelaida Fernando aka Dely Atay-atayan. They had one child, Alfonso, a dancer, whose three daughters became actors, while a grandson, Manuel Villegas Quizon II, is an actor-singer.

Villegas and Fernando were partners in bodabil, performing at local events such as fiestas and functions, including the 1939 Binibining Liwayway of the popular Liwayway magazine. They were both members of the Radio Variety Revue Company that performed at the Palace Theatre in Santa Cruz, Manila. They were a stage comedy-dancing team before becoming a radio singing comic duo in the early 1930s on KZIB, where they earned the monikers Andoy Balun-balunan and Dely Atay-atayan, respectively. Balun-balunan is Tagalog for chicken gizzard while atay is liver, hence the duo’s theme song “Awit ng Manok” (Song of the Chicken). On 21 Jan 1940, Villegas hosted a song and poetry competition sponsored by the Hermoso Drug Store on KZIB in line with the celebration of the feast of the Santo Niño in Tondo, Manila. He soon produced several radio shows as a blocktimer. On KZRF, Villegas produced the San Miguel Brewery Hour, which aired at 7:00-8:00 pm on Fridays. University of the Air was a variety show that used both Tagalog and English. It included Tagalog comic skits. He also produced a Tagalog drama with Hermoso Drug Store as sponsor.

The inseparable Villegas-Fernando pair was the biggest earner of all prewar blocktimers, earning more than a thousand pesos a month, a handsome amount in the 1930s when a regular employee earned a monthly salary of around 25 pesos. Radio veterans consider the couple as the pioneers of singing commercials on radio, the most popular of which included Kiko Baterya (Kiko Battery) and Alviz Tailoring. Their programs included a Saturday evening program at KZRF where they played husband and wife. Their routine later included a new character, a daughter, played by Chichay. Dely Magpayo, whom colleagues and fans later called “First Lady of Philippine Radio,” credits Villegas for launching her career as a radio announcer when she joined the duo as a group singer. Villegas made Magpayo read commercials and introduce musical numbers.

Villegas and Fernando starred in several drama films including Lakambini (Muse), 1938, produced by Cervantina Filipina Corporation; and Nag-iisang Sangla (The Only Pawn) by LVN Productions and Libingang Bakal (Iron Grave), both in 1940. Some of the more popular songs they recorded were “Cadete” (Cadet) and “Alila” (Slave). “Cadete” is a novelty song with comic banter estimated to have been recorded circa 1940 or earlier as it mentioned the Second Sino-Japanese War, which lasted from 1937 to 1945. “Alila” is a metaphor for the country’s condition under colonial rule. The song begins with a comic exchange between Villegas and Fernando and ends with a Tagalog kundiman (love song) finale delivered by Fernando.

The couple’s command of the airwaves was cut by the Japanese occupation. Villegas refused to join the Japanese propaganda effort and refrained from performing. He died in 1944 at the age of 35, before the war ended. Written byDivine Marie Joanne P. Endriga

text:
VIRIÑA, LOIDA (Loida Chanco Flores Viriña) b. Caloocan City 3 Feb 1931. d. Manila 13 May 2019. Radio-television-movie scriptwriter, radio drama actor. She was the daughter of Fernando Palma Flores and Silvina R. Chanco and sister of Lina Flor, columnist, scriptwriter, bilingual fictionist, biographer, lyricist, cartoonist, actor, and teacher. She was married to the late Benjamin Irlanda Viriña, with whom she had six children. She attended Caloocan Elementary School and Caloocan High School. She earned a bachelor’s degree in literature and journalism, cum laude, from the University of Santos Tomas in 1953.

 

Her voice was heard a few times on Lina Flor’s program Si Aling Juanang Mapag-impok (The Thrifty Madam Juana) when she was seven, but she began dramatic acting in radio dramas on DZRH at 18 and while in college, and is best remembered for her role as Luisa in Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), 1949-56. However, it is as a prolific scriptwriter that Viriña is noted. She wrote dozens of scripts and at times directed soaps, variety shows, and sitcoms for radio and television as well as movie screenplays.

 

In 1956-67, she wrote the scripts for ABS-CBN’s DZXL productions of the soap Eskinita (Lane), the musical comedies Boarding House and Darigold Jumbo Jamboree, and the game show Linggo ang Bola (Draw on Sunday). At the same time she served as publicist of LVN Pictures and its sister company Dalisay Pictures, for which she wrote and directed the radio variety show Fiesta ng LVN (Feast at LVN) and wrote the screenplays Masusunod o Hindi (To Be Obeyed or Not) and Doon Po sa Amin (In Our Place).

 

Viriña wrote for ABS-CBN Channel 3 and ABC Channel 5 The Charito Solis Show and the sitcoms Ang Honey Ko Naman (Oh, My Honey), Gloria-Luis Show, Si Tatang Kasi (Blame It on Father), Ginang Milyonarya (Madam Millionaire), Kikong Mapangarap (Kiko the Dreamer), and My Family Three, 1968-72. During this period she wrote the screenplays Tararadying Potpot (a playful verbal play in Tagalog), Somewhere over the Rainbow, Haw-Haw di Karabao (a playful verbal play based on a child’s ditty), Hotdog, Tatlong Mukha ng Pag-ibig (Three Faces of Love), Jack and Jill sa Amerika (Jack and Jill in America), Pic Pac Boom, Bagsik at Kamandag ni Pedro Penduko (Ferocity and Venom of Pedro Penduko), and Gulong ng Buhay (Wheel of Life) for Lea Productions, Regal Films, Viva Films, and Topaz Films.

 

In 1972-74, she wrote the scripts for GMA Network’s DZBB production of the soap opera My Little Angel, and the government station Channel 4’s sitcom of Naku Po, Tatang (Oh, No, Father). In 1975, she served as script supervisor for the television series Sangandaan (Crossroads) and Lino Brocka Presents. She joined the government as media specialist of the Department of Public Information, 1976-78, while scripting for IBC Channel 13’s Habang May Buhay (As Long as There’s Life).

 

In 1978-2012, she scripted GMA 7’s Baltic & Co.; RPN 9’s Andrea-Amor, Flordeluna, and the television version of Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate); IBC Channel 13’s Si Mahal Nakialam Na Naman (My Honey Meddled Again), Mommy Ko si Tita (My Aunt is My Mother), and Sang Yugto (One Episode); the government station Channel 4’s Naku Po, Tatang (Oh No, Father); ABS-CBN’s Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad), Home along da Airport (Home along the Airport), Onli in da Pilipins (Only in the Philippines), Oki Doki Dok (Okay, Doc), Pwedeng-Pwede (Can Do), Kaya ni Mister, Kaya ni Misis (What a Man Can Do, a Woman Can Do), Da Pilya and da Pilot (The Naughty Girl and the Pilot). During this period she served as ABS-CBN’s creative consultant for the sitcoms OK, Fine, Whatever and Dots My Doc and creative consultant for the dramas Gulong ng Palad 2 (Wheel of Fate 2) and Maria Flordeluna. At the same time, she wrote the screenplays War Kami ng Misis Ko (My Wife and I Are at War), Wanted: Perfect Father, Hataw (Beat), Home Sic Home, Home along da Riles da Movie (Home along the Railroad: The Movie), parts 1 and 2, and Oki Doki Dok: The Movie (Okay, Doc: The Movie) for Star Cinema and RVQ Productions.Viriña began serving as script consultant for ABS-CBN in 2013. Written byEdgardo Ray G. Pedroche

 

Sources: Aniceto 2007; Viriña 2014.

text:
VOICE OF FREEDOM The Voice of Freedom was an improvised shortwave radio station operated by the joint Filipino-American forces in Corregidor during the first four months of 1942 as they resisted the Japanese invasion of the Philippines during World War II. It served as the main propaganda medium of the United States Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE), which retreated to Bataan and Corregidor at the end of 1941 under the command of Gen Douglas MacArthur as the Japanese forces aggressively advanced toward Manila.

The station was built out of equipment that MacArthur ordered commandeered from KZRH before leaving Manila even as he ordered the USAFFE to blow up all private and commercial radio broadcast equipment rather than let the Japanese lay their hands on what was believed a critical propaganda medium. Ironically, the Japanese found more remnants of KZRH equipment, which formed the backbone of the Japanese-controlled station KZRH, later PIAM.

Prewar KZRH announcer and chief engineer Ted Ince and KZRH technician Cheng Sian Yok, a Chinese national who adopted the name Simeon Cheng upon his naturalization as Filipino after the war, built the station’s studio inside the Malinta Tunnel in Corregidor. Christened Voice of Freedom by MacArthur, the station aired from 5 Jan 1942 until Corregidor was captured by the Japanese on 6 May 1942. It played American popular music and occasionally carried the signal of US Army station KGEI in San Francisco, California. A program also titled Voice of Freedom broadcast nightly, opening with the American anthem “Star-Spangled Banner.” Its announcer, newspaperman Carlos P. Romulo, who was also general manager of prewar Far East Broadcasting Corporation, updated listeners on the effort to repel the Japanese forces closing in on Bataan. Following the program was its Tagalog version, the Tinig ng Kalayaan—Tagalog for Voice of Freedom—with translator and announcer Philippine Army lieutenant Francisco Isidoro.

Romulo, Leon Ma. Guerrero, and Salvador P. Lopez took turns writing the script of the evening broadcast in English, while the English announcing staff included Romulo, Guerrero, and prewar KZRM announcer Normando Ildefonso Reyes, better known as Norman Reyes. When Romulo was evacuated to Australia before the Japanese capture of Bataan on 9 Apr 1942, Reyes took over the program Voice of Freedom. It was Reyes who dramatically read Lopez’s now-classic piece, “Bataan Has Fallen,” which chronicled a critical loss to the Japanese forces but also attempted to raise the spirits of the remaining USAFFE forces in Corregidor and the Filipinos who were tuned in.

While the stations in Manila fell silent at the end of Dec 1941, KZRC in Cebu continued broadcasting freely, carrying the signal of the Voice of Freedom until the Fall of Bataan, and then subsequently airing its own resistance broadcast until the Japanese overran the province in May 1942. The Voice of Freedom fell silent upon surrender of the Filipino and American soldiers in Corregidor to the Japanese army. Knowing the impact of broadcasting Japanese victory on the Filipino audience, the Japanese made Maj Gen Jonathan Wainwright—who commanded the resistance in Bataan and Corregidor following the evacuation to Australia of Gen Douglas MacArthur—announce the surrender on the air on 7 May 1942 over the Japanese-controlled KZRH.

Upon MacArthur’s landing on Palo Beach, Leyte, on 20 Oct 1944, a new Voice of Freedom went on the air as he announced his return to the Philippines on the naval radio station VLC-6, one of the stations Filipino guerrillas monitored on shortwave while it was in the high seas, now a land station called WVLC. The announcement, long awaited by the Filipinos, flooded the country and signaled the beginning of the end of the war. WVLC transmitted from equipment set up on a weapons carrier parked on the beach of Palo. With American soldiers as news writers, announcers, and engineers, it relocated to a Tacloban schoolhouse before moving to Manila. It broadcast American music and other shows. Written byElizabeth L. Enriquez

Sources:

DeLay 1951; Dunn 1988; Isidoro n.d.; Malay 1959; New York Times 1944; Ongpauco 1982; Reyes 1995; Romulo 1943; Tayag, Lopez, and Arguilla 1946; Trinidad 1953; Sunday Times Magazine 1946.

article_title: Voice of Juan de la Cruz
text:
VOICE OF JUAN DE LA CRUZ The Voice of Juan de la Cruz was a makeshift Filipino resistance radio station against the Japanese occupation of the Philippines during World War II. It went on the air about a week after the defeat by the Japanese of the Filipino-American forces in Corregidor in May 1942, which also silenced the anti-Japanese radio station Voice of Freedom. The station’s tag is synonymous with the name of its founder, Carlos S. Malonzo, then 18 years old.

In 1941, Malonzo quit Arellano High School to work and help his mother support their family. He found a job at the National Foods warehouse in Santa Mesa, Manila, assisting driver Geronimo Ejan Yata with deliveries. At Malonzo’s suggestion, the two enrolled at a night school but the school closed shortly before the Japanese bombing of the American naval facility at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, which immediately preceded the Japanese invasion of the Philippines. To fill their time in the evening, Malonzo and Yata watched films, including the American documentary Norway in Revolt, which gave Malonzo the idea of broadcasting in enemy-held territory.

Malonzo left his job when the Japanese Imperial Army entered Manila at the end of Dec 1941. He and Yata met again in Apr 1942 shortly after the Fall of Bataan. Malonzo was not a professional broadcaster but after witnessing a Japanese patrolman slap an elderly Filipina for failing to bow to him, and upon the downfall of the Voice of Freedom, he moved to set up a resistance radio. With Yata and their collaborators, he stole 50,000 pesos’ worth of goods from Japanese supply warehouses. The items were sold in the black market and proceeds were used to launch the Voice of Juan de la Cruz. Malonzo and Yata recruited Tony San Juan and Oscar Arellano. San Juan, a radio technician, found and assembled old parts to create a workable transmitter. As the station’s voice, Malonzo wrote his scripts in Tagalog, which Arellano translated to English.

Before its initial broadcast, the group scattered pamphlets on the streets from Pasay to Manila City Hall, encouraging people to listen to its broadcast in an hour. The Voice of Juan de la Cruz went on the air regularly at 11:00 am and signed off after an hour or more depending on the length of the script. The broadcast began with a description of Japan’s aggression followed by commentaries on local and international news as reported in the Japanese-controlled press. It included reports of Japanese cruelty aimed at bringing international attention to the Philippine situation. Its sign-on music included the Philippine National Anthem and the recorded voice of Malonzo singing the American anthem “Star-Spangled Banner” while the sign-off piece was “God Bless America” or Carmen Miranda’s “Chica Chica Boom Chic.” The Voice of Juan de la Cruz was picked up and acknowledged by KGEI in San Francisco, California.

The Voice of Juan de la Cruz was a mobile station that moved from one hideout to another every few days to elude the Japanese. Its original quarters was a house at the south end of San Andres St. In Jul 1942, the group felt the Japanese closing in so Yata went to Zambales in search of a more favorable site for their operations. In the meantime, on 4 Jul 1942, Malonzo married Violet Brown. Six days later, the Japanese caught up with Malonzo and some of his colleagues. In Yata’s stead, the Japanese held hostage at Fort Santiago his pregnant wife and her sister. Upon his return to Manila three days later, Yata surrendered to the Japanese at Fort Santiago. Brown was then released but Malonzo and eight others were executed by the Japanese. Brown and a few others continued the broadcast for another two months. Written byDivine Marie Joanne P. Endriga, with notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez

Sources: Enriquez 2013; Sunday Times Magazine 1945.

text:
YABUT, RAFAEL (Rafael Canlas Yabut) aka Paeng Yabut. b Candaba, Pampanga 10 Dec 1925. d. 22 Feb 1997. Radio host, commercial reader, newscaster, commentator. He was married to Margaret McVey Hally of Lucena City, with whom he had five children. He attended Far Eastern University, where he earned an education degree.

Yabut was a guerrilla during World War II. He fought in the Korean War as an ensign with the Philippine Army contingent of the United Nations forces, 1950-53, and then served in active duty with the Philippine Constabulary as lieutenant colonel until 1975.

His first steady job was as electrician at the DZRH radio station in 1947. When radio announcers took their holiday leaves, Yabut pinch-hit for them. The American general manager of Manila Broadcasting Company, Hal Bowie, saw Yabut’s potential and gave him his first two-hour daily Tagalog program, Tayo’y Mag-aliw (Let’s Have Fun). The show featured news, popular music, and live performances of popular showbiz stars before a studio audience. He combined light entertainment with stinging news commentaries and impassioned attacks against certain government officials. He criticized Pres Elpidio Quirino while praising National Defense Secretary Ramon Magsaysay, who subsequently defeated Quirino in the presidential election.

Yabut’s radio program was so popular that several radio news commentators imitated his fiery style. In 1957, he was urged to run for president against Carlos P. Garcia. However, he supported Manuel Manahan, and then switched to Jose Yulo, who both lost at the polls. DZRH disapproved of his political involvements and suspended him from his program and terminated his other radio shows: Ruleta Musikal (Musical Roulette), Tatlo Lamang (Only Three), and Gumising sa Pagsikat ng Araw (Wake Up at Sunrise). His feisty commentaries earned him supporters as well as enemies. On 23 Feb 1968, a gunman ambushed him along San Marcelino St following his on-air tirades against the Philippine Charity Sweepstakes. He survived the attack. Upon recovery, he joined the government station DZFM, but by then his listenership and popularity had waned. He briefly hosted The Rafael Yabut Show on Channel 7 before the declaration of martial law in 1972. After the EDSA Revolt in 1986, he joined DZBB where he was assigned to the graveyard shift.

Yabut appeared in the LVN movie Mr. Announcer, 1959, with fellow broadcasters Eddie Ilarde and Johnny de Leon. Written byAlex R. Castro

Sources: Aniceto 2007; Views from the Pampang 2009; Yabut, n.d.

text:
YAP-DAZA, JULLIE (Julie Ngkaion Yap-Daza) aka Julie. b. 15 Jun 1942 Manila. Journalist, columnist, television producer, host. She is the daughter of Thomas Yap and Lolita Veloso Ngkaion. She married Francisco Ma. Daza with whom she has four children. Her daughter Patricia Pauline Daza is with ABS-CBN in charge of talents. Her niece Cory Vidanes is head of broadcast at ABS-CBN. Her son-in-law Michael, a filmmaker, is a son of Tony Tuviera who is producer of Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!) and several movies. Her nephew Sandy Daza hosts a show on ABS-CBN’s Lifestyle Channel. Yap-Daza finished her elementary education at the Anglo-Chinese School in 1953 and secondary education at Immaculate Conception Academy in 1957. She obtained a bachelor of arts in journalism from the University of Santo Tomas in 1961.

Yap-Daza is one of the first Filipino woman journalists who provided editorials and opinions on social issues in her newspaper columns and television talk shows at a time when women journalists were mainly relegated to writing about entertainment, lifestyle, light features, and home-oriented issues. She started her journalism career as reporter, desk person, feature writer, and editor for the newspaper Evening News from 1960 to 1964, and also worked for various newspapers such as the Daily Mirror, 1963-72, where her column Medium Rare became the longest-running column from 1964 to 1972; Times Journal, 1972-86; Philippines Tribune, 1986-87; The Independent, 1987-88; Philippine Graphic, 1990; Manila Standard, 1998-2004; and Manila Bulletin, 2005 to present. She collected her essays in anthologies such as The Best of Medium Rare, 1979; The Love Stories of Julie Y. Daza, 1980; Etiquette for Mistresses … And What Wives Can Learn from Them, 1993; Manners for Moving Up, 1996; and Mistresses Play, Men Stray, Wives Stay, 2011.

Yap-Daza’s early work on television was as a talk show host in Zoom In, 1973, GTV 4. She was producer-host of the weekly late-night talk public affairs talk show Tell the City, 1980-81, BBC 2, later Tell the People, 1981-97, KBS 9, and Tell the People Now, 2001-4, ABS-CBN News Channel. The program discussed with guests a wide range of issues that include politics, entertainment, popular culture, and psychosocial topics. A notable episode of the show was when she interviewed Gen Prospero Olivas who was in charge of the investigation on the assassination of Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr. She also hosted Business with Pleasure, 1975-78, BBC 2, a lifestyle magazine show; Star Games, 1978-80, KBS 9, a sports-oriented talk show program with co-host former basketball star Freddie Webb; and Jullie, 1998-2001, ABS-CBN, a celebrity-oriented talk show in which she interviewed entertainment celebrities about their private lives .

Yap-Daza was named Outstanding Journalist by the Rotary Club of Manila in 1986. She won best public affairs program host in the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) in the 1980s. Her show Tell the People was awarded the CMMA Hall of Fame Award for Best Public Affairs Program for having won in the same category for three years, also in the 1980s. Tell the People was awarded at the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards for Television in 1991. Written by Gian Carlo C. Librojo, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

Sources:

Buensalido and Florendo 1999; Cajilig and Celis 2007; Daza 2014; National Centennial Commission–Women Sector 1999.

text:
YNFANTE, FRITZ (Francis Ynfante) Fritz Ynfante finished his secondary education at De La Salle High School, 1957. He obtained a bachelor of arts in philosophy from Ateneo de Manila University. In high school, he took the female lead in most of the plays he joined. Fr James Reuter, SJ, got him to play Queen Elizabeth I. He completed his master of arts in film and television production at the University of California in Los Angeles, early 1960s, where he trained under cinema luminaries John Frankenheimer, Sam Austen, and Francis Ford Coppola.

Ynfante directed numerous weekly music programs, variety shows, beauty pageant shows, and commercials. His works were always a party, marked by extravagance that draws inspiration from Broadway and the world of big musicals. Ynfante calls his directing style choreography. His shots and editing are always rhythmic, and his actors’ movements always go with the music.

He did production and directing work for J. Walter Thompson in the mid-1960s, which included the famous Shell Zoom-Zoom TV commercial before Mel Panlasigue, an ABS-CBN executive, invited him to join the director and be part of the network’s pool of directors of musicals like Mitos Villareal and Freddie Cochrane. His first pre-martial law TV show was a fashion musical for cosmetics product Pond’s Cream in the mid-1960s, followed by a series of musicals on ABC 5. During the early years of the martial law period, he directed two TV drama anthologies, Tatluhan (Trilogy), BBC 2, a weekly one-hour program that featured three stories, each directed by a different director, and Roco, GMA, starring then young actor Bembol Roco. He got into trouble with the Board of Censors, which during the period required pretaped programs to be submitted to the body for screening prior to airing, when one episode of Roco featured incestuous love between a man and his sister who went to Manila to become a sex worker. The censors’ body eventually allowed the episode to be shown on evening primetime, but pieces of conversation from the dialogue of the drama were blipped off the air.

He went back to musicals after this brief experience with drama. From the 1970s to the 1980s, he directed the TV specials Jose Mari Chan Specials, Rico Puno: If My Friends Could See Me Now, and Victor Wood Alive. He directed one of Philippine TV’s most popular dance programs, Penthouse 7, 1974-81, later renamed Penthouse Live, 1982-87, both on GMA, produced by Freddie M. Garcia, and hosted by Archie Lacson. The show popularized dance steps such as the Robot, the Bump, the Jacksons, the LA Walk, the New York Hustle, Pop-Locking, and Locking. It had an instructional portion where performers taught viewers how to do these steps. Some mainstays included Marlyn Feliciano, RayAn Fuentes, Rosie Garchitorena-Gan, Anna Garcia, Tito Garcia, Sandy Hontiveros, Pipo Liboro, Mike Monserrat, Nini Morato, Susan Payawal, Poncy Quirino, Ronnie Henares and wife Ida Ramos, Gina Valenciano-Martinez, and Nanette Inventor. One of the show’s most popular segments was the stand-up comedy of Doña Buding, a character created by Jose Javier Reyes and played by Nanette Inventor. The comedy sketch was a social satire that ridiculed the manners, sensibilities, illusions, and delusions of the rich. It was also on Penthouse Live that viewers witnessed the unfolding of the love story between popular singing stars Martin Nievera and Pops Fernandez, who co-hosted the show.

Ynfante reincarnated the 1968 Caronia commercial in the 1980s, choreographed by Douglas Nierras, using the same jingle but with more contemporary lyrics, with four models in fuchsia and electric blue mini-dresses dancing in front of life-sized Caronia nail polish bottles. The 1985 production had Camara again playing Jesus Christ, Cherie Gil as Magdalene, and Ray Ann Fuentes as Judas. Ynfante appeared in drama movies like Mananayaw (Dancer) and Gumising Ka … Maruja (Wake Up … Maruja), 1978, Jose Rizal, 1998, and Spirit Warriors, 2000; and in comedy films like Dobol Trobol: Let’s Get Redi 2 Rambol (Double Trouble: Let’s Get Ready to Rumble), 2008, and Enteng ng Ina Mo (Your Mother’s Enteng), 2011.

Ynfante presented an exhibit during the Holy Week of 2013 that featured unique Stations of the Cross at the Philippine Center for Saint Pio in Libis, Quezon City. The exhibit was characterized by its Filipino touches such as the palengke (market), the tsinelas (slippers), the bayong (woven basket), and a Filipiniana costume for the Virgin Mary who was played by a cancer survivor that Ynfante hired for the occasion.

He won two Citizens Awards for Television in the early 1970s. At Long Last, Celeste! won five awards, including Best Director for Ynfante for a single musical-variety series, from the Philippine Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, 1976. Written by nbsp;Eulalio R. Guieb III

article.value: YNFANTE, FRITZ (Francis Ynfante) Fritz Ynfante finished his secondary education at De La Salle High School, 1957. He obtained a bachelor of arts in philosophy from Ateneo de Manila University. In high school, he took the female lead in most of the plays he joined. Fr James Reuter, SJ, got him to play Queen Elizabeth I. He completed his master of arts in film and television production at the University of California in Los Angeles, early 1960s, where he trained under cinema luminaries John Frankenheimer, Sam Austen, and Francis Ford Coppola.

Ynfante directed numerous weekly music programs, variety shows, beauty pageant shows, and commercials. His works were always a party, marked by extravagance that draws inspiration from Broadway and the world of big musicals. Ynfante calls his directing style choreography. His shots and editing are always rhythmic, and his actors’ movements always go with the music.

He did production and directing work for J. Walter Thompson in the mid-1960s, which included the famous Shell Zoom-Zoom TV commercial before Mel Panlasigue, an ABS-CBN executive, invited him to join the director and be part of the network’s pool of directors of musicals like Mitos Villareal and Freddie Cochrane. His first pre-martial law TV show was a fashion musical for cosmetics product Pond’s Cream in the mid-1960s, followed by a series of musicals on ABC 5. During the early years of the martial law period, he directed two TV drama anthologies, Tatluhan (Trilogy), BBC 2, a weekly one-hour program that featured three stories, each directed by a different director, and Roco, GMA, starring then young actor Bembol Roco. He got into trouble with the Board of Censors, which during the period required pretaped programs to be submitted to the body for screening prior to airing, when one episode of Roco featured incestuous love between a man and his sister who went to Manila to become a sex worker. The censors’ body eventually allowed the episode to be shown on evening primetime, but pieces of conversation from the dialogue of the drama were blipped off the air.

text:
ZUBIRI, BEN (Benjamin Wenceslao Dacayana Zubiri) aka Iyo Karpo. b San Nicolas, Cebu City 28 Sep 1911. d. 9 Nov 1969. Composer, lyricist, singer, and radio entertainer. He was the son of Jesus Zubiri, a Spaniard, and Sergia Dacayana, a Cebuana who taught Ben to play the guitar at an early age. In Bohol he met and later married Luz Butalid, with whom he had five children. He studied at San Nicolas Elementary School.

Zubiri was a pioneering radio entertainer, a prolific music composer, and a popular stage and movie actor. He began his radio, music, and acting career in the 1930s by winning amateur singing contests on the first radio station in Cebu, KZRC, often singing his original compositions, and acting in the theater groups of Greg Bacua, a well-known Cebuano writer and dramatic actor, and Toting Villarino. In 1938, he played the lead role in the first Cebuano talking film written and directed by Piux Kabahar, Bertoldo ug Baludoy (Bertoldo and Baludoy), produced by Virgilio Gonzales of Pampanga for Hispano-Filipino Productions. The film was a hit in the Visayas and Mindanao.

Zubiri was known for the songs “Karon Ulahi Na” (Now It’s Too Late) and “Ang Palad Nagbuot” (Destiny Decides). The genesis of these songs can be traced back to prewar Cebu when a beautiful girl who admired Zubiri caught his heart. Their closeness was interrupted by Zubiri’s sojourn in Manila to represent Cebu in the national finals of the radio singing contest Amateur Hour and also to record his songs with Victor Recording Studios. When World War II broke out, he went home to Cebu on the Corregidor, a passenger ship bound for the Visayas. The boat sank but Zubiri made it to Cebu together with other famous radio personalities like Antolin Alcudia, Suix Cabase, George Nator, and Maning Villareal. However, by the time he returned, the girl he loved was married, thus the titles of the songs above.

During World War II, Zubiri joined the guerrillas under Colonel Cushing. While with the resistance movement, Zubiri wrote the well-loved Cebuano song “Matud Nila” (They Say), and “Ngano Bang Mipakita Ka” (Why Did You Come) and “Pukawon Ko Ikaw” (I’ll Wake You Up). Well loved too were his “Ikaduhang Bathala” (Second God), “Katulog na Inday” (Sleep, Inday), “Tuhoi” (Believe), “Pasayawa Ko, Day” (Let’s Dance, Day), “Mito-o Ako” (I Believe), “Bisan Hain Ka Karon” (No Matter Where You Are), “Ikaw Na Lamang” (Only You), “Pangandoy Ko Ikaw” (You Are My Dream), “Pangutan-A ang Langit” (Ask Heavens), and “Gugmang Gibati Ko” (The Love I Feel).

After the war, Zubiri returned to KZRC (later DYRC) where he sang once more. He also became the director of musical programs such as Haranista (Serenader) and Gabii sa Tirana (Night of the Love Song). He also became the director of Camay Theater of the Air. From 1950, Zubiri managed the radio dramas of the Philippine Manufacturing Corporation (PMC) starting with Ligid sa Kapalaran (Wheel of Life), a daily morning serial drama on radio and Asa Ka Inday? (Where Are You, Inday?), which aired in the evenings. He also had other morning programs like Sinugatan sa Bag-ong Adlaw (Presents of a New Day) and Mugrazu Time. From 1951, Zubiri managed the long-running and record-breaking PMC Amateur Hour in Cebu, a one-hour weekly musical-variety show. Zubiri’s management of the PMC Amateur Hour, under the pseudonym Iyo Karpo, made him an immediate household name. People crowded to hear his programs which were played in the plaza because the studio was too small to hold the audience. Zubiri’s jokes entertained his listeners, and his program also helped to find radio talent.

In 1955, he started another radio program, Pangutan-a Ako (Ask Me), which responded to inquiries from listeners. He also worked on the weekly Darigold Jamboree and the television variety program Channel 3 Presents for three years. Later, Zubiri hosted his own television program with ABS, Ang Banay ni Iyo Karpo (Iyo Karpo’s Family). He starred in the 30-minute radio serials Dear Iyo Karpo and Dahon nga Natagak (Fallen Leaf), which he also directed. He was also recruited by Boie Laboratories to star in the DYSS drama Langit ang Paghigugma (Heaven Is Love).

In 2007, Zubiri was posthumously given the Jose R. Gullas award, given to outstanding Cebuanos by the newspapers The Freeman and Banat News and ABS-CBN’s DYAB. Written byHope Sabanpan-Yu and Gizelle Louise M. Dasmariñas
